For a king sized bed, they provided only four teensy tiny square pillows - I've never seen anything like it.Hotel staff were friendly, meeting spaces were serviced promptly, and food served on site was reasonably good.  The location was convenient for most of the downtown area, and almost anything in the tourist-y area was a safe and quick walk away.  The valet parking was well staffed, and we never had to wait long for our car.I wouldn't object to staying again, but I'd bring my own hair dryer.My second time staying here!!! Nice, great customer service, and great balcony views. I would stay again if in the area!Ok, we asked 6 months ago for 2 rooms adjoining but we are on separate floors - even though we are Elite status customers!I was having a resonably nice time on a business trip until I was walking into the bathroom and saw a good 1" black fat cockroach go skidding across the floor.  I stopped at the front desk while rushing to my next meeing, I said, "I'll be back in about an hour, then I want to know what you would like to do to fix this situation."  While I was away, shift changed and previous shift left no mention of my issue.  Luckily, front desk got me a new room on the same floor -- really annoying to have to move, but stay away from 520 -- unless you like big black cockroaches... (shudder)  Skip the food at the bar.  Depending on the bartender a single can be a double... ;-)We had bed bugs in our room. Need I say more? We were told by the manager and I quote " they were brought in by foreigners two days ago" Their solution to the bugs getting into our luggage was an offer to put our clothes into the hotel dryer. The heat might kill them. When Marriott front office manager L. Davis was contacted she suggested we had mosiquto bites so prevalent in Memphis. I have a picture of the bed bug my friend found crawling on her and that I squished with the hotel key card folder. Don't stay here!My wife and I checked into the Courtyard Marriott on June 22 to celebrate our 40th wedding anniversary. We had a king balcony suite, but they must have upgraded us to a 2nd floor corner balcony suite on the corner of Main and Jefferson. So far, so good. When we entered the room, I noticed a large dark stain on the carpeting. Things take a downturn. My wife found a dirty sock under the bed.Then, since I'm in the IT business, I checked their Internet speed and found that I could use the free Internet, or for for $5.00/day I could get higher speed Internet suitable for streaming video. I was already paying $264/night, but I registered for it. I left my phone on free Internet. I checked their "high speed" connection, and found it was barely 1 Mbps. I went down to the desk to inform them of this. They told me to go back to the room and call the desk and they would connect me to tech support. When I talked to tech support they seemed a bit clueless to the point of asking me to clear my browser cache and try it. When I told them that had nothing to do with Internet speed, they said they would get it fixed. The next day it was still slow. Desk said they would delete the charge from my bill and promised to follow up getting it fixed. When we left four days later, it was still slow. There were two TV's in the room, one in the bedroom and one in the living area. The one in the living area flickered constantly, and was very annoying. The next day I told the desk about it, and they said they would have it replaced. That night I turned it on and nothing had changed. I called the desk and told them this. They said they would send someone up from engineering. He looked at it and said it was a problem with the set and they would replace. The next day it wasn't replaced. The day we checked out it hadn't been replaced. There is no full service restaurant or bar in this hotel, just an all purpose area they call The Bistro.There were some things that were good.  The curved balcony was nice for people watching, the room was large, and the bed was very comfortable. There was a fitness room on the same floor, two treadmills, an elliptical, free weights and a few machines. The machines were not very extensive, however, and I couldn't finish my usual workout. There is only one ice machine on the third floor. I would rate this hotel "less than satisfactory," because of the price. I could tell the staff was frustrated because of the types of problems I had, and having their hands tied by corporate. Marriott Corporation has 15 hotels in the Memphis area. I'd advise them to have a rep stay in each hotel for a night on a regular basis to make sure that the prices they charge are worth it.I haven't stayed in a ton of different hotels in my time but this is definitely one of the best experiences I have had. Place is clean and staff is friendly. Great amenities. Had breakfast here every morning at a decent price. Love it! I hope I get to come back to Memphis one day and if I do I will definitely stay here. Thank you Courtyard!I stay at the Courtyard Marriott downtown Memphis for business. Now, I will say that the bedding in this hotel is great and the balcony rooms have a great view, and that I've had better experience in the past. That being said, I've always ran into at least one issue each time I've stayed. This particular stay, I had multiple.I couldn't change the TV channels using the numbers on the remote and the TV did not display channel information. So, no way to go to a particular channel and then I wouldn't even have a way to know what channel I'm on. This is frustrating when you are coming back from working long hours and trying to relax. I called down and 2 different folks came up to see what was going on. They brought replacement remotes but to their surprise, they didn't know the not being able to use the buttons thing was even an issue. "You would think that with these flat screens that you should be able to change the channel, you know?"The toilet would randomly leak water every 15 minutes or so (flushes on its own). One of the guys that came up for the remote, replaced the seal for the flusher (excuse my layman's terms). However, instead of flushing on its own every 15 minutes, it turned into every 30 minutes. Awesome.Last thing for this trip, the shower door, when opened and close, makes a CRAZY loud squeal sound. It probably just needs some oil on the hinges. You would think that Housekeeping would have been annoyed enough by the sound when they are cleaning that they would have fixed it...This was all in room 624, which I would avoid if you plan to stay here.Me and some friends stayed here to have a fabulous Fourth of July weekend staycation. I was very impressed with the employees. Everyone we came in contact with was so friendly it was unbelievable. I almost didn't think i was in Memphis. The room was great. We had a king bed with a pull out couch, both pretty comfortable. There was even a mini fridge which to me is a necessity when you stay in a hotel. Second floor had a hot tub which made a fabulous ending to the night. Probably would have gave 5 stars if the hotel bar/cafe had more than one person working the station.We had a wonderful stay here! Friendly check in- valet parking was great as this is downtown so hard to find parking- we stayed in the part of the hotel that was annexed and super nice- comfortable bed - new hair dryers - quiet  and clean suite - walking distance to some great Barbecue - police patrol was everywhere so felt really safe - carriage rides will pick you up at the back doors and front desk will call them to reserve your carriage - fitness room was small but clean (televisions were broken on the treadmill and elliptical) -  free breakfast was hard to beat with a large variety for all my crew- free Wi- Fi - we will be staying here again when we come back :)This is a great place to stay for the most important reasons for me; it's clean and quiet. In fact, the entire place is immaculate. I had breakfast there and it was decent though the scrambled eggs were a little on the runny, slimy side. Customer service was neutral which to me is not good. The front desk staff was not friendly or helpful (get a job talking to boxes).  The only service I got was from one very friendly security guard (the other two were far from this and should be guarding boxes) who helped me with places to eat and use if their computer and printer. I'm glad I didn't have to pay for the stay as the bill was more than I would be willing to pay.Don't know about the hotel but the "bar" was horrible!Nice hotel, well kept. The staff, especially at the front desk when we checked in, was exceptionally helpfulq and friendly. Room was really clean and well maintained. I recommend this hotel as a downtown stay especially if going to Beale St.So much nicer than the springhill suites which is old and worn. Bistro, laundry machines, hot tub. Room was light, renovated and clean. Will stay here every time over the springhlll suites.
review_content_20: The hotel is great. Rooms are adequate and the staff is really friendly.  However, this hotel has the worst pillows of any hotel I've ever used.  They are old and worn out.  The pillows are stuffed into the end of a pillow case and the case is folded inside itself to make them look bigger (see pic).  The carpets are dirty in many of the rooms.This is 1 of my favorite Marriott Courtyards in the USA.  It is the newest hotel in downtown Memphis at only 3 years old.  I have stayed at several full service hotels in Memphis and none will hold a candle to The Courtyard, for a discount hotel room it is more plush than the finer properties here, super clean, super state of the art, so open and welcoming.  Great taste on the decor and the lobby and bar area is massive in size.  Within walking distance of Beale Street and all the major places you want to visit while in Downtown Memphis.Very nice, clean and updated. The only thing is parking. You have to pay to park unless you park on the street which most people do. However for Platinum Marriott members at most places this is free. But not here. Also, we had to wait at the front desk for about 10 minutes before the employee came from the back to check us in. Not sure what she was doing.Stayed in Memphis for five weeks on a project as a guest of the Courtyard. It's relatively new and not in a terrible location, right on Main St and pretty easy walking distance to Beale St. and downtown restaurants. The negatives- the breakfast food is terrible, the crew is disorganized and they are frequently out of things. The walls are thin, and do NOT stay on the 8th (top) floor- the elevator mechanism is on the roof and the soundproofing sucks. Lastly, every room they gave me had something wrong with it- one, the curtains wouldn't close. Another- the shower door wouldn't close and showers would flood the bathroom, etc..... Then again, not sure what your other options would be in downtown Memphis unless you want to shell out the big $s for the Peabody.....I only write reviews on hotels at which I've had multiple stays and I base them primarily on location, cleanliness, value, and staff. I was not expecting such a pleasant experience at the courtyard. I was there for an extended stay (6 weeks) while I transitioned to Memphis. Value- compared to other hotels in the area, this is an outstanding value. Peabody is charming, but at 100 more (at least) per night, but with smaller older rooms, no comparison. The Westin is very nice, but valet parking is terrible, staff is not particularly friendly and it's at least 100 more per night Staff- so friendly it's almost a comical! Just nice relaxed and very friendly people!! There's more, but that's enough.We stayed here with several family members for a weekend wedding. The location is awesome, right on Courthouse Square with an easy walk to the river and to Beale St. The room was large and comfortable, the closet held both of our stuff, and the bathroom was fine, the shower powerful.Our only issues were with service. The front desk did fine, but they did not keep the self-service store very well stocked, and the service at the Bistro was abysmal. They had one cook and one counter person on duty no matter how busy it got, and the counter person was often overwhelmed. This made for long waits. Once we even gave up and went somewhere else for breakfast. The prices at the Bistro were also astronomical.The maid staff did not show up on our first day until nearly 5PM. (We had been gone touring in the city for most of the day, so there had been ample time to do our room.) At that point we were getting ready for the wedding, so we had to refuse maid service and sign off that we had done so. The furnishings and rug were showing their age. There was a light stain in the middle of the floor between the TV and the bed. All in all, an okay experience, but for $159 a night I would expect more.The hotel is the first one in Memphis to be built with Marriott's "refreshing business" concept. The spacious lobby has a full-service bistro that serves breakfast, lunch, and dinner, plenty of space for sitting and working, and private booths with TVs that are equipped with laptop and iPod ports.The Courtyard also has a large workout room, guest laundry machines and a completely genius computer where guests can print their boarding passes for flights. There's also plenty of meeting space. There are two boardrooms, a large conference hall that holds 120, and a media room that's perfect for meetings (or movie screenings).The Courtyard has 131 guest rooms, all decorated with luxe furniture and muted colors. Some of the rooms have balconies, and all have ports to hook laptops, iPods and more to the TVs. Since Courtyard was designed with business travelers in mind, it's also got free wireless internet.The Courtyard is located directly across from Court Square in the center of downtown. It's about a 15 minute walk (or short trolley ride) to Beale Street, and a five minute walk to the Cook Convention Center.I take a road trip through Memphis once or twice a year...have always stayed in the Marriott just a few blocks away. Saw that this Courtyard opened up in late 2009, so we wanted to try it out...will NOT be going back to the regular Marriott. This Courtyard is AMAZING and reasonable.Do valet...it's only $3 more and you don't have to walk a block to get to your car. There is a quasi-Starbucks in their lobby, along with a limited selection of foods, but it's perfect for a business traveler or someone who is just staying the night.This will be my Memphis hotel for the foreseeable future!Absolutely would become one of your favorite hotel. I like the rooms atmosphere so much. Front desk is very welcoming and staffs were so kind. Breakfast is best too.I really enjoyed my stay at this hotel. It's in an excellent location, the staff is really friendly, and the beds are clean and super comfortable. The room was small, but well-designed. The only thing I wish is that they had continental breakfast. They do have a cafe there, but the food is not included with your stay. It didn't matter to me for the most part the weekend I was there, because a lot of the meals were already planned. But had I wanted breakfast, I would have had to pay on top of what I was already paying for the hotel. I did eat there one morning, and the food would have been good if it had been warmed all the way through. It took them forever to make the egg sandwiches we ordered because they forgot our order. Then I'm pretty sure they just heated pre-made sandwiches up in the microwave because the outsides were hot, but the insides were cold. Oh well, the coffee was good. I'd go back to this hotel despite my cold breakfast.The Courtyard is in a great location. With a plethora of options for dining and entertainment all within walking distance, you can valet your car and not pick it up until checkout. The rooms are spacious, clean and comfortable. And the fitness center is top notch for a hotel this size and price. I would definitely recommend this hotel to all friends and family traveling to Memphis.Great rooms and fantastic location. Good service upon check-in. Definitely a place to stay if you are in downtown Memphis.I stayed here during a weekend trip to Memphis. It was great! It's right along the trolley line and just a short walk from Beale Street. I appreciated not being RIGHT on the busiest road in the city actually. It was quiet and the staff was friendly. It would be awesome if it had a pool but I won't hold that against the staff. There's a small cafe in the lobby that serves happy hour which we hit up when we first arrived. Not a huge selection, but convenient. All the staff we encountered were friendly and directed us to all the hot spots.Great service, nice rooms and a comfortable bed. I enjoyed our stay.Valet is a little slow but thats okTim C has a point re the activity of the staff and friends, which I onlydiscovered as I was leaving-at 4;45AM.  It was a little odd to see anon uniformed person come from the office when I inquired aboutmy reservation for a ride to the airport and there were two peopleusing the computers who were definitely not guests.  I mentionthis because on the other nights when i was up early, they hadone of THE BEST people I have EVER DEALT WITH workingthe graveyard shift: Jessica Brown.      I CANNOT say enough goodabout Jessica, because she BENT OVER BACKWARDS to help me---and it was JESSICA who clued me in to the factthat i could use the pool at the 2 doors down MarriottSpringhill Suites, as well as partake of the buffet breakfastoffered there.  MAYBE not everyone gets these 'perks'(Andthere were 2 hilarious earlymorning encounters with someone from Springhill who told me I could NOT but then within2 minutes, as I continued to use the pool, someone elseappeared and said YOU are more than welcome to usethe facilities.  I should also mention that Katherine whowas at the front desk when I arrived and Elesie whoworked in the pm were helpful, friendly and reallyfirst rate.   I also was 'amused' to see James Barton,the General Manager, looking somewhat 'harried'(as a GM should) come and go from his office andnot seem to mind that I insisted that Eleslie engagein conversation with me(knowledgeable aboutthe Hollywood scene which is always fun for me totalk about) and to have him say that Mr. Bartonis accessible, knowledgeable and I feel runsa good hotel. THERE ARE SOME PROBLEMSwith the area: the homeless folk  who lingeroutside are no more unsavory than those i encounter in LA, but the backdoor is not locked 24 hours,which means that some of these folk wander in andout, helping themselves to coffee, using the freecopy machines, etc.  HOWEVER, the factthat they have these available for the guestsis so great-the Business Center actually works (!)and the coffee is strong enough to send youout to Beale St. as if you were a marathon runner.The Bistro offerings looked tasty and theStarbucks staff was really friendly, but I wastoo worried about the calories to try thevery appetiziing looking lemon bars.   TheSpringHill Suites is undergoing rennovations-which maybe why I was allowed inside-I was theonly one using the pool (which is not heated but gave me an invigorating workout).The buffet breakfast was tasty and I had funtalking with Felicia, who did not say a wordwhen I helped myself for takeout......andthe great thing was that the police alsoenjoy early morning oatmeal and althoughi was not up to talking to them, it was justgreat to have them right alongside.The room was fine-apparently rooms in allhotels are not cleaned before mid-afternoon,but when i asked for towels, they arrived!I would have liked to have a tv guide re.the channels-but that is a petty complaint.Kerry C's review covers in far less words the itemsI may have missed.We had a wonderful weekend planned in Memphis including dinner and the Orpheum Theatre  for my daughters birthday. in route to downtown Memphis we were involved in a car crash, which scared us all to death. So we arrived late at the Courtyard down town. We parked as quickly as possible and went to check in, we were immediately assaulted in the lobby by a gentleman wanting to know where we parked, Did we park in the parking lot? That's for the SpringHill Suites he said (where i wish i had stayed by the way) so we needed to make a decision right then and there if we wanted to self-park or valet. I said "Can i please just check in and then make a decision"? We went ahead and valet park since it was $18.00 and self-parking was $15.00. The lady at the check-in kiosk was not very friendly either. We hurriedly placed our belongings in our room and headed for our late dinner. After the show at the Orpheum we walked back to the hotel in the rain to find the front doors out of order, so we had to walk around to the back of the hotel in the rain to get in. I asked the person at the front desk what the problem was and stated they were trying to find a part. going to bed exhausted after a long day we were woken up this morning at 8:00 AM by a wake up call we didn't request. since i had been woken up i decided to go ahead and take a shower. after doing so i was going to dry my hair just to find out that either the blow dryer or the electrical socket is bad. So i thought i would ride the annoying elevator that has the lady that speaks to you and write this review. We are Marriott gold members and stay in allot of Marriott accommodations and this hotel does not measure up in many ways. If you are wanting to stay in downtown Memphis and want to stick with the Marriott brand, which i do stay at the Spring Hill just down the street. They will provide a breakfast with your stay where the Courtyard will not. If you are not in a hurry try to find a place on the street to park. Really disappointed!

review_content: I used the Hyatt Place Primacy Parkway for all of my wedding block rooms. Hyatt was ideal for hosting wedding guests because the hotel has a free breakfast (standard hotel breakfast, nothing fancy), large lobby and gathering space, pool, and a 24/7 bar. Each room has a sitting room area with a couch that pulls out into a queen bed, so each room can accommodate additional people or people handing out. Each room also has a microwave and fridge. There was a free shuttle that operated from 7am-9pm in a five-mile radius, which includes lost of restaurants but not the airport.I found the rooms clean and spacious. Moreover, my wedding guests loved the accommodations because they could hang out in rooms or the lobby and had a free breakfast every morning. They hotel and its guests are very chill, so we held after parties in the lobby and later in the rooms and no one complained (but some joined in!).Dealing with the sales staff was fine- worked mostly with a very sweet lady named Tiffany. They were extremely polite and accommodating when I called, but they work only 7am-4pm on business days, so I found it hard to get them on the phone. I also had to follow up a few times to get updates on our hotel block and how many rooms we had left before the block closed and the hotel filled with people. (We got married the same weekend as the Southern Heritage Classic, so lots of people.) So they are not very proactive in working with you and identifying issues, but they are responsive if you voice an issue.Easy going. Booked it on hotels.com and had no hassle at the desk. Very friendly staff, even includes a downstairs mini bar but it's kinda expensive. Recommend this place for sure though!Wow this place is a dump. A reviewer said a year ago that the rooms were under renovation? Maybe they haven't gotten to the 6th floor yet because aside from the 6 year old plasma in the room, this place is falling apart. The door looks about 20 years old and so does all the furniture and bedding. To top it off, it isn't clean. I found hairs in my bed upon arrival which just grosses me out. Not only will I never stay here again, I may never stay at another Hyatt Place. Absolutely disgusting.Excellent hotel!! Great service!! Awesome breakfast every morning!! Hyatt Place Brand is consistent!! It is tucked away between two other hotels across from the hospital.My wife and I booked a nights stay at the Hyatt place in Memphis on our way to Texas from Virginia. We have stayed at a many of hotels in our time but I must say for the price, this was one of the nicest hotels we have stayed in. The lobby is very inviting and the customer service was better than expected. The breakfast bar was good, the king bedroom was beautiful! We have all intentions on staying at this location whenever we are in the Memphis area!I was impressed with the room. Beautiful! Employees were super nice and helpful. Check in was a breeze. The fitness room is clean and has plenty of equipment. There was a business room, as well. The internet connection was terrific and free. There was a complimentary breakfast available. The room had a small refrigerator. There was a coffeemaker, too. There was plenty of parking.No problems at all with checkin. Clean, roomy, and up-to-date suites. Comfortable, clean beds. Modern, small bathrooms. The floor plan of the rooms are funky though with the bathroom, closet, and beds all scrunched into one half of the room, which made for a difficult time entering and exiting the bathroom. The breakfast is nice as well as the attendants, even at 6:00 in the morning.I had a great experience I was visiting here. I wasn't there for business, only pleasure. It was a lot of family reunions when I went so I thought it was going to be noisy but it was peaceful. The rooms were really clean, the front desk was very professional when I went. I probably wouldn't go during the summer again because of so many family reunions it can get crowded in the day time and breakfast area.I stayed here last weekend, Friday and Saturday nights. We had a reservation for a room with two double sized beds and a sofa sleeper. We are three guys in our upper 50s and we're not great sleepers. When the three of us (guys on a trip to see Johnny Cash's boyhood home, the Sun Studio, Graceland) started the check-in process the desk told us they couldn't give us our room. They said they had to close down some rooms and couldn't give us a room. I told them we were very disappointed in them and asked them what they were going to do to fix this. They said they'd move us to another hotel in their chain. We were already out on the eastern edge of Memphis, as far from Beale Street and the places we wanted to visit on Saturday as we wanted to be. I told them this and they proceeded to explain that "Memphis is a big circle" and then suggested a hotel with the type of room we reserved. I said as long as it isn't east or south of here we'd probably be okay with it. I then got the "Memphis is a big circle" comment and assured we'd be "closer to where you want to go." The hotel they suggested was east and south of the Hyatt Place, definitely outside of "the big circle"! I said this was unsatisfactory and after a few more clerks got involved they came back with a suggestion to move us to a room with one king sized bed and a sofa sleeper. They did agree to take 20% off the room rate. That was decent and probably what motivated us to agree to the move. That and the fact that it was now 6:30 pm and we were tired after the 450 mile dirve and wanted to close this deal and get some bbq.The room was nice enough but after the first night I'm convinced that some of us would have slept much better with separate beds. At least two of us are restless sleepers. The breakfast the next day held another surprise: no eggs of any kind! One of our group is on a gluten-free diet and depends on eggs to get his morning protein and to get something nourishing w/o it being pancakes, muffins, toast, bagels, etc.. Maybe our bad for assuming they'd have eggs but a place promising a full, hot breakfast ought to have eggs in my opinion. His protein option was peanut butter on a banana to go with his hot (non-instant envelope) oatmeal.The hotel was clean and other than the no eggs at breakfast the accommodations were as promised. However, the reservation of a certain type of room is fundamental. At the time I set up the reservation I did have the option to reserve the kind of room we were given. Even if the rate had been 20% less I wouldn't have reserved that room. My point is that the three separate beds was the point of our making that reservation and they failed to keep their end of the contract.On a side note, am I too picky in expecting an ice machine to be on every floor? This hotel has ice on every other floor so if you are not on first, third or fifth floors you have to take the slow elevator or the stairs to get your ice bucket filled. It would also be nice if the ice bucket liner was big enough to fit the ice bucket. And if you are going to provide real glasses and coffee cups for a room for three adults it would be nice to have at least three of each, not just two.Really nice and spacious hotel rooms. Free wifi, lounge area in the room with a large couch and ottoman. Large flat screen tv that is mounted and pivots. Working area with lots of outlets. The workout area is poorly equipped. That's why this doesn't get a 5 star. Free continental breakfast and parking. If you have a good company rate you can good a really good deal. Like $80. Hahaha.They do have dry cleaning service that picks up on the weekdays and coin laundry onsite if you needed. The location is really good, on Germantown Pkway and TONS have food places to pick from.========================================================ok, so I came back to change it to a 5 star because IT IS THAT GOOD. The service in this hotel is EXECELLENT! I've been coming here for almost 3 months now on a weekly basis. Try it out if you're a frequent traveler to this area.I've been in quite a few hotels. Never heard of not having room service. That's brand spanking new to me. The staff isn't too friendly. I called down and someone answered the phone saying " yea". Another time, I ordered food and received a call to pick up my food. When I answer the girl is like " yo food done". No greeting, just that. the rooms are decent. Nothing spectacular however I didn't really care bc I was there for business and didn't spend much time in the room. However if I was visiting I would've gone to a different hotel bc of service alone. I know all hyatts aren't like this but this one definitely sucks. Most if the women are bitchy but the men are pretty chill.40 year old single white male business travelerI stay at three hotels in the area, Hyatt Place, Courtyard and Hampton. The general quality and staffing are very similar. I will focus more on the differences. Pros: nice free breakfast, free coffee in the lobby in the morning, the free wifi speed is good enough to watch movies on Netflix. The pool area is visually great, but kind of public being right next to the street and parking lot. The wifi is very spotty in the pool area. Cons- no microwave in the room. Not sure why, since there is a space for it. Much like the other three, the "restaurant/bar" is really more of a glorified snack bar. This may not be a "con" for you, but for me; lots of kids at the pool. I stayed here three times and every time, the pool was packed with kids. The lobby was very slow, not a big social area. The shower only has one very small wire shelf. The soap falls through and you cannot keep soap, shampoo and conditioner all inside. I prefer hotels with a full restaurant and active social area, but overall, I do like the hotel and have never had a bad experience. For the price, I think it is a good value.Wonderful business atmosphere. I have had several occasions to stay in the Memphis neighborhood due to teaching duties and in my opinion this is the best available within the surrounding area. Staff is friendly and helpful. Rooms were clean and floor plan was convenient to work on data for the next days presentation.Popped in with no reservation after trying the same thing at another local Hyatt Place. That one was in the middle of an office park and was full. They sent us to this one, which looks like it was built yesterday. (Google maps don't show the driveway yet, and keep wanting you to go to the end of the block and make a U-turn because they don't know there's a cut in the divider.) It's in the middle of nowhere, but there will probably be an office park there soon. Good amenities; if this was a downtown hi-rise, rooms would probably be well over $200. (We got one for $89 a night.)Bed was nice, big TV right at the foot was nice (first REAL HD I've ever seen on a hotel TV). The "jack rack" is very cool; you can plug ANYTHING in to the TV if you brought the right cable (VGA, HDMI, composite video, component video, mini-plug audio). The Wi-Fi showed 15mbs download speed and 5mbs upload, way better than my cable internet at home. There's an ethernet jack too, if you have a cable and don't want to use Wi-Fi.Room was big, everything was new and spotless, very nice shower.One-cup coffee maker, but it's a big cup and makes very good coffee. The hot free breakfast is not spectacular, but it's pretty good stuff. Staff were very nice and helpful.This is my first stay at a Hyatt Place, but I'll keep an eye out for them in future travels. For the price of a typical motel, you get a pretty good imitation of a classy four-star hotel. They've obviously studied the process and done their homework on these. It's a smooth-running place.Oh, the location of this one is way out there. A good half hour away from downtown and Beale street. There are plenty of restaurants and shopping in the area, though.We had a pretty bad experience at this hotel. They put us right next to the ice machine, and it felt like a party of people walked by talking loudly to get ice like every 10 minutes (the ice getting was also loud). Those walls were thin, so it woke us up a lot. Since we were driving cross country (between Virginia and Dallas, TX) it would have been nice to have had a good night's sleep between the two legs of the trip, but c'est la vie. Oh and the A/C was this old fashioned, super loud, difficult to regulate system. When it was on it was super cold. When it was off it got super hot. The bed was okay, pillows were uncomfortable (so take your own if you're going to sleep there). Breakfast was acceptable.Pros: Clean, convenient location near shopping and restaurants, staff was friendly, reasonably priced, rooms had nice decor and a nice seating area, tv, microwave and fridge. Also had a small snack bar/case next to the check in desk for all your munchie needs. :)Cons: the bathroom or lack thereof!! I HATED that the sink and vanity was not behind closed doors. It was right across from the bed. So much for letting someone sleep in while you get ready! Also, if you're traveling with someone I hope your cool with them watching you pop pimples, floss, tweeze your eyebrows, get dressed etc. The toilet and shower are behind a closed door but you have to be totally in there to even close the door. Very small space. It also annoyed me that there were no hangers or even a place to hang clothes. Would be willing to stay there again IF I couldn't find something in the same price range nearby.Someday, when the machines take over the world, they will stay at the Hyatt Place Memphis Primacy Pkwy when they visit the grave-site of Robo-Elvis.Like so many others, I made my reservations here online. I didn't need to actually talk to anyone made of flesh, when I had nice friendly pixels explaining prices, features, amenities, and everything else I needed to know.Upon entering the front lobby of this ultra-modern hotel, you are presented with a choice: check-in with a "human", or use the automated kiosk. That's right, you don't need to deal with a line, just input your information and it spits out your room's key card.The room has the nicest integration of a computer to TV setup I've ever seen. Component video, HDMI, VGA and stereo RCA cable hookups with an input selector right next to the TV. Handy if you travel with your X-Box and the video game "Robots".Searching for my favorite ethanol, I stopped by the hotel bar for a drink. Again, a automated kiosk allows you to place your drink order. The same person that handles check-in can also take drink orders, tend bar, and serve food in the restaurant. I'm pretty sure she wasn't human, but a series T-1001 series robot. Either way, service did not seem to suffer.Despite the nice tech advances, the overall effect did not wow me. The shower was sub-par, but I guess that in a hotel built for machines, the bathroom would be an afterthought. The bed was pretty average, but not bad if you are planning on going into sleep mode for a limited period of time.What is nice, is that this hotel gives a glimpse of the hotel of the future. A hotel for when the machines rule the world...... and we will......resistance is futile...This hotel is a great value. We were able to fit 2 adults and 5 kids in a standard double room. The breakfast is free and hot with eggs, sausage, and pancakes as well as other continental items. Free wi-fi made our teens happy and they offered Starbucks for purchase also.We stayed here for two nights during a recent vacation in Memphis. It turned out not to be central to anything we did on the trip except for the night we ate at Gus's fried chicken joint down the street, but we honestly didn't mind the 20-minute commute at each end of our days.The hotel staff were very friendly, but I almost wish I would have seen the automated kiosk MJD wrote about because I'm totally for minimizing human-human interaction in all situations up to and including reproduction.It may have been overpriced and might not have been a great selection, but I really appreciated the option to purchase freshly cooked food 24 hours a day. If you've traveled a lot on business you've found yourself dropped off in a hotel room with no transportation outside of "normal" eating hours. Usually your only option is to purchase snacks from a vending machine and cry quietly into your pillow, but here you can get something a little more substantial even if it's just a cheeseburger.The rooms were OK, but I thought it was dumb that the sofabed totally blocks the front door. When I worked out after the kids were asleep I had to climb on the bed going in and out of the room. Also to shut the bathroom door you have to get all the way inside the room on the other side of the toilet before the door will have enough clearance to close. Even with the gymnastics, ours was too warped to fully close, a fact I really appreciated when my non-privacy-respecting 4 yo boy kept walking in on me pooping.The exercise room was standard motel fare, but the night shift never had the towels stocked, a fact I never remembered until I was done working out and dripping with sweat.The breakfast was ok and the staff never stopped replenishing the items to be sure we all had access to the juices, toasts, english muffins, cereals and biscuits & gravy.One other cool thing about the room that's been mentioned before: unlike the standard hotels that put locks on the TV to prevent you from watching your own stuff on it, this one had a panel with just about any kind of connection you could want including HDMI. We didn't bring anything this time, but usually we have some sort of portable media player and would have appreciated the ability to hook up to the big screen TV.I visited Memphis for a business conference that took place in this hotel. The hotel also had a special deal for the people who's attending the conference with the rate $90/night. I stayed here for 4 days / 3 nights. At first I got lost on finding the location of this hotel because I didn't believe such a nice hotel would be on some small road behind a giant strip mall. I called the hotel and they gladly assist me on finding their location.There's alot of parking space up in the front and I walk in and the same person whom I spoke on the phone with was there at the front desk greeting me. I asked to be checked in and gave them my ID and the print out confirmation. I was checked in really quick and ask if I have their membership. I said no and they went over the membership application and the benefits of being a Hyatt Gold Passport member. I took the application and they wrote down my room number in the card key slip.They also went over the layout on where to access the pool, the fitness room, the Internet area which is free, showing me the breakfast area and room service area. I took my stuff to the 2nd floor and went into my room. I did not expect a double to be that spacious. There's a whole giant living room with a dining table, working sink, coffee maker, a small mini fridge, L shape couch, and room for me to do exercise from the free TV channel teaching you yogas and stuff. The air condition was working very good because it was really, really cold in the room.The service is very good as the front desk person remembers my last name, maybe it's because I am one of the people registered for the conference and they know everyone that's in the conference. I had a good swim at the pool, it's a typical family friendly outdoor pool. There were some dead bugs in it but it wasn't too bad. The fitness area had a good amount of jogging machine and biking machine, some light weights, and a TV for you to view.The free breakfast in the morning is wonderful. It had some good hot food with good selection of cold food. Although there wasn't stuff like scramble eggs or bacons, but the grits with gravy was very filling. They brew Seattle's Best Coffee and had 3 different types (2 regular and 1 decaf), there's always someone to monitor and make sure to refill anything tha'ts out as there's alot of people eating the free breakfast every morning.The room service was very convinent as you could just order the food you want to get from a POS kiosk. You simply slide your room key to charge anything you order to your room and you could sit at the free Internet area and they will bring the food to you or bring it up to you. The Internet center is good as they use those remote login software wihch the computer would restart every 20 minutes so it would clear out any cookies that may have saved while you browse the Internet.One thing that I didn't like was that the hotel was very far from Memphis downtown, but it is right next to the one of the Galleria mall and it's surrounded by stores such as Target, Barnes and Noble, lots of different restaurants to choose from, etc.Over all I had a great pleasant experience with this hotel and particulary Hyatt chain. I would recommend this hotel for anyone who's visiting Memphis to stay here, even if it's very far from the Memphis downtown, it's still a good place to stay as sometimes downtown is more expensive and pretty scary at night.
review_content_20: everything is okay just. worse than the hyatt place in OK.the staff did not give me basic info about fitness or parking or  breakfast when I check in. I had to ask later.the fitness center is not as well equipped as other hyatt.but, the location is nice and convenient for sure.On a recent road trip from Houston, TX to Columbus, Ohio we stayed at this Hyatt, twice. On the way up we had a decent experience, on the way back... not so much.The Good:Spacious rooms, huge tvs with decent channel selection, free wifi, near loads of restaurants and shopping, in what appears to be a decent neighborhood and cheap. They try a little too hard to be 'hip' and the service is just ok.The Bad:The included breakfast is TERRIBLE. Everything tasted like freezer burn. Completely inedible both times we stayed. Security is a major problem. The second time we stayed here on the return leg of our trip, our truck got broken into. Obviously I know this happens in lots of places but this one is special. The hotel did nothing aside form a very nice maintenance man who helped us tape up our window for the 10 hour return trip home. They wouldn't even call the police for us. When the police came this is what we were told... "Thieves in Memphis target vehicles from Texas because they think everyone in Texas has a gun in their car." His partner was down the street at another hotel filling out a report for someone else who's car was broken into that same night. And the police officer told us that the city removed patrol from that neighborhood because they're wasn't enough crime. So basically if you stay in this area, there will be no cops anywhere to help prevent this sort of thing from happening. We drove because we couldn't afford the plane tickets. A few tanks of gas, an oil change and two nights at a hotel cost less than airfare for 3 and a rental car.  After the break in and the $450 deductible, we ended up spending more :(We called to make a reservation for 1 night July 16, check out July 17. At the time of making the reservation, I let the reservations representative know that we would probably be arriving well past midnight, as we were driving into town from Mississippi. A couple of hours went by and I hadn't received my email confirmation. I called the hotel again and they confirmed the reservation and emailed me my confirmation. We arrived at the hotel at 2:00 am, and the main entrance was locked. We were pounding on the door for a while, and it so happened that a couple of guests saw us from inside and opened the door for us. At the time of checking in, we were told that they were booked!!! Nobody called us to let us know that the hotel was booked and that they wouldn't honor our reservation. After complaining, checking if any hotel nearby had rooms available (which they didn't) and trying to understand THEIR LOGIC BEHIND THE CONCEPT OF MAKING A RESERVATION, we were ready to leave past 2 in the morning and drive for over AN HOUR to a hotel that had a room available. We were told that we could be accommodated at a La Quinta that was right behind the Hyatt Place. We were also told that "Management" makes decisions as to "re-arranging" reservations. The name of Jerry Roach - General Manager at the Hyatt Place - Primacy Parkway was given to us as the party responsible for these decisions. If I wanted to stay at a La Quinta, I would have made a reservation at La Quinta. I did not want to stay at a La Quinta. Nobody makes a reservation at a specific hotel only to find out that your reservation has been moved to another hotel. I ask the Hyatt Place, what is the point of making a reservation??? I have never had this happened before. I even called to confirm the reservation. This is not a serious business. Do not take your chances here.I love Hyatt's in general. A first visit for  Hyatt place.I must say very impressive room for the price point. Excellent Svc ! Tried the food last night. Just the right touch after a long trip from Cali . Excellent breakfast!!w/Starbucks included in the price of the room.Rooms are undergoing some renovations, but laid out really cool.  I like the super larger TV in the middle of the rooms with easy connection for those who have kids who travel with game systems.  All the food you could ever want is close by, but only one place that is really in walking distance.  For this place being located so close to I-40 the rooms are very quite and you never realize that your that close.Stayed here for 6 nights the last week in May. All the staff members were helpful and friendly. Hotel room was big and clean, nice TV 42' and free wifi. We enjoyed the living room and bedroom area being separate. Housekeeping cleaned our room everyday. Breakfast was free but, not that good. We drove to Chick-Fil-A which took about 3 minutes. We had a great stay !I have stayed at two other Hyatt Places, and this one was pretty much a carbon copy of the others.  I really like the decor and interiors of the rooms.  I also like the check in kiosk near the door. Yay!  No interaction with local humans!Downsides: double beds instead of queens kinda bites, and it took us forever to get extra blankets for the pull out.  Other than that it was a pretty flawless visit.Clean and pleasant.stayed here for the thanksgiving holiday and to explore memphis. booked the room online through the hyatt site and got a rate of $80/night..not too bad.The hotel itself is pretty nice. Friendly staff, very very large rooms, HUGE tv, a seating area, very clean and well stocked rooms. really to us the only downside was that it was not near downtown. If you are younger and looking to go out i'd recommend staying downtown and not here. We drove into downtown most afternoon/evenings once we were done siteseeing around memphis. that said though it is not a reason to not stay here if you dont want the hustle and bustle of downtown. the hotel is otherwise perfect and a great value.I really loved this place.   If I ever visit Memphis again, which I hope to, I'll definitely stay here.  It's by no means the nicest hotels I've stayed at, but it's also very far from the worst.  I found the rooms very spacious and clean.  I personally prefer softer beds, so I loved the mattress.  As Joshua noted, the self-service check-in was pretty sweet.   In a perfect world, I would have liked this place a little closer to downtown Memphis.  However, I don't think it took me more than 10 minutes to get anywhere from the hotel (downtown memphis, graceland, stax musuem).I was very impressed with everything about the Hyatt.  Especially since I got a King Size bed for $82.00 a night w/tax!!After spending all day traveling to see your recent love interest the one thing you want is a decent room. While the 42'' flat screen tv did make early morning talk shows a little more enjoyable, sinking into a hole at night left a little more to be desired. Sure everyone likes a comfortable, soft bed, but there is such a thing as TOO soft!!! No room service means you have to leave your room to eat even if you're too tired too. Of course these problems are minor, however it's the losing a reservation that brings me to yelp.     After your sister travels to memphis to put up with a couple days of mushy talk between you and your love the last thing either of you want to hear is "im sorry we dont show you registered here."  Of course mistakes happen and if that had been the response we received maybe we wouldn't be so upset. I would expect a little tackiness if we were staying a motel 6 or a no-tell motel but when you're paying $139 a night is it too much to ask for a little kindness? The "lady" at the front desk refused to offer us any form of assistance, she took one look at her computer and that was that. The next 5 minutes of her time was spent snapping her neck and rolling her eyes at us like we were some transients off the street with no common sense. It wasn't until we made a fuss and the manager came out that we were even offered to be put up in the same room. Needless to say I withdrew my money from the hotel and we went on to stay at another one near by.The hotel was beautiful and the decor was cozy. The staff on the other hand is in need of some serious class time with Mrs. Manners!

review_content: Best bang for our buck in downtown Memphis. Rooms were clean. Bed was comfy. Staff was friendly. Very convenient location. Not a lot of parking spaces, but you can park for free if you find one. They do give you the option to valet your car for a small price.Room was VERY small, and everything was clean but the bathroom. I've seen worse, but this was pretty bad! Bed & pillows weren't very comfortable. The location of the hotel was ok. 7-8 blocks from Beale street where all the action is. I think I would tell people to stay elsewhere though.NEVER AGAIN! Management was rude. No customer service.Given the amount we paid for the room I was very impressed with the comfort and amenities during our stay. Nice location, short walk to Beale Street. Very friendly staff. Decent hot breakfast.What a great Sleep Inn! This place is high quality with great rooms and a perfect location in downtown Memphis. Parking is reasonable and safe, and my second visit here was excellent!The continental breakfast isn't bad, your typical bagels, cereal, waffles but they also have scrambled eggs and sausage. I'm OK with it! The staff is always friendly, though slightly slow with some things, but I really enjoy staying here!The rooms and service were fine. The staff has always been friendly and informative. unfortunately when you're on travel, you want to have a nice breakfast. This place was a NO GO. The first day, I go down and there is moldy and bruised apples on display. I got a bagel only to realize after I ate it that there were other bagels on the tray with a dark green powder on them. YUCK!!! The next day I kept with packaged foods. Even the apple juice I got had hard sediment in the bottom. Sorry but this needs to be fixed!!! 2 stars for not seeing this blatant flaw in the food you're servingExcellent room! Cozy is a better word than small, because it is comfortable and has all the amenities. Minor problem with the in-room safe, but the staff quickly attended to it and it works fine now.I am usually wary of 2 star amenity hotels, but this was quite a pleasant surprise. No, there's no in-house restaurant or bar, but it was walking distance to to Beale street, restaurants, bars, Martin Luther King museum, Mudd Island, etc. Also very cool was that the trolley stop was just steps outside the door of the hotel. As stated in other reviews, the room was pretty small, but it was clean and super cozy with a puffy inviting bed, microwave and fridge to keep your snacks and leftovers. yelp.com/biz_photos/slee...We had a river view, although you did also stare at the parking lot, there were some nice sunsets. yelp.com/biz_photos/slee...On the other side of the hotel, you get a pleasant view of Court Square park. yelp.com/biz_photos/slee...There was a complimentary continental breakfast. Nothing amazing, but it covered the basics you might need with bagels, oatmeal, eggs, waffle maker, etc. Free wi-fi, which is nice. The last more expensive Hilton I stayed charged for my wi-fi. Greedy corporate bastard. They do charge for parking in their own parking lot. A total peeve of mine which the hotels do these days. But it was on $12 which was nothing compared to the $30 I paid last month at a So. Calif. hotel. So not bad price, but still not cool. I paid ~$100 a night and that was the cheapest I found at that time, and I was so happy with it. I had tried to find hotels closer to Beale which cost more, but they were all booked up. I am so happy that I ended up with this cheaper place which was still so close to Beale, I didn't need anything closer and really covered all of our needs. Didn't need an in-house restaurant or bar because everything was so close anyway. I would stay here again.Thoroughly enjoyed the service from the team and to me that is most important in a hotel stay. All hotels have beds, but this one was very comfortable. Although the room was tiny, the updated room and the breakfast area (with a WAFFLE maker) made up for it. Next time I will choose this hotel and I will choose a suite :-)Front desk staff is rude and unaccommodating. They will talk behind your back if you have a disagreement with them (due to their unaccommodating nature). Considering this is a low end hotel with tiny rooms, you would think that they would make up for it with customer service; not the case here.Pros:: The cleaning staff did a great job tidying my room. There is a fridge in the closet, so I loaded up with snacks from the City Market store a few blocks away. The hotel is also in a great location in Downtown Memphis, right on the park and main street. Cons:: Tiny rooms. I usually love lounging in hotel rooms, but this room felt like a small box. Also, the light from the hallway came in under the door, so I had to use an eye mask to sleep. The room was also either too cold or too hot, which was weird. However, my largest complaint would have to be the rude, unhelpful, disengaged front desk staff. To be fair, it seems like it is just the one guy who is rude, but still, it left me with a negative impression multiple times. Don't work at the front desk if you don't like people. I probably would NOT recommend this hotel to friends.Cramped room unless you are by yourself. Pubic hair in between sheets.Shower stall tracks caked with dirt. Small, half size pillows to sleep on.Michael at the front desk is a total dick. Doesn't even look at you when you're checking in. Other than than that, it's not bad.Very pleased with our stay. It was only for one night, but there are many reasons for the 4 stars. First of all, the location was perfect. The trolley was 30 feet from the rear entrance. The area around the hotel was lovely and very clean. Within easy walking distance to Beale St. The streets alongside the trolley tracks were very attractive with a lot of trees, lampposts, many benches, and cute shops. The room was clean and decent-sized and the bed was comfortable. Bathroom was small with only a shower stall, but the shower was roomy. The breakfast served was pretty impressive to me since most hotels offer a complimentary breakfast that consists of cereal, a muffin, an apple, or a banana. This hotel includes a hot breakfast with bacon, sausage, scrambled eggs, and a waffle bar. And the woman at the front desk even gives you a map upon check-in showing exactly where we were located and the number of blocks to Beale. If I'm ever in Memphis again, I will come back!Hotel lobby was clean and updated and check in staff was friendly. The room was small. We are a family of 4 and it was tight. The sink is outside the bathroom with the shower and toilet in a tiny room. But it was clean and updated. My bed was a bit lumpy but sleep able. Location was great walking distance to Beale street and close to the trolley. Can't beat it for the price. I would stay here again.I definitely would stay here again.What I like about this place1. Location is great, in the heart of downtown2. Breakfast is pretty impressive3. Clean4. Soundproof between suites5. Free wifi5. i thought the price was affordable for its qualityWhat I dislike1. This guy who works in the evening after 3pm, is not nice2. The computer in their business center is slow3. No shuttle bus from and to the airportI strongly recommend this place if you are traveling to Memphis TN.Perfect place to stay in the downtown area. Surprised with the price, approx $100 for a sat night stay! I hope it stays that way. Beautiful hotel, soft bed. You can walk out the back entrance and the trolley stop is directly out that door. Everything is walking distance, even Beale St. People were super friendly here.If I had paid more, this would have been a three star review. I booked on hotels.com about a month in advance. The rate I got was $90 a night including tax. Not too shabby for downtown Memphis! The pros: - the rooms are clean. Very clean! - newly remodeled. Sometimes when you book with hotels.com you end up in the crappy rooms... but our room was newly furnished with nice spreads and dark wood furniture. - $12 a day self or valet parking. In Chicago, this would cost you a fortune a night so I thought it was a deal. - free continental breakfast - in room microwave and fridge - beds are COMFY - you leave the cleaning staff a few bucks on the bed, they leave you an extra roll of toilet paper and handfuls of toiletries and coffee packs - conveniently located downtown - trolley station literally steps from the back door of the hotel Cons: - the valet is SLOOOOOOW. Call at least 20-30 minutes in advance - the staff is feast or famine. Either extremely helpful or extremely surly and unhelpful - our key had to be "re-magnetized" every single day. We'd get all the way to the 5th floor and then have to go back down to get the key fixed.- the bathrooms are teeny tiny. Minuscule. The only thing that separates you from showering and peeing in the living space is a small sliding door. No bath tub. All in all, I'd stay here again, especially if I got this rate. The pros outweighed the cons in my opinion. It was a great deal!I'm one who wants everything for a bargain.If location matters to you, in any big city, it's difficult to find the biggest bang for your buck - especially right smack in the middle of an entertainment district. With anywhere I go, $120 per night is just about the max I want to spend, however, most everything in downtown Memphis was $150 (PLUS tax) average and above.I went with the Yelp reviews here, and this place is just about the least expensive for the location. I stayed on a Fri-Sun, so the rate did increase, and INCLUDING tax and everything, came up to 145-155 p/night, which was still OK with me.The location was great, and within walking distance to downtown, Mud Island, Beale St., the historic trolleys, etc. You can't go wrong here! Across the street was Confederate Square, great views of Hernando DeSoto Bridge. and immediate access to Riverfront Park.The room was fairly updated, nicely appointed, and as clean as you might expect 2-3 star hotel. The bed was comfortable. The great thing about the lower-star hotels (vs. business-class hotels) such as this one is that they had free internet in the room, and also a microwave, and refrigerator. They also had free breakfast, with cereal, fruit, so-so pastries, juice, coffee, and make-your-own waffles. A note on the fruit and the fruit salad - it seemed that they brought the same ones out from morning to morning (i.e. mushy fruit salad, and whole fruit that was getting too soft to the touch).What wasn't OK is that they have their OWN parking lot, yet they charge you for using it. If they want to make the extra money, shouldn't they be charging ones who AREN'T hotel patrons for using it? I have a gripe about this because when I was checking in, the front desk person did NOT call it out that I was going to incur an additional charge. The only thing she said was, "You got a car?", after which I said, "yes," and she handed me a parking stub that she instructed me to hang on my rear view mirror.It wasn't till after I checked out and looked on my bill that I had noticed the $12/night charge for overnight parking (in addition to the rate I mentioned earlier). Had I known this, I would have consciously used "metered" street parking, which is free on the weekends, and was within a block of the hotel.My only other gripe is that the windows were so filthy from the inside/out with finger prints, grime and all, that it was cloudy looking out the window, so I washed the interior windows for my own piece of crazy mind.Had it not been for these last two points, I prob would have given this place four stars.A very solid hotel-stay at what seems to be a reasonable price for the neighborhood.Free wi-fi.I found the bed very comfortable, and the bedding to be a nice heavy quality. The shower itself was spacious and pleasant due to an unusual design that should be more widely adopted.The breakfast was fairly good for a chain-type hotel: hard-boiled eggs, yogurt, juices, waffle-maker, some basic pastry and bagels, cereal, plus bins of scrambled egg and sausage patties. There is a free safe in the closet unit which was a nice touch.The service was very friendly.
review_content_20: I was so impressed!I was on a road trip recently and passed through Memphis. I didn't need anything fancy so I started calling around and pricing area hotels. This was certainly (not surprisingly) one of the cheapest. It's location is great though, right on a cute little square between Front and Main streets. This made it very convenient to get around. Parking is only $12 a day (seems that $25 is standard from my recent experiences) and I was able to jump on the wifi connection for no additional charges.There isn't a gym or pool but there is a free continental breakfast which actually wasn't too bad either. They were also really nice about letting us stick around a little after check out the next morning so I could finish up some work before getting back on the road. The only reason I didn't rate this 5 stars is that while I was overstaying my welcome, housekeeping came in to clean and let's just say they didn't really clean... kinda gross. But overall, it's probably not too different than the nicer spots in that respect.We will definitely stay here again on any future trips to Memphis. it was in a great location. We had a view of the river from our room. The room was VERY clean, smelled clean, and the bed was comfortable. The room was a little small, but you just sleep there, so it's not a big deal. The staff was very courteous and friendly.We really liked the bathroom, it was small, but had a big shower instead of the tub/shower combo. Parking is only $12 on top of the room rate, which we paid only $99.Sleep Inns are generally on the low end of the Choice Hotel chain. This one does not fit the mold.Clean, centrally located, downright inexpensive. It's the best value for the price that I've seen all year.Very small rooms and not enough lighting, so it was quite a bleak stay for me. What made up for this was the housekeeping and front desk staff. They were so funny and sweet!I paid 109 for the night, Got an excellent room on the top floor with a river view just like I wish and asked for. The room looked nice, newly renovated, and the internet was free and the location was really very central and ideal. I would recommend to everyone. I didn't have more than like 10-20 cable stations, but the beds knocked me out right away anyway.Great location, Mud Island park is a short walk over the bridge, Union Ave and Beale Street a short walk or Trolley Ride.  Very clean, great breakfast, but most of all the staff was amazing!  very helpful and friendly.  will go back here in a heartbeat!Great location; great value.  I would stay here againGood hotel.  Great value, very clean and great location!!Very nice hotel at a great price. Rooms are smaller than most hotels I've stayed in,but newly remodeled and super clean. Flatscreen TV and the bed was very comfortable. Offers free wi-fi.  Great location and Beale street is only a trolley ride away! ***Don't confuse this hotel (Court SQUARE Sleep Inn) with Court Street Inn. My husband and I made this mistake and upon entering the wrong hotel room, which felt like a crime scene, we knew we were at the wrong place and switched reservations right away. Would recommend this hotel and stay again.Great location downtown, close to the Convention Center and Beale Street.  The staff was helpful and friendly, the room was clean, the rates are reasonable (for downtown).  I had an uneventful stay, which is all you can ask for from a chain hotel you picked because of its location and price.very nice hotel for the money.  everything was spotless and the bed was super comfy.  the parking lot was a little tight because it's shared with the marriott next door.  the location of this place is perfect...the trolley is right outside and beale street is only a few blocks away and there are a bunch of good rib joints in the area.  it can seem a little shady at night, but the people are friendly and you just need to stay aware of your surroundings at all times.

review_content: I had read so many bad reviews about this hotel before we arrived, but my partner and I were traveling across the states on a budget without a car so needed somewhere cheap and central. Econo Lodge was that. I was paranoid about bed bugs so the first thing I did was check the mattress. Not a single trace of those little blood suckers. The bed was HUGE and super comfortable. The room itself was huge as well, with a nice bathroom and it was very clean. The pool wasn't in operation because it was November. Yes the hotel is old and a little tired looking but for the price you pay you get a comfortable bed and a clean room. The breakfast wasn't super exciting - pastries, toast, waffles, cereal etc, pretty standard. The service was pretty non-existent, but we didn't want housekeeping to go into our rooms so had the sign on the door to keep them away. Location wise, it's an easy walk to anywhere in downtown memphis. The bus from the bus station is right outside (we walked, which was about 20 minutes) and the bus to Graceland leaves from just down the road too.I'd definitely stay here again if I was to return to Memphis.One of the nicest econo lodges ive ever been too. Still doesnt deserve more than 3 stars. Free parking, close to beale st and a big spacious room and pool are the best parts. The elevator sucks, ask for a low room if you can and take the stairs. Its doesnt have ac and i had sweat dripping off of me in my 7 minute ride down 3 floors, it was well over 100 degrees inside of it and it was full of people because apparently the other elevator doesnt work. They need to fix this, someone is gonna pass out, its that bad and a health concern now.The front staff was pretty rude. After getting into our room we were sitting and watching tv and someone came into our room. Seems they might of double booked the room. I called down to the front desk and she didn't seem to care. She just said ok and hung up. Room was pretty dirty and you might die in the elevator.One of the worst hotel experiences I've ever had in my travels. The staff at the front desk watched 'Maury' on tv during my check-in as drunk locals argued near the reception area....at 3pm in the afternoon. The elevators were slow and seemed on the verge of crashing. Our room smelled terribly, with furniture that was cracked and stained. The level of noise going on at night made us lock the deadbolt and put a chair against the door for safety during the night. In the morning we ran into a security guard who discussed with us that other guests for a convention were making noise on the floors, 'but what can you do?' he said as he ate a bowl of Cheerios in front of us in our hallway. How about some command and control over the hotel? The continental breakfast was disorganized and messy and appeared just thrown together and abandoned at some point in the morning. I understand this is a budget/commuter hotel but I shouldn't feel grossed out or unsafe to leave my room. Forget about it being near Beale Street...Avoid at all costs.Okay, I get that this is a budget hotel.  The name openly advertises that fact.  However, even at a budget hotel, I have certain expectations.  These expectations are not luxury expectations, but reasonable expectations; these expectations are merely that the hotel meets minimum standards with regard to cleanliness and service.  This place failed to meet many reasonable expectations that any hotel should meet regardless of whether it is the Hilton or the Econo Lodge.The elevator is painfully slow and the floor numbers do not appear inside the elevator because the display that shows what floor you're on doesn't work properly.  If one elects to take the stairs instead of the elevator, be prepared to walk into a musty and damp stairwell that would make a fitting setting for Hollywood's next horror film.  It also becomes apparent rather quickly that the interior of the building hasn't been properly maintained for a long time.  From cracked pictures hanging on the walls to damaged ceiling tiles and dirty carpets on the floors, the halls bespeak the same, serial-killer atmosphere as the stairwells.  One glance out of the window, at the hotel's pool, similarly disappoints.  From one of the upper floors, debris was visible inside of the pool such that it looked like the pool was struck by Hurricane Katrina.  If memory serves me correctly, Hurricane Katrina did not devastate Memphis.  What, then, was the excuse for the condition of the pool? The room itself was surprisingly mediocre.  Yes, the hair dryer didn't work according to my roommate.  Yes, the interior still exhibited signs of wear and tear.  But, with properly lowered expectations, the room itself was bearable.  One gleaming error: one of my "clean" towels had a hair folded into it.  The towel itself was clean otherwise, but no towel should have a hair folded neatly inside of it.  I don't need such a gift.  Otherwise, the bed linens looked clean and the bathroom was clean too.  At the very least, if I stayed in my room for long enough, I could close my eyes and convince myself that all of this was merely a bad dream.  I think my exhaustion level, after over 10 hours on the road, impaired my ability to care about anything but sleep by the time I made it to my room.However, when I woke up the next morning and sought out the free breakfast, a familiar depression set in again.  First, breakfast is served in a tiny room somewhere on an upper floor (the 6th, I think).  Second, I only discovered where breakfast was served after bumping into another hotel guest in the hallway.  There were no signs indicating that breakfast is served in such an odd location.  If I hadn't bumped into this guest, I'm not sure I would've known where to look.  Finally, when I found breakfast, I was sorely disappointed.  Most free breakfasts, even at budget hotels, include some assortment of common breakfast foods, such as scrambled eggs, sausage, etc.  Here, there were biscuits, cereal, and some danishes.  That was about it.  I took one of the biscuits, doused it in the complementary gravy, and began eating only to discover that half of the biscuit was hard as a rock and, thus, inedible.I traveled here last spring (2015) for an event with a student organization from my local university.  As a result, the goal of booking this hotel was to save money for the group.  In this regard, I think my student group succeeded.  As the old adage goes, you truly do get what you pay for.  This place was no exception.I know it's budget friendly, but it's not worth it. We arrived and there was a sketchy group of guys hanging out in the lobby. The people were not friendly at all,and to be honest it wasn't the safest part of town. Don't waste your money or your time it's not worth it.I would have given this hotel a 4 star except we got a call from the office at 6:00 am to come move our Harley. My husband had to get up out of bed & go outside in the cold.  He parked where the attendant told him too!  Then when we asked to check out at noon since we were woke up by their staff, she refused to give us the extra 15 minutes. The rooms were clean & decent but the staff needs a good course on customer service!Never, ever, ever, EVER again.One word: Yuk.Of course I'm here to elaborate on that but oh  my gosh, yuk. It's very old-style, decor is daggy, the lift is rickety and you know you're in budget accommodation. Staff were fine, not unfriendly but not O.T.T. No problem.At first glance the room we were put into was fine. Spacious and what we expected. The coffee pot didn't work. We slept the first night and went out during the day to see Graceland and Sun Studios. We had a knock on the door at around 9am by cleaners and we told them 'no thank you'. With laptops and other valuables (and suspicious minds) we left the sign on the door. We were only staying two nights and didn't need things changed over. I came back early and my room smelled like smoke. It hadn't smelled like that the night before. It was cold so I pulled back the covers. We generally don't check the covers when we check into a room because we ASSUME things are fine - WRONG. I'm doing this every single time I book into a room.ARRRRGGGGGHHHHH!!!!! See for yourself. Stains and splodge marks. It looked like blood stains and had gone an icky brown. When my husband returned I told him and wanted to say something but he asked me not to, didn't want to cause any problems. I wish I had. That night we slept on top, away from the gross marks. We checked out and got the hell away from there. We flew from Memphis airport to Las Vegas (Memphis Airport, another story altogether) and sat next to a Memphis police officer who told me 'that hotel is nasty.' He told me that a few years ago a guy murdered his girlfriend in one of the rooms there but the body wasn't found for weeks afterwards, despite cleaners going in and out, they hadn't lifted the bed. That's where she was hidden. Very creepy. I've since contacted the Choice Hotel Group who forwarded my complaint onto the manager of Econo Lodge Downtown Memphis who responded with this:-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Thank you for bringing to my attention your unpleasant experience at ourproperty. At our EconoLodge, the Owners and Staff pledge to do everything wecan to make you feel at home during your stay with us. We understand thatnothing replaces the feeling of home, but we will do our best to make sureyour stay with us is as comfortable as possible.We are very sorry that you were dissatisfied with our housekeepingefforts with the linens in your sleeping room. I appreciate your feedbackand have discussed every issue in your letter with our head housekeeper. Shewill be addressing these matters with her staff and is committed to ensuringthat these problems will not occur again. In the future, never keep an issueto yourself, most hotels want to make things better for you.This property has NEVER had any shootings and/or murders, again NEVER.The information that was given to you could not be more wrong. We are notresponsible for any bad happenings at other Choice Hotels and should not bepooled in with them. Again, there has NEVER been any shootings and/ormurders in and/or around this hotel.Once again, I apologize for your inconvenience, and if there is anythingelse I can do to help resolve this further please contact me at901-522-7050.Sincerely,Adam HoleyfieldGeneral Manager-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Sorry Mr Holeyfield but I think you're full of crap. Clean the frickin' sheets and blankets, throw out the ones that have blood stains on them, fix your coffee pots, don't allow people to smoke in rooms, tell your cleaners not to knock on people's doors at 9am, set up a better security system in your hotel lifts and invest in something more than pastries and porridge for your breakfast. Alternatively, burn the place down. That might be better for everyone.The entire hotel smells terrible, breakfast is served from 6-9, however get there early because once everything is gone, its gone. Bring some extra towels because they'll take your towels and not give you any. They also give great elevator rides, where you'll be able to explore the entire hotel, with one push of a button. Also, be sure to bring a bulletproof vest for when you decide to leave the hotel. In sum, dangerous location, poor service, scary elevator, rundown.This place was such a nice change after the horrid night we spent at the Weatherford OK. Americas Best.Located a couple blocks from Beale St, totally walkable, this place is inexpensive and oh so nice. Their garage is attached, so that's a plus. Every staff member we encountered was so super pleasant.My husband checked us in and we went up the garage to the "top", parked, and proceeded to our room.This was not the room at a budget hotel. This was more like a room at an older 5 star hotel. Deep thick tapestries for drapes, a large plush bed w/ an ornate headboard, a beautiful vintage 4 claw chair... yes please.  And my favorite part, clean. It was so clean!Seriously we paid a bargain hotel  price to stay in this hidden luxury. I don't think Ive slept better while travelling.Stay here. We will be again.By far the worst hotel I've ever been to in my life. I don't want to give this hotel a star but this is forcing me. It deserves a ZERO.
