We arrived, staff was rude when we checked in, went up to our room and it reeked of smoke. The room was marked non-smoking but it smelled terrible. The sheets were stained and the room was so old. The ceiling had brown stains all over it and cracks. Being a college student and coming to memphis for two nights I thought it would be an OK hotel and I could bare it. Nope. We walked in saw that and got the hell out. We were there for maybe 15 minutes. And of course when we left the lady working was incredibly rude. But it was worth just getting out of that dump! Please do not go here!Basic accommodations at a good price in comparison to other downtown hotels.  It was about what I expected.  Nothing fancy.  The hotel sits on top of a parking lot and part of the lot is used for hotel guests, who pay $10/night for the convenience.  The hallway smelled like cigarette smoke but I was pleasantly surprised at the odorlessness of my room.  Not sure if 'odorlessness' is a word but you get my drift.  The shower was a narrow, old-school tub with a narrow curtain-holder (I'm accustomed to the curtain rods that bulge outward to give more room!).My room was on the opposite corner of the building from the elevator bank, so it was nice and quiet.  Continental breakfast was in a conference room on the 9th floor and was simple yet enough.  Biscuits and gravy, cold cereal, fresh muffins, and juice/milk.Would definitely consider staying here again in the future.Oh, man.  We needed a place for the night, preferably near Beale Street, and this technically worked.  But man...The room was rundown.  Not awful, and things were clean, but not up to par.  The neighborhood, like most of Memphis from what I saw, was iffy.  The garage had some very dark corners that made Sweetie nervous.  The free breakfast was just passable.  And then we couldn't get back into our room.  Yep, the key was bad, and we were on the 10th floor, so a ride down- only to have the replacement key not work either.  So back down for another, which also didn't work.  Maintenance guy finally let us in.  I was a little surprised his key worked...And those elevators.  Hellavators, as someone said.  Jerky.  Noisy.  Music cutting in and out.  Indicators, inside and outside the elevators, that pretty much showed random numbers.  I am not exaggerating.  Waiting on one to arrive, I saw it read 1, 2, 5, 9, 2, 6, 7, 9.  Inside one, it said 4,5,6,10, 9, 10.  Yeah.  Check your floor before you get off!Service was good.  That's about the best thing I can say.  Next time we'll find somewhere else.Yes this is just a 3 star. Needs updates on everything. However you get free breakfast. Also want to add $10 a night for parking if you have a vehicle. We had a nice view of  North Memphis. The room smells, probably the disgusting carpet. Elevator had some problems. I would take the stairs. I won't stay here again.My time at the Econo Lodge was not a pleasant one. Positioned in an unfavorable part of town in what is currently the most dangerous city in the U.S., the Econo Lodge (which is nothing more than a parking garage with the top three floors "renovated") is a dirty, filthy mess. You never feel safe here- you walk into the lobby and find no window of safety between you and the homeless people roaming the streets. You get in the elevator and feel like you're on the Tower of Terror, never quite sure when the rackety thing is just going to drop. You get to your room and find that your room service didn't bother to make your bed for you, but the TV is on when you know you turned it off before you left (perhaps the maids enjoy their television entertainment for than their job). The only time I felt safe in Econo Lodge was when I was leaving it. The place, as mentioned above, is in dismal condition. I would not jump in the pool if my life depended on it. The pillows feel like they haven't been washed in a year, and the bed has a broken-in and overused swing to it. The whole place is supposed to be smoke-free, but I found nowhere in the hotel where I could not smell the characteristic after-fumes of nicotine. The whole place feels like a matchbox- and one that doesn't provide an adequate fire escape, to make it worse. The soda machines are all broken in one sort or the other (one doesn't take money, one takes your change but acts as if you didn't pay). There's no out of order signs to warn you of this either. For $80 for 3 nights, this may seem like quite the deal. The one plus of the place was a free continental breakfast (and to an extent the variety of TV channels- you get. 30 channels or so, including HBO, which was quite a contrast to what I was expecting). However, in the end, it isn't worth it. This place doesn't have much life left in it- either the health department is going to shut it down first, or that elevators going to finally give way,kill some innocent people, and prompt legal fees the Lodge won't be able to pay for. Trust me- don't risk your life for a cheaper hotel. Pay a bit more. There's plenty of better hotels around- the Sheraton and Courtyard Marriott are just a street over (even if that's too much for you, there were others around, but I forgot their names). But please- don't support this. Don't risk your life for this. Stay away from the Econo Lodge.I'd give it five stars but the building is a little too worn down for that. The location is great for getting around downtown and the staff is friendly and helpful. It doesn't look great but it's clean and the price is right.I paid $300.00 total for four nights here including parking. Room was clean and included a microwave, refrigerator and free Wi-Fi. . Location is awesome.For $60/night and it's close proximity to Beale Street, I can't complain too much about this Econo Lodge.  Parking is $10/night for hotel guests.  There was a sign for Memphis Redbirds game parking for $5 in the garage.  I don't understand why hotel guests would pay more for their parking than those going to a baseball game nearby.  Despite the relatively low price for parking, I felt ripped off after seeing that sign.The configuration of the parking garage in proximity to stairways and elevators is awful.  We had to unload our suitcases from the car and drag them up at least one level of the parking garage in order to get to the elevator.  In addition, the elevator felt like it was going to stop working at any moment.We only stayed here one night.  I would've been extremely unhappy with the hotel had we stayed here any longer.  The bed linens were terrible, and the pillows were so flat we had to fold them in half.  There were only 2 pillows on the bed, which meant one folded pillow for each of us.  I woke up with a sore neck the next morning and did not sleep well.Generally the room was clean.  But the air was so dry in our room that I woke up with a dry, fake-sounding cough.  This contributed to my sleeping poorly as well.The front desk staff was lame.  I find it really aggravating when I have to stand there, looking at 3 people working behind a desk who are all engaged in conversation with each other and ignore me.  I am standing at the desk holding a suitcase.  Obviously I want to check in.  And when they finally broke their posse up, the counter girl took her sweet ass time getting us checked in.This Econo Lodge is fine if you are only staying one night and want to save some money.  I don't think I would stay here again though, and I would avoid this hotel if you are staying in town multiple nights.  I'm giving it 2 stars for 2 things:  price and location.This was home base for my 2 nights in Memphis.  It had some good and some bad.  Here they are.............Good-  Inexpensive.  $60 a night.  Real close to Beale St and only 2 blocks from AutoZone Field.  $10 a night parking with tons of available spaces with in and out privileges. Staff was friendly.Bad-  Dated rooms. Crappy towels.  Shitty elevator.  Bed was not too comfy.  Floors in the room and bathroom just felt "icky".  Thin walls.Would I stay here again?  By myself, yes.  With my wife, no.  It would be a decent hotel to crash at for a guys weekend or something but its far from fancy.Not bad but I really can't give it more than 3 stars. We were traveling the weekend before Thanksgiving and were stopping overnight in Memphis. I got the Econo Lodge for $75 a night before taxes. Not a bad deal. The location is great, waking distance to everything downtown. The hotel has a parking lot that's $12 a day. The staff were, eh. The room was clean but very basic. Make sure you bring your toiletries, they don't leave any conditioner. If I could get a cheap rate again, I'd stay here in the future. It's not worth more than what I paid.
review_content_20: The room was large with a fairly nice view, but everything about the hotel seemed pretty cheap and grungy.  Also, my non-smoking room was very smokey.  The location and price ($70) were decent.This place has "meh" written all over it, but that's not the worst thing in the world. The price was decent if you go through Expedia ($89 with tax), but parking was somewhat of a ripoff. $10 for hotel guests, but there is definitely a cardboard sign in the windows that says "Public Parking $5.00". So...there's that.Rooms look like they were probably last updated in the early 90's, even though I heard the guy at the desk telling another guest they had just recently updated the carpet and beds. Maybe 5 years ago, but seriously man, not recently. The sheet didn't quite fit over the bed, the pillows were flat, and everything smelled a little funky, but the good news is the windows are all screwed shut so you can't open them. Oh, wait.The people at the desk were nice, the room was clean, and overall it's just a cheap, quiet, old hotel downtown. I just came to Memphis for one night to hang out on Beale St., so honestly, I'm not that worried about it. But seriously - update something, Econo Lodge! Anything!Great location, close to downtown. You pay for what you get though-the fitness room had one tread mill and only five pound weights. It was very clean and pretty quiet. I would stay here again if I were on a budget.For an economy hotel we were pleased. It was clean. The staff was courteous. The cleaning crew on our floor were so accommodating to our needs. The ice machine was out of order on our floor, but working on the floor above. Decent continental breakfast. Lots of attractions close by. Enjoyed our stay.This property was great. Reasonable rates and a downtown location. I was here for the St. Jude Memphis marathon, and the hotel location was about 2 blocks from the race start. No better place really, especially with the comparable rates from nearby properties.I didn't have any problems with the hotel, although when I needed a bandage for my foot, the hotel desk did not have any to spare. Oh well, I guess they aren't as big as the other chains, but they fit my travel budget to a tee. The room I got was a king bed and the room was clean. Bed was comfortable and slept pretty well. Clean and comfortable, that's basically what I look for in a hotel. Nothing fancy.I had fun in Memphis and managed to rock a PR in the marathon. If I ever do come back to Memphis, this is the race I would do again.Don't expect much for the low price. Faulty room keys, half washed sheets, and an Internet connection to rival the speeds of dial up are a few of the problems that plague this hotel. The rooms are severely outdated; this TV looks like it's from the mid 90s. The windows looking out from the rooms on one side of the hall are limited to the view of the communal pool, and I can imagine that the view from the rooms across the hall only shows the building directly across the street. The beds are quite comfortable, and the bathroom/sink is not bad. It is really cheap compared to other hotels in the downtown area, but it is noticeably more disappointing. While it is a good alternative to the more expensive hotels, it is certainly a compromise.I found this hotel on Travelocity. It was close to Beale street which was the attractive part. It seemed cheaper than nearby hotels so I thought I was getting a deal. Was prepared for a "cheap" hotel. Well the $20 in taxes and fees (more than 2x the other hotel I booked) brought the price up to a Non deal price. Still ok with my decision cuz any closer to Beale street and your spending twice as much anyway.. Parking was only ten bucks a night which I considered a deal.(chicago would be $40+) Easy 10 minute walk to the restaurants and pubs we wanted to go to. A/c was quiet and cold but the hotel blinds and curtains did not block out the annoyingly bright outside lights... Kept waking up thinking it was 9am when it was really 3am... This is the biggest reason why I gave a low rating. I was expecting a cheap hotel but I was looking forward to those blackout blinds/curtains that all hotels have. I wanted to sleep well!!!If you are looking for a hotel that is close to Beale street but affordable, this hotel could be a logical choice. Just be prepared for a mildewy bathroom, an elevator that has not been well maintained, a parking structure with burnt out lights, and an unsecured stairwell that can access every floor of the hotel without passing by the front desk. We had a safe and comfortable stay in the end (which is all you can really ask for at a discount motel), but we did worry about the security of both our room and our car because of the aforementioned issues. To be fair, I mentioned these problems in a survey that the Econolodge sent after our stay and the general manager emailed back right away to say that they would be addressed.We stayed there and it was CLEAN and the people were all very helpful.. The breakfast was about what you would expect : bagles and cereal and bisq.& gravy. For the price it was all GOOD and we walked to everything we needed to go to: even Gus chicken when it was cold we would take a cab home ro about $6 bucks.. It is OLD and tired in the hallways and Lobby and even the rooms could use a facelift but rooms and Bath were very clean- that is what counts .. If you want NICE stay at the Hampton for  $199.+tax or the peabody for $245.00 but we only slept there so we were HAPPY! for $65/nt + tax!I won't say it's the worst hotel I've stayed in.  But lets just say I've been to Detroit.  The location was great, walking distance to Beale and Main streets.  The parking was ample and seemed safe.  Wi-Fi was strong and fast.  Pool area looked pleasant, we didnt use it as it was a cold rainy day when we were there.  The problem was the elevator.  After several attempts to call it, we finally walked up to the 9th floor (parking goes up to 7th) through a very smelly outdoor-type stairwell.  Later when we did finally convince the elevator doors to open, it took us from 6 to 9, the doors tried to open, then back down to 7.  I took the stairs the rest of the time.  This is not a handicap accessable hotel.  The staff started vacuuming and shouting to each other in the hallway at about 8:30 am, so dont plan on sleeping in.  The breakfast was very simple, but ok.  Overall, next time I would spring for the extra $50 and stay at another downtown hotel.Nothing special.

review_content: Wonderful experience! Stayed one night and didn't expect much since this was just a stop along the way to Florida. Ended up loving the experience and will be planning a trip back. Some excellent things to mention: staff is very friendly (Willie the valet went above and beyond), clean hotel, beautiful historic building, one of the best free breakfasts I've ever had, 5 blocks to Beale Street (great music, food, and drinks), close to the trolley line, spacious rooms with huge windows, lots of towels, bottle water in the room, clean bathrooms, and very comfortable beds. There is also a fitness center and outdoor pool and hot tub. Didn't get to try those because we ran out of time but did take advantage of the complimentary WiFi.It's an okay hotel, really a 2.5 for my tastes, but I'll round up in honor of National Random Acts of Kindness Week.I chose this option for its location, but in retrospect it is far better suited for business travellers than one-night pleasure vacationers such as myself.  The surrounding area was completely desolate on a Sunday evening; all of the fun stuff is south and/or east, although some of it lies at the edge of walking distance.  Furthermore, in the morning I found that the nearby Mud Island River Park was closed for the season, another disappointment.But as a hotel it was fine.  The "suite" aspect was wasted on me, but there is a serviceable kitchenette--emphasis on the "ette."  The hotel offers valet parking for $15 per night.  Fifteen dollars is not necessarily a happy price, but it is actually the least among all the downtown Memphis hotels, and for some reason costs the same as self-parking.  So you may as well use the valet.The complimentary breakfast cannot compare to Hampton Inn, but offers a fair variety and mediocre quality:  scrambled eggs, sausage patties, ham; hard-boiled eggs; breads and pastries (still covered in plastic); whole apples, bananas, and oranges; whole strawberries and cubed cantaloupe; cold cuts; hot oatmeal; make-your-own waffles; coffee and tea; apple, orange, and cranberry juices; and ice water.Details:+  Real glasses+  Lemon-sage scented toiletries+  Lots of outlets, including on the bedside lamps+  Exhaust fan in the shower room-  The TV is positioned between the bed and the sofa, so that you get a neck crick either way.-  The bathroom and sink are uncomfortably close to the bed, especially for a suite.We usually stay here or the Courtyard Marriott when we travel for business. We prefer this over the other because there are usually less problems when staying. Staff are friendly. Rooms are clean.They need to upgrade their cable package though. I couldn't even watch the Memphis Grizzlies vs Atlanta Hawks game on TV!I would most likely not stay here again.  We checked in and the guy was not very friendly and pretty short with us.  It was a busy day but being a little friendly goes a long way.  Our room was in the old Kress building on the 5th floor.  I took the elevator up to the 5th floor and could not find our room.  I called the front desk and asked him where it is.  He said you take the elevator to the 3rd floor walk to the end of the hallway and then take a different elevator to 5.  Taking two elevators to your room is ridiculous enough but why didn't he tell us that?  There was no way to know to do that unless he told us and he didn't.  We get in the room and it looks good.  First thing I do is use the restroom and the toilet overflowed!  Not just clogged but it overflowed onto the floor and I had to throw every towel in the room down there.  I called the front desk and he said he would send up maintenance.  I said I wanted to change rooms (I didn't consider that bathroom to be sanitary after the toilet overflowed!) and he said he would send new keys up.  The maintenance guy brought up the new keys along with a plunger and he started plungering before we even left the room.  The new room was bigger but had no view.  That room worked out fine.  The free breakfast was good.  They definitely cater to Europeans with things like lunch meat and nutella.  Parking is $15 a day for a lot across the street.  Parking should be free.About 10-12 minute walk to Beale StThe shower was clean and hot with great water pressure. It's so terrible to end up with a luke warm shower with terrible water pressure. This was excellent. Free breakfast included all the basics of a continental breakfast as well as waffles, scrambled eggs, sausage patties, turkey patties, fruit, cereal, etc. The breakfast was actually pretty good. The staff were all absolutely amazing. Everything was as the website explained it. No mess ups. My wife has a very mild case of OCD. We usually have to always alter one thing or another while on a trip. Not one single thing needed to be done here. No problems. Great room. Awesome people.  Thanks Springhill.Go to the SpringhillLooking for a nice place to stay for our Memphis getaway, the Springhill looked like the top choice.This hotel exceeded our expectations in every way.: Courteous staff: Excellent location within walking distance of the downtown historic area.: Large comfortable rooms: Included free breakfast that equals what you would pay for elsewhere.: Parking is extra, but, is worth it for what you get overall.My fiance and I took a road trip to Memphis for his birthday and we stayed here on a Friday and Saturday night. I chose this hotel because of the positive reviews it got on TripAdvisor and the reasonable price. Many of the "better" hotels downtown tend to get pricey. I just wanted to make sure to book something nice that was close to the famous Beale Street and wasn't going to break my bank.We drove up and checked in with ease. All the staff we came in contact with were really friendly and helpful. We were given the option to valet or self-park. We chose to use the valet because it's the same price as the self-park($15). Plus the parking garage is two blocks away from the hotel, so we decided to let them look for the parking spot for us.They put us on the 2nd floor in the Main building. Our room was facing Main St with  view of the trolley station right outside our window and we loved the view! To be honest I was a bit worried about the trolley keeping us up at night being so close to our room and also from reading others reviews. But the sound of the trolley did not bother us at all! Maybe we are use to hearing a little background noise when we sleep or others may be more sensitive, but it didn't bother us. Plus the trolley does not run all night. The room was pretty nice. We had the King Suite. I loved how the bed was so comfortable because most hotel beds are anything but.The locations of this hotel was awesome! It is close to all the lively spots downtown. It was only about a 7 minute walk from Beale street and only about a 2- 5 minute walk to some restaurants and shops off of Main St. We didn't have to use our car for the entire stay!The hotel even had a decent fitness room which we used only one time. There is a stationary bike, treadmill , elliptical machine and free weights. They have breakfast that runs from from 6 to 10:30. We didn't get to try the breakfast so I cannot comment on that. We were too busy finding places to eat brunch on Main St( try Majestic Grille).Overall we had a really good experience at this hotel. We would stay here again if we visit Memphis in the future and I would recommend it to anyone planning to visit Memphis!Dirty rooms.  Nothing in the rooms really looks or feels clean.  When I checked into my room there was handprints on the desk and you could tell it had not been wiped down.  There are stains on the floor and the rooms feel gross.  From what I hear this is what you can expect from any of these older hotels here.  Just has a really run down feeling in it.  I would expect a little more from the Marriott, but I guess not.More like a 4.5. Stayed here 2 nights. Everyone was really friendly and complimentary breakfast was hot breakfast with a good selection that was constantly restocked. Easy check in, good price, great customer service (had room issue they immediately resolved). Feels old but maintained well and clean. Negatives? $15 to valet park or self park for $5 across the street and one block down. Not unusual for a downtown hotel. Also corner/angled rooms have only one very small window so little natural light. Also, I am a fitness facility user and was worried that there is only one bicycle, one elliptical, one treadmill, one bench, one ab mat, and some free weights. However, I was here both mornings for an hour each day and only saw one other person. Note also there is an outdoor pool and hot tub that are open year round (there was snow on the ground so nobody was in either). They are small and dated but inspection certificates on wall in gym say a 98/100 health department score so must be OK.The hotel has seen better days, but the location and staff make the stay. It will depend on your expectations and what you value.  The rooms are not the most modern or kept up; there were horrible stains on the carpet of the first room we had. We requested a second room with two beds, and the same stains were evident on the carpet. We had a view of the park, which was nice, and the trolley runs right by the back door, making local transportation or just a fun ride to the Peabody or surrounds very easy.The gym is meager. There is one bike, one elliptical, and one treadmill plus free weights. On the plus side there are towels and water. On the minus side, the equipment faces a floor to ceiling window and directly across from it is a building with glass windows that reflect back the hot sun. There are no window coverings so it makes working out really challenging from both a glare and heat perspective. When I was there, the remote for the TV was missing and the staff didn't have a replacement. They said ordering one would require them to "program the TV again"--apparently above the skills of the staff. The pool and hot tub are very small, with a view of an alley.Breakfast is a plus. Big buffet with plenty of variety. Stay away from the scrambled eggs, which tasted powdered. Waffles, hard boiled eggs, yogurt, fruit, bagels, cereal, meats, biscuits, etc. A plus is coffee available 24 hours a day in the lobby.There is a small bar off the lobby with hefty prices for drinks. There is a small area off the front desk where you can purchase soft drinks (at twice the price of the coke machines on your floor), sundries, and snacks. Two computers are available free in the lobby. When I was there, neither of them would print to the printer but the staff let me use their office printer which was great. Free WiFi in rooms as well.The staff are really great. Super friendly, always greeting you. By the end of our week we felt like family, and that really makes up for a lot. There is a small fridge in the rooms along with a microwave, coffee, and safe so that's a plus if you need snacks, want to make a lunch or your early-bird partner brings up breakfast while you sleep in.You can walk to the Mississippi, riverboat rides, and Mud Island as well. You have to balance the condition of the hotel with the location and staff, then determine what's more important to you. Be aware that there is a $12/day charge for parking regardless of whether it's valet.Acceptable. Valet Parker looked like a rapper wannabe (hat turned sideways). Not a great first impression. The guy at check in was at least 104 years old. Rooms were ok. GPS took us to the railroad tracks in front of the building. Had to use the force to find the entrance. No breakfast or coffee until 6:30 (must be a union thing?).Wouldn't come back unless I had to.I generally do not stay in Springhill Suites but I am happy with this hotel.  This location could easily be converted to a full service Marriott and has most of the amenities one would expect from a full service hotel. Lobby bar, small swimming pool and a streetcar station just steps from the door.My room on the 7th floor had furnishings that seemed new and a 40" HDTV was mounted on the wall in a way that it could be swiveled for viewing from both the living room and bed room.As other reviewers have said, the AC seems like a unit from a 1970's Motel 6.  The neighborhood seemed ok to me, a few homeless people were hanging out on the street but it was no worse than other places in Memphis...I stayed at this hotel after reading all the excellent reviews.  Unfortunantly, had a horrible experience.  I will start off with the positives - the location is great.  It is right next to a trolley stop and very close to Beale street and the mississippi river. It has free breakfast, a swimming pool and a very nice lounge area with a bar.The rest of the story is different.  The hotel is split into two sections - a newly renovated section and something the staff calls the 'historic' section.  I checked in with my husband and infant baby.  I had heard about the trolley noise and asked for a nice room away from the noise.  I got a room in the 'historic' building.  I later found out 'historic' meant old, moldy, dirty and smelly.  The room we walked in had no sun, the window was adjacent to another tall building.  It smelled of smoke and as if it had been flooded.  The bathroom was very dirty and I was afraid to put the baby anywhere on the bed or the couch.  I called the lobby and requested a new room - they seemed a bit irked that I made this request...They provided me with another room in the same building.  This room was right on top of the trolley stop and right across the elevator.  We had nonstop noise in here - when the trolley wasnt moving, the big radio speaker right outside the room was playing.  The lights outside from the businesses were very bright and not able to be blocked by the curtains.  The window had so many spiderwebs and was disgusting (see picture).  The bathroom was extremely tiny and the sink is located outside the bathroom.  In fact, each time you opened the door, it touched the toilet - you literaly had to stand in the corner of the bathroom to open it and step in/out.  I did not want to annoy the staff anymore, so I just stayed here.  Bad idea - on the second day my baby got pink eye from the dirtiness.  The staff is not very accomodating.  They knew of the circumstances and did not help.  Throughout my stay they ignored my presence.  In fact, I called to see if they could order me a taxi. I came down 15 minutes later and found out they had still not called for a taxi.  I then had to wait 15 additional minutes in the lobby for a taxi.  I later called yellow taxi on my own for future rides and was able to get on a taxi within 10 minutes.  I recommend staying at the residence inn right across this hotel.  It is just as convenient for location, is much cleaner, and has much friendlier customer service.My stay at the hotel was nice, and the staff was friendly and helpful while I was there.  I can't speak for the food but I slept comfortably in my room.BUT after leaving the hotel, when I found I had been erroneously charged more than $650 for a room that was supposed to be charged to someone else, the front desk manager (Mr. Silva) was considerably less helpful.  In my case it was problematic to have $650 disappear from my bank account unplanned - I was hit with overdraft fees as a result.In fact I felt Mr. Silva was quite rude to me over the phone and instead of taking responsibility for the mistake and making it right, made an already frustrating situation even worse.  I have worked in customer service quite a bit and I know how important it is to listen to a customer with a complaint, and treat them with respect.  Instead, Mr. Silva was argumentative, spoke over me many times when I attempted to outline the details of the situation, and overall left me feeling very upset.  Before my conversation with Mr. Silva, I was merely anxious to receive a refund of the erroneous charges; after, I felt angry and stepped-on.  Great job, sir.The location is ideal for tourists who want to see the main attractions for Memphis. and not worry about car rental and parking. The Trolley is in front of the hotel. However, it is a very quick walk to Beale Street and all of its sights and food, Rock N Soul Museum, Gibson Guitar, Lorraine Hotel and Civil Rights Museum, etc. The price is very competitive for hotels in the area. We were in the main hotel and did not stay in the older Kress building. The rooms are a good size and a standard suite with frig, wet bar, two large tv's etc.  The Breakfast had a good variety of food and the staff were very friendly.  They periodically come out of the kitchen to greet guests and make sure you have things you need or just chat with you.The beds were very comfortable with lots of pillows, also.The high Star rating is due not only to the location, price, and amenities, but also service. We had two issues that arose both of which were handled not only promptly but beyond our expectations. Things can happen no matter where you stay, but you just want someone to take care of it.  We really felt "pampered" by the way things were handled for us! TIP:  It is easy to get to the Rock N Soul Museum from the hotel.  Once you get there, you can take a FREE shuttle to Graceland, Sun Studios, and Heartbreak Hotel. You can stay at either of these sights, or go from one to the other as we did. Call the Museum or go on line for the shuttle schedule.Nice hotel. I have stayed at just about every Marriott and Hilton brand downtown and this is my favorite. Nice lobby and good location. Also has a bar in the lobby which many Springhill suites don't have. Only complaint is the room ac was only fair. More like a fan. May have been configured for heat since it was middle of Jan. and I like it cold, like 60 degrees cold.Springhill Suites are not fancy, but comfortable. The furnishings are modern and inexpensive to achieve the casual look they are seeking. I like it, but it may not appeal to some. They provide a complimentary breakfast and Internet. I did not try the breakfast. Honestly after 140 nights in a hotel I can't say I have enjoyed many free breakfasts and prefer to go out.Very nice hotel.Excellent location.Great Value.Our Suite is very nice. The people are friendly and accommodating as well. You can walk to many places from here. Very small pool and hot tub.. Breakfast is good as well.Room was nice. Carpets and fold out bed left something to be desired. Housekeeping didn't seem great. Left a note and tip asking for extra towels and still had to call front desk to ask for towels. Pool is nice and breakfast was pretty good as well. Very convenient to everything!We were in town this past weekend for the UFC in Memphis and chose to stay at this hotel. It was pretty much as good as it gets, location was perfect. Rooms were HUGE and super clean. Friendly staff. 2 full beds along with a pullout bed was just great. Free wireless internet along with a good breakfast in the morning. Would definitely stay here again, its a huge suite with room for a large crowd.
review_content_20: I'm really starting to love Marriott  hotels. We're two for two for having great  stays on this week long cross country trip. First off, the location is great! It is located in the middle of Main Street which the the main downtown street and the trolley route. Walking distance to Beale Street, museums such as the Rock-n-Soul museum and the Gibson Factory tour, and excellent restaurants. If you prefer to ride the trolley, you can.Valet and self parking are the same price ($12). Parking hasn't been an issue. We stayed at the Kress hotel, which is adjacent to the main hotel. It can get a little confusing because if you enter through the main entrance you have to take a couple of elevators and cross over to the the next building. However, they are great at offering alternative routes to getting to the Kress hotel. There's actually a direct entrance off Main Street.Complimentary breakfast which the whole family loved! Free Wi-Fi. Nice exercise room. Very very friendly staff and community.You just can't beat the location of this hotel!  You can step outside and walk to the bank of the Mississippi River or head on down to Beale Street for a night out.  The hotel itself was very nice as well.  We stayed in the historic building, which was very charming.  Loved the beds and the extra little sitting room by the door.  The lobby is gorgeous, the staff is super friendly, and the included breakfast was better than most. If you're planning to visit Memphis, I highly recommend staying here!Those who gave it a 5 star review must not have stayed in the Kress building which is part of the Springhill suites. I had a room overlooking Main street in the Kress building. It wasn't a "5 star" experience.First off, there is a raised walkway on the third floor connecting the two buildings. So for my room, it was an elevator ride to the third floor, walk down the end of the hall, then another ride to the fourth floor. Not a really big deal unless you gotta pickup your car from the valet every day and go back and forth.Then there was the room. The closet door was broken. I mean off the hinges, smack you on the head if you opened it broken. There were a couple of bulbs out in the room and the floor CREAKED. Not just in one spot, but all over. I felt bad for the person in the room below me if there was one. The windows were very drafty and I was lucky enough to be there during an ice storm, so it was cold outside. I had to keep the drapes closed and the heater at 77 to stay comfortable. And what the windows lacked in heat insulation, they also lacked in sound insulation. Luckily I sleep like a log, but when the trolley came by, it sounded like rolling thunder.And finally, the location. It is downtown on Main street. And there is all kinds of stuff within walking distance... as long as you go before 6pm. After 6pm, that whole end of Main street starts closing up and there is nothing open. Including the Walgreen's which closes at 8, (7 on Saturday, 6 on Sunday). All in all the room was clean and the bed comfortable. Which is why I still give it 3 stars. Just try to stay in the main building and not on the Main street side. P.S. The car accessible entrance is on the North Center lane side of the building. Turn west on Court avenue from Front street to get to it.The pros were Sarah at the front desk (so nice and helpful), the location was great, the room was very big.  The cons were some of the other staff were surly, my bathroom wasn't very clean and luggage carts weren't readily available.  Loved our time in Memphis, but would probably try another hotel for another stay.It was clean, you get a decent breakfast and they have coffee available all the time, plus internet is free.  They have 2 buildings, main building and a historic Kress building.  The only thing about being in the Kress is you have to take an elevator up, cross over to the other building and take another elevator up.  Annoying with a kiddo and luggage in tow.Location is good but not grat.  It's a quick walk to anything, about 7 minutes to Beale st.  Memphis at night (outside of Beale) is rather vacant and I didn't like walking with the family down quiet streets.  So a location closer to Beale st. might be better next time as we wouldn't have to walk quiet streets at night downtown.What is happening to the Marriott chain? Kevin at the front desk was great; very friendly and eagar to assist. I had read a review about the carpet being stained and the furniture being bargin basement and thought, oh please. But our room was kindof gross. The carpet in our room was pretty stained; makes you feel everything is dirty. A large front sitting room area with a small glass and aluminum table.  Food was yuk.  Had a bagel the first day from the breakfast buffet that was so stale! The next day I though maybe if I toasted it, but the bagels were so hard, I didn't even try to cut it to do so. The location is pretty good. Not too far to walk to Beale St, but got hit up a lot by vagrants (obviously, no fault of Springhill Suites; just be warned).Very good hotel.  Great location.  New and clean.  Friendly and helpful staff.  Parking is reasonable.  Right by the trolley.We stayed in the historic section, rooms are very nice.  It was a little wonky getting to the room, we had to take two elevators each time, which wasn't a bit deal.  You could get around this if you asked for the 3rd floor of the historic building.Overall great experience.The SpringHIll suites is being renovated-but I slept at the Courtyard,two doors up, but was permitted to use the pool and enjoy theBuffet breakfast, where Felicia was amused (I hope) that Ihelped myself for post meal snacks.  Jeanette Myers was in chargeof an event promoting the Hotel for Bridal parties and she wasgracious when I appeared, as I am always interested in thesekinds of things. It turned out that the caterer who provides thefood for all of the Marriott events, is absolutely first rate-the dessertprepared by the l8 year son of the owner was so rich and sodecadent-that i am still longing for another taste.  There are afew people who are also sales managers who need to relaxwhen it comes to what they think about who might have significance but dont fit their rather old fashioned ideas about'appearance' but this is a minor complaint-given the numberof marginals who hang around outside, one would think they'dbe able to discern the difference.  Sigh.Great rooms for the price, and the service is always cheery and excellent.  We stay here once a year for the St Jude Marathon, and always have a pleasant stay!I've gotta say that this SpringHill Suites was one of the most cozy and comfy hotels I've ever stayed in.  I don't know if it was the sea of soft pillows, the soft linens, the whirring on the A/C, or how the shades completely blocked all sunlight; but I was happy.  I slept 2 nights like a baby.  It really felt like home.  The rooms were big.  We had a seperate room with a sofa-bed and it's own TV.  Everything was clean and worked great.  A huge reason to stay at this hotel: the convenience.  It is right in the heart of downtown Memphis overlooking the Mississippi River and the bridge to Arkansas.  It's only a few blocks away from Beale Street and all the surrounding jazz/blues bars.  Beale Street can be a blassttttt if you're visiting.  The ability to WALK to Beale street instead of driving is a terrific advantage.The Springhill Suites Downtown deserves three stars for location.  Everything was right outside our door  and the Main Street Trolley stops right in front.   There is also a Walgreens right across the street. The downside of this hotel: -Not clean, the trash cans had not been emptied, the mirrors had gross smudges on them, and our toilet did not flush-Our coffee machine was broken and coffee ended up everywhere in the kitchenette area-There were no local brochures in our room, which I expect in a tourist location-The pool had not been cleaned-The television offers many choices for chargeable shows, it takes time however, to find your free channels, it's very easy to accidentally select something with a priceIf you can get a good rate at this hotel I would recomment it, but don't expect any thrills.This is your basic bargain hotel, The location is fantastic, with a streetcar stop right outside the hotel that will you get you to anywhere you would want to go downtown, for $1 a ride. The room rate was NOT a bargain, but I think that's because I was there for "Memphis in May", which is the local high season for tourism. The public areas of the hotel are clean and modern and pleasant, apparently very recently renovated. We chose a room in the "historic Kress building" because they're supposed to be bigger, but this wasn't really a plus. It was large with a high ceiling, but it's not really a suite - there's no door between the sleeping and living areas. There is an old standard (not flat screen) TV that swivels so it can be seen from either part of the "suite." The living area kind of dwarfed the furniture - a small loveseat and two chairs, and a simple desk. The "kitchen" area included a mini-fridge, a microwave, and a coffee maker, with no dishes and only enough coffee to make one cup. (It was dreadful.) The room was a little tired, with cracked bathroom floor tiles, some crud oozing from the shower safety bar, and so forth, but over all it was adequate and quiet with comfortable beds. The guy who checked us at the front desk managed to not say a SINGLE word to us until he handed us the keys and told us where the elevator was - so obviously we had to figure out for ourselves that breakfast was included in the rate. The breakfast itself was pretty good, with eggs, sausage, bacon, biscuits, bagels, cereal, sweet rolls, juice, and all that - other than the crumbly scrambled eggs and weak coffee, it was really quite good. Kevin at the front desk (NOT the guy who checked us in) was incredibly helpful and friendly, and called a ride for us to the airport that worked out great. All in all, there's no reason not to stay here, as long as you're not expecting the Ritz.

review_content: I'm giving it 4stars as I feel I've been to a lot worse. I stayed here this past weekend to attend a dance convention with my daughter. Location and ease to convention center is nice. Location in general is what it is considering the high crime in Memphis. The check in went smoothly for me and the bell hop check to make sure our key cards all worked at club lounge. Staff at lounge were bland and sometimes rude. The food was mediocre but it got my kid some food before a long day of dancing. The beds were comfortable. A lot. The room was decent sized and the bathroom had adequate lighting for three dancers to apply make up. There is a fridge and safe and real glasses to drink from. There is no microwave- but access to one on 3rd floor. I do think at this level, a micro should be included. Only real complaint was how the room would get up to 80 degrees after we set it lower. I heard this complaint across the board.  The fitness center was ideal and had plenty of equipment. Was able to use most everything. View was less than stellar on the mill- but... Pool area looked nice. We tipped valet- and like some say- hit or miss. Lots of people but still waited a good 40 mins for bell hop to load our belongings and take to pack car. That said, they did so more efficient than we did! Service at bar area was kind of slow too but people were all kind and friendly there.The Sheraton Downtown Memphis is a very nice hotel. My husband and I happen to arrive during a convention. The convention center is attached to the hotel which makes it convenient for a lot of guests.The parking is valet only and $22 a night not including tax. I think it would be convent to have parking onsite but charge a smaller rate, but they do have a small parking lot. If you do not want valet or pay the price, parking is conveniently located across the street for $10. Now the parking had some conditions. You must move your car by 7AM or you'll be fined $20. Also, once you leave the parking lot, you will have to pay another $10 to get back in, and it doesn't matter if it's the same day. The attendants are nice and willing to work with you because they don't have notices aren't everywhere. We stayed on the 18th floor which allowed us a great view of the city. If you pay a little more, you are able to access the club lounge. The club lounge is beautiful. Breakfast is prepared every morning and hor dourves are served every evening. They have a very nice spread, comfortable seating, tv's, magazines and other things you may want to enjoy while relaxing. We had a small issue with accessing the lounge on one morning, and the attendee did not allow us to enter. She told us we had to go down to the front desk and sort things out, mind you, another couple was having issues getting in, and in order to get to the lounge area, you have to use a key card on the elevator. We went downstairs and the receptionist order new key cards for us and for the other couple as well. We went back up stairs, and the cards still didn't work. The attendee gave us a hard time and then allowed us to enter, then told us we needed to go downstairs and let front desk know the issue again. I asked her since we just went down to the front desk, if she could use her walkie talkie and alert them of the issue since other people are having the same issue. She said no and apologized. I went down to the front desk and the manager assisted me and went to the lounge and talked to the attendee. He guaranteed me the situation will be taken care of before happy hour. He was right, everything was taken care of.My husband and I both enjoyed our stay. The fitness center is renovated and opened 24/7. The pool is clean and the water is warm. They offer towels for your convenience and headphones if you need them. The deck is great if you want to sunbath. Overall, the experience at Sheraton was great. We had a wonderful time. The housekeeping staff was friendly and asked what we needed. I would come back and enjoy another stay.This hotel used to be a Marriott and switched a couple years ago to be a Sheraton which seemed great because the only other Starwood property in downtown Memphis is the Westin Beale Street which is typically above my company's nightly cost requirement.  Yes, I know the Sheraton is across from the Convention Center and it's a huge hotel that doesn't always have a personal touch.  But I get my SPG points, right?  And as a lifetime Platinum member I get access to the Club Lounge, right?  Sadly, neither is usually the case.I can tell you that the rooms are generally clean, the beds are comfortable, and the on-site restaurant & bar are decent.  The location however is horrible unless you're going to the Convention Center across the street or you enjoy dealing with homeless and indigent folks as you walk to any of the "nearby" restaurants which are all at least a few blocks to walk.  Valet parking, hit or miss.  Access to the Club Lounge, it turns out they either don't care or they screw up the key card coding just about every time.  And your SPG points (for those who care) - my last 3 stays at this property on a AAA rate were put into the system as a "non-eligible" rate for SPG points despite the fact that it was clearly an eligible SPG rate.  The money I spent at the restaurant & bar was awarded points on each stay but my room expenditures were not - and I'm still fighting to try and get the points I'm due for a stay that was almost a month ago.  Hmmmm.  I understand that many people at a convention hotel may not care about SPG points but it strikes me as entirely dishonest and unfitting of a Sheraton to try and screw their most loyal members out of their SPG points - if it was a one time occurrence that would be one thing but at this point it clearly seems to be a consistent, systematic choice by hotel management.Quite frankly I don't plan to ever stay at this hotel again, even if I have to stay at a less desirable Marriott property instead of Starwood which I've done a couple times.  The lack of customer service at the Sheraton Memphis Downtown is just not good business, but I guess if you're a convention hotel with unscrupulous management it may work out in your favor overall but that still doesn't make it right,  This hotel should be kicked out of the Starwood family, and I can only hope that it happens sooner rather than later.Stayed here for 6 nights and everything was great. Staff was friendly and helpful, the room was clean, modern and well stocked. The location is good if you want to be in walking distance to Beale St but not right in the busy, noisy area. I'd stay here again.I was only in Memphis for a short time, but the short stay was really great. We stayed here at the Sheraton on the 18th floor, which was cool because it was a clubhouse level that required your room key to access. The view was pretty spectacular, too. We could see the pyramid and all over Memphis. The valet parking was a little pricy, but I did enjoy how friendly the attendants were. They were also really quick at getting the vehicles out of the garage. The room was really nice. Pretty much your average nice hotel room, comfy bed, couch, and desk. It was all really clean. That's what matters most, right?All in all, Memphis was a good time. It's a really cool city and the stay here was great!The hotel was recently renovated - nice rooms, clean, comfortable.  Executive Lounge was very good.  Nice staff.  Location is so-so.I'll be honest, I've been putting off this review.  Mostly out of disdain for having to re-live my short, yet still too long, one night stay here. I was also hoping that in some way, some how, the hotel would at least ATTEMPT to make things a little better. Well, no such luck. So, let's get down to it.    We arrived at the hotel around 3:30, tired and hungry from a day's worth of riding in the car. Since our, and I'm quoting here, guaranteed checkin time was 3:00, we were right on schedule. But, as I bet you've guessed, our room wasn't ready yet. They were gracious enough to not offer an excuse, inform us that he couldn't give us an approximate time when the room would be ready, and tell us where we could leave our luggage while we waited. At 4:45, we'd had enough of sitting in the lobby. I went to the front desk to ask when we could go to our room. Would you believe they had JUST finished cleaning it? Yep, didn't even get a chance to page us yet. I never knew I had such killer instincts, but I suppose I should start picking lotto numbers too.    Fast forward to 11:00pm, 7 hours before we intended to be back on the road. Since words cannot accurately describe, and I don't have visual aids, the next 5 hours must be intangibly visualized. Imagine hell. Now make it worse. Drunken young adults screaming, crying fighting, banging on your door. Trampling up and down the hall ways, puking in community garbage cans.... Yes, that all happened.... until 4:30am. I, of course, called the front desk. Then again. Then a third time, being assured that security was there and police were on their way. Then a fourth time. Then a fifth. Finally, about 4:30, I walked into the hall determined to stop the chaos at any cost. My neighbor, a cameraman who had to be on set at 6:00, was already out in the hallway. He was mad. Very mad. And rightfully so. The security guards were there as well, FINALLY tending to the situation. Too late. WAY too late. If I'd have known we wouldn't get any sleep in the hotel, we could've just drove straight through to Nola.   Bottom line, we went to the hotel to get some sleep. Not to party, not to swim, not to watch T.V.... TO SLEEP! We purposely stayed at one of the nicer (more expensive) hotels in hopes of a restful night. Needless to say, we didn't get what we paid for. If you went to a fine French restaurant, paid the bill before you received your food, and they came back and told you all they had was rotten potatoes and charged you anyways that would be unacceptable. Same here. We got NOTHING for the money we paid. Not even a voucher for a free bottle of $3 water. NOTHING. HORRIBLY managed. Knowing that Sheraton, as a company, finds this acceptable will keep us from EVER even considering them as a place to stay again. Do I have to say that I wouldn't recommend this place?Stay somewhere else. 1st room...ants on the desk, ants in the bed,  ants on the towels,  ants in the tub. I call the front desk, they say they will send someone to spray but I asked to be moved. 2nd room...ants in the tub, ants in the shower. At this point its nearly 9 pm and I have to get up early. I call the front desk, they move me again...to a lower floor. 3rd room...I am only turning on one light and getting into the hopefully ant-free bed. Oh, the front desk comped my valet parking. Yipee...too bad the company was already paying for it. Do not come here. There are too many other choices to have to deal with this...at a Sheraton!!Update...went to check out, parking hadn't been comped, there was a charge from the bar that I didn't visit,  and it only took the girl 20 minutes to have me check out.2 1/2 StarsThe good...the valet staff and the front desk staff, Darell and Velisha.The bad...mosquitos EVERYWHERE in the lobby AND an unfriendly bartender at the bar.The ugly... Club Level room- the minimalist and outdated decor, no toiletries and no refreshments except Diet Coke in the Club Lounge!This hotel has definitely done a 180 since I stayed here years ago. Not sure when it was remodeled, but it looks absolutely beautiful. The room was very spacious and the bed was very comfortable. All in all, I was pleased with my stay.But...the reason I give it 2 stars out of 5, is that when I came to check in (it was 1:30 AM on a Monday night..) the hotel clerk/receptionist gave me a room that was already being occupied by other guests. Yes, you read that correctly. She had given me a room key to the 3rd floor and as I opened the room, there were people in their beds. Such a horrifying experience. When I came back down and let the hotel clerk know, she didn't seem to be as concerned as I was. Does this happen regularly here? Safety is key, and that is not a mistake that should ever happen again.This place is great!! We really had a great experience here! We had a room that was very new and clean. On top of that, they also gave us a ride to Beal Street, and a ride back! I really had a great experience here at the Sheraton Memphis Downtown.I loved this hotel. The room was perfect, comfortable, efficiently designed and very clean. The overall atmosphere gave me a sense of protection as I was alone on business. The staff made me laugh every day and had me looking forward to seeing their smiling faces in an unfamiliar place. As a millennial, sadly, I don't immediately think to tip hotel staff but this was different. Before I ran to catch my plane, I made sure to break some cash and give it where it was deserved. I had to come back to Memphis the following week and decided to stay closer to where I'm doing business, not realizing how much I'd miss the Sheraton. I know where I'll be staying next time.Not pet friendly.  Told them twice when i made reservation that i had dogs.  Told  them at check in i had dogs. Four hours later they told me i had to move because i had dogs on a non pet friendly floor. When i said i would not move i was told there had been complaints about the dogs and if there was one more i would be asked to move to a pet floor. I explained i had told everyone possible that i was bringing dogs i was then told that if there was one more complaint i would be asked to leave the hotel and not just moved to a pet floor.I was given a three page document i had never seen before that stated i would never leave the animals unattended in the room. I was escorted to my room by a front desk supervisor who stated she was the "night manager" and who was unavailable for further discussion for 20 minutes before her shift endedMy advice: stay away from the "pet friendly" Sheraton Downtown Memphis.My friend and I had a pretty perfect stay at the Sheraton for a long weekend. I was worried based on so many mixed reviews but our stay was great!Our room was perfectly clean, no funky or stale smell in the hallway or the bedroom. Sheets spotless white, turned down, no undesirable stray hairs or objects. Bathroom was clean and modern, good water pressure. I have to really highlight that I did not feel gross or dirty while staying here. I have that problem sometimes where everything feels very icky, not here. Beds were comfortable, not too firm but not super plush.Staff is extremely nice, valets especially. If I am remembering correctly there are two towers to the Sheraton. We were in the North Tower, it seems to be brand new basically which probably explains why our hotel room was so nice and clean. I think I read that the other tower is older, we did not visit it, maybe it is a less enjoyable experience, but the North Tower was great. I used their fitness center as well, this was also really nice. Quite a lot of machines, ellipticals and treadmills, free weights and weight machines. Very nice and clean as well. I was very impressed, it's nicer than my actual gym at home.Solid 15 minute walk to downtown, which for me, living in Chicago, is nothing and worth the walk to save money on the hotel. For other tourists who maybe aren't use to walking to bars and restaurants, you might find this hotel to be a bit far out. I would stay here again.Do not stay in room 1136. I had a horrible experience and I just want to warn people about this hotel. As a flight attendant for over 6 years I stay in many hotels. I checked out of this one in the morning a bit itchy, thinking I had about 5 bug bites. By the time I was done with work for the day and undressing for a shower in my home that night, I noticed that I actually had over 40 bites. I will post a picture. I dont know what bit me. To begin with, the hotel airport shuttle picked us up 30 minutes late. 30 minutes of waiting on the curb calling the hotel and asking them when our shuttle might arrive. During my stay I went for a 30 minute walk. The valet saw me about to walk around the neighborhood and told me to "be careful." During the 30 minute walk I probably had about 100 bums try to strike up a conversation with me. The neighborhood is the most annoying neighborhood I have ever walked through. The bums are out of control but apparently its okay with the city of Memphis because the bums are all super friendly, telling me to have a great morning, how is my day going, where am i off to, god bless you, etc. I felt like I was living the spare some change episode of southpark. So annoying. I couldn't find anything to eat during my 30 minute walk through bum-ville. Every place was open but with literally no one eating there, so I never stopped anywhere and just assumed I would order room service when I got back to what I was still thinking was a clean, bug free room. I ordered room service and it arrived and was not what I had ordered. She left it there and told me she would be back up with the correct order. I never saw or heard from her again so i ended up eating somebody elses cold food about an hour later while listening to my next door neighbor tell his wife about his trip on his phone. I could also hear her end of the conversation crystal clear thanks to the super thin walls.The rooms are newly renovated and seem clean, but when I laid down in my bed it almost seemed like the top of the mattress collapsed down and I pretty much was laying on a wooden beam covered with a bunch of fabric. When I got back up to look at it, it looked like someone had slept on that side of the mattress every night for 50 years straight and left a huge hollow spot. Obviously the mattress was not new.That leads me to my 40+ bug bites that I ended up with. I guess I had roommates staying with me in/on that old mattress that I was unaware of when I checked in to the room. When I exited the elevator on my way to check out in the morning I was greeted with a super cheerful "Good Morning!" by a smiley old bum who had made his way into the lobby.  Our hotel airport shuttle was 10 minutes late picking us up for the airport that morning and if any of you are flight crew then you know a 10 minute late pickup can cause a flight delay. If only I could go back in time. I would rent a car at the airport for my layover. I would drive the car to kmart and buy the cheapest tent and sleeping bag that they had on sale. i would stop by mcdonalds on my way to the nearest KOA campground. I would eat my chosen dinner on the campground picnic table, and have a better nights sleep in my sleeping bag on the rocks. I would wake up with probably only about 10-15 bug bites and I wouldn't have to throw away all of my possessions as opposed to bringing home new "friends." It would have been cheaper, less stressful, and more comfortable than staying at this dirty crap hole and having to buy a new suitcase and new clothing and work uniforms. This was by far the worst hotel ever and I have stayed in a wide range of hotels over the course of my lifetime.Thanks sheraton memphis!!!!!!!!!! great job!!!!!!!!!!I had stayed at this hotel a few years ago when it was a Marriott. Sheraton bought it a year or so ago and apparently have been doing renovations and updating things, because there are certain things that have been vastly improved.The staff is among the friendliest I've come across in my many travels. Always willing to go the extra mile and help in any way they can. That's especially appreciated after driving over 10 hours and stopping for a night. There is a small convenience store open until 11pm and rooms service is also available. I did not have the opportunity to try out the room service, but I'm sure I will get the chance fairly soon.Rooms are improved and updated since my last stay (when it was a Marriott). Bathrooms are modern, well appointed and very well lit. Beds are comfy, carpet seems new and has that "cushy" feel. This Sheraton could take a cue from fellow SPG property (Aloft) and get updated and mounted flat screen TVs that can be controlled with a mobile device. A refrigerator would be helpful, too.A couple gripes:1) Valet parking is the only option. It's not the price but the inconvenience that matters here. After driving for several hours, I don't have my wits about me to the point that I'm not going to forget something. There is 24 access, but it requires you call down so they can get your car. I'd rather pay a smaller fee and park myself so I can have access and be able to grab my toothbrush at 2:30am without involving someone else.2) Maybe they are renovating with a phased approach, but there are some things that need attention. One that stands out are the elevators, at least for the south tower. Several buttons are broken and the lit up Sheraton logo on the inside has seen better day (seems like the bulb is too hot and has browned the logo paper). It's one thing if the hotel matched, but most of the hotel is modern, clean and elegant... it's a little disjointed to step into a less nice  elevator.NOTE: I've become a fan of SPG hotels (Sheraton, Aloft, Westin and others) mainly because a vast majority accept pets, which is important for me and my wife...and my pug. Given the choice, I'd probably pick another SPG hotel in Memphis, the Westin on Beale Street, but it's usually about $50-$70 more per night. All in all, this Sheraton is very nice. It's reasonably priced for the services you receive. I was going to rate it 3 stars, but because of the hospitality and friendliest staff I've met in a while, I'll go ahead and give it 4 stars.First let me say that the location was great for the trolley transportation and proximity to attractions.  Deep breath, that said...it gets 2 stairs because:1.  The mosquito infestation inside the hotel is horrendous!2.  The service staff was lazy in the restaurant bar area every day3.  We had to change rooms due to getting locked out constantly and finally offered another room on day 2 1/2 and husband insisted 4.  The pool was overrun with unruly kids until we asked for assistance from staff to bring order before someone gets hurt5.  Did I say the bar closes at 11 on friday and saturday?!!!Came for a convention, greatly enjoyed our stay! All of the staff were very polite and answered any questions. Rooms were clean.We had a small leak in the ceiling, but it was fixed quickly. Car did not receive any damage in valet parking. I would stay here again.My family and I have stayed here quite a few times when it was Marriott. it's one of our favorites!! As a Sheraton Hotel it's even better! Friendly Staff.. great rooms ..pretty views!love it! !!Stayed there May 17-21, 2015 .Had lots of bites due to bed bugs on both hands, and it was very difficult to sleep  due to the itch. More bites showed up over the next two days after I checked out. I called and spoke to Bernard, an assistant manager,  he said they will take the room out of commission and that someone will call me. Two days later, their " head of security" called me to get a report - he even asked for my date of birth....??   Two days later, another guy called to tell me that they looked at the room, and someone else was going to call me very soon. Yesterday, one week after my initial complaint, an "insurance adjuster" for Sheraton  called me from Texas and gave me claim no 972 012 1136 and asked me to tell the story all over again. She asked me if I had my clothes cleaned , and I asked if I needed to clean my suitcase or dispose of it. She said that she could not tell me what to do, but asked about the "damages  that I am claiming". She said that she did not receive any inspection report but will call me later. Fast forward two weeks, still no call backHey guys, I only wanted to let you know that I had a sleepless night thanks to the bed bugs and apparent lack of hygiene at your hotel. I did not ask, and I do not want a free night, or reimbursement for my laundry expenses, the Benadryl pills or to pay for my disposed luggage. I called you as a courtesy to the next guest that will stay at room 443. I expected an apology, and it doesn't look like I am going to get that either. I stayed at this hotel every year since 2004 when it was still Marriott. Looks like 2015 was my last at this Sheraton.BTW, the receptionist that handled my checkout for my three rooms at 12:30 PM on June 21 was beyond rude and arrogant. She needs to be retrained.
review_content_20: Honestly I booked a room here for business not sure what I was getting seeing the 3 stars. Perhaps this place started to listen to its customers because I had hardly a single complaint. I was promptly greeted when I showed up, my luggage loaded and held in the lobby for me by Eugene while I checked in. The staff the whole way through was friendly and professional. My room was clean and very welcoming. The location of this establishment is right on the limits of downtown with the trolley line running right outside its doors. Or take an Uber/taxi which ran about $5 down to Beale street. I think my only real issue was the TV acted funny with the remote, but honestly I mostly had the TV on for background noise so as long as it turns on I'm okay. Will stay here again.Dirty room. Toilet wouldn't flush. Starbucks cafe sucked. Customer service, although kind, wasn't efficient and didn't care enough about doing things in a timely manner.I think they were just wrapping up construction during my stay.  It also seemed like they really didn't know what they were doing at any given moment.  I think they had vouchers for different meals and then they never took them for me or tried to bill me - it was all very confusing lol.The staff was extremely nice though through all that was going on.  I was on the club level and the girls running that lounge were sweet and helpful.What I didn't like, is that I had ants in my room and the last night finally got transferred out of there.  I mean...ants were all over my things it was awful.I hope with their new upgrades they catch on to how to "run" things and take care of any infestation problems they have.Much thanks to Scott (from Thousand Oaks) for helping us out with our situation. See you the next time we're in Memphis!  You and Sheraton Hotels ROCK!!!We made reservations more than 30 days in advance. We arrived at 11:30 pm to find that they are giving away rooms "first come, first served." This is stupid, what the hell is the point of making a reservation. Could be the last Sheridan Hotel I stay at. I. Top of that, valet parking only.Clean, comfortable beds. The view from our room faced the brick wall of the north tower and there was no microwave in our room. Other than that, the staff was friendly and service was extremely fast. There is no parking onsite except for valet parking at $22 per day, which was worth the price, especially since we were traveling with an infant.Myself, my wife, and two little boys stopped at this hotel on our way home from Florida. Definitely not what I was expecting. A/C didn't work, my 4 yr old slipped on a puddle of spit in the elevator , I went down to order a drink for my room from the bar, and sat for twenty minutes without one person offering to help me. Don't waste your money, I will never return to a Sheraton as this one has left a real bad taste in my mouth!!I like this place great for being right next to the convention center. Rooms are large and comfortable. Restaurant is pretty goodStaff is very nice and courteous. Hotel is conveniently located next to the Convention center. Not much nightlife in walking distance, but taxis are readily available to take visitors to Beal street or Graceland.Absolutely zero complaints. This hotel was pretty and staffed with folks who were just incredibly helpful.  My colleagues and I were in Memphis for a short stay, and we were so lucky to stay at the Sheraton for this visit.  We were greeted with valet, which is priced $21 a night.  We were checked in quickly and shown to our rooms.  The beds had pillows on pillows and were just so very soft.  The comforter was not overly thick but it did the job on a freezing Memphis night.  I used the fitness facilities and I wish I could show a picture (cell phone camera is not working-I would NOT give 5 stars to Apple right now).  But that gym. Woooooooo.  LOVED IT.  Let's be honest-what do I do when I go to a gym?  Walk realllly slowly on a treadmill and watch TV.  But if I wanted to climb a rope ladder? I could do it.  If I wanted to do exercise things on a huge mega-ball, then I could.  Fitness beyond my skills was accessible to me, and it made staying at the Sheraton seem like a real treat.  The indoor pool features a skylight and access to an outdoor deck.  Not something that I was interested in, again FREEZING in Memphis!  But such a nice feature.  Loved staying here and look forward to staying again soon.So far so good! Yes the hotel is going through a renovation right now, (looks to be almost completed) from an old Marriott to a new stylish contemporary Sheraton. Our room on the floor we are on seems to all been part of the renovation, all new!We had a quick bite at the bar and was totally amazed! I had the Bacon Cheeseburger and the my wife had the Turkey Club! Both of us agreed that it was one of the tastiest experiences we have had! And the hand cut Fries excellent! Definitely worth checking out!People here have been super friendly!Very clean, safe and hospitable. Twice while I was walking to/from our room to the elevators I saw security personnel walking the halls. Rooms and very clean and personnel was friendly. Breakfast prices are outrageously overpriced. $9.00 for oatmeal, $11.00 for pancakes! We went to Blue Plate Cafe, which is just a few blocks from the hotel, and enjoyed a homemade southern style breakfast at good prices.The hotel is located downtown but the area is very hood. Its scary to walk around. The place needs to be renovated.A Priceline bid allowed us to enjoy this Sheraton, a fancier hotel than we usually frequent as a couple.  The front staff treated us just as nicely as any other of the (many!) people who were checking on on a Friday night in June.  A Bruno Mars concert was happening that night, so it was a madhouse, but the valet and front desk staffs did a great job keeping things moving.EVERYONE was friendly and helpful and smiled alot.  It was like being at the Ritz Carlton, having such great service.  We asked for extra towels and they were there in less than five minutes (at 10 pm!)Great shower head. Granite in bathroom. Kingsized bed with great linens and pillows.If you ask IN ADVANCE for a special door knob notice, you can get back "voucher" points.  That is, if you say it's not necessary to have maid service , I think it's six dollars per day you get vouchers for.  Not sure how that works.On the sixth floor, we did not have a fridge or microwave. Some floors' rooms offer them, I think.  Without a special key, you can't get onto the top three floors. But the view is great from the 16th floor, if you want to ride up in the glass elevator and see the skyline of Memphis.  (And grab a free USA Today off the credenza there - is that okay??)The trolley stop outside the hotel is between it and the convention center. You should take the "long way" around, down by the river - the "loop" - it gets you to Beale street in about 30 minutes instead of ten....but you get to see the sites of the city for just a dollar!  Including the MLK museum and between its buildings, the hotel balcony from which he was killed (including the cars of the day).Remember to tip your valets, bellhops, and housekeeping!!(PS - WiFi and ethernet cable&connection were both available in our room. Both were fast - - BUT - - both knocked us off A LOT, even during non-business usage hours.)We waited well past check in time for a room.  The staff could not provide any reasoning for the delay.   They also could not provide a time frame for which we could expect our room.  After sitting in the car for nine hours, the last thing I wanted to do was sit in the lobby and wait.  My husband complained again after 45 minutes, and the hotel produced a room.  This also developed into a disaster; by 11 pm, as our kids tried to sleep, dozens of college aged kids began yelling, fighting, and banging on doors.  Unfortunately, this was not an isolated incident, and this carried on for hours.  We made multiple calls to security, as did another guest down the hall.  The situation was not handled, and continued well past 3 am.  The hotel needs to contain disruptive guests, and in a timely fashion.  It should not take for hours to stop drunken yelling and fighting in halls, and far worse, obnoxious kids banging on our doors all night long.  We left with only a few hours sleep, and no apologies from the hotel.What a bad experience.  The people working the front desk and valet were wonderful, could not ask for any nicer!  First night we were next to a room of loud, no sleeping women!  All night would not shut up, we could hear their conversations over the tv.  Then when they left, they were doing construction in the room above us.  Are you kidding?  They moved us finally to another room, and gave us a credit of $50, and Whitney sent us a nice fruit tray!  We left for the day, came back and our tv did not work, sent someone up yo work on it, with no luck.  So off to another room.  Asked for a late check out the last day, could only do 1 hour.  We come back next month, but will look at another hotel!!!Okay...so looks like a very very nice hotel...but you just don't know. On our first night we met the producers from ghost asylum..I think that in itself says enough. This building is on a huge fault line. When you go up past the 10th floor..well number one you can see the lights flickering in the elevator..and the floor just isn't even..so uneven you feel like you're about to fall...you will even see the "do not disturb signs" on doors rattling. And once you do decide to see memphis...you will find that there are so many homeless it's so accepted that they have panhandling licenses for this..they will harass...follow..chase..yell...and even threaten you with knives. There are so many the police man told me "well ma'am it isn't illegal to carry a knife"...oh ok sir certainly had no idea about the law..which is why I would approach you..concerned in the first place. Thank you memphis "police." If you must stay here stay under 10th floor and don't leave or you will be harassed by 100s of men.The staff at this hotel is the nicest hotel staff I have ever met.  They have customer service down.  Everyone you meet is so helpful and friendly.  We will definitely stay here again and you cannot go wrong by booking here.  The rooms are clean and do not smell.  The lobby is a great place to chill and enjoy a glass of wine.We chose the Sheraton so we would be close to all the downtown attractions. First, the room is clean and well appointed. It's also extremely noisy from the adjoining rooms so if you are expected a quiet night, it isn't likely. We stayed on the 17th floor, a club level room. The view would have been nice other than it appears as though the windows haven't been cleaned for over a year. The club level offers a breakfast on the 19th floor and it was a free for all.
