If I come back to Memphis I will probably choose a different hotel based on location alone.Very nice clean rooms and service. The beds were soooo comfy.Good example of a 3-star. And the front check in service is 4+. You can get a really good rate with Priceline but bar & dining is crazy expensive for Sysco food. Sub 3-star for food. Room was clean but drafty and is a 3.5 star. Parking is terrible at times and is a 2-star.We stayed during a someone else's family reunion and these folk were loud and overran the lobby area.  Fortunately, the hotel clerk put us on the 22nd floor so that we could avoid the noise.  The room was okay, the furnishings were damaged slightly (bleach stains in the chair and the wires were popped in the shower's soap holder).  The bed was comfy. Overall, it was an okay experience.This hotel is in a good location.  Close to food and stores.  However the rooms are small, there were 3 of us in my room and we could barely move around.  Its about a 20 minute drive from downtown.  The restaurant is pricey, I guess that's to be expected from a Hilton.  Needless to say, I'm not pressed if I ever stay here again.  It was okay, nothing to brag home about.Oh, it was bad. Yes, three roaches in one night in our 17th floor room (all found in the bathroom). But that wasn't the only thing that was wrong. First, if you are a non-smoker, never accept a room on the 6th floor. When we checked in the room reeked of stale smoke and after we complained we were told that the 5th floor was smoking. No wonder. It was then they moved us to the 17th floor. Here are my complaints in no particular order: (1) the air conditioning does not work. The air blows but it is not cold. The thermostat can be set to 65 but the actual temperature never gets below 75ish. Fortunately we were in Memphis when it was only 85 outside. (2) They still charge $10/day for internet access - absurd. (3) There are almost NO useable outlets in the ancient rooms (4) No mini microwave or fridge (4) No free breakfast included (5) To add insult to injury, the restaurant does not open until 6:30 which is useless when you have an early business meeting (6) $4.50 for a 16oz bottle of water in the room (7) The carpeting in the hallways AND in the room was not vacuumed in days, if not weeks. White socks will turn black (8) In room lighting very dim and poorly place (9) And, oh yes, the roaches...To be fair, there were two staff members that went out of their way to help us during our abbreviated stay. It gave some humanity to a visit that couldn't have ended soon enough. The sad thing is that in checking out other Memphis hotels in the general area, none of them rated very high on Yelp and other consumer feedback sites. Which leaves you sort of helpless and hopeless when forced to visit Memphis again.

review_content: Staff here is among the best of the best. Harold at the Valet is wonderful and so helpful. Phyllis, Connor and Ida at the front desk are more them willing to help with anything. Knowledgeable and very kind. They arranged a shuttle serve for us that picked us up right at the hotel and John our driver was AMAZING! You cannot go to Graceland, The civil Rights Museum or anywhere in Memphis without John as your driver. Thank you all!The Madison Hotel is Memphis' trendy boutique hotel. Located close enough - but also far away enough - from Beale St., it's location is actually what I liked best about my stay. It's close to all the good restaurants, bars etc. on Main St. (as well as my favorite coffee shop, Tamp & Tap). I typically stay at the Westin when I'm in Memphis for work and it's a 10 or 15 minute walk from there to this area.I definitely prefer the vibe of the Madison (chic, modern lobby tastefully decorated), and the staff is very nice (you get sincere "hello, how are you doing" at every turn). Rooms are similarly cool, but mine felt rather dreary (most likely because I was on a low floor looking out onto some kind of bleak, deserted street). Not really a big deal, given the excellent rate I received for my stay, but if I were paying their normal rates, I'd be more disappointed. I was also not crazy about the fact that while there was a card on the mini bar stating the bottled water was complimentary, the free water was nowhere to be found. One of my biggest pet peeves in a hotel room is the lack of bottled water, even if you have to pay for it. Nothing like waking up first thing in need of water and having to drink out of the faucet (yeah, yeah, first world problems). The weird thing is, they (or the previous guest) had filled the ice bucket before I had checked in. Another thing-- the Keurig hadn't been cleaned between guests as I found it full of water (typical. People don't know how to operate these annoying devices and abandon their efforts). The hotel gym is located in an old vault. How cool! I loved reading about its history (it was actually a club in 1960). The first day I used it, I entered and was hit with a musty smell of decay. That the room was also unbearably hot (I later found the thermostat and I guess guests can adjust it themselves, so I have the previous person working out to thank for this). The TV was on and music was playing creating quite the noise (thanks again, to a previous guest. Who does this?) I didn't realize until it was after my workout that I could have turned off the music. The TV remote was nowhere to be found. In addition to this type of unsavory environment, the fridge had a sign stating that there were cold towels in there... but they were all gone. I think that kind of thing can be avoided if the gym is attended to on the regular. Oversights that management should really be on top of in a hotel like this one. Other than the aforementioned issues, the workout room is well-equipped and both days I had it to myself, which was pretty nice. There's two elliptical machines, two treadmills and at least one bike. There's free weights, a cable machine and one bench... one stability ball. One uncomfortable experience that bears mentioning has to do with safety. My coworker and I arrived back to the hotel around 1 am and there was a dude loitering outside of the adjoining bar. When he saw us, he saw fit to join us in the elevator. He was stoned as hell and clearly on his way to hang out with us, uninvited. WTH? Security was nowhere to be found (normally there are doormen, but I think they are dismissed late at night). Luckily he was out of it enough for us to avoid him once we got to our respective floors, but this is unacceptable. I'm no shrinking violet, but I'd hate to think of women feeling threatened in similar situations. My coworker had an early flight and left the hotel at 5am. Guess who was still lurking around the same area when she left? Speaking of the bar, I want to mention how enjoyable my time was there after I checked in. I always get into the situation where I'm checked into a hotel at around 10pm and I'm hangry because I hate eating airport crap. My travel time was around 6 hours, so it was unavoidable. I don't know the bartender's name (she's a young African American woman, really cool and friendly), but she made sure my hummus plate was vegan and just was a pleasure to talk with in general. I think I'd stay here again as I prefer it to the Westin, but my first stay here left a few things to be desired.I wanted to try an alternative to the Peabody so i booked a night here to attend the Grizzlies game. We stayed in a 1 bedroom king suite. Overall just an average stay. I will probably stick to the Peabody in the future if the price is not outrageous. The classic luxury at the Peabody is a little more my style versus the Madison's modern artsy look.The valet process was quick and seamless. Attendant was nice and joked around with us. Check in was also quick, but the lady at the front desk was not quite as jovial. I had to ask about the amenities of the hotel and the locations rather than being told up front as part of the checkin process.In the hallway on the 7th floor there was a tray of old food sitting on the floor which stunk up the whole hallway. It was still there when we came back several hours later.The room was a bit small for a suite but had a nice wood floor living room with mini fridge and wet bar area. Bed was comfortable, pillows were flat and not too comfy. The bathroom was large with a walk in shower, but was missing a trash can. There was also no shampoo or conditioner, just a bar of soap. Quite inconvenient. The rooms were a bit noisy as well, with the whole room shaking when someone else let their room door slam shut. The location is excellent, right off a strip with some nice bars and restaurants. Also walking distance to the fedex forum and Beale steet, but make sure to stick to the main roads.Downtown memphis is short on fancy hotel selections. If you are willing to shell out the cash I would stick to the Peabody. But the Madison is not a bad alternative if the price is right.This hotel was completely underwhelming. The room, service and food. If you are planning to pay this much for a hotel prepare to be disappointed. Unfortunately, my normal Memphis hotel was booked. :(Updated. 12/26/15 I stayed at this property again last week while home for Christmas. I have to admit the food was awesome this stay. The service is still a huge opportunity for this property. All and all I would stay again when in Memphis.Very bad first impression with terrible customer service. Staying here for business travel. Single valet working and he was very polite but completely overrun. Then, entered building and could not find signage indicating where to check in. When I did finally find front desk, I was not greeted by staff. I had difficulty checking in that required manager intervention. She did not even attempt to correct the problem. I eventually left, dissatisfied and without a room. I do not plan to return. Update: I did have to return the following night as I was unable to find another feasible hotel room. The customer service remained poor. Not once did a single staff member acknowledge the inconvenience caused. I have another trip scheduled there next month and I am actively working to ensure I don't have to return.Our room was incredible! The entrance had a little bar and a cool seating area with a TV. Through French doors was our bed and bathroom. It felt like a cozy little apartment! The bathroom was perfect with a separate shower and bath. They also provided robes which I love! The staff was friendly & helpful & they all seemed to really enjoy their job! There is a rooftop bar which is a great space to either begin or end your day. They offer a few mini guitars in the lobby for guests to enjoy during their stay. Cons: $29 valet parking only. However, there are parking garages all around where you can park yourself. The complimentary coffee in the room tastes terrible.Great service, the breakfast at the hotel restaurant is delicious, and the rooms are clean and comfortable. The staff is extremely friendly, and the rooftop bar is lovely at night. This location is perfect - it's right by the river, close to the airport, and a close walk to Beale Street, but far enough so that you aren't stuck in a noisy section of town. And I walked to Gus' from here :)Like others mentioned I think the service here leaves much to be desired. This is one of the more expensive hotels in the area and it's always given 4+ stars by all the hotel websites. It's not worthy. I woke up to construction which the hotel staff denied at first. Then they told me it was only on the outside of the hotel (yeah, outside my wall). It eventually stopped but not from any effort on the part of the hotel staff. And I never heard even so much as an "I'm sorry".Then it was the really, really gross bathroom. I think there was a slight leak in the shower head which kept the shower very moist. Add the high heat and humidity in Memphis and this equated to excellent conditions for growing mold and mildew. The shower was just covered. We showered at a relatives place. I didn't even want t o go in there. We asked the staff to address it and I noticed there was a slight difference, but it was still not a place you want to be.I would never go back.Drove in last night and arrived around 11:23 am. We had hoped to get in earlier and enjoy the splurge of the room - a stop on our road trip to upstate NY. We carried our own bags and luggage- no one asked. We went down to bar for light snack and a drink. The bartender was more focussed on closing than providing the service that you would expect for this hotel. The bar was infested with mosquitoes and the bartender initially denied this until they started biting her. We ordered some Mac and cheese- stone cold and more like soup. Sent it back. Got to room- concave mattress with a thin sheet and worn mattress pad meant for a queen was used. Pretty gross. Got bill under door this am- 345.00I feel cheated. Not what I expected for our splurge.Follow up- my room rate was adjusted to address the concerns. Thank you Madison Hotel!Made reservations over 5 months ago and got a corner room no view. I requested a change but got a polite brush off from the desk clerk. Room was much smaller than expected for the price. Maybe just the one I got. Everything else was nice. There is a wet bar with prices. Best part was huge bed and bathroom was great.Service was impeccable. Rooms were very nice and clean. Will stay here every time when we come to Memphis.This is an overpriced hotel that is really underwhelming. We are paying almost 400 dollars a night for an "executive" double room... Well there is nothing executive about our room. The toiletries were opened, there were used kleenexes in the box (not kidding), the tub is just a run of the mill regular tub (very disappointing), not oversized or luxurious as advertised. The concierge was useless, and there isn't a turn down service as advertised.Honestly, if you saved up money because you wanted a nice vacation, don't waste it here.I hosted an employee retreat here. We had dinner as a group in a private room which was excellent. The rooms are sharp- clean and nice high end toiletries in bathroom. Bedding very nice quality and mistress soft and comfy. Worth the price. Felt like a 4 star hotel.We stayed here for a night on our honeymoon road trip and it is a beautiful hotel! Love the decor and the staff is extremely nice and helpful!! The walls are very thin and there were stains on the sheets, which I'm sure they would've gladly fixed if we'd noticed before we came in from a late night out on Beale St. The Twilight bar is breathtaking at night... It's a must see! Don't be in a hurry for your car, or at least call down for it 15-20 min before you need it. Other than that, great hotel!Very nice hotel. We have enjoyed our week long stay. The staff is very polite and helpful. Everything in our room was great we stayed in the jr king deluxe. My only complaint would be the restaurant. The food was not good tried a few things and did not like any of it. I was so disappointed being they have such good reviews on TA. I would stay here again. Had troubles finding good food and decent places to eat while in Memphis. Prob won't return to this town kinda a big let down.I loved my stay at the Madison hotel. I booked my hotel at hotels.com and they messed up my reservation but Madison hotel fixed it and upgraded us for free. The entire staff was friendly and attentive. I lived in Memphis for 2 years prior and knew exactly where to book during my quick visit. I definitely made the right choiceMy husband did an amazing job picking this place on his own and surprising me on Valentine's Day. I was impressed the minute I walked into the Lobby. Boutique decor and friendly staff. It reminded me of a hotel that we love in downtown Portland (The Nines). I was over the moon when he led me to our corner suite on a top floor. You walk into a sitting area (couch, mini bar, TV), round the corner into the bedroom and bath. Both very spacious. Rain shower head. I appreciated all the tall windows and the view of the bay. The colors in the room are very warm, inviting, luxurious. Wifi worked. A few negatives- no bubbles for jetted tub. Our room service was ok. The ice cream for my blueberry bread pudding was melted and the shrimp appetizer was breaded and soggy. Of course it would happen if you cover the food at once and let it sit. If I were more hungry at the time, I would've been more upset. Luckily, I was in a good mood and the bread pudding was delicious. One more negative was that the gym was out of service but no one told me. I just found out when I got down there. None of the machines were working. Had to do weights and jumping jacks! It felt a little like a dungeon. I have to hand it to my Love for having great taste. We had a wonderful time and would probably stay again when in Memphis!Very nice accommodations. Pro's...great location, can walk to Beale Street. Roof top bar has the best views in the city. Very friendly staff that is eager to please. Con's...rooms are a bit small and parking is a bitch. Valet park is really the only way to go.We were there for a wedding weekend and the block of rooms that was reserved for us was at the Madison. Great location downtown as far as ease to get places. The issues I had and that would keep me from leaving a 4 or 5 star review were based on customer service or lack thereof on at least three occasions. Everyone was perfectly nice, but multiple times there was no one to valet cars (yes, that sounds ridiculous to say, but they were all just sitting around the corner because every time I inquired with the front desk, she radioed to someone and they walked around the corner). The room was nice enough though. We had a weird room location near the elevator which made it a bit noisy. All in all, it was an okay experience but could have been better.Overpriced for what you get. The walls were a bit dirty and we had to call to get a second robe and for ice. Staff was helpful. The terrace is nice but not in January.
review_content_20: My family just got back from a beautiful time in Memphis. We stayed at the Madison hotel and we were very impressed with the professionalism of the staff. The room was stayed in was spacious, modern, with a nice very of the river. We happened to get a room on the top floor. The roof top was really nice and the kids had a great time in the pool. Check out the bank vault in the work out room. We also had Easter dinner at the hotel, as much was not open around 7:30 - 8:00 pm on Easter Sunday. Our entrees were wonderful, apps not as impressive, but all in all truly impressed, and far better than you the typical "hotel fare". I loved having coffee and breakfast at the bar in the morning before it got busy.We are so happy we stayed at the Madison, rather than a big chain such as the MarriotThis is only based on their service as i did not stay in a room here.We ate at their restaurant, 83, so I valeted my car, which the valet guy told me would be $10. When I got to dinner my friends informed me that it's complementary valet if you're eating at the restaurant. After dinner we wanted to go upstairs to their rooftop. The server told us it's free if we show them the receipt from dinner. So we go upstairs and the girl tells us that it was not free. I look outside and it looked like it had rained and all the chairs and tables were wet. There were only 2 older couples sitting outside. Before I could tell my friends that, the girl said we could go out there this time (after she called someone) but that it's not usually free even if we have had dinner at 83. When we went outside everything was wet and their WERE only 2 elderly couple out there. There was no where to sit as they had not even cleaned the furniture. We walked right out. If she had actually charged us $10 each she would have had to deal with 4 pissed off customers. How are you going to charge $10 when everything is wet and no one is out there? Soooooo we decide to go have drinks somewhere else, we walk to flight which is one block over. We have 2 drinks and head back to our cars. The valet guy says it's $10 and we have to pay because we left the restaurant and came back. I'm thinking 1) you told me I had to pay even though I was eating at the restaurant 2) maybe you should tell people that they would get charged if they leave the restaurant. So we go inside to pay. THEY VERY NICE LADY at the counter says to go to the restaurant and get our tickets stamped so it's free. So we did. As I am coming back out of the hotel the valet guy opens the door for me but before I could even step out he leaves the door and let it hit me in the arm and it pushed me out. That really pissed me off. He ran inside to tell the nice front desk lady that we had left the restaurant. I walked back inside and told him "You are lucky I am not getting your name for being rude because you hit me in the arm with that door!" Of course he's like no I didn't. Blah blah my arm felt the door, I could have opened it myself and would have been fine.The whole point is that this is suppose to be a nice hotel and it did not feel that way at all. I have had great experience at the Westin and their restaurant. I felt like I was getting ripped off and then beaten up and thrown out. I would have gladly paid $20 for valet because I didn't want to walk far in heels as that's the whole point of valet, convenience, but their service made me feel like I was at a cheap trashy hotel. The lady at the front desk was the nicest person there and I made sure to let her know. I wanted to tip her but I wasn't sure if that was even appropriate.Horrible customer service. Had to call them twice and manager was supposed to call back and never did. I shouldn't have to spend my whole day calling to try and get someone who can make decisions on the phone. Just awful. Will update once I stay there since I am forced to.Great location close to everything and right on the trolley line. Interior decor is like a boutique W - very nice, upscale, and modern. My complaints were few - for their price I expect a really crazy attentive staff, and they missed the mark by a hair or two. The gym area smells like mildew, although the equipment is decent. I had to call for cups to the water machine.Nice rooms with rainwater showers. Don't skip the rooftop bar.Husband and I booked the King Suite on the corner. It was nice with modern decorations. The Jacuzzi tub was a nice touch. We also had the breakfast package, which was ok. The total came out to a little over $100 for just breakfast and they were 30 minutes late getting it to our room, however the lady was nice. I would DEF not use their valet. The wait time is HORRIBLE! The men are extremely rude. If you want to get your car out, they act as if it's a hassle and the wait time is FOREVER. We ended up waiting 30 minutes for our car at checkout and missed our massage appointment we had set up at a specific time. Also, the restaurant that is attached does not have a good variety, took a long time to get seated with many table open, and ran out of the menu items they did have. Overall, it is an ok stay.What a fabulous place! Great service, from valet upon arrival to checkout at the end of our stay. This hotel is in a great location, walking distance to Beale St. and a short 10-15 minute drive to Graceland. The rooms were large, well decorated, and immaculately clean; a great overall vibe. Beds and pillows were comfortable, and the bathroom boosted a large shower with good water pressure. Would definitely stay there again.Typically when you pay $200 a night and stay at any luxury / regular hotel they offer complimentary coffee in the mornings down in the lobby area. 3 weeks ago the Madison offered this however I learned during my current stay they are now charging $3 for coffee to go. As guests we pay a pretty penny to stay here and that is at least one complimentary option of which they can offer to their guests. The coffee isn't even Starbucks and they feel as tho it's worth $3 ?!?!? First and far most I've started at several hotels across the US of which I've stayed so much I earned Platium Status and I've never seen this before. I tried to speak with the front desk lady Rose but she was not helpful at all, I prob won't have never wrote this review if she had just provided me with some complimentary coffee. Therefore, I am writing and following up with the manager as well.We decided to stay at the Madison overnight on our way to Chicago from Dallas. The hotel was very nice and the staff was very friendly. The room was not huge but it was nicely appointed with a flat screen tv, ipod docking station, honor bar, and big closet.. Although the bed was a tad uncomfortable. The hotel also has a very nice fitness facility that we enjoyed. The only thing I was not impress with was the Twilight Sky Terrace, the pictures made it sound cooler that it really was. Overall, I enjoyed this hotel and where it is located. I would stay there again.Very nice hotel. I had a Jr Suite which was very spacious, very large bathroom with a separate shower and tub. The walking distance to Beale is reasonable but not optimal in inclement weather. Right on two trolley lines although the trolley service was hit or miss. I felt it was a little pricey and not a great value. The staff was generally very friendly although when I arrived at almost 6 pm they told me the room wasn't ready, at 6 pm? One major complaint. When I asked about getting to Graceland they arraigned a car at 50$ round trip. They failed to mention the free bus that picks up downtown hmmm. I liked it but would look for better value in the future.The Madison is considered a four star hotel, but should be a three. We pricelined this place for $130 (total $160), plus $29 overnight valet. So, I guess you get what you pay for. The room absolutely not worth the $289+ regular rate.We were on the 12th floor and our room was in serious need of repair (the ceiling, the air vents, the pipe coming out of the ceiling in the shower).We got a queen room, which was small, but adequate for downtown. There were very few rooms on our floor and we were right next to the elevator. I didn't notice any elevator noise, but I could hear noise from the street, especially in the morning.This hotel only does Valet, $29 overnight, unlimited in and out. I did not see any parking lots or other self-park garages nearby.I thought the location was excellent. 5 minute walk to Beale street and maybe 10 yards from Main Street.The staff was amazing. Friendly and competent.We did not have a drink at the roof top bar, but did go up to take some photos.We had an average experience when we stayed at the Madison. We were celebrating a birthday with a weekend away. When the reservation was made, we notified the hotel of the birthday celebration. At that time, We asked for early check in and a river view. We arrived at the hotel about 11 AM, and we were told our room was in the process of getting cleaned. Early check in ended up being 2:30 rather than the regular check in of 3. We also didn't get a river view. Our room was nice, but I certainly wouldn't give it more than an average rating. During the second day we were there, housekeeping never cleaned our room. Service overall was pretty poor except for one bartender in the bar. When we go back to Memphis, we will try another hotel.The staff makes this hotel. Every single person I encountered gave me a greeting and a smile. The day I checked in their computers went down and they had to deal with a ton of stuff. You could see that they were stressed but everyone held their own.The room was comfortable, great shower, great pillows, comfortable bed.The roof top deck is a must see (no seriously, we told everyone that we encountered).Location is great...not that there is much in downtown Memphis.Overall I would gladly stay there again and again and againWe've stayed here twice. Once in May 2012 and again in June 2013. I am averaging the rating...First visit was 4 stars. Room wasn't huge but the bathroom was just lovely, separate shower and tub, lighted make up mirror, very cool little room. We saw Zach Randolph in the lobby :). Free breakfast was awesome, overall great experience.Booked again (through hotels.com) and the room was cramped and LOUD... We finally couldn't take it anymore and around midnight asked to be moved. One positive note: the lady that works the front desk is excellent, best part of our experience. She moved us to a really nice, quiet room on the same floor...wish we had asked to move earlier!Also, I know it was a weeknight but the rooftop patio was not exactly welcoming... We got a glass of wine (the bartender was pretty nice) but we were the only ones up there and the music was blasting. I WOULD have had another glass but the manager came up and closed the bar down. He seemed inconvenienced by our presence... So no more wine for me, no last call, nothing. They did, however, leave the WAY TOO LOUD music on for us....uhhh thanks? Weird experience, not like the first time we went up there (pre renovation). Why renovate your rooftop patio if you don't want people up there? Based on our experience before, we got up early to get breakfast...but unfortunately they no longer offer that. We asked a lady out front (NOT the nice lady from the front desk) about the breakfast and she asked who we booked through and then very bluntly told us "you booked through hotels.com so you don't get breakfast"Wow. So much has changed in a relatively short amount of time! We couldn't wait to come back based on our first experience, now I think 2 stars would be generous for our second go round...Done with the Madison. And Hotels.com for that matter.Will find somewhere else to stay next time we stop in Memphis.I like the Madison. I won a free staycation here through a drawing and stayed here with my boyfriend at the time. We both were locals and never had done a staycation before in downtown but thought it would be a lot of fun to play tourists.We started out our night by having dinner at the hotel's restaurant Grille 83. We escaped barely with a tab slightly under $70. We gor drinks and 2 entrees and salads. He picked up the tab since I won us a free $200 room! After dinner, we ventured to the roof top where they has some soft jazz music playing and we relaxed with a wonderful view, drinks in hand, and a fine breeze blowing through. Later on we went out to a couple of places downtown. We caught the trolley to South Main which luckily there is a trolley stop not too far from the Madison. Seriously just a good night. We did feel like we were out of towners while staying there.The rooms are very modern-esque. The bathroom was very small, but it had a nice shower which was a plus for me. I loved the big shower heads where it does feel like you are in an actual shower and not being sprayed with a drizzle. The bed was a little too hard for me, but it was very spacious. Nice flat screen tv too. I'd say it's nice to stay in. Would I have paid for it? Probably not. I'm ok with staying in low budget hotels when I travel. But for those who enjoy simplicity with nice a room and the ends and outs, then the Madison would work for you. Especially I'd you want to splurge $200 a night.What a fabulous location! Close to all of the action of downtown yet still located in a nice little nook that isn't inundated with tourists too. The staff was super friendly from the valet to the front desk and cleaning crew too. My room was spacious and offered up a beautiful bathroom with a separate tub and shower arrangement. My room was located near an elevator and unfortunately I experienced the noise from the hallway a few times during the night. It would have been nice to be disclosed that my room was going to be in a higher traffic area.I loved the decor and vibe throughout but could do without the $23 valet fee and $10.95 service that is billed after you check-in. Why wasn't the service fee part of the original booking price again?My boyfriend and I got a deal on Expedia.com. I feel for the money it was worth it and a better deal than Peabody (I've stayed at the Peabody before so I can knowingly compare the two).The front staff was very polite and thoughtful. They checked us in and also helped us call for a taxi when we were leaving for the airport. At 5pm they were offering complimentary petit fours and Shirley Temple's in champagne flutes.You get a complimentary breakfast buffet. The book in your room will say it's on the Mezzanine level, but I had to walk around, and found out it was at the hotel restaurant...so when you check in ask where breakfast is. Breakfast is eggs, bacon, grits, muffins, bagels, croissants, and fruit. You get your choices of juices, coffee, and tea. They'll bring you a bill but it'll say Complimentary and you can write on your tip for your server. Our servers were really attentive the two mornings we had breakfast there. One morning the manager greeted us and he was very engaged and nice. Our last morning, he even came out from the restaurant because he saw me waiting at the bellman stand in the afternoon, and he quickly helped me with my luggage.We had a nice, clean room. Our rate didn't get us a view of the river, but that's okay. We took the elevator to the top floor and saw the view. It is breathtaking!There is free wi-fi. Our room kept dropping the connection in the bedroom, but I was able to find a connection in the bathroom (hello.).The hotel itself is a quick 5 minute walk to Beale Street... or a slow 10 minutes. We felt safe walking to/from Beale late at night.Across the street from the hotel is Walgreens so that's helpful to know if you forget to pack something from home and need to buy it in Memphis. You can also buy postcard stamps there. There's also a dollar store type place close by if you need to pick up ponchos because of rain.Great service and nice rooftop. No complaints.I will come back to the Madison.Out here visiting colleges with son. Could not get into Peabody which has a deal with the college. Came to Madison on recommendation of locals. Although kind of expensive (9th fl junior suite $400 plus), the service and property itself were worth it to us. Apparently don't need the Peabody!Room very clean, comfortable and quiet. A junior suite is a single room with a sitting area at one end. A double would probably suffice but we needed some work areas for paperworkValet service - very prompt and helpful with car and curbside service.Breakfast - served free on Mezz level until 10am - great touchPublic Areas - attractive - this is a 1905 property that has been updated a la Kimpton so it has postmodern design but in very good taste.WiFi - ok on ninth floor. Able to open VPN and not too frustrating. No extra charge - good deal.Rooftop - PH level has a rooftop deck facing the river. It would be beautiful up there on a warm day. Totally worth seeing the view however.Check-in - we came in on a redeye flight from LA and after a day of touring were dead. We got to the hotel at 230 and we were allowed to check in early. We passed out in the room. i vaguely remember that a butler entered our room around 4 presumably because we did not respond to knocks. I woke up enough to see that he was dropping off a cellophane-wrapped plate of snacks for us. He apologized for disturbing us and ducked out.. When we came-to around 6 we found we had a really nice plate of toasted ciabatta with peppers, cheese and fruit. Really nice touch and that was very welcome as we had not eaten in 12 hours.Staff - we cannot get over how people here are outgoing and friendly. Maids, valets, desk staff all five star. butler service and room service staff offered the kind of service you see in five star resorts on the west coast, but far more believable here. For example, the maid on the ninth floor engaged us in conversation on a couple of occasions and made us feel very welcome, even gave us the scoop on things in the hotel and local area. If this is Southern hospitality, then we are hooked. Well done, Madison!Generally nice hotel. Friendly staff. Don't pay for parking, though. They charge $29 and only have valet. You can literally park around the block and pay $8/day.While I didn't stay at the Madison (something I'd definitely consider, as it was often suggested by locals, regularly accompanied by animated gesturing), I did manage to make my way to the rooftop show/party they were throwing on a Saturday night. The rooftop bar experience really seems to be part of what winds Memphis up, and on this night, locals relaxed with cocktails or grooved in the open air to the band, who pounded out rock standards. Expect if you go here to pay somewhere in the neighborhood of ten bucks or so to just for the privilege of being on the deck: expect that the bar will likely be cash only (although as I recall I did get the bartender to help me finance a couple of cold ones without running a tab: weird, but effective). In all, if you want to listen to some music and sip on a cocktail with friends under the Memphis stars, you could do worse than the Madison Hotel. My experience wasn't consummate, but it was definitely worthwhile. I'd go back.
review_content_40: I will never stay at another Memphis Hotel! This is really a gem. The hotel staff is stellar. There was complimentary champagne and chocolate covered strawberries in the evening. The location is perfect - close to great restaurants. I also had access to an event on the rooftop bar that had a great view! The bed was comfortable and the bathroom was huge. My one complaint is the $10.95 amenities charge. Unexpected, as it wasn't on the original reservation. What's up with that? Also, like someone else said, I had the room immediately to the right of the elevator and had a lot of traffic noise. Nothing that bothered me once I was sleep, but I did find it distracting while I was working in the evening. A heads up would have been nice...I guess that's two complaints...but that's ok.Heated pool is great and the daily breakfast voucher was much appreciated!I can't stop talking about how wonderful my stay at the Madison was. They know how to make their guests feel special from the coffee, to the fresh ice and chocolates. The Twilight roof deck had the most spectacular views of Memphis and the DJ played tunes that went perfectly with the vibe. The staff were beyond polite and courteous. I went to the Gaylord Orpryland after my stay at the Madison and it didn't even come close to comparing. Thank you for making my stay in Memphis so enjoyable!I am doing work in Memphis and have stayed at the Madison a couple of times. Love this place! I have also stayed a few times closer to Beale Street and this location is still downtown and a bit more quiet. I like it better. The staff are very friendly, the rooms quite comfortable and the rooftop bar has a great view. I would recommend that you ask for a room that does not have a pedestal sink in the bathroom. Don't know if it is more expensive, but without this there is absolutely no room to put your things in the bathroom. This is my one complaint. I really like the Madison and will be back on a regular basisI chose the Madison thinking it would be a special experience on our wedding day--a place to get ready with my bridesmaids, then return to that evening with my husband. It looked pretty and was a little cheaper (but not much!) than the Peabody. Here's what happened:Problem #1: Despite arranging MONTHS in advance to check into our room an hour early so my bridesmaids and I could get ready... and following up the week of the wedding... we learned on the spot that the person who made that promise was mistaken because they were booked. So, our ENTIRE WEDDING DAY was delayed by an hour. That meant the ceremony started an hour late, we paid the band for an hour that we didn't get, and the whole day was mayhem. Not to mention, it was embarrassing that I had a bunch of women waiting around in the lobby for an hour and no one even apologized. Yet last week, when a similar overbooking happened to my friend at the Peabody on her wedding day, they immediately put us in a conference room to get ready, apologized profusely (see #3 below), and brought us champagne.Problem #2: We had a few trays of food out as we got ready--pasta, sandwiches, etc. I asked the front desk on our way out if they'd clean the room so the food would be gone when we returned that night. My maid of honor made the same request. I even called later to follow up and make sure they'd done it. But when my husband and I returned to our (expensive) room that night, NOTHING had been cleaned and it smelled like rotting food. Not exactly a dream wedding night.Problem #3: I wrote the Madison a letter via their website AND sent a hard copy in the mail right after this happened. I gave them all my contact info, but no one responded. I followed up; still no response. It's been OVER THREE MONTHS and I still haven't gotten as much as an apology for all of the trouble that the Madison caused with their terrible service. This is the most disappointing fact of all. I am dismayed that a hotel that promises great service and a fine experience would treat a bride and groom with such little consideration and care on their wedding day. Summary: Choose the Peabody or the downtown Marriott (I have no affiliation).There's nothing that annoys me more about a hotel then surprise fees. This hotel is valet park only, so you're already paying $25 more than the rate. But then there's also an $11 "amenities fee." What are the amenities? A pool and slow internet. Resorts can charge a resort fee. But hotels that charge extra for basic services should just raise their rate instead of tricking the customer.I was here for a wedding this past weekend. The valet people were so nice and helpful. The front desk staff were just as helpful. My room was great. The beds are very comfortable. Plenty of pillows. the decore of the whole hotel is wonderful. Very chic. The restraunt in the hotel was fabulous as well. the food was amazing and very good size portions. I would definatley have my out of town friends stay here.The Madison Hotel is a very cool place, with modern decor and beautiful, rich color patterns in their rooms and suites. It's pretty centrally located in downtown Memphis so you're within walking distance of Beale Street, AutoZone Park and some great restaurants and bars. But don't forget about Grill 83, the hotel restaurant, which happens to be one of my faves. The Madison hosts a rooftop party on Thursday nights during the summer that are always alot of fun. If you've never seen the view from their rooftop, you should definitely make a point to go. Simply amazing. Service is friendly and accommodating, and the staff really outdo themselves making sure guests are happy.Beware of the blonde bartender on the rooftop, sticky fingers...overpriced drinks with no receipt.I just went to Memphis for a wedding, and the whole party stayed at the Madison. This hotel was fantastic. The service was excellent, the rooms were spacious and clean, and the staff could not have been nicer.Great location in Memphis, close to most of the things you want to do (Beale st, museums, waterfront, restaurants). I would recommend the Madison to anyone traveling to memphis.Madison Hotel in Memphis is a modern, very clean, very friendly, very centrally located hotel. I stayed here while in town for the Memphis St Jude Marathon and was very pleased from everything from the room decor to staff to location, highly recommend.Very nice room, comfortable bed, recently renovated. I would definitely stay here again. Rooftop is awesome!Bets hotel in Memphis, hands-down. Everyone on staff makes you feel like you're family. The rooms are delightful and you can't beat the location. I wouldn't stay anywhere else when visiting Memphis!If you are looking to stay somewhere in Memphis that is grand or upscale- you've got one of two options. The Peabody or the Madison. This hotel is much more modern and crisp looking than the Peabody. The rooms are very colorful and decorated quite nicely- they also offer a tab bit more space than the Peabody. I love their rooftop. I've been up their for the rooftop parties on Thursday, summer nights. The river views are amazing. It's breathtaking and surprisingly quiet (if you aren't at the party of course), to sit up there at night with a glass of wine and just take it all in. They have Grill 83 on site, which I haven't been to but hear great things about. You can't beat the location if you are staying here. It's a short walk to the downtown attractions and an even shorter walk to the trolley. Though I will always advise people to try and stay at my favorite, Talbot Heirs, this is always a second choice if their rooms happen to be sold out.As a local, one of the things I like about The Madison Hotel is the weekly rooftop party held there during the summer months on Thursday nights. Now the crowd does skew a little older, and I joke with my friends that instead of checking your ID at the door, they ask to see your AARP membership card. Because, whereas there are some token younger people there, most are well over 40, most in their 50's. Even so, I LIKE this event. It is much smaller than the competing rooftop event held on the same night at The Peabody. The views of the river are just awesome, and if you go early you can catch the sunset. The band starts around 6 and winds down at 10.The Madison is billed as the most luxurious hotel in Memphis - all the sports teams stay there when they are in town. However, it lacked a few things that come standard with four stars: 1) a spa - seriously, spas are becoming standard in Hyatts and Hiltons2) service - they called our room past midnight because another guest of the hotel asked them to. I can understand a polite call to humor a guest during the daytime but after 10 is just out of line. Not to mention, in our digital age, if we really wanted to connect with this person, I would have given them a cell number. 3) seamless coordination - they put us in a room next to one that they were doing construction in. Our room smelled of paint and we heard loud banging noises. The hotel was far from fully booked. Now did it make any sense to put us on the same floor as one undergoing construction. Really. They offered us dinner to make up for the mistakes. However, after dinner we were informed that they were only comping one dinner and no wine. Ridiculous. The best part is when we called to report these things,awesome place to stay. the staff was great from the doormen to the bartenders. the room was very comfortable and relaxing. also, quiet on the floors. not loads of people coming and going. the food in the restaurant was great and they do a reasonable happy hour. would highly recommend this hotel.It is physically impossible for us to drive from NC to TN because of the winter storms Cleon and Dion and although Expedia told me that we should be able to cancel due to this fact, the hotel manager for this hotel not once but twice refused to allow us to cancel. Really? So I have to pay for a hotel that I can't even get to. I will never book this hotel again for this reason alone. Just another word of caution, I booked this hotel on Expedia.com and could swear that the cancellation policy was 2 days (we attempted to cancel within 2 days) but when I got the confirmation email, it said 3 days. Double check this when you book anywhere online...My husband and I had the pleasure of staying at The Madison this week and it was a delightful stay. The service, the rooms, the rooftop area (bar wasn't open yet)... it was all amazing. I would highly recommend it to anyone visiting Memphis.Poopsie and I stayed there last weekend for a staycation. The room was nice, but not exceptional and the staff we came across were very nice too. But for a supposed "luxury" hotel it lacked a lot. A couple of particular issues:I had a scotch neat in the bar a couple of times. The price for a scotch was a bit on the high side, but acceptable, but the kicker was that they charged an extra dollar for it "neat". In other words the charged extra money to not do anything with it. The first time I commented on it, the waiter said it was because they poured a larger shot for a neat drink. (It didn't seem larger than other places. Does that mean they are giving you a short shot in a mixed drink?) The second time I had it, I didn't bother commenting on it.The other issue was the complimentary breakfast. I was expecting something really interesting from a "luxury" hotel. What we got was worse than a Best Western. It was chintzy, cheap, small, lacked variety. A definite disappointment. The next morning we went to the Arcade for a decent breakfast.I general, it seemed like they did not have enough staff. There was no doorman and the valet parking guy was running his butt off. He was a great guy, very friendly and informative about what was going on. There was only one person at the front desk, both on check in and out. There was bar staff lacking the first night we were at the restaurant and the second afternoon at sunset time on the roof. Other than the scotch issues, the restaurant was OK, but we only had late night snacks. The view from the roof is excellent, it was too bad they did not open the bar up there.Stayed for a weekend in June, 2009.We picked this little boutique hotel in hopes that it would be a nice alternative to a chain. It was.For a competitive price, the Madison offered a great clean room with a great view. Mind you: this is from the time when both American's and their tastes weren't Supersized, so you may find the rooms a bit small. But there's certainly more than enough room for a couple, and the king sized beds are very comfy. Oh yeah, the bathrooms are quite large!One block away is the Memphis Trolley to get you to any of the popular tourist attractions. One bit of advice: skip the valet parking service. The garage 1.5 blocks away on South 2nd Street just south of Madison allows for 24-hour parking and is much more reasonably priced.
review_content_60: Loved it. I stayed here during the Memphis Marathon weekend and the service was excellent.  When we walked in the door, at 1 p.m, they greeted us with a smile and had us checked into our room early.  The concierge, Stacy, was extremely friendly.  I had spoken with her prior to arrival to arrange transportation to the hotel and also a rental car for our last day in Memphis.  She was the best help ever!The rooms were big and the beds were comfortable.  Not quite as soft as a sheraton sleeper bed or of those offered in the Hilton hotels, but it was nice.  The linens were nice as well.   Molton Brown shampoos and soaps were offered and were quite nice as well.  The breakfast was good, cereal, bagels, toast, fruit, coffee, juice...  My sister asked for peanut butter one day and they went out of their way to find some for her.  Staff was very helpful.The only things I wasn't thrilled about in the room are.. the TV is old, not a flat screen and there weren't a ton of channels.  The hallways were cold, but the room temp was easy to control and was toasty warm.  The hotel was a little expensive for my typical taste, but I enjoyed every minute.My wife and I and our 18 year old son stayed here four nights and were very pleased.  We had the suite with a pullout sofa, giving us all the proper amount of privacy.  The room was beautifully cleaned each day, with turndown service at night.  All personnel were extremely friendly and helpful.  We are fussy folks but it is hard to come up with a complaint that is even minor.If you are on the breakfast plan, be aware that for some foolish reason you get charged extra if you want toast with your eggs and bacon.  The food and beverage manager might consider altering this off-putting policy.The shower head wasn't that great, but that is the ONLY thing we found lacking in our recent stay at the Madison. The rooms are graciously appointed, clear down to an umbrella in the closet, and two nice robes. The lobby is stylish and comfortable, the bar friendly and unpretentious, and the restaurant small but good. Best of all, and the reason I give it five stars, the service is unpretentious, genuinely friendly and responsive. Maids, bellmen, concierge, waitstaff and desk clerks all went out of their way to make us feel welcome, and that makes up for a shower head, in my book, any day.word of advice .  Do not plan a wedding at the Madison.  The accommodations can not support more than 60 + folks..  My experience when they were trying to serve the food to the guest they set off the fire Alarms and my guest were greeted by the Memphis Fire Department..   If your are planning a rooftop reception, beware of the temperatures  my wedding cake melted...Let me start by saying that I have not stayed at the Madison Hotel, and that my review is based on my experience dealing with the hotel staff while booking a room as a gift for my sister's honeymoon.In short let me say that the Madison lacks considerably in organization.  My request was to simply book a suite for my sister and her husband for two nights.  The first night would be under the honeymoon package and the second on the dining package.  While this appears a relatively straight forward reservation, the staff at the Madison managed to thouroughly mishandle it.  Let me explain.During my initial call with the reservationist, I was graciously offered a discounted room rate since I was booking two suite packages during my sister's stay.  After checking the confirmation however it appeared that not only was my quoted rate incorrect, but that they had also improperly entered the order in which I wanted the suite packages to be delivered (honeymoon package on the first night, and dining package on the second).  Fortunately I noticed the errors and was able to make another call to have the issue corrected.  At least I was assured that they had been corrected...When my sister arrived at the hotel, it appeared that they had still not managed to make the appropriate changes.  Not only was the rate still incorrect, the hotel staff had also neglected to deliver the items that accompany the honeymoon package.   Yet again, I placed a call to correct the situation, however at this point it was already too late.  The sole intent of having the honeymoon package on the first night was to have champagne, candles, and strawberries waiting for them upon arrival.  While the hotel staff seemed quite apologetic when this was brought to their attention, the champagne would still not arrive until late in the evening on the second night of their stay.  The candles and strawberries never made it to the room at all.The dining package posed problems of its own.  When they arrived for dinner, there was no mention from the staff that the package included a wine pairing with the meal, so they ordered their own drinks through the meal.  They were then billed for their drinks, and the wine was never recieved.   This was corrected from the room charges ultimately, but yet again the Madison had failed to deliver. The final gaffe took place at checkout, when a bill was presented for a $30 charge for valet parking.  Unaware that the reservation should have included valet parking on both nights, my brother in law paid the bill.  To correct this, I personally left a message for the front desk manager, however to this day he neither has returned my call nor made the correction.Ultimately, the Madison bills itself as being on-par with the finest four & five star hotels in the world - yet I have found this to be far from the truth.  Without ever having set foot on the hotel property, the Madison has managed to disappoint me greatly.  Even worse, they failed to live up to their promises on my sister's honeymoon.  It requires an exceptional staff to manage a great hotel, and in this area the Madison appears to be quite lacking.  While the rooms and property may be well appointed, I can assure you that the "service and luxury" that they tout on their website is overpromised and under delivered.I don't know how this gets a 41/2 star rating.  The hotel is fine, however they don't offer transportation to  and from airport.  Worse is that they told me that taxis weren't available for 40 mintues, however a private limo service was in the area now, but it would cost $10 to $15 more. Well when the limo driver came in the lobby to get my luggage I walked out to see a taxi waiting in front of the hotel and he offered to take me to the airport for $15 less.  How could a class hotel do this??????Poor communication and managementWe had communication issues from the start, but the rooftop view was key to our trip. Check in was easy but the rate was wrong, concierge was never on their game. Details were missed and dropped, and for a surprise for my wife, I ended up making all types of calls - making excuses to step away. The suite, yes suite, was tiny. Not small... TINY. For $300, it should be decent. Far from it. It was two small areas about 8x10 with a closet and bathroom in the middle. The bellman did not come for check out service, the car was not pulled up - yet I paid handsomely for valet and tipped very well. Never got the final bill, but got overcharged and had to send several emails to get a reply. You could not pay me to stay there again.you can get this one on priceline, fyi.booked a room here for ufc 107 and it was cool. plenty of douches (as in my review of the hotel glenn in atlanta) but nice spot. the room was a decent size for a boutique hotel. one negative... i requested a room with two beds on the phone with someone the wednesday before my trip. didn't happen... they did bring up a rollaway, and i'm told it was quite comfortable. this particular room faced another building, so there was no view (fine with me, pricewire was decent to me). "continental" "breakfast" really wasn't anything to speak of. just a bunch of simple carbohydrates and orange juice from concentrate. i had two slices of bread with butter/spread that actually held me over until we got to gus'. also, there was a sign saying the breakfast was being served in the restaurant, but it wasn't. it was in the meeting room and i would have never found that out had i not bumped into a housekeeping lady. i'd certainly stay here again if i found myself in memphis again, but not before checking out the peabody first.eric bGreat boutique hotel, friendly staff , elegant modern design. Centrally located to Main St, Beale St is within walking distance. Great views of the river from the roof. Would staff there again and will recommend it to friends.Good but not great, did not meet expectationsWe stayed for a couple of days here in the summer.  Location is very good if you want to be downtown and the staff was mostly nice and very helpful.  (they could have warned us to avoid Beale Street on Friday night). Room was ok; bathroom had no counters or sink storage, but had deep windowsills to accommodate our stuff.   The room was not very quiet, even on weekends.  Good consistent AC would have helped, but it only came on now and then, with incredible noise, and blew straight on the bed.  We spent nights alternating freezing in the draft and being awakened by street noise.  There was a decent lap pool in the basement.  Very strange that most downtown Memphis hotels have pools only in the basement, not very conducive for hanging out by the pool to get a break from the Memphis summer heat.The Madison Hotel in Memphis was the best hotel experience that I have ever had. I've stayed at other 4-star hotels and B&B's, but the Madison Hotel has the best service by far. There were four of us total with two to a room. Both us of got Queen Bankers rooms which are small rooms, however they made a good use of the space. The bathroom was quite spacious and the pedestal sink had plenty of real estate for two people. The twice daily housekeeping is a nice touch. We loved coming back from dinner to find our bed turned down with ice waiting in the bucket and chocolates on the pillows. They also turn the CD player on when they do turndown and move the TV remote to the table next to the bed. It's all the little things that were really cool for me. I've had turn down services before, but never to this level. The rooftop patio truly is the best view in Memphis. The view out over the river at sunset is breathtaking, and night is beautiful in its own way. The Mezzanine was also a nice place to sit and have a drink the second night when it was cold and rainy. It looked out over the lobby and there is a good music mix so it had a really chill vibe. The free breakfast is served at Grill 83 their restaurant.  They don't have a ton of choices, but it's tasty and it's free. The staff is what really puts it over the top. They remembered us every time we saw them. They would ask things like if we wanted tea since we had tea the day before. They also mentioned how good their restaurant was, but didn't push it on you. They always smiled and were just genuinely nice. I will say the valet parking is a little slow, but really I don't think it could be any better. The blocks in downtown Memphis are small and the staff does the best it can with the available space.  In closing, if you ever find yourself in Memphis, a stay at the Madison is a must!I was informed upon arrival that this hotel is the place where all the nba players stay when playing the grizzlies. I like lead ins like that. Styain with the ballers....place was great and i am told by locals that its superior to its much better known sister down the street The Peabody. Modern, clean and hip with a nice gym across street. Stay here. There aint a lot of alternatives in mumphuss.

review_content: Parking was too much so I just parked on the street in front. Little strange that the front door to the hotel was locked at night and you had to go around back to get in. But the room was nice. The TV wouldn't show a picture but it had sound. I figured out how to fix it though. It wasn't awesome but it wasn't badRoom is comfortable but the hotel in general is in dire need of an update. Items attached to the wall in the bathroom are loose and would fall off if pulled on at all. There is a musty smell that's probably the old carpet. All in all it's not a bad place to stay but the reason I only gave 3 stars is because of the totally unusable free wifi. So much for member benefits. When you could connect at all, it only lasted a matter of seconds - maybe a few minutes. The best part of our stay was the extremely friendly and helpful shuttle driver. He knew everything from the best places to eat downtown to history of the city, and the upcoming return of the trolley system to the city. He was there when promised to pick us up for our return to the hotel. Overall, he was a very intelligent, courteous, and entertaining driver. He more than deserved his tip.The room was nice, clean and comfortable. The professionalism of the staff was lacking at the registration desk and the hotel is currently undergoing construction. This was not known to me until I got to the hotel. And I was not informed of what time construction started in the morning. Needless to say, I was rudely awakened by construction noise when I needed to rest up for my road trip cross country. Also, Parking is not free at this hotel!!! Breakfast isn't complementary unless you purchased it with your room.I see potential for this hotel however, they need to work on their professionalism and communicationThe hotel stay was good. I didn't like that I came during the time they are renovating this hotel It felt like I was staying at a Motel not a hotel. Everything about it felt outdated. The fixtures are old and drains are not working correctly. The dinning area feels like a large conference room. I would not stay here again. The staff however was super friendly and the rooms were clean. They could have stocked the shampoo, coffee etc which they didn't.Awful. Checked in at 11pm and the lady in the front desk didn't even greet us (didn't even look up!). She didn't ask us what size bed we wanted nor asked if we wanted a smoking or non smoking room. She just asked for my id and my credit card and proceeded to swipe our guest room cards. When we got up to our room, we were given 2 double beds and the room was poorly lit with one lamp that had those awful LED lights. We were coming from a 9 hr drive and was so tired that we didn't even bother to get our room changed. We were finally settling in when someone in the hallway were drilling something at 11:30 pm!! Seriously?! Parking was $17 overnight. It should have been free since they were renovating at the time. It was our first time in Memphis and let me just say that this hotel left a bad taste in our mouths.This hotel cancelled our reservation before we arrived without letting us know. The official cancellation policy on our confirmed email reservation said we had until 6pm to arrive (or needed to add our credit card to assure a late arrival). We arrived at 4pm. They had overbooked the hotel so they just started cancelling rooms. They kept saying "we're just following policy" even though this was clearly against their cancellation policy as a stated in their email. They didn't seem very sorry about it because they knew they just had to deal with their overbooking problem. They did call around and find another hotel room for us and we were assured the same rate. We had to move down the street to another hotel. I'm grateful they found us a place. But their complete lack of attention to the real policy and general apathy was bad service.These are the sweetest, most pleasant people I've ever encountered in a hotel staff. I will stay here every time I come to Memphis - construction or not. Reginald is a phenomenal shuttle driver and Cleo is a awesome as well. The front desk staff is friendly and knowledgeable and they'll help you with anything you need. They've been handling all the woes of construction with grace and I know their lobby is going to be absolutely beautiful when finished. Also the French toast at breakfast is DOPE. Try it. No where else I'd rather get snowed in!Stayed here a few times on Thursdays before Friday AM flight. Check in was slow but did greet me as a Platinum, bonus points, and upgrade. This hotel does not have a Platinum Lounge but they do give you 1 free drink upon check-in... This is a negative for me - I like the lounges. Not really walking distance downtown a cab will be needed. They didn't offer me shuttle service but it looks like they have 1.Rooms were ok been in better - but it was clean and comfy. Nice little bar area downstairs with overpriced drinks and decent food. Didn't receive my wake up call on 2 of 3 occasions.Avg $150 a nightSo so:)It's about $100 + parking lot $10-15. If you wanna save some money, you should park at the parking lot around church.Room:clean, nice view, decent sizeSwimming pool:outside, smallGym:small, water cooler, weights, elliptical, towel, tvStaff:niceLocation:a little bit far from fun areas but you can use  shuttle serviceRestaurant and bar: Good price. Nice service. Friendly stuff.This hotel is definitely not any better than a Holiday Inn.  Actually it is not as good as The holiday inn.  We had to ask for several things to be fixed in our room and only one got fixed.  The HBO and other cable channels did not come in.  Was going to purchase a bottle of soda and a bag of chef mix in lobby but decided not to after I found out it would cost $10.  Parking is $17 per day.  A bit run down, but not horrible.  No free breakfast.  Generally worn out, loose sink faucet in bathroom.  No microwave or refrigerator,  not even a pen and paper.  Pretty bare bones.  Will not return.I stayed here with my parents on a stopover on a road trip to OKC. The hotel is right off of the interstate downtown and very convenient in that aspect. It's definitely more than walking distance to the festivities on Beale St, but there is a shuttle that they provide for guests to go down there. The rooms were well appointed and the first beds were very comfortable. You could tell the hotel's age in some places as some of the paint was chipped near the door to the bathroom in our room but there was nothing major. The staff here was absolutely 5 star. From check in to check out, they were very helpful and attentive. We requested a room facing downtown (which I recommend) and they made it happen. It really added to our visit. However, there were a few negatives- -They do charge $17/day for parking and that can really add in to your final bill. I would have preferred to just pay $10 in the nightly rate as opposed to having it tacked once we arrived. -I got a great deal on the hotel through Priceline, however we got the feeling that everyone got a great deal here as there were some seedy characters that were also staying here. Upon our arrival there was a large group of people smoking right by the front door that we had to walk through to check in. It definitely killed the otherwise upscale atmosphere and they would benefit from having a designated smoking area.Lousy wifi. $17/day to self park. Poor insulation in bedrooms. Some might say, Meghan, why 2 stars?Well the bedroom furniture is pretty contemporary and the location isn't half bad. I'd suggest the Holiday inn or Hampton inn and suites. They are closer to Beale & probably cheaper.Basic hotel amenities but very well managed. Staff all very polite and accommodating. The shuttle drivers are the best! Reginald and Mr. Turner gave wonderful recommendations for navigating to various restaurants and sights without needing to pay for a tour package.Pros: free shuttle to downtown, certain staff members were friendly and wanted to help (not all, but there were a few that spent time and effort to try to help)Cons: dirty rooms (had to switch 3 times) and was still left with clogged sinks and tubs, hotel is in need of maintenance, air conditioners can't keep up (room couldn't get below 69F) and the one in the rooms are SO NOISY, the hallways are not airconditioned so it smells like mold and feels like hot, stagnant air, the location is not as close to Beale street as they lead you to believe. The free shuttle helps, but for $10 more, upgrade and stay MUCH closer to the action (and not the highway!)Nice hotel extra security and nice staff the thing was there were a lot of mosquito biting but I know cause we were on the Mississippi River but besides that everything was wonderful even room service was coolOuch!! This place has bed bugs! I was itching my legs the whole time that we stayed here. 9th floor. Do not stay here unless you plan on having the worst itching sensation cause you a tremendous amount of pain. Where I was bitten, burned, itched, and wouldn't stop itching even with Extra Strength Benadryl cream. Do some research, there are bed bug registry reports out there and this hotel is on there by other people also. Parking is overpriced at $17 a day charged on top of your room rate. Shuttle service is nice but overcrowded and overused. You will do a lot of waiting and have to fight for your spot on the shuttle especially late at night. Beale street is live and vibrant till 3am but the shuttle stops at 11:45pm on the weekend and 10:45pm during the week for its last pick up. The shuttle is not worth it considering it comes with high stress, bed bugs, and a housekeeping staff that doesn't understand you when you ask for a trash bag or complain about the bed bug bites. I showed the housekeeper my bites and she said it was because of the laundry detergent and changed the sheets. That didn't help, I still got eaten alive!! BEWARE - do NOT stay here!This place came up uber cheap for our random Memphis trip. Room was clean, beds and pillows were divine...really great toiletries. Appreciated the aromatherapy after the long drive. Only issues with this place...the little bus of theirs that takes you downtown, which is literally some blocks, stops running at 11....luckily in our drunkenness we had no problem just walking back, less than 10 min really...security was cool and staff was very nice. $17 bucks to park outside in their lot...not cool. Across the street is a church parking lot, $5 bucks for the day. Memphis police was everywhere so safety not an issue at all. But for a place that does not have free breakfast and shabby furniture...the parking price was ridic. Also a very late check in time. Its all a scam but the bed was great.Excellent staff from the desk personnel to the shuttle driver (Reginald). Clean comfortable rooms. Check in was a breeze. No worries here.The hotel is in a great location, about a mile from the famous Beale Street. Room is clean and I like the little extras they leave on the bed like scented oils and lotion that will help you sleep. The bathroom is a little small. The staff was really friendly. The two women we encountered at the front desk were really helpful with answering questions. They have a complimentary shuttle that will take you around the downtown area which is great! And they drivers of the shuttles are also very friendly and engage in friendly conversation. I'd stay here again when visiting Memphis again!I booked a king non smoking room at this hotel for a brief work trip. I'm understanding of the construction but the room was sub-par. My room faced the freeway and I was certain that I could hear the radio station of every car that passed. The radio had a sound machine setting, but it did not work. The TV had a large green line from the bottom of the screen to the top of it which was very annoying. The light switch in the bathroom had a short so I had to tap it to get it to stay on, this made me very nervous to be tapping while I was in the shower. I barely slept because of the noise and the walls were paper thin, I could hear everything above me, next to me and all the commotion in the hall. When I inquired of the front desk to see if this was an older room that would be renovated, I was told that 'your room is fine'. I honestly couldn't believe her response as I checked out. I will never stay at a Crowne Plaza again and would not suggest it to anyone.
review_content_20: I do stay here regularly when I come to memphis since this is my crew hotel. Tonight I was given one of their worst rooms. I had a leaky faucet, broken desk phone, the desk leg is loose and wobbly. The TV had sound but no picture, so maintenance came up to tell me the TV needed rebooting because it's old, not to mention this is a flat screen LG TV. So he turned it off and back on and it did work this time. The bathroom had no toiletries but they left me a half used tube of hotel lotion from the previous guest who stayed there. I realized the desk was broken when I tried to pull the chair from under it to seat and couldn't without slightly lifting the table. Someone or housekeeping intentionally wedge the chair under it to secure the desk, thinking no one will use it. So they knew about the problem and brushed it aside.This hotel is well on its way of losing its crowne because it's not up to standard with the Crowne Plaza chain. Rooms are outdated and often times smelly. To me this just another low budget hotel with a big name.I decided to give The Crowne Plaza in Memphis a try as it seemed to be situated in a reasonable area and near to downtown Memphis.So I'm going to start with the good things about this hotel.1) Reginald the hotel shuttle driver, will take you just about anywhere within reason, in Memphis and pick you up as well. He works until around 11pm and he is a REALLY, REALLY nice guy. Plus he'll give you some local touristy info as you drive around.2) Very nice bathroom amenities, shampoo and conditioners.Unfortunately that's where it ends.1) There is NO working internet at this property as far as I can tell. Despite asking the front desk staff twice about this, I was told that this was due to current high occupancy. To be brutally honest, if your internet only works when there is nobody staying at the hotel, then you have some serious issues that need to be resolved. 2) The walls are paper thin, such that you can here the guy next door ordering his pizza and almost hear him eating it as well.3) The room we stayed in needed some major refurbishment, chipped doors and cupboards and a general unloved feel. 4) Front desk were somewhat offhand and rather inhospitable.All in all, rather disappointing.Poor customer service the lady was yelling to someone in the background while trying to converse with me. The shuttle bus driver tried to hustle us so I just said no and drove my own car to Beale. The room needs updating, lampshade cracked and broken, and the electrical outlet didn't work. So disappointed this was my birthday celebration trying to stay in a nice hotel and enjoy Beale. To share something nice, I liked the pillows and the flat screen.This hotel is not up to the standards of other Crowne Plazas. Its currently under construction, which is fine. It needs major updating. What's not fine is having your hotel lobby dirty. The floor is gross. And the rooms are cleanish. They clean it but they do not try to hard or look closely. Also, in between nights they refreshed the room but didn't leave any new soap or shampoo. Also, hair dryer was broke. Called down to front desk and the front desk was great she had one sent up unfortunately, it took around 40 mins to get and a few calls down to the front desk. The breakfast is so basic and not good. I asked for a cooked to order egg item and the server was a little rude. They way she asked the question I didn't get what she was asking. What do you want when I replied eggs she was like what do you want. She could of politely asked how do you want your eggs. It wasn't that busy to be rude to a customer. The front desk was the only good part of this hotel. They are friendly and helpful. The rest of the staff not so much. Also, workout facility is on the 11th floor which this floor is a little creepy since no one is on it. It has major room to improve. Very disappointed in it being a Crowne Plaza.This is my favorite hotel in this area. It's a great place to stay. There is a particular bar tender in the restaurant who is pretty unfriendly. I can't think of her name but she knows she could do a better job at such a great hotel. I won't let it stop me from staying here but if she's working I drink and eat elsewhere.I'm checking out of this place now and heading to The Madison with my fingers crossed. This place is dirty, the walls are paper thin (heard a normal volume conversation from the room next door), the wifi was slow, the room had a funny stink that was covered by bleach, the breakfast buffet was cold (with watered down coffee and OJ) so we ordered from the menu (should've gotten breakfast elsewhere like we did yesterday), and I'll say it again.... it's LOUD - you hear everything. Don't get a room by the stairs or it'll sound like a shotgun is going off outside your door. Maybe it's better on some floors but I doubt it.The staff is friendly. The beds were clean and comfy.Definitely not worth their higher ratings on travel websites. Motel 6 quality... and that may be an insult to Motel 6.Let's start with the pluses--The hotel had friendly staff and my room was very clean and nice. It has a nice location right off the highway and near downtown. Now, to the not so nice. The hotel reeks of mildew and mold. The hallways and entry way are disgusting and there is a real lack of amenities. The ice machine on my floor doesn't work and the floor around it is literally falling apart.
