The location couldn't be better right off of Beale Street, plus they have tons of event spaces for locals. I recommend this hotel, 5 stars!I've stayed in Westins before, and never regretted it. First, this is one of the more expensive Westins I've stayed in personally. 185.00 plus tax, plus 18.00 parking, plus nice guys you can't say no to for helping you with your bags. Think Holiday inn express NOT luxury hotel. I didn't have a single issue with customer service like others, staff was good. But I definitely feel like I got a bit cheated for what I payed. Final bill must have been in the 250.00 range. Plenty of beat up furniture to go around and the place needs a deep cleaning. Spots, etc. Everywhere you look. Just stay at 2.5* hotel and save the money. Seriously.Enjoyable. Will stay here again.This is a very clean property and up to date.  Staff at the front desk could not have been friendlier and very helpful.My son was moving out of his dorm and he joined us for one night. He thought the guitar check out feature was great, as he was able to play a rather expensive Gibson jazz guitar.It was fun staying off Beale Street. We are not big into the party scene over there but walking over is much preferable to driving in and trying to find some safe place to leave one's car.I had to work in the room over two days.  Not crazy about the CFL glare in the room. Not really the local property's fault, but the desk needs one task light.I was under the impression that the Westin chain was a 5 star resort. After my stay, I would consider this a 3 star resort honestly. Maybe 3.5 and that's only because of the location and skyline views from our 7th floor room. The traditional room was very small. We tried to upgrade at check in but were told no rooms were available even though they showed executive suites available online. There were scuff markings on the wall and carpet was dingy with spots. The room and bathroom had a musty non welcoming stale smell. The shower could have been a little cleaner. Also, there were not enough small face towels for two guests. There were only two so that meant one per adult. The bars , one located in the lobby and the other in the restaurant were nice and stocked any and all beverages you could possibly think of...they had my Tuaca so i was happy happy joy joy! other then that i would look for a better hotel downtown Memphis next time.For my first trip to Memphis, I wanted to experience the city as a tourist, to try and get a good feel for it.  When I am traveling, I would like to be able to relax in a calming atmosphere.  That boiled down my choices to the Peabody and the Westin.  Since I am an SPGer and have AAA, I couldn't but not pass up the deals here.  I got a AAA bed n breakfast rate for $159 a night (when the rooms are normally $179, with no breakfast)- and a daily $40 credit for breakfast.  Unfortunately, the Peabody couldn't come close to offering something like that.So never being to Memphis before and having it be late at night, I just started driving til I saw some lights that would look possibly familiar- in the end, it was easy to find.  They have self parking (which I utilized) and valet.  They are $18/24 a night respectively (theres that hotel pricing I look forward too!).Since it was about midnight local time (on Valentine's day of all days), I was able to sneak in the lobby from the garage.  As I walked in, I realized how nice and how new this place was.  I also noticed the White Tea Aloe scent permeating the air.  That is an addictive scent- and this is coming from a beer drinking macho.Check in was smooth, and I was on my way to the room. On my way to the elevator, I realized the nice case of Gibsons just sitting there- apparently for the guests to enjoy in their room... I will have to keep that in mind for next time- I just didn't want to put on an improv concert in the middle of the night... When I got up to the room, all I could do was laugh when I looked out my window and was greeted with the huge letters of "FEDEX FORUM".  I had to remember who's backyard I was playing in (for those of you out of the know, I work for their main competitor).The room was spacious, clean, and I was shocked to see a soaking tub as well- I was just in a basic room (on the SPG floor).  I didn't have any issues getting to sleep- or staying asleep.  There was a stocked mini bar too (with that being said, not much, if any room to put anything else in there).Since I forgot to polish my shoes before I left, I called the desk, and dropped them off.  When I came back from my late drinking, my shiny shoes greeted me on my desk ($14 later!).  That was a convenience!The fitness center is being remodeled as we speak, but its cool- as it over looks the Gibson factory.  The business center is equipped with enough goods to get your email and Yelp on.  Comes in handy!  Overall, this is the nicest Westin I have stayed in, and I think it's an awesome addition to Memphis. Good call!! I was only an incident away from giving this place 5 stars- as my credit for my breakfast never went through, so having to deal with that was enough from making it perfect.  But other than that- this is a SOLID property, and I will surely direct my friends and family to stay here when they come to visit!I like a good bathroom. If I was rating the bathroom alone, it would be five stars. Give me hot water with a good showerhead and I could not be happier. My room at the Westin had a glass standing shower with a separate tub. Yippie!I had several nights of great sleep due to the comfy bedding. The pillows were fantastic and what I assume is a down duvet kept me very warm at night.Many attractions are within a walking distance from here. Beale Street is a block away. Gibson Guitars is across the street and offers daily tours. If the hotel had good internet service, I'd have gone to 5-stars. I paid for the premium service ($12.95/day) which touted 1Mbps speed but was never able to get over about 384Kbps. Poo. I had to resort to using MiFi off my iPad in order to get quality access to the outside world.If I make it back to Memphis, I'd totally stay here again.
review_content_20: My husband and I went to Memphis to actually go to Gibson and booked our stay at the Westin, which is located right across the street.  What a nice place.  We originally booked a traditional room but was upgraded to a suite.  All I can say is OMG.  Huge, spacious, comfortable.  The beds truly are heavenly.  We brought our dog who everyone fawned over as well.  The room service was great, the Bleu food was wonderful and the staff ever so accommodating.  If anyone ever goes to Memphis please consider staying here,This hotel probably should have been badge as a "W".  The location is loud and to in the middle of it all to feel much like a Westin, even with the white tea scent everywhere.  Arrival parking is sure to set things off on the wrong foot - no directional signage in a very congested location.  Room helped make up for everything but you can't enjoy the view at night because of the lighting and sound assault.  Fun for a party weekend, not a high-end visit to a city.If the Peabody is the "historic" classy hotel in near Beale, then Westin is the "business" classy hotel (or "new/shiny/polish [insert adjective here]"). Westin's, in general, cater to the business crowd, and this one is no exception. Beds are comfortable, bathrooms huge with fantastic showers and separate tubs, and for $5, they'll give you workout clothes (did not try that, but duly noted). Though I'll still never understand why a hotel that caters to business travels charges a daily wireless rate. I suppose because they assume their employers are paying for it. Parking is about $18/day for self park. If you are there for Bourbon...I mean, Beale, Street (DEAR GOD WHY?!), some of the rooms even overlook it. Oh joy.We stayed 4 nights and it was great.  The room was big, beautifully decorated and the bathroom was very spacious.  The entire staff was wonderful.  Everyone was helpful and professional.  The location was prefect, the food was 4 star and the bars area in the lobby and lounges were well appointed.  I hate to exercise but the workout room was outstanding We are definitely staying againGood location, good beds and decent food. They don't have a pool however. It is right across the street from the rock and soul museum and also where the free shuttle picks up from. Restaurants on Beale street are steps away.What's a welcome reprieve from the neverending road when driving from Chicago to Austin? Memphis. And when stopping in Memphis, a trip to Beale Street is essential no matter how weary or anti-tourist you're feeling. I found a special for $179/night which is a solid deal considering this Westin's 'spit-and-it'll-hit-Beale' locale. Factor in a complimentary upgrade to the Starwood Preferred floor which included free bottled water (blah) and shared air space with celebrity basketball player Tony Parker (YES!) and the solid deal catapulted to remarkable status. Hint: If you're a basketball buff, book at the Westin when the Grizzlies are playing at home. Being surrounded by a small but tall chunk of the San Antonio Spurs team easily made my night!The property included all the usual Westin bells and whistles and some extras: The legendary heavenly bed, an oversized bathroom and a killer view of Beale Street. Make note that if you make a purchase at the neighboring Starbucks, it will come up as 'Westin Memphis FB' (food and beverage) on your credit card as it's technically located on their property. I called so you don't have to. Oh, and Gibson guitars straight from the factory across the street are on display in the lobby and are available for a borrow. Enjoy!Great hotel. Great staff (Brad at front desk is wonderful). Room was perfect. I always opt out of housecleaning and take points instead, so I can't comment on housekeeping services. Bleu restaurant was good (Tevin was a great waiter!). Get the caprese salad. Yum! Location is perfectly placed next to Beale St. Don't hesitate, stay here!From the moment we drove up, to the 'see you soon!' handshakes and hugs when our stay was over, the Westin Memphis Beale Street staff made us feel like family.The room was perfect, the hotel location is great, there's a Starbucks just around the corner. We walked to everything: Gibson factory, the Mississippi, Beale Street, great restaurants, so forth.Yes, it is what some malcontents call 'pricey,' but jeez, you certainly get what you pay for: lovely, quiet, clean, fresh room; professional, helpful friendly staff; a truly heavenly bed; luxurious bathroom; superb valet; excellent bar atmosphere.Five stars, baby!Perhaps, I just came during a very slow time of the season but this place seemed like a Ghost Town. I have always enjoyed my stays at Westins throughout the years especially because the Heavenly Bed is the stuff dreams are made of. (pun intended) Although, there wasn't anything terrible about my visit, there just wasn't anything fantastic either. Bleu Restaurant located in the hotel lobby was closed early each night. I tried to order dinner room service and the menu only offered slim pickings due to lack of inventory of food? I tried to order a veggie sandwich or salad and they advised me that they were lacking some of the key ingredients... I believe that it was during prime dinner time, 8:30pm?!However, the staff did offer up some other suggestions and ended up delivering me a salad albeit plain, but it sufficed. Next, I was disappointed by the size of the small fitness center as many of the other Westins that I have visited boast beautiful facilities. However, judging by the fact that I was the only person working out both times that I visited, this could explain why they didn't invest in this area. I also scratched my head as the comfy Heavenly robe was not waiting for me in my room like usual... is this a new Westin procedure?Some pros that do stand out is the convenient location of this hotel to the happenings of Beale Street, other tourism, and freeways. If you don't have your own vehicle, you can easily hoof it or take advantage of inexpensive cab fare to some of the fun that this city has to offer. I also appreciated the cleanliness of the grounds and rooms and customer service of what staff I did come across during my stay.Always a fan of The Westin, I'll continue to be a patron of this Starwood brand but I have to admit that this Beale Street location leaves a bit to be desired...Yelp365#10The Westin Memphis Beale Street is a very solid choice if you are staying in Memphis and perhaps even your best choice if you need or want to be in the downtown area.  The location is great.  It's close to Beale Street (right around the corner), and the Fed Ex Forum, Rock and Soul Museum, and Gibson Guitar Factory and Store are all right across the street.  The National Civl Rights Museum and nearby Central BBQ are within walking distance, also, but you might want to cab it there and back as the surrounding area is a little rough in spots.  Just sayin.  The rooms are spacious and nicely appointed.  If you have stayed at a Westin recently, the rooms will seem familiar, as will the scale of the hotel.  The hotel has a lounge and a surprisingly good restaurant.  The service was excellent.  The service is typically excellent at Westin hotels, but, here, you get that plus southern hospitality and manners.  Every member of the staff I encountered over a four day stay was friendly, welcoming, and genuinely helpful.  I would have given five stars but for the lack of a sundries store on site.  There are no such places nearby, so the lack of that amenity at the hotel was a  disappointment.What makes The Westin such a great place to stay during a trip to Memphis is the level of hospitality displayed by all the staff working there. Everyone had a genuinely friendly demeanor and were very attentive to our needs. Quintessential Southern Hospitality. Period.Every inch of the hotel is beautifully decorated and well maintained. The bar in the lobby was pretty cool and there was piano music on some nights of the week. What my travel buddy loved best was the case of Gibson guitars by the reception desk, which were available for loan during our stay on a first come first serve basis. After signing a lending agreement with the hotel, you get the guitar of your choice, an amp, and headphones delivered to your room. Very cool .Speaking of rooms, I adored that Heavenly Bed in the room and, if I had the extra coin, would purchase the bed for my home. I stayed in a room facing Gibson for more peace and quiet. I would recommend that you do, too, if you need to sleep as Beale Street is right around the corner. For me, the topper was the bathroom - so spacious and luxurious - with the double head shower and tub. I've stayed there twice on two separate trips to Memphis - once during the busy season in June and once during the slow season in December. On both occasions, it was a soothing experience staying at the Westin. Anytime I am in the city of Memphis, the Westin is my home away from home.Extremely friendly and competent staff, decent sized rooms, large bathroom, comfortable beds, excellent location just a half block from Beale St and they loan you Gibson guitars for your room! Pet friendly! No pool though...I think I've stayed in too many Westins and perhaps I was a little disappointed overall with Memphis.This Westin is conveniently located (across the street) from where the NBA Memphis Grizzlies play and is on the backside of Beale Street.  Honestly, I don't know how Memphis supports an NBA franchise.  There was a game on one of the nights I was at the hotel.  I walked outside to soak up some of the ambiance of an NBA crowd expecting fans, crowds, street vendors, etc.  It was a ghost town.  Beale St. wasn't much better:  it consisted of really only 4 or 5 places that weren't all too clean.Back to the Westin.  It was okay.  My room was dirty, the hallways were dirty, and the elevators were dirty.  In the morning, beer bottles were still in the lobby from the night before.  Valet service wasn't good either -- only one person was working and it took a good 30+ minutes to retrieve my car.Pros:Awesome locationNBA stays hereNice roomCons:Can't get basics right like calling an early morning cab (they never requested it the night before so it showed up 20 mins after I needed it)A bit pricey for amenitiesLOVED this hotel! Went to the Justin Timberlake concert at the FedEx Forum, and only had to walk right across the street! Super comfy bed, friendly staff, awesome shower... Very convenient  and clean stay :) Definitely recommend.JoJo loves me a WestinWhats not to like?  Giant Bed, kick ass shower - I'm currently writing this review drinking a cup of complimentary coffee I made with my complimentary bottled water whilst on my complimentary wifi wearing a westin robe.Hint: join starwoods PG kids, you get points regardless of how often you stay - if ya'll get a credit card you get more points and they give you free water.the people in memphis are SO NICE.  Seriously, so nice.  And this hotel is clean, comfortable, the food is good and it overlooks beale - which is great if you want to walk in memphis with your feet ten feet off beale, and then go into your hotel room, take a heavenly shower and fall the eff asleep.  You won't even hear the rowdy kids playing at the bars.My hotel is PACKED this week because the clippers are in town and they're staying here...so I if I wind up in LA with a new spin on Basketball Wives don't hate, I'll remember you little yelpers helped me on my way to stardom.Location...location...location....yes siree Westin is within walking distance from Beale Street where all the great BBQ restaurant are located, plenty of clubs with live music across the street is FedEx Forum home to the NBA Grizzlies, Rock N Soul Museum and Gibson Guitar Factory....the biggest surprise when we check in was we found out you can borrow a really nice guitar with a small amp for your entire stay at NO CHARGE....how cool is that.....plus our large room 231 is facing the Gibson factory which we requested....bed so comfy, clean crisp linen, extra pillows, AC kept its temp steadily...bottled water free, bathroom is very roomy nicely decorated with high end amenities....staff are super friendly like Chris Griffin who made us feel like we are her BFF...Gary at the front desk sent someone to fix the door problem in less than 5min...Jean Marie who check us in was exceptional...Ozzi the room attendant was so sweet who gave us extra water when she found out I didn't very feel good...Westin own restaurant serve healthier food...Starbucks around the corner....we were not disappointed at all....we will stay at Westin Beale Street again when we return next yearConsidering the price, the Westin Beale Street was a tremendous disappointment. For starters, my television was out of service. Practically nothing is complimentary. Would you like a bottle of water? That will be $5. Internet service? $6.95 per night for a slow connection, $12.95 for a fast connection (really?!). Oh, and if your room is on the side of the hotel facing Beale Street, don't plan on getting any sleep. It's 11:45 p.m. as I type this, and the worst cover band I have ever heard in my life is playing "The Humpty Hump" literally right outside of my window. It's loud enough to feel vibrations in the floor.Ah, "The Humpty Hump," that timeless blues classic. Didn't W.C. Handy write that?On the upside, it's less than a 10-minute walk to the best fried chicken on Earth, Gus' Hot & Spicy World Famous Fried Chicken.From the moment we checked in we were treated wonderfully.   We were upgraded because of our gold status (which doesn't always happen).   Our dog was greeted every time he passed through the lobby.   Carlos at the bar could not have been nicer.   Location was great!   Stay here, you won't be sorry.   Thanks guys!Good hotel but a little below average for a Westin.  The positives.... for starters it's a Westin which means a Heavenly bed, dual shower heads, and all the standard amenities you'd expect from a Westin.  The location to Beale Street is ridiculously close too so even if you get tore up drunk it'd be tough not to find your way home.  Also I found the staff here to be extremely friendly & attentive.  As far as negatives ....this Westin seems to be a bit worn down, probably expected when a good % of your clientele are going on drunken Beale Street benders.  Upon arrival they couldn't find my reservation eventhough I had my confirmation email & number on my phone.  Took a while but they figured it out & upgraded my room so there was a silver lining. Also one morning we ordered in-room dining for breakfast and they forgot to put in our order then when they did bring it they had only brought half the food.  I ended up waiting about 2hrs before I actually got my breakfast.  The Boston Celtics were staying at the hotel at this time and I can bet that Paul Pierce wasn't waiting 2hrs for his blueberry pancakes!! Overall had a few glitches with our stay but I'd still stay here next time I'm in Memphis.
review_content_40: Like Michael K we were upgraded to the NBA floor at the Westin. However, no famous people staying at the hotel that weekend...well, except for the stars of the weekend: my friend (the bride) and her soon-to-be groom.Since I was on bridesmaids duty while in Memphis I didn't spend much time in my hotel, but like all Westin hotel rooms it was comfortable. It was on the smaller size, but I may just be comparing it to the bridal suite...which was quite large. Thank goodness cause we needed lots of space for 14 bridesmaids to get hair and makeup done.Much of my time at the Westin was spent waiting for their very slow elevators. Two elevators isn't nearly enough for this large hotel- they could definitely use a few more.  The staff here was very nice...actually everyone I met in Memphis was very nice. Gotta love that southern hospitality.I usually judge hotels based on their workout room, but didn't make it to this one since my big workout was dancing at the wedding. However, my husband said it was adequate.This was my first time in Memphis, but if/when I make it back I'd definitely consider staying at this centrally located Westin again.The in room snack bar has a sex kit...need I type more?This W is a block off Beale street so after you bar crawl you end up at the front door of this place. They even let you sober up on the huge patio and serve coffee for free without judging you as you throw up in their bushes.While this hotel lacks proper insulation if your room is over looking Beale, remind me to tell you the story about the drunk girl yelling at my window, but there is no window tint so be careful walking around in your Bday suit...hence the screaming drunk girl.This is your typical W hotel with the yummy over sized pillows, plush pillows and robes you try to steal. You have to use a key card to gain access to your room floor, which is fabulous because I have traveled alone. The concierge is smooth, getting us last minute reservations at a hard to get in restaurant yet this hotel doesn't offer valet. Memphis became my haven this Summer and after experiencing some less then desirable hotels, we always end up at the W. Did I mention the sex kit...If possible, I would have given this terribly run establishment zero stars, but that's not an option. We were here for 4 days and our room was never cleaned once. We complained FOUR times with the fourth time getting the manager involved and that still didn't do anything . We have no toilet paper, no towels, and the toilet is broken. I would never recommend this hotel to anyone who cares about any customer service. Choose this hotel if you don't want any clean sheets, clean towels or working toilets. Absolutely dissatisfied with the customer service and experience here.I am giving this place 2 stars instead of one, only because I finally talked to a manager who was able to correct 2 full days (Day and Night) of terrible service.  Props to Leigh!!!!!  She finally acknowledged our problems and gave us a comped night.  She also treated us like guests.  The other staff (except in the restaurant)  were mostly ill equipped to work in the service industry at a high end hotel.)  LEIGH was the epitome of an excellent hotel manager!!!!  Too bad she was not there until Sunday morning.I will come back to the hotel at Leigh's invitation to try the hotel again..Chronology - So many bad things happened I cannot capture them here.Afternoon Day One - No valets were at the front in an city hotel with no curbside parking.  We got blocked in the main entrance for a good 10 minutes.  It was as if there was no way to check into the hotel.  We went inside and the hotel room was not ready  at 315 pm but the desk was not overly busy.   I was told to wait and I could have a seat or enjoy the bar (that was closed) at 3:15 in the afternoon.  Little did I know they were not expecting my room to be ready until 6pm.  Went and talked to desk again and she said "I never said it would be a short wait!" in a very defensive unprofessional tone.  People were steadily arriving into the lobby and by 415 pm there were about 50 guests waiting to be checked in.  The front desk was frustrated and did not have the resources or ability to handle this problem.KICKER: A GUEST WHO WAS NOT TOO UNPLEASANT (above) had the police called on him by the staff and was "BANNED FROM THE HOTEL FOR LIFE"  When I left for dinner and the police were talking to him outside,  I asked him and his very lovely wife if they needed any testimony to their behavior because it did not justify a police call.  They were well behaved but upset.  I should look on you tube to see if it is out there.Night Day One - Upon return at midnight and check-in I asked if any accommodation had been made for our inconvenience of not being able to change for our dinner party and if the manager Gary or Don was ready to talk to me.  The lady at the desk knew nothing about it and when I started to tell her the story she told me to not raise my voice to her and then when my wife came over to see what was wrong I told her there was no resolution.  The lady at the desk snapped at me "Don't Tell her that - I said I would work on a resolution."   Who talks to guests like that?????  My wife told her not to talk to me like that and the lady at the desk did not like that at all.  We checked into our room because I did not want to be arrested in Memphis at Midnight and noticed a piece of garbage in the hall outside our room that remained until we checked out Sunday.  Our room was dirty (see pictures with post-its)Morning Day 2 - No resolution or accomodation made to us.  Morning service much better.  Tells us she hopes we get some resolution to the problemEvening Day 2 - No resolution or accommodation.  Little better service from the front desk.   Get back to room late and Gary had called and alluded to the fact that there was some sort of perceived debacle in the lobby Friday night.  Are you kidding?  There were 50 pissed off guests hanging in the lobby Friday...Morning Day three - Sunday - Checkout.  Leigh answered.  Leigh was AWESOME and did all we wanted which was that  she apologized on behalf of the hotel.  She did not blame the large group. she did not blame anyone, she took care of business and handled it professionally.  She comped us one night which was great.  Overall - the problem was the late check in and the dirty room which was easily remedied but the hotel staff  made a problem much worse with such incredible rudeness.   Leigh and the morning staff were refreshing and well training.  I am thankful she worked there to smooth over the other problems.I am a gold preferred guests with about 100 lifetime nights under my belt at all different Starwood hotels.  This was my worst experience and hopefully it was a fluke and I will give it a second shot.The shower was clogged and I showered in several inches of water.  When I told the front desk, they said the next guest would appreciate that I told them.  And that was it. I would expect some type of credit; it was disgusting and my wife wouldn't shower after me. There aren't a lot of choices in Memphis, but we were just shocked at the lacking service- in the bar/ restaurant, room service, front desk.  I just expect a lot better from a Westin.I do love the Westin's bedding.Great stay! Check in was easy, ate at the restaurant for breakfast, lunch and dinner ( both days) ...I enjoyed my dinners, lunch was ok, I'm not a fan of the way they prepare chicken when added to salads, both days they were kinda rubbery :/, loved the breakfast buffets that were prepared (sweetest fruit ever!) ....awesome staff, very polite.  We were a group of 10, there on business, and we all really pleased with the service & attentive staff.  Will definitely stay there again.   ps, our window faced Beale street and it was not noisy, got a good nights sleep each night.This hotel is "okay" as long as you don't have a billing issue. I was erroneously charged for an additional room which was cancelled 3 days prior to my reservation. After 6 WEEKS of phone calls and e-mails back and forth, I finally have this issue resolved. This ONLY occurred after repeatedly calling Starwood Resorts. It was finally explained as a "glitch" in their system. If you do have a billing issue, don't count on the Westin Memphis staff to be concerned enough to resolve the problem. After, FINALLY, making contact with Don Michael Norwood (Guest Relations Manager-Westin Memphis), he was seemingly uninterested and unwilling to adequately investigate the issue. After providing him with documentation proving the cancellation, I never heard from him again.In my profession, I actually instruct people in proper customer service. As a consolation for my bad experience, I now have the perfect example of bad customer service which I will be using for illustration purposes.   This has literally been the worst customer service I have ever experienced. I spend approximately 150 nights per year staying in various hotels around the country. You should not have to fight this hard to get people to do their job. I am extraordinarily sorry that I chose Westin-Memphis.The hotel is a fairly nice spot. I have to say that the bathroom is pretty nice, with a standing shower and separate soaking tub. The room itself is fairly spacious and looks modern enough.The staff here is very kind and very attentive. There were plenty of people to great us and help make us feel invited.It's close to the FedEx Forum (where the Memphis Grizzlies play) and also close to the Rock n Soul Museum.Overall, a pretty good place to stayI just returned from a  four-night stay here. We were given a free upgrade to a deluxe corner room on the top (NBA) floor. How do I know it was the NBA floor? The shower heads were installed eight feet high! I could not even reach the diverter lever for the hand shower.The bathroom was spacious and clean, as was the room itself. The bed was super-comfortable. The room was quiet, despite the proximity to Beale St., and the AC worked perfectly. The room is equipped with a decent HD TV, but wi-fi service is $7 extra per day. The staff here was polite, friendly, and helpful. We didn't eat breakfast at the on-site restaurant, opting instead for Starbucks next door. I'm giving this hotel an unequivocal five stars for this: There is a glass case in the lobby displaying ten beautiful Gibson electric guitars, products of the factory across the street. I remarked to the desk clerk that I though they were cool, and she said, "Do you play?" I replied that I do, so she said, "Pick one you like, take up to your room, keep it as long as you wish, then bring it back when you want to try a different one." Wow! With it, they loan you an ampllfier-emulating effects pedal and headphones so as not to disturb the other guests. Awesome.Was able to check in as soon as I arrived !Around the corner from Beale St. Had  a great time at the hotel! One bad thing is that there was no free WiFi!I like Westin's. They are usually well appointed, clean and have great service. The Westin on Beale is very conveniently located across from the FedEx Center and around the corner from Beale st. WHEN YOU GO- The staff at this Westin was not only friendly and professional but HOT as well (always a plus in my book). If all this has been so great, why only three stars? Glad you asked. HAIR! I checked in exhausted from being crammed into the coffin of a plane known as United Air ( that's another review) and just wanted to get out of my suit and have a drink. Upon walking into the room, I checked the bathroom and was greeted by a dozen + long, black hairs on the floor and in the shower. Now I have to pick up all my stuff and go back down to the front desk to get a new room. Staff was apologetic and moved me to a room with a better view and hooray, no hair. I'll go back...with a lint roller!Read current reviews and book elsewhere. 4 days before my stay (reservations booked well in advance and confirmation # issued) I received an email notifying me that the hotel overbooked and they could not honor their commitment.This seems to be a trend with this hotel. I have stayed at hotels all across the world and have never been told just a few days in advance that I had no reservations. If the hotel continues to do this and people continue to complain online, they will not have any business so I guess the problem with "overbooking" will be solved.Interesting part is, the confirmation emails state: "Rest easy, your reservations have been confirmed" apparently this means nothing to this hotel. I would think that a hotel would rather have a few rooms go unsold rather than overbook and have unhappy customers. Unfortunately, this Westin will give all other Westin's (and Starwood properties for that matter) a black eye.  The email notifying me that they overbooked states: "I hope this email finds you having a delightful day. It is with regret that we must inform you that we will be unable to hold your reservations..." I was having a "delightful day" until I received this notification.I called Patrick Jordan - General Manager (or that's what it states in my confirmation email) and left a message. I called Don Michael Norwood Guest Services Manager - and left a message. I emailed Mr. Norwood. I then called and spoke with Paris in reservations. After I told her that I received an email she then stated that if I received an email last night or this morning then I no longer had reservations. She stated someone from management would be contacting me today or tomorrow. As of this writing - I have not heard from anyone. I did receive a second email confirming that the reservations were no longer good and that they would contact me.   I wish I could review the hotel itself - but considering I didn't get a chance to even see the hotel I can't. Considering how it appears this hotel is managed - I can only assume the qualities of the hotel are as poor as their reservation system. It would appear this hotel management puts profit above all else leaving its customers "out in the cold" -  literally.The second email I received provided hotels "in the area" that had rooms available - BOTH IN ANOTHER STATE - TUNICA, MS - approx. 30 miles and 45 minutes from Memphis. If I had wanted to stay at a casino I would have booked there in the first place.  I did NOT book through a 3rd party (Priceline, Kayak...etc.) so that cannot be used as an excuse from Westin.Avoid. There are many other hotels in Memphis that rate much higher. Such a shame for Westin and Starwood to be associated with service like this.A reasonable 3-star hotel, but not a 4-star hotel by any means. For the price, I can only give it 2 stars. The bed was very comfortable; however, there were a number of other minor issues that in combination did not contribute to a completely positive experience.For example, the bathtub was marginally clean (hair), bathroom tile was old and stained. The front desk is very small for a hotel this size and never appeared to be staffed with more than 1 (or often 0) people, making service very slow. I requested shaving cream and a razor twice and was told it would be delivered to my room; I never received them or any explanation. We attempted to go to the lobby bar after a long day on the road, but ended up waiting 10 minutes for service from the bartender who was engrossed in a conversation with another patron. Upon checkout, we were billed for a $5 candy bar from the honor bar that we never used; this was removed from our bill.In summary, a decent experience but not great, particularly for the purported 4-star rating. Having stayed in a number of other branches of this hotel chain, this location does not seem to be up to par.I've stayed in a lot of hotels, and I'm pretty picky when it comes to service. The desk clerk got us checked in fast and was very friendly. We ended up in a high room facing Beale. The room was clean and cool and well equipped. The bed was piled with pillows and down comforters and was very comfortable. I wish my bed at home was that luxurious. The bathroom was large and I was glad to see a separate tub and shower. The shower also had dual heads with was pretty awesome. The bathroom was stocked with a full size hair dryer and all of the mini toiletries you need. We were just there for one night, but the stay was nice. I loved that they had Starbucks coffee in the room, and after a night on Beale st I sure needed it. The hotel was just steps from Beale which made it very easy to walk wherever we wanted to go. I would definitely stay here again.Location: Excellent. Just a block away from Beale but that block makes a huge difference when you just want to come back to your room and sleep after a long day of work, while others are just waking up to go party! Property: Not the most exciting, but then who visits Memphis to spend time in their hotel? Decor: Liked the Gibsons guitars in the lobby! Room: I was upgraded and had a huge bathroom, which was fabulous!I made two reservations at this hotel 45 days prior to our arrival.  Seven days before our arrival, the manager called with a "courtesy call" saying the hotel had sold out to a group and I no longer had reservations at his hotel.  I couldn't believe it.  At that point, every other nice hotel was sold out.  I called SPG and they could do nothing, actually, I was quite surprised at the poor level of service I received when I called SPG customer service.I really loved my 3 night stay here.  I found the staff to be very friendly and accomadating.  They even asked us before we checked in if we wanted a Beale St. side and warned us that the music from Beale can get noisy.  Sounded perfect to us.  Our room was on the top floor overlooking Beale St and the baseball stadium a few blocks away.  The music was never too loud but added to the "Memphis experience".  The room was spacious as was the bathroom.  The shower stall was amazing.  The only drawback (and I don't really blame the hotel) is the amount of panhandlers as soon as you walk outside.  This is a tourist driven area and every 30 seconds some one is begging for a handout.  I think that's more of a city of Memphis problem but the hotel should provide some sort of security for its guests as well.I was lucky enough to be upgraded to a suite, and the suite was fine. However, the small things caught my attention. Stains on the carpet, small amounts of mold in the shower, towels not replenished when they should be, all made me feel as this was just shy of what it should be. Still, having been to Memphis many times, this remains the best hotel option in town.We didn't stay at the Westin, wished we would have.   We did however, have breakfast there 2 days and found the server staff especially Donna the best.  Next time for sure we'll stay at the Westin.  Great location, very modern and clean.   Parking deck attached which is important including self as well as valet parking.As a SPG Platinum trying to stay loyal to the product, this is the only place to stay when in Memphis. In total, my July 2010 stay was probably my 5th stay here. I would have to say that this is the best location in Memphis. 100 yards from Beal Street and all the fun that goes on there... Directly across the street from the Fed Ex Forum. I've been there around New Years when the Liberty Bowl is happening and this hotel is always the headquarters for one of the teams playing in the game. The rooms are are what you would expect from a Westin... Heavenly beds, dual shower heads... Very nice. If spending some time in Memphis, I can't think of another place I would rather stay!
review_content_60: Prior to my arrival at the Westin, I checked the Yelp reviews and was surprised a Westin had only 4 out of 5 stars. I'd say they're all 5 stars in my book, well, then I showed up. Being located 20 yards from drunk fest silky o  sullivans bar and the fact that you can walk around downtown memphis with open booze doesn't mean the guests of the hotel have any class. We mostly shared the elevator with complete drunks. As we walked down the hall to our room, there was catsup on the wall. Oh great.  I dont think its the Westins fault, is the fact that people have NO respect at all. Poor Westin.  I also thought the hallway smelled like pot. We arrived in our room to see the bed skirt was hanging off the bed and a huge stain the carpet.  All the informational cards had stains on them or 'crinkled' , folded corners. How challenging is it to have fresh, crisp promotional materials. I just felt like the room had some parties in it. The bed was heavenly, as well as the shower, the bathroom and over all room cleanliness was good. The staff always seemed busy but nice and informative when we needed them. The catsup was cleaned up within 20 minutes of me seeing it. That made me happy. The room was quiet and overall it was an okay experience but there are plenty of other nicer Westins. This hotel is 10 yards of the Fed Ex Forum and Beale Street. You really can't get any closer.Stayed here during the International Blues Challenge and for once got a great night's sleep in Memphis. The walls are thick, the rooms well arranged to keep you away from your neighbor's noise, and the air conditioning is quiet. While you hear the doors, you don't get much hall way conversation. And the bed... very comfortable. The staff was universally friendly and professional. Only touch an item in the honor bar/snack holder if you really want it... all automated. They are happy to bring you a separate fridge for your own snacks at no charge and they did this promptly. The on site restaurant "bleu" has a modern menu and everything I ate was fabulous, though slightly salty - apparently a regional taste preference. Just ask for no salt added. The room is not large, there's no table, just a desk and corner chair, but it is all very comfortable. Couldn't be more convenient to Beale... we performed at Blues Hall and it's right around the corner. For the finals at the Orpheum we only had to walk 2 blocks. Highly recommended.I read some negative reviews on this place before my visit and was a little worried about dirtiness and rudeness. I found neither. It was just like the place I expected when i booked it, and better. The location is perfect and the rooms are what you expect in a Westin. I was also worried about parking, but accidently found a place next door for $15 a day, which was better than the hotel was offering. It is right past the valet and is open to the general public. So all in all it was perfect for my trip. The price wasn't bad depending on your night of choice.Was here for a meeting.  Had a room overlooking the stadium which was a bit loud on game night, but otherwise this was a classic westin room and classic westin service.  Close enough to the touristy area to visit, but thankfully not right on the street.We wanted to stay in the downtown Memphis area at a place with a King sized bed and close to Beale St.Things I loved:- The PRICE! For a King sized bed, additional tub and its location? ($132/night) It was cheaper than other hotels in its area!- The shower head... As with all Westins, the heavenly shower made me extremely happy. :)-  An additional tub! I had been traveling the past three days and a nice soak was perfect.- The parking, for the reviewer who had a problem with parking, we had gotten the $18/day deal. But every time you park, you have to get the ticket stamped so that the cashier for the lot would not charge you. It was actually pretty cheap/convenient for us.- The staff. I know that someone had reviewed a problem with the staff, but we had no such experience and everyone was super friendly/our room was very well maintained. The person who checked us (sadly I don't remember her name) was incredibly helpful! All kinds of information, giving us a choice in what side of the hotel/view we wanted.- The view! I know it isn't the ocean. But I love city lights! :) :)Things I didn't love:- The self automated snack bar? I was terrified of putting anything near the set up, because if the weight changes in ANY way, they charge you!  TERRIFIED.This hotel will never have our business again.  Stay here at the risk something could get stolen and neither Guest Services Mangers will do anything about it.  Long story short I left my purse with my wallet in it in the room for a couple of hours while we were out and one of my credit cards was stolen.   I discovered it was missing when my bank called and asked about 500 dollars in charges that seem out of the ordinary.  I looked in my wallet and saw that one of my cards was in fact gone. I spoke to Gary immediately who took a report but never filed it.  I spoke to Don the next morning since Gary said he would leave the report for him to review and that he would contact me before we checked out.   Don did not know anything so we filed another report.   We checked out the hotel that day and have heard from them once confirming that one of their staff did come in our room when we were out.  He said he would call me again after they had more information and here it is 2 1/2  weeks later and we have heard nothing.  We finally called Starwood Corporate and reported the issue to them.  They had not heard anything from Gary or Don either.  They offered us some points as a "we are sorry this happened" gesture and said they would try and get some answers.   We are not holding our breath that anything will be done.The noise is killing me. The loud music until 5am for the cost is terrible. The hotel location is wonderful and the hotel is lovely but I would never come here for work or with a family. Being here on a girls weekend is still so hard. No sleep is no fun.Great hotel, great staff, and great smelling lobby.I stayed here for the Memphis Marathon Weekend.  I was able to check in early and got a nice room on the top floor with a view of Beale Street.  The beds were comfy and the shower was fantastic.  If you like coffee, there's a machine in the room.  The in room coffee makers scare me, so I hit up the Starbucks around the corner.  Oh, and everything else - food, shopping, hotels, bars, museums, and the Gibson Guitar factory are around the corner.  Bonus part of the stay, there was an NBA team staying on my floor.  The Fedex Forum is across the street, so if you stay here you might see some famous faces.  Price is quite steep, but overall a good stay.We stayed here on our way home from Mississippi back home to Chicago. It was a beautiful hotel just on the other side of Beale Street. The staff was delightful and the rooms (beds and shower) clean and comfortable. Will definitely stay here again on the next trip to Memphis.Other than the beggars right outside the entrance, this place was clean and comfortable. We ordered room service one night in and they only brought out one of our dishes. I'm sure that was just an isolated incident. Close walking distance to Beale Street and The Memphis Redbirds stadium. There's a Starbucks just around the corner for coffee lovers like me. I was very pleased with the room and view. Bathroom was huge. Separate tub and shower...which was luxurious with duel shower heads. Parking garage is conveniently connected to the hotel. Very good location. I'd stay here again.Got a great deal on Expedia. GREAT LOCATION if you want to party on Beale and be close to Mud Island. As Westin's go, nice hotel, nice bar, nice restaurant, great concierge, nice Heavenly double head shower and Heavenly beds. Starbucks right around the corner. Great workout facility in the hotel. Did I mention the great location? Its also right across the street from the Fed-X Forum arena. As cities go, hate paying for garage parking per day, way too expensive. I would have given 5 stars but the hotel did not clean my room. Granted, we had the tranquility sign out till 11, they should have come back and cleaned. I did call and got a loud fresh towels right out of the dryer but I was super disappointed in the housekeeping service. My other issue was my room faced Beale so you could hear those Blues all night long. If you stay here, be SURE to request a room facing the opposite wayMy stay was Excellent!!! Just a minutes walk for the excitement on Beale street. The hotel is very clean. My room was perfect. The bathrooms are huge! My bed was Extra Comfy. This will always be my hotel of choice while visiting Memphis. It's just one thing I didn't like $24 a day to PARK!!!! WTF....Fab hotel and the best location.  Agree with others to request a room away from Beale Street.  The hotel and staff are awesome.  Always greeted you with a smile and very willing to help. The valet staff was superb.  Very helpful and gave us coupons to Graceland. Room service very pricey but their molten chocolate cake was to die for.My husband and I stayed at the Westin on Valentines Day a few years ago. It was a great little package deal. We had a private catered dinner on one floor of the hotel, with only a few other couples scattered throughout the large banquet room. A 4 course deal, with an excellent filet, fresh steamed veggies, hot buttered bread, and creme brulee for dessert. The servers were extra attentive, and the ambiance was quiet and romantic with low lights and candles scattered throughout the room. Our room itself was beautifully decorated with a comfy mattress and a great shower (I won't go into details here because many of the other reviewers already have). One of the things that I have always thought was extra clever about this hotel? One floor is supersized- high ceilings and doorways as well as extra-long beds to attract all of the out of town NBA ballers coming in to take on the Grizzlies. As the hotel is located just steps away from FedEx Forum, this concept is supersmart.The Westin Hotel downtown Memphis is one of my favorite spots to visit for Happy Hour ... I have enjoyed the great customer service, I get every time I walk thru the doors, most of the employees know my name because I always go to the Grizzlies games from there... Just recently they became one of my vendors for Lotus Energy Drink and have made it a house hold name for their customers, as the bartenders always have a new drink made with our product avail for me to try... I give the managers Lance and Lance two thumbs up for their professionalism and efforts of keeping the Westin Bar and Restaurant a great place to visit for lunch as well as dinner... Oh yeah! And don't forget the all you can eat Crab Legs on Friday night and Live Smooth Jazz music at the lobby bar as well .... As a matter of fact I'm headed there now!!!!!The beautiful wife and I came to Memphis for our anniversary, and based on rates via the various travel sites (and previous Yelp reviews), the Westin was our choice ($132 for a king)We were very pleased -- the "heavenly" concept for the rooms (and that great dual shower head) lived up to its name.  With the curtains drawn, you are bound to sleep like a babe (though I recommend having a fan brought to your room.  The air circulation isn't the greatest).Checkin was pretty much a breeze (though there was only one person working at 2:30, when the official checkin time is 3:00 -- you'd think they're have more people ready).The bathroom is huge -- as noted above, and in others reviews, that shower head is really nice.  The tub isn't worth much unless you're a petite female.  And the fan clears out the condensation quickly.The view isn't anything, but unless you're looking at an ocean, who really cares about the view?Upon leaving, the parking situation started to bug me.  We self-parked and paid through the hotel ($18 or 19 per day).  But then I realized the garage wasn't an hourly, it was a per-entry.  The days we were there, I think it was $5 on Wednesday and $6 on Thursday (didn't look for Friday).  So we ended up paying around $60 for $17 worth of going in-and-out.So, if you're sticking close to the hotel and not going in/out all the time, park yourself and pay at the garage gate.  Oh well, lesson learned.Except for no free breakfast, this is a lovely hotel. I got a great deal from Westin too, the first night I paid the last two digits of my birth year (hey, did you know I was born in 1925) and the second night was $199. Fair deal in my opinion considering the location (steps from Beale Street) and the high quality rooms. Very nice showers, yes, everyone likes the showers.And there was some lovely live music in the restaurant on Sunday morning from this goddess singing "Across the Universe".I love staying at Westin hotels because I can wallow (yes, wallow) in their lovely pillow-top beds.  This Westin was no exception, and had the added bonus of being close to everything my group would need to reach during our stay.  This hotel has decent space, very large bathrooms (another Westin staple) and friendly, helpful concierge and bell staff.  The front desk staff was a little stand-offish, which was only really apparent as a contrast to everyone else with whom I interacted.  The lobby seating space is comfortable and variable, with room for several groups to be seated without bothering one another.  The one oddity is the passage between the hotel and the adjacent garage (not owned by the Westin).  You exit the luxurious, modern lobby through heavy metal fire doors and are immediately in a cold, stark concrete hallway.  If you want to get to the garage without having to go up a set of stairs, you must exit completely outside and go up the sidewalk.  It was just a bit odd to me, but I guess the garage is also used for the sports/concert venue across the street.Overall, a much better experience than my first Memphis trip (to the Peabody).  A professional staff, good size rooms and great location will trump every time.Do not stay here. Internet didn't work - had to spend 45 minutes on the phone with a separate customer service operator upon arrival. Also, TV signal kept going out. The room was fairly nice and clean. Biggest complaint, however, is the noise and a rude manager. When we checked in we asked if they had a quiet room (meaning NOT facing Beale St.) They lied and said "Yes, we'll put you in a quiet room" and put us in a room facing Beale St. which was so loud all night we couldn't sleep. We called the next morning to see if they had any other rooms. Nope, all booked. We asked to check out. They told us we would be charged for the remaining night. So we spoke with a manager about checking out. His name was Don. He told us under no circumstances would they refund us for the remaining night. My husband told him, "That is unethical, since you lied about the quiet room. If the front desk had been honest, we would have simply gone to another hotel." The manager then said, "Stop calling me names. I'm going to charge you with slander!" Really?! First, Don should look up the definition of slander in the dictionary. My husband responded, "Sir, I did not call you a name. I said "that was unethical," referring to your choice of action." The manager proceeded to argue with my husband, claiming we were calling him names. Really, we cannot believe that a hotel manager would be so rude to a customer under any circumstance. We were not refunded, but we will never again stay here or recommend it to our clients, family, or friends.Very nice hotel.  Very nice staff.  Great location!
review_content_80: A most disapointing stay.  They charge 18 to park in a lot that is 5- 10 dollars for the public, but they don't mention you could opt out of their charge.  They charge 3.00 for a  mini bottle of water, that they have next to to the room coffee.- in very small fine print is the charge.  The bed and location were good, but if I was to return I would go to the Hamtpon insted. For the price they continue to nickel and dime you to death.I love Westins what can I say! I stayed here with my family on Friday May 8th and held a graduation reception on May 9th in the Tennessee Room. My lil sis was graduating from U of Mphs at the Fed Ex forum - it was perfect to be able to walk right across the street the morning of the graduation. We also got a great room rate on line at $199! This Westin is great for walking down to Beale Street - less than 50 steps away!! I don't think it has a pool of spa but it does have a workout facility. Also, we had a little reception after the graduation in the Tennessee Room - let me say get the Black Eye Pea Hummus!!! yummy Marquis, Alfonso, Jennifer, Juli and Jeff all were fantastic!I love The Westin anyways, but location here is awsome. Walk to The Beale street. Visit sun studio, blues museum and Gibson guitar. We only could stay two nights there but I enjoyed every moment of it. Corner room, quiet and very helpful staff. I think overall experience was awsome.This hotel is just fine for what you're looking for!  It's nicely furnished, clean rooms and classy interior lobby, etc. You couldn't ask for a better location!  Beale street is right around the corner, and the river walk is just a few blocks away. The restaurant is very good.  Food and service.  As far as the staff goes, well, you will receive service that goes beyond and above!!!!  Amanda at the desk was so very accommodating, willing to extend the effort, and very honest and sweet!  Steven was oh so down to earth, professional, and made us feel at home, and Calvin greeted us with smiles, good conversation, and a welcoming attitude.  We can't remember the bartenders name, but he had a great sense of humor and provided us with great recommendations.  Wonderful stay!  Employees enhance the stay and care about your personal experience!  As far as price?  No different than anywhere else.  You're on vacation.  People love to complain on this site and every other site.  Everyone's a critic.  This us a positive review!Exceptional location, but the service left much to be desired.  Our room was not properly cleaned prior to our arrival - evidence included trash in garbage cans left over from the previous occupant. Strike 1.Our bedding and towels were stained - makeup on the towel and a mysterious black stain on a pillow.  Not the end of the world, but kind of gross. 2nd strike.The most disappointing aspect of our stay was the fee associated with WiFi use. Practically every hotel I've ever stayed in (including the crummy airport Hilton that I bunked at my first night in TN) offers free WiFi as a courtesy to its guests. The 3rd and final strike.However, if location is important (and you are able to look past the aforementioned issues), you really can't do much better. Its proximity to Beale Street makes it an ideal spot to hang your hat for a few days.Also worth mentioning are the valets. Extremely friendly, polite and eager to help. Not the worse place I've ever stayed in, but definitely doesn't live up to the hype.As a regular traveler to Memphis (on business), I am thrilled to have another good hotel option downtown.  The Marriott, located at the other end of Main Street (bordered by 2nd Street), is frequently booked with conventioneers, and The Peabody is both old and expensive.  My taste tends to run to the modern, the spare and the luxurious.  The Memphis Westin doesn't have the concrete floors of The Shore Club in South Beach (and thank goodness for that), but the style, for the most part, is that of understated, unflashy elegance.  I'll take it.There is some variability between the rooms of this newly opened hotel (May 2007).  While my room was spacious, well lit (ask for a high floor for both light and quiet) and had a rather extraordinary bathroom, my colleague's handicapped accessible room was a little, well, sad by comparison.  Whereas I had a gorgeous steam shower separate from the soaking tub, he had a shower suitable for wheelchair access including a pull down in-shower bench and an open closet with very low clothing racks.  Note: I'm glad, of course, that this nice new hotel has lots of accessible rooms; I was just confused by the fact that they gave my colleague one when the hotel wasn't full.Anyway.  Like other Westins I have stayed at, service isn't its strong suit.  Room service breakfasts took too long, and one day, housekeeping never did show up.  I keep my room pretty neat anyway, and there's a Starbucks downstairs; as long as the TV and internet work when I'm in the room...cool.  I'm cool.Not a fan of the hotel restaurant, an outpost of The Daily Grille.  But it's a chain and I tend to be anti-chain (other than chains selling coffee, in which case I ask "where can I get a franchise?"), but the Memphis people seem to be enjoying a break from the barbecue of nearby Beale Street.Valet parking is expensive, but a must.  Memphis has some issues with crime, violent and not, so if you're traveling, do it.  If you're a woman traveling alone, do not hesitate to valet.Rack rate hovers around $250/night.  Not cheap so search around for discounts before bookingMy husband and I visited Memphis for the first time this past week.  As a gay couple, we weren't quite prepared for the reception we got in this city, but the staff at Westin (with the exception of one manager; think his name was Patrick) set the tone for what was to be a fabulous experience.  Upon check-in, the staff took ample time to explain the highlights of the area; even embellishing with some of their personal faves.  We are a very low-key couple, so we chose to indulge in the bar located in the lobby of the hotel; Beale Street was unbearably loud.  The housekeeping staff, Sabrina in particular were phenomenal.  It seemed we continued to get superior service from the staff even when we were not there.  One person moonlights at Rhodes College in their on-campus pub, while another moonlights at the airport.  Even on these occassions, these people were quite friendly.  Our one hiccup:  After sitting at the bar one night, we decided to venture over to Beale Street just for the heck of it.  Well, we pretty much turned around to retreat back to the hotel's bar.  Before sitting, we asked the bartender (Courtney) if it was too late for service.  He welcomed us with open arms and stated there was absolutely "no rush" (very conscious of this because I bartended for years).  At this time, there were two other gentleman at the bar (who did not look like us - wink).  As soon as the left the overnight manager, Patrick (?), came over with much urgency in his voice telling the bartender over and over in front of us that he had to close immediately.  The bartender was taken aback, as were we; he politely excused himself from the bar to have a conversation with the manager.  Upon return, with manager in tow, we were apologized to, and even offered a glass of wine on the house.  Although this somewhat tainted the remainder of our stay, I refuse to shave off any stars because of this one person.  As we were packing to leave, we noticed the light on the phone blinking: a message from Courtney apologizing once again.  In the words of my Granny, "One monkey don't stop no show."  Ooops, I almost forgot: Joan you were the bomb.Location location location.This hotel is right by Beale St (comes in handy while walking home and drinking a Diver) and is across the street from the Fedex Forum (we ran into some Utah Jazz players there during our stay).Rooms were great, comfy beds, GREAT bathroom. The concierge was very friendly and helpful. They don't have a hotel shuttle from the airport, so you're gonna have to rent a car or cough up 30 bucks for a cab.Prices were a bit high, but again, location location location.Beautiful hotel! Great location! Great bath amenities! Awesome towels! Great beds! Reasonable rates! Here is an insider tip, always ask for a room that ends in 01. These rooms have the best corner views! Two minor, minor drawbacks: the front desk staff is too lean and no concierge room for elite members.Let me start off by saying I am a Starwood Preferred Guest Gold member...which means I stay at a lot of Westn hotels throughout the nation. I am a huge fan and love Starwood and Westin.The Westin in Memphis is a beautiful hotel and the location is perfrect. You're right on Beale Street and just a few blocks from amazing Memphis attractions like The National Civil Rights Museum (the site of the Lorraine Motel where MLK was assassinated), within a mile of Sun Studios, Stax, et al.The service and attention to detail at this hotel is awful. It's pretty much the newest - and nicest - hotel in downtown Memphis but the staff leaves much to be desired. The only exception was the valets. They were great...espeially Rob. Here is what happened to us on our three night stay there:1. Staff at check in was not very friendly, and frankly, standoffish. This is your first experience with the hotel and it is not good.2. Rooms were maintained well but several things were missing in our room including pillows, coffee, soap and other small items that tell me housekeeping is not very good.3. Because Beale Street attracts all types, there are lots of beggars on the adjoining streets and the hotel doesn't try to disuade them in any way. I know they can't stop it bu they really don't have an real security that I could see.4. Our last night there, a water pipe broke and we had no water into the next morning. They did NOTHING to proactively communicate what had happened or what was happening to the guests. We paid top dollar to stay here and I couldn't even shower before my long trip home the next day. Not even an apology or "make good" for one of their most loyal guests. It was just unacceptable.5. Due to the water issue, the elevators were not working. When we checked out, we got lucky that a maid walked by and offered to take us in the service elevator. Had we not seen here, we would have been in the dark. Awful.Again, I am an incredibly loyal Westin customer. But this experience was awful...but in Memphis, there isn't much else.Checked in at 1 a.m. without all my baggage.... was greeted as a weary/bleary traveller should be.  Clean, up-to-date.  Slept like a baby in an uber comfy bed.  The double "heavenly shower" heads were an especially welcome touch the next morning.  [and i also got it for a steal through hotwire)I have to agree with the negative reviews.  This is a hotel that charges $260+ a night for luxury beds, bedding, and decor.  But the staff is cold (a lot like the modern decor) and there is no way in the world I would ever spend that kind of money again on a hotel room.  For that kind of money, I expect to be greeted warmly and treated like a guest -- not just another number.Very clean and up to date as most all Westin Hotels are. We stayed here because it is "very" close to FedEx Forum; like across the street close. If you are attending an event, such as a concert like we were, staying here is perfect. It books up quick, so reserve your room(s) early! Expect to pay the "quality price" that Westin asks for. Staff was pleasant and attentive. Even though you are in downtown Memphis, there are some safeguards such as having to use your key to get to a floor when entering the elevators. My wife and I did not venture downstairs to eat at the Sole Restaurant that is on property. We were just enjoying the moment of being away from the house and kids and getting ready for the concert we were attending. However, we did order room service from the room service menu. The food comes from Sole Restaurant downstairs. Food was great, room service was fast that early in the evening. Later that night, the wait was up to 45 minutes for a piece of cheesecake. We opted out of that one. Self parking for $18 or valet for $25? WAY easier to just valet for the few bucks extra.

review_content: It was a nice hotel. But I couldn't understand for the life of me why most of the channels on the tv didn't work. And I was in a Hilton Honors room. But besides the tv it was nice. Parked on the street for free so I didn't have to pay $25 valet. The lobby was slick depressing. It didn't look bad it just made me sad. Personal problem right?  I'm used to the Westin. But seriously they should consider making it brighter and add contemporary furnishings. And there should be a lobby bar. The TGI Friday one doesn't count.  If they had a bar I think they could have cool nightly entertainment on the stage in their lobby. But you know no one is really thinking about the lobby when they go to a hotel except me.  It was a nice hotel.  I can't say how it compares to other Hilton properties. But it's not a ratchet place.Let me preface this two star review by saying that this review does not reflect the staff inside the hotel. Upon check-in and throughout our stay the front desk to housing keeping was friendly and polite. With that said, Hilton needs to strongly consider renovating this hotel. Our floor, the 10th, smelled funky, the carpet dated, and our room was small with obvious "repairs" made, primarily in the bathroom. The room was clean but the bed uncomfortable and the tv had a very limited channel selection. I found all of this odd as a Silver HHonors member, I stay in various Hilton partners hotels often and Double Tree is usual very nice. This two star review would be a one star if it wasn't for the inside staff. What dropped this hotel is the fact that the valet dented the rear bumper of my rental car. When informed, they did not argue this and wrote it up. As of right now nothing has come of it and I'm hoping the rental company doesn't notice the damage. I'll update this review as needed.Pros: comfortable and clean room. Nice staff who checked me in at 11pm on a Tuesday. Cons: called for room service breakfast at 6:40 and 7am, and no one picked up to take my order after a good 1-2 minutes of ringing.  (The menu states room service starts at 6am) I pre-ordered 3 large bottles of  water ($2 each) to be in my room upon checking in, and there were two tiny bottles of Nestle water.  Lastly, when I woke in the morning I discovered there's a window A/C unit in my room. There's no central air/heat even though, oddly enough, there's a control on the wall.  But there are no air intake or returns in the room.  This wasn't a problem since the room temperature was fine, but worth noting for the review.If this hotel represents the Hilton Hotel brand, then Hilton is in trouble.  We are Diamond Hilton members and stayed on the Hilton Honors floor.  The room on this "special" floor was anything but special.  Good grief--I wonder what the non Honors rooms look like?The hall had a weird old stale cigarette smell.  In our room, the curtains did not match, did not close and had holes in them.  The HVAC had issues--we could not turn on the heat.  The room did not go above 63 degrees!  There were leak stains on the ceiling.  The windows were old and thin and you could hear everything from the street outside from our room on the 8th floor.We valet parked the car.  It took us 40 minutes to get our car.  While I was waiting, I noticed that the valet attendants left the car key rack/box unattended and wide open.  I could have had a field day stealing cars.  We decided to not valet park our car on the second night of our stay.  We let the front desk and the valet people know that we would not valet our car but it still showed up on the bill.  Frustrating.We asked if we could check out a day early.  This hotel is the pits and we wanted to move to another hotel in the city.  They told us there would be a $50 early checkout fee.  It was 9am when we asked.  I thought you had until 6pm to cancel.  Whatever.  So much for that Diamond status.The breakfast for the hotel was offered by the TGI Fridays adjacent to the hotel.  THAT restaurant was a disaster.  The hotel should be embarrassed to be affiliated with that restaurant.If you are in downtown Memphis, don't bother with this hotel.  The only good thing about it is the location.  Other than that, stay at The Peabody across the street.Nothing bad during my stay! I admit after reading some other reviews I was a bit nervous to book a room here! Service was great at every level. Let's talk about the parking situation. Valet only- yes pretty weird, however it works. Yes at 5pm I decided to circle the block a few times until the very small driveway had enough room for my tiny car. If you prefer to skip the whole scene, park at a nearby lot (I counted 6 reasonable lots within a very easy walk, even at the other Hilton property Hampton Inn) and just roll your luggage to this Doubletree. If you go valet, they are fast and friendly. . .don't be scared, Memphis is teeny-tiny. The room, nothing special but certainly nothing terrible. Noise- not an issue. I am a terribly light sleeper, on the 10th floor (Rm 1019 on a corner) and didn't hear anyone ever. Not a great view (but who cares, Memphis is not known for its skyline!).The room was acceptably clean and well maintained. (Here during a tremendous heatwave the AC was able to keep up while in the 100's outside). Even with the parking issues I like this location more than the other Hilton property downtown Hampton Inn. You sleep in a hotel but otherwise go outside and listen to some great Memphis music! (This review applies to International travelers, very good safe location and Memphis is super hospitable to Euro travelers. . .yes even you Brits ; ) )Spent the weekend in Memphis, Tennessee for a conference. I cheated on Marriott, it was worth it for the cookies. I'm just kidding, but the cookies at check-in are delicious. All of the front desk staff were friendly and very accommodating.  We were given our breakfast buffet coupons and when we needed a cab they had our driver there before we even got off the elevator.I like the location of this hotel because it's so conveniently located to Memphis Cook Convention Center and also to Beale Street. When I called down to the front desk about toiletries that I had forgotten, I was just about to offer to go downstairs to pick them up when the clerk told me it would be delivered right up. And it was, there was a knock on the door from housekeeping in less than 3 minutes. Excellent service all the way. The only disappointment was Sunday breakfast in the TGIF. Our used plates were never cleared and the coffee was never refreshed. I like this hotel and would stay again.Terrible service! After staying here for every week for 3 years straight, my misfortune that I was stuck in the Hospital and wanted to extend the room for the family, but was turned down because of " March Madness". 3 years of putting up with "bad rooms, cockroaches in the roomFor a doubletree I was kind of disappointed. The room was kind of falling apart. From the blinds not opening to the hole in the closet door. The floor was sticky. The positive is its down the block from beale street. The only block with entertainment it seems and the hotel lobby isn't too bad. Staff was nice. Just had problems with third party booking with this hotel. If I had to stay in Memphis again (which I probably wont) i don't think I would stay here.This hotel has a pretty lobby and friendly staff, but the rooms are run down and not well kept. The house keeping is what really lacks here: mirror has smears, there are stains on the wall, stains on the bathroom door, and scary mold or dirt in the shower tile grout. I want to stay in a clean room with no sign of anyone there before me.At the price point it's OK. The desk staff were welcoming and courteous. Housekeeping people could not have been nicer to us. Warm cookies were lovely. Valets were fairly prompt.  I thought that the HHonors app was pretty nice the way it lets you choose your room like a seat on a plane. And the confirmations and info by email all great. The location is great. Essentially same convenience as when staying at the Peabody at about a third of the price. Much more convenient than the Madison, which is only a few blocks away but seems isolated from the restaurants, etc.  Short walking distance from Tamp & Tap, which is a huge deal for coffee people.Room was clean. Re-purposed historic building, so some rooms have lots of windows, which is cool.  The historic facade rebuilt in the lobby was cool.  We aren't really TGI Fridays people so didn't check out the morning breakfast buffet but it looked OK. This property caters to a younger clientele than the Peabody across the street, so the service level is going to be different. In the porte-cochere you're more often than not seeing people unloading and loading their luggage themselves. Also, on a Saturday night, the lobby can be rather boisterous at times. Parking: $22 per day is just wrong. I'll tip the valet. But $22?  Yeah I get it that this extortion is common throughout downtown Memphis. But this ain't SF  or NYC.  That it's widespread doesn't make it right. It's not that desirable to be down there. If the public garage operators lowered their day prices to 10 you might see a renaissance of interest by the locals who don't like to go down there now because of astronomical parking rates. I suspect that those structures would be filled.Lighting.  Some of the wood blinds in the room appear to have been intentionally disabled so that they could not be raised. I need natural light. Especially in this era of ugly blindness-inducing fluorescent bulbs. My God how I detest CFL lighting. Especially first-generation. I get all stabby. Like the rats in the famous experiment with yellow and pink fluorescent tubes back in the 60s.  If this is the future, it's going to be a dim dystopian one indeed. And the lobby. Come on. It's the best feature of the hotel.  I really wish that the lobby was lit in something other than cold-blue CFL. The lobby and public areas are attractive and the designer's work is just ravaged by ugly cold lighting. I get that there is an energy saving connected with those hellish lights, but must people never come first in this brave new world? I had the same complaint about the Westin Beale St. so you're in good company.Noise.  I asked for and got room 433, which overlooks the ball park and the intersection of Union and Third. Cool idea in concept. Never again. Go for the highest floor available. Something higher than 7.  This is a historic building so not soundproofed the way a new property might be. So, OK.  Just be aware that if one tries to work in a low-floor room during the day, one learns very quickly that Beale Street is visited predominantly by Harley riders and fools in exhaust-mod pickups both of whom feel the burning need to rev engine three to four times during the stop light and then burn out when it changes to green.
