And they all head out of town down Union St.  The windows don't block out that noise, so just be aware.Working in the hotel: This place is fine for partiers, vacationers and casual visitors.  I would not stay here again if I needed to work in the room. I had to work this weekend but was really frustrated by weak wireless. No ethernet connections.  At all. There was a prop ethernet connection on the desk. It was a prop because it was not connected to anything.  Wireless was so weak in the lobby and in the room that the signal was crowded out by the much stronger ones from other users' hotspots and the Holiday Inn across the street. We were dropped every two minutes.  I had to connect through my iPhone to get usable vpn.  I walked around looking for signal and found that it was very strong on 10, but there were only rooms up there so, if you have to work try to get a room on 10, or go to Tamp & Tap.Finally, I think that the Hilton flag implies a little higher standard of physical plant upkeep. Light fixture in bathroom had come undone from its anchors and was drooping down over the sink; Windows were filthy on the outside, really smeared and covered in grime.  Wireless strength needs to be punched up. The A/C is really loud. It vibrates at a low frequency,  Until I realized what it was, I thought they were sanding a wood floor upstairs.Lets start off, its not a terrible hotel. On the plus side, its in a super great location right downtown Memphis and across from the ballpark and the Peabody hotel. the lobby is very nice and I personally found the desk staff and valet parking folks very helpful and cheerful.On the down side, the A/C-Heater in my room as pretty noisy and the room was only just clean enough. the room size was good and the rooms all seemed to have what you'd expect from a Hilton. The TFIG Fridays that in the lower level of the hotel is pretty terrible and although it hard to believe, breakfast was at best mediocre, for sure not worth the $12 for the buffet, better choices can be found nearby. Be warned, DO NOT TAKE A ROOM THAT FACES SOUTH unless you want to keep the window blinds closed tight all night, there is a giant LED sign that flashes all night long across the parking lot and its super annoying.I stayed here for a business trip so the price did not sting too much, but if I had the choice, I'd have stayed at the Peabody.Disappointment is the only word I can use to describe this Doubletree.  As I walked into the lobby I grew excited because it looked like a really nice hotel. When I got to my room the disappointment grew with every step I took into the room. From the bathroom that we in need of a good cleaning (rust) to the doors and walls needing fresh paint. It was just one let down after another. To make matters worse for those of us business travelers beware. There is NO desk in the rooms in which to work on. The resturant (TGI Fridays) attached to the hotel is HORRIBLE. Bad food, worse service, and even worse attitudes by employees.The lobby is decent, the staff is friendly, but my room was awful. There wasn't enough light in the room, the blinds were broken, the curtains didn't close, I was in the 3rd floor and all night I heard the drunk people walking on the street, the cars passing by, the outlets in the bathroom were crooked, the bathroom door didn't close... What a nightmare! I basically could not sleep in 3 days... Don't stay here!I will kind of echo a lot of reviews posted about this hotel.The location is great . The staff is great. The room is spacious and clean. The cost is high and it's not that special of a place. I would stay here again only if rates weren't as high. I don't think you get what you pay for here. The only extras we got were 2 cookies when we arrived and 2 free glasses of wine on second night of stay.We were very disappointed in this property, for a variety of reasons. I will say that the valet & bellmen were spot on when we arrived & the front desk staff were so friendly & helpful. It's definitely these 2 groups that earned the 1 star I gave. We were there on business and took a client out to dinner & came back to the hotel lobby to have a drink and wrap up. The restaurant adjacent to the hotel was remodeling so their bar was set up in the lobby, along with the only entrance to the restaurant. There was a girl who was obviously inebriated being given drinks by security & talking loudly and obnoxiously to everyone walking through the front door. She caused more than one scene throughout the hour we set there and was finally escorted out after she dropped a glass on the floor. (The one security had given her minutes before.) I was embarrassed that we had brought anyone here on business, much less that this was where we were staying for 3 days.The walls are PAPER THIN. Our neighbor rocked out on Beale Street his first night in town & I could hear him crying around the next morning on the phone. However, just to paint a solid picture of how thin the walls are, I could also hear the woman he was talking to clearly & she wasn't on speakerphone.Housekeeping skipped our room on the first day & on the day we left, it had begun raining sometime in the night & a waterfall had commenced in the downstairs hallway from a leaking ceiling. Nobody seemed concerned about it either. I was glad we were getting out of there. The room was dimly lit & the curtains wouldn't close all the way, so the morning sun was sure to get you up with it. The shower dripped so much that there was a constant puddle in front of the tub.I hope we never have to stay here again. Ever.Nice use of existing building in the lobby for a great architectural aspect. Paid valet is a down side for me. Location is great.Easily one of the worst Doubletree/Hilton-affliated hotels I've stayed in. I've been to other Doubletrees in the country and they have always been awesome experiences so I was excited to find out we would be spending a weekend here. However, I was left very disappointed. The only reason this place deserves a star is thanks to its location. Conveniently right in the middle of downtown Memphis, this hotel is across the street from Autozone Park, the Peabody and the Children's museum. Only a few short walkable blocks from the very popular Beale Street and Sun Studio . Also the staff was very courteous and accommodating but they could not make up for the shortcomings of this hotel. As expected, DoubleTree typically charges for parking, but I found the $22 required valet parking to be very excessive in a city with plenty of parking areas and generally very uncrowded. The lobby was maintained very well but unfortunately that did not translate to nice rooms. The first room we stayed in was a very cramped standard room with an awful smell that just lingered. No personal fridge was available. There is a $15 buffet breakfast option located at the TGIFridays within the hotel. From what my friend told me, the selection was not very good and nothing tasted fresh. Now, what completely grossed me out of this place was when we were moved to a King room and found a huge yellow stain on the comforter. It was NOT something you could easily overlook. After staying in two different style rooms here, it appears they need to renovate with a fresh coat of paint and deep clean the carpets. This place just did not live up to Hilton-standards and my overall stay was very unpleasant. Would not recommend.A little dated and overall cleanliness needs to be improved.  Valets were great.  TGIF attached is dirty and service is poor.  Only had breakfast there and would not recommend it.Good locationGreat hotel. Service at the front desk, at valet and at breakfast was friendly, pleasant and helpful. My traveling companion is an Honors member, so that may be why we had nice service but he can be a pokey lil Honors guy, asking for corner rooms, upgrades, free water, rollout beds, free breakfast, more free breakfast, etc.. and still. Great time.It's right on the main road in to downtown Memphis, just a few blocks from Sun Studios (wow!!), next door to The Peabody (see the ducks!!), attached to a TV I FRIDAYS and across from Denny's, and across from the minor league stadium. Oh wait there's more. It's a two block w alkaline to Beale Street, FedEx Forum, and Rendezvous Ribs. Score!There is valet parking, but it's expensive: I think over $20 a day. And this was the day before the big concert at FEDEX.  The morning buffet breakfast and omelet station take place in TGIFridays. More great service and a ton of delicious breakfast basics: multiple eggs, multiple sausages and bacons, cereal, bagels, a toaster, etc.The Hotel Atmosphere and lobby are rad. Definitely recommend staying here.DoubleTree's always have good service, but the staff here is exceptional! Very nice and accommodating.
review_content_20: Refused to make us an omelet with real butter. I offered to get him some from another part of the restaurant and he refused. I was denied the right to safe and healthy food.  Not to mention the poor attitude and lack of hospitality.The staff varies greatly as evidenced above. Good location. Valet parking is $22.My friends father, hooked my crew up with a hotel room here, for our first night in Memphis.  The room, though we were not there long, (stayed up pretty late on Beale street and riding around Midtown) was great!  I wish we could have stayed here the whole week but we had to leave after one night!  The staff were all super polite asking us how our day was, and they even had an awesome piano player playing awesome Jazz/Blues Standards in the lobby when we arrived!  The location of this hotel is 2nd to none, right across the street from the Memphis Red Birds Stadium, a couple blocks from Beale, and within walking distance of Sun Studios!  If you are going to stay down town Memphis, I would reccamend the Doubletree to anyone!Fairly safe place to stay in downtown. I was given accommodation here during my interview here. People always talk about the Peabody next door but this is a good hotel. Interesting thing is when you walk in, you will notice a wall with windows preserved from the original building. It gives a nice touch to the interior. I was very happy with the room service. They had live music in the evening. Happy hour was really something with drinks and live jazz. I would recommend this place to anyone who is staying here for a game, just want to walk to the night life or just enjoy Memphis.Not horrible, but would look elsewhere when visiting again.  Here's some things that I experienced that I felt were not typical for a Hilton. I added  a rooming partner to my reservation. I called and confirmed she was on the reservation since I was arriving very late after her.. When my room mate tried to  check in - she was informed she not listed on my room. She ended up having to show the front desk my email re: the confirmation as they had NO INFORMATION noted about her. The shower leaked (we could not shut it off) and had to call for maintenance (which came promptly). Also our room  (509) was very dimly lit.. we had to request extra lamps/ and a table. I tried to call for room service one night around 8:45 pm on 1/24 -   no one ever answered. I gave up and went out. The restaurant for breakfast was understaffed. I showed up Wed. trying to get a seat/find a menu - only one waitperson seemed to be working? It was IBC week - surely the hotel could have had another person working. I gave up and did not eat in the hotel at all  the entire week.This hotel is not what one would expect for a Hilton branded hotel, nor what you would expect paying $200 per night, nor what I expect as a Hilton Honors Member. We stayed 4 nights, Wednesday-Saturday for the IBC. When we arrived our room was OK, nothing special, and really needed a good cleaning. It wouldn't hurt to reattach the curtain rod to the wall either! Thursday housekeeping never came, I called down to the front desk and they did send up clean coffee cups and fresh towels. Friday, housekeeping never came. Called down and requested cleaning, towels, and coffee cups... None of that ever arrived.Saturday when we were headed out for the day, we stopped by the front desk and related our concerns and requested... Well maybe demanded... Housekeeping service. The lady at the front desk apologized and said that she would comp 2 days of valet parking for our troubles. And our room would be cleaned.Thank goodness our room was cleaned that day and we had fresh linens and cups. However, Sunday morning when we checked out our valet had not been comped and we didn't have time to wait for a manager to fix the problem. I did request a phone call... Which I still haven't received. Do yourself a favor and look into other hotels!I tend to judge hotels by their amenities. Their body stuff is lovely. The towels are plentiful and large. The pool is a hidden gem on the 2nd floor roof.There was nothing that stood out about this place.  My girlfriend booked it because of the pool.  The pool was nothing special, but during the day it was a very quiet place to chill out and have a drink or two before getting the day started.I'm with some others on here who think that, for roughly $200 per night, you should get a refrigerator....without having to pay extra.  Not so.  The room was your everyday standard room.  Nothing special about it.  If nothing else, it was very clean.Note to those going, do NOT get room 425.  The toilet runs forever, so unless you feel like playing the fun game of lifting the back top off of it and trying to use the handle to flip the little rubber cap back over the pipe drain so the thing will fill up again, make sure to avoid this room.  We were in the room, probably longer than most, recovering, recouping, etc., so this particular fact was noticeable.  By the time we realized what was going on, it didn't seem worth it to try and switch rooms.Oh yes, and as far as the WiFi, it's free, but it's awful.  It's not super important when you're in a great city like this, but if you need it for something, you can't count on it.The staff were very friendly and it's location is decent.  But for this kind of money, you could probably find a much better option.For the great expense of the rooms, which are not anything special, you'd think they wouldn't charge for amenities. Almost $200 a night, and you want another $15 from me for a refrigerator? No thanks!We checked out early and got a room near Graceland for almost 1/4 the price for a comparable room WITH a fridge and a microwave. The staff was nice enough, but this hotel's policy is not very appreciative of their guests' patronage.Extremely helpful and pleasant staff. The hotel is well appointed, room was clean and service was good.  We had a corner room and the windows were a little small. I would have also liked to have had a refrigerator in the room and when we arrived we could hear the TV in the next room. Maybe because it was an adjacent room and the sound was coming from the door.  But, the beds and pillows were comfortable.Pretty glad I booked this place to stay overnight as we were passing through Memphis. Hotel staff was really friendly, and of course the cookies were delicious (cookies are a thing now... you can rate hotels on their COOKIES)! Lobby was nice and felt safe. Yes, the valet parking is steep, but I assume they park your car in a secure garage, which means it's worth it. The actual room didn't feel too dated, was clean, but the biggest complaint I have is that the room was TINY! Really, really small. Probably another factor of the tiny room - the toilet was so loud, it could easily wake someone up. Great proximity to Beale St. We got there super late and were able to walk there. It was a little sketchy - but then *any* city after midnight can look a little sketchy. Never felt unsafe on the walk. The next morning, I walked alone to Beale St to buy some souvenirs, and it was super safe and touristy.Noisy room.  I stayed on 5th floor on the east side.  Rooms are ok, nothing fancy.  Good location but if staying here stay in a room on the south sideI love Doubletree Cookies with a passion!! Delicious! The best perk for staying at a Doubletree!This is a nice hotel, right across the street from the Peabody and in the heart of downtown Memphis. This hotel was very clean, modern with nice rooms. I didn't have any major problems or concerns when I stayed there. The only thing that really sucked was that they only had valet parking so you had to pay 20 bucks I believe per night and you couldn't have regular access to your car to get something you forgot. The staff was friendly and helpful, and it is only a 5 minute walk to Beale St.Great location within a short walk to Beale St., and across st., from the Peabody Hotel. Friendly staff.  However valet parking - - too long of a wait, rooms we're just ok, window blinds didn't work, very noisy to street traffic and bathroom needed lots of work.  Picture included of poor patch job on the wall by the tub.  And the worst part, now that we're home we both have large blotchy rashes over a large portion of our bodies...could that be BED BUGS?....I'm not sure what I can say negatively about the hotel (TGIF as the hotel restaurant was kind of lame, I guess).  The people there were exceptionally friendly and helpful.  The lobby was very modern with a touch of classic (large brickwork structure) and had a cool glass elevator overlooking it.  The room was very clean and bed comfortable.  Not much more you could ask for! Oh, and they give warm cookies when you check-in, but that might be Double Trees everywhere.Stay here if you have no other choice.  Location is good for access to downtown but way to much money.  The staff is fantastic that's the biggest part of this hotel.Great location, nice lobby, great staff, mediocre rooms, terrible smell.I spent last week at this hotel and will not be going back. Every day after returning from a long day at the client the last thing I want is to be hit by a wave of stench on entering my hotel room. But that's what I experienced all last week.What did it smell like? It smelled like a combination of damp musty towels and dirty fishtank filter. Or maybe just a drainage ditch. Wait, I got it, it smelled like a gulf coast tidal pool at low tide on a hot day.So no matter how nice the bed was (and it was really nice) or how excellently the air conditioning turned the room into a meat locker (and it really did), every time you would go near the bathroom the stench was almost enough to make you retch. And I'm not alone in this, three of my peers all had the same experience, although they also complained about the rooms being dirty in different ways.So that's four of us that will be staying at the Courtyard by Marriot on subsequent trips to Memphis. And I will be advising my other coworkers to do the same if they end up visiting Memphis.Oh, one other thing... I was not driving this trip, but if I was I would have to mention the entirely too small valet/parking area in front of the hotel. It's the size of a postage stamp.Compared to other hotels & other Doubletrees, this one needs a facelift, dye job, and SPANX!!! Good:The beds were comfy - no complaints there. :-)The A/C works well!Free cable (obvious)They have a complimentary happy hour for Hilton honors members. If your not a member, sign up! It's free & u earn points for hotel stays or goods. from 5:30-6:30 p.m. which is pretty sweet.Normal check-out is 11 a.m. & late check out is 12 p.m.Right next to the Peabody & Baseball Stadium.Within walking distance to restaurants, bars, and a couple little stores.  Do not go to Beale street alone at night, women.There's a mediocre chain restaurant (Friday's) connected to the hotel.Neutral:Stairwell is in a weird location - u kinda walk into the back of the kitchen (right next to elevators) & then to the right.Free computer use in lobby - only thing is that the monitors face EVERYONE!Bad:Bathroom was annoying - toilet had flushing issues. No complimentary breakfast. Poop heads! j/k, I'm not name calling! :-PYou can hear the motorcycles driving around late at night on Wednesday nights.When I am in the Memphis area (which is often) and don't crash a friends couch I stay here.Great Location to do some day drinking on Beale Street.Three blocks to the Main Street Trolley.TGI Friday's on the premises.Peabody Hotel is right across the street so you can go see the ducks at 11AM or 5PM.DoubleTree Cookies-YUM!The rooms are roomy and decent. I didn't get this smell everyone seemed to get when they walked in their room.Staff was friendly and got us checked in fast.Just an overall solid hotel.Hotel was nice, but fairly expensive. Didn't think hotel staff was that helpful. Requested towels (when housekeeping failed to leave enough) and waited over an hour. There was construction going on in the lot next door which woke us up about 5:30 am. Staff didn't really help explain parking or other amenities. Best part about the hotel was its proximity to Beale Street.Clean and comfortable and in a great location. We had no problems with the room. The staff is very helpful and friendly. The lobby is beautifully styled and seems recently renovated, however the upstairs rooms are a little shabbier, with faded walls and carpets. Nothing terrible, but could definitely use a pick-me-up to match the lobby. Free cookies upon check in, and valet parking (for a fee). The TGIF hotel restaurant seemed atrocious though why would you eat there when Beale st is a two minute walk away! In fact, it's the location that bumps this up from 3 stars to 4 for me.
review_content_40: This is a very good hotel. nice room, great staff, perfect location and nice amenities. Its really hard to fault this hotel. Security is present 24 hours which is a good thing, but they spend a lot of their time indoors instead of just on the perimeter which is where it needs to be. I had a few issues checking in, which the lock on my door did not work but they sent someone up pronto to fix it. the other problem was that they didn't give me my breakfast coupons and should have known I was part of the group on check in. Still thouhgh Staff is wonderful. Everyone from the TGIF staff in the restaurant, to the house keeping to the bell man. Lobby is great and there is happy hour and breakfast each morning. Free internet all throughout the hotelYou are literally 20 steps from the Peabody, a few more steps to Beale and Rendezvous, basically, anywhere downtown you need to go you can walk in 10 min or less. Cant fault this hotel at all. They have a sign out front that says "Parking, only $22 a day" Really? ONLY? Stay a this double tree if your travels take you to downtown Memphis. You will be glad you stayed here over the Peabody next doorWell... this hotel certainly has improved my Tennessee work trip! Though I suspect my contacting the hotel and posting on Yelp and Twitter helped. Either way.... for the moment, I'm still happy I became a Hilton HHonors member and ditched Marriott Rewards (despite my status, but no biggie, I travel so much I'll be an HHonors Diamond member by October. Back to the hotel... it's pretty fabulous. Literally every single person who's passed us has welcomed us and asked how our stay is... southern hospitality or cranky travel writer perks? Either way... it's nice. It was easy to get to the hotel and parking was fairly easy, once I flagged down a valet (took about 15 minutes). The location is IDEAL, for visiting downtown Memphis. Beale Street is just 3 blocks away... and very walkable. The hotel allowed us to check in around 1pm, which was much appreciated and we're perched in a HUGE room on the 10th floor (top floor and an HHonors floor). The lobby is very grand and has a very cool vibe to it. They have comfy sofa's and a piano, along with some cool art work. Also attached to the hotel is a TGIFridays. I'm not a fan of the chain, but it's convenient for a snack or a drink. Our room is VERY spacious, VERY clean and nice and cool (making it a nice respite for the humid streets of downtown Memphis... it may be April, but it feels like July). We have tall ceilings and a view of the baseball stadium. Our bathroom is quite spacious with a separate tub and shower. Much nicer looking that your standard hotel room bathroom and appointed with some cool Memphis posters. We took a stroll to Beale Street right after checking in, and came back to a surprise.... our blinds were open (I had tried to open them, but they were broken, I didn't complain because it wasn't a big deal)... but apparently they just knew and fixed them. Our carpet was also wet, which was alarming... we called maintenance and Rome came up to investigate. Funny enough he'd said hello to us as we were walking back from Beale. He let us know they came in to deep clean our carpets while we were gone. A little weird... but OK. Rome left and came back a few minutes later with a little goody bag for the "inconvenience"... it hardly was one, we were just concerned there might be a leak. Either way it was a nice gesture and Rome was very friendly. All in all the experience here at the DoubleTree by Hilton Memphis Downtown has exceeded my expectations and has left me impressed with the brand. A real "save" from my last two nights at the DoubleTree in Jackson, TN. If you're looking for a nice hotel with friendly service in a great downtown Memphis location, look no further than the DoubleTree by Hilton Memphis Downtown! You can tell them the Snob sent you :)Now, I'll just cross my fingers that the rest of my Hilton stays emulate THIS level of service... Homewood Suites in Cannonsburg, PA for three days next week and Hilton SF Airport Bayfront the week following (and pretty much every week after that in various locations across the US until October 2012).I came to Memphis with a group of friends, primarily to see a Memphis Redbirds game. The Doubletree is directly across the street from the Redbirds' stadium, plus they offer ticket packages if you book directly with them. It's also an easy walk to Beale, tons of restaurants, FedEx Arena, etc. Our room was very clean and we had plenty of room for four adults. The cherry on top was the hotel staff; Sheila was so accommodating at the front desk, Willie (bell hop) was so helpful and even filled our cooler with ice, and Janae (marketing) went out of her way to make our stay pleasant. We'll definitely be back!I have always been a fan of the Hilton chain and I am a Hilton Honors Member. The best description I can give this place is that it is located close to Beale street and the customer service was very good but our room was horrible.The bathroom door was kept together by nuts and bolts holding the panels to the door. The hotel is loud with TGI Fridays attached to the lobby with the hostess yelling out for names on the waiting list.There was a college fraternity in many of the rooms and it seems the management and hotel security did nothing to control their behavior.Very disappointed and will stay at the Peabody on my next visit to this great town.I won't stay here again. It didn't feel up to par with the classy Doubletree I'm used to experiencing.Pluses: attentive, friendly, polite valet and desk clerkMinuses: ambiance and valueWhen I checked in, my room wreaked of cigarette smoke and my eyes started itching immediately. The bathroom sink would not drain. While this was annoying, the hotel agreed this was unacceptable and moved me to a room with no smoke odor and a working sink.If you're looking for friendly hotel staff alone, then stay here.I want a great room and posh experience from 3.5-5 star hotels. This was more 2.5 than 3.5. Maybe a 3 star hotel but bit shouldn't be a 3.5.Next time I'm going back across the street to The Peabody. Don't care if it costs more.I booked this place very last minute for one night at the government rate of $93 (total $107). People who work here are friendly and helpful. The room was not big but acceptable. I found the beds with lots of pillows pretty comfortable to sleep on. The bathroom was also not spacious but in a good condition. Amenities were lacking but you can call to get whatever missing. The location is definitely the best!! I would be a returning customer if I ever go to Memphis again.Very slow and angry service. I was very calm and nice during my 20 minute check in process. There were 3 of us in line and one of us was being checked in.... 20 minutes. No "sorry" for the delay but just a pissed off attitude. It turns out I was telling her sorry the management left her with all this work. She said "yeah, it always turns out this way". Here I am being the hospitality toward the person in the hospitality industry.The bar... well.. more of the same. I'm not looking to be coddled and fawned over but the service was "angry".Bed was nice and they have ESPN U. Upon checkin she let me know of the breakfast and that "...it is not complimentary". I said "Pardon?" She said "Breakfast isn't part" of the package....The hotel was great but if you use you honor points for a free room you will be treated as a 4th class customer. Got there at 1:00..Valet said "no issue- your room will be ready by 2:30! Came back at 2:30 and made me wait until 4:00 just because. Saw 7 other people check in - I guess they were not using points. To me 4:00 is ridiculous for a check in time in the first place. I travel every week and NEVER have to wait past 2:00. But then again- I was a paying customer. Not a very customer first type of operation that is for sure.This was our second and third trips to the Doubletree in downtown Memphis. We stayed there on our way through from Chicago to Dallas and then on our way back a week later. We previously stayed there 2 years ago and had no complaints. I love the location. Maybe because we're from Chicago but walking around at night down there was not an issue for us at all. We walked to Beale Street, we walked around, we walked to the market a couple blocks away. It's a really central location and super convenient. The one down side is easily the parking. $24 a night is steep. Yeah, it's nice to have valet but I would rather pay like $10-$12 and have to park it myself. But, whatever, we got a decent room rate so we couldn't complain much. The staff at the front desk were super pleasant every time we had reason to speak with them. Love the Doubletree, it's our go-to hotel when we're staying in Memphis.Stayed here for 2 nights and kept visiting the Peabody next door wishing we were staying there! Let me start by saying the staff here is very helpful and friendly. However, the rooms are small, and just not super clean, look clean on the surface, but the baseboards, corners, are dirty. Our air exchange was very noisy so we turned it off. Our room faced the Peabody hotel and what looks like their loading dock. One morning I was woken up at 4:45 AM, across the street by the loading dock a man was throwing palletts into a truck making god awful noise for quite some time. So , guess the rooms/windows are not well insulated. Would love to stay next door at the Peabody if we visit Memphis again...sorry. Oh, and called the front desk as we did not have a clock radio in the room...never arrived.Cookies are epic. I prefer the residence inn. However if they are booked the Doubletree is always my 3rd choice. In Dwntown Memphis areaIn town for a concert and was very disappointed in the length of time to check in. The staff running the front desk seemed to be in slow motion. When it was my turn, to find out that my room was not ready did not make me happy. It was 6pm. Late check out? That makes no sense to me. Rooms should be ready by 3pm. We greeted housekeeping as she was leaving the room after insisting we be allowed to take up our luggage because we needed to head out to the concert. The room was ok, dated a bit. I would have preferred a comfortable couch versus two chairs in the living area and two in the bedroom. It was nice that the suite had two full bathrooms. The one attached to the bedroom was spacious except for counter space, it basically had none. I hate that. Getting ready and washing your hands or washing your face just gets everything wet. On the plus side, the bed was ok, valet was quick, the shower had great water pressure and got steamy hot, the AC worked wonderfully-like an icebox and its a great location, just a block off Beale.Best hotel to be location-wise if you plan to stay in downtown Memphis on vacation. Walking distance of everything! Free cookies and nice staff. Only downside: no airport shuttle. I booked the hotel through Hotwire.comStay here when visiting downtown Memphis!OK is the best I can do... We were traveling to Memphis on the motorcycle to experience what the city had to offer (i.e. Beale Street, Blues, Graceland, Etc..) We specifically chose the Doubletree due to our previous experience while traveling last summer.Two factors kept this review from being a 4: #1 - the parking garage, unlike the other comments, I noticed that parking was going to cost extra, it is clearly stated on their website, and I was also pleasantly surprised that motorcycle parking is 1/2 price of a car (which makes sense when you consider you can park them in less space). The problem is the garage is a MESS (you won't see this if you just have the valet park your car). There are some great opportunities to utilize some unparkable space, but you have to move the trash people!!! There was old carpet, boxes, and most disturbing SHEET METAL SCREWS on the ground where they wanted us to park the bikes. How much trouble would it be to spend some quality time cleaning up the place.#2- no shampoo. Not a big deal if you know that ahead of time, but when you are traveling very light on a motorcycle, you only bring what you need, and when you expect shampoo, and they don't have it (and when you call the desk you get a myriad of excuses).If the location and the quality of the rooms were not of normal doubletree standard, this would have rated a 2. If I go back, I will be trying another of multiple options in the area.Proximity to Beale Street gives it the third star, otherwise it'd only be a 2-star. The lobby is nice with a pianist playing. The staff is super nice and cordial. The rooms are clean and quiet, but the hallways need updating. The gym is TINY and a bit smelly. Their dumbbells have rubber grips which make them slippery and dangerous. The treadmill was broken AND had a towel under one of the foot pods to even it out. It was too cold to check out the pool so no comment there. The only parking they have is valet so prepare to pay about $20/night unless you want to chance it in a nearby open lot. The TGIF (accessibly via the lobby) is the room service provider.A lazy, second rate Doubletree. I've been to many and this one is moldy and the service is sub-par to say the least. When it comes to downtown Memphis hotels, there have to be better stays. When I visit again, the Doubletree will not be my option.Rooms were in disrepair, no hot water, bad location. The staff was responsive and pleasant to me however. The hotel desperately needs updated.Beautiful lobby but pool was closed. Our toilet didn't work and we changed rooms and got a dinner voucher. The town was nice and we would go back.For the price we paid, about $200/night, what we got was less than what we expected. First, on the positive side, the location was excellent: very easy to walk to Beale St. And the room was spacious and well tended. However, the service here was never friendly or proactive. Asking for something seems to provoke annoyance rather than friendliness, and, even once you ask for help, only the minimum possible response/action is provided. For this price, I would seek better value elsewhere.The location near Beale Street is ideal for walking around Memphis. The rooms are new and contemporary with Internet access. The addition of the Fridays that is attached is nice for socializing while on business. Plus, all you can eat warm cookies. I'm in! There is no parking other valet which is a little annoying.
review_content_60: The lobby of this hotel is beautiful -- but I wish they would have spent some of the money on the rooms. While it didn't necessarily feel dirty, the room was dilapidated. The carpet was stained, the ceiling in the bathroom was brown and sagging, and the stopper in the bathtub was broken so it kept falling closed. Yes, these are little things, but they do make a difference. No free breakfast here, which was a surprise as all of the other Hilton hotels we stayed at on this trip offered it complementary. Apparently there was a Hilton Honors member happy hour, but we were not told about it at check in, and when we asked about it in the restaurant (TGI Friday's), no one knew what we were talking about (even though there was sign right outside the entrance). Does anyone else find it strange that the "famous" DoubleTree cookies all have nuts? Ours went in the trash...By in large, this hotel is ok, but the one killer is the very loud AC unit in every room. It woke me up three times the first night and twice the second night. Since the key feature of a hotel room is usually to provide you a good night's sleep, I can't give this place a very good score.I didn't notice it the first night, but on the second night, the room was musty. The drop ceiling over the entrance looked like it could cave in any second. I felt like Indiana Jones dodging into my room to avoid the impending cave in.By in large, the rest of this hotel is fine, but it was hard to get drink vouchers for the free cocktail hour.Great location... just a couple of blocks from Beale. TGI Fridays attached. Rooms just ok. Pool was closed. No maid service the day we were there.I really can't understand the poor reviews of this place. The rooms were fine, the building was nice, and the location is fantastic. Within walking distance of any place you'd want to go in the city. Yes, I did notice staining and wear on the carpet in the hallway, but I could have cared less. I wouldn't hesitate to stay at this place again. Even if there were more stains in the hallway.We booked this the weekend before Thanksgiving for $99 a night on Hotels.com... and I was not disappointed. Yeah, the extra fee for the valet sucked. But it was valet. Yeah, there is a Greyhound bus station across the street. But I didn't pick this hotel to just sit outside all night. We picked it because we could walk to Beale Street. A nice, short walk. Super convenient. We had no problem checking in. No line and had a room within 5 minutes of stepping up to the counter. The beds were comfy. The room was clean and updated. Do I just have lower standards than everyone else here? Maybe. But we were pleased with the room. My one complaint... it took FOREVER to get our car back from valet when we checked out. Check out early and avoid the nonsense.Okay, so the room I stayed in (two double beds) was a bit dated and not as polished as I like- buy the staff and the ambience of the hotel make up for it. Friendly people, manager's reception (aka free beer), live piano until 8:30- overall a nice value. Tip: skip the TGI Fridays breakfast- over priced. Valet parking is $22/ day but the attendants are fast and nice.As a flight attendant, we don't have a choice where we stay, and our company puts us up here in Memphis. Location, Location, Location... This place has it going on. This is a mid priced chain hotel. If you want style and elegance, and pomp and circumstance stay at the Peabody. I like Double Tree because of the warm cookies you get upon check in. The rooms have been renovated recently., and the amenities are a little better than average. You get more than just shampoo and soap. You also get facial cleanser and face lotion which is a nice touch. The beds are rather comfortable.Historic building with a GREAT LOBBY....with a free HHonors Happy Hour.....located right across the street from an excellent AAA baseball team and park (make sure to go) and 2 blocks from Beale Street - which I think is WAY over rated.....can be a scary walk back to the hotel later at night.....Service was excellent at check in, I was in room #433 on a prepaid rate....room was large and bed was great....only issue was the bathroom is HOT - must be no a/c in there.....and the place is a little "beat up" but I believe that gives it charm.....Didn't take advantage of the breakfast - its served in a TGI Friday that is attached......but I liked the place....very quiet at night!Total - $136.50 + 12.63 + 6.83+2.32 taxes = $158.27I was able to Priceline this for for $72 so I really can't complain. However if I spent much more I would feel pretty cheated. The entire lobby and atrium was under renovation which was a bummer as I'm sure it would have looked cool otherwise. The waiting area downstairs as a result was very small and cramped. The room was nice but the bed was certainly not comfortable. On top of all that parking was $21 a night. In this area you best pay for parking and not go on the street. Who knows they may have just parked me on the street anyway. All I know is my car was covered in snow so it wasn't in a garage. I found the interior space nice and clean as expected but just not as nice as other doubletrees I have been to.Another stay in a cookie cutter corporate hotel. The good:Great location (I could see the outfield of the baseball stadium from my window);Comfortable bed;Powerful air conditioning (every day I was there the mercury was 90 to 100);Decent water pressure and toiletries.The computers seem to have been upgraded in the business center (they were fast)The bad:Poky front desk service when I was checking in;Peeling wallpaper in the bathroom;Scattered bleach stains across the carpet just outside my door.If my travels take me to Memphis again, I might consider a second stay.Perfect location in downtown Memphis. Safe distrance from Beale Street. And across from a Denny's for a late night treat.The rooms were nice and clean. And the service, for the most part, was really good.Room service is TGI Friday's full menu.Would definitely stay again.The only reason I won't tag a "five stars" on here is because their hotel lobby bar is a TGI Fridays - not my idea of a good time. I feel like they could venture out a bit with that, or at least add a little stand-alone bar in the lobby. Other than that, everything was lovely. The staff was very polite and friendly. The rooms are clean and comfortable. The lobby is spacious. The location is excellent. We were within walking distance to Beale Street and a lot of fun bars and restaurants South of Beale. The hotel is next to a Greyhound station, which can bring about some creepy characters (not judging! just stating the facts!). When we were unloading our car we were immediately approached by someone begging for money. Living in New Orleans, we are used to things like this, but I could see how someone might be freaked out or feel uncomfortable.On the bright side, the Doubletree is located directly across the street from the famed Peabody Hotel so you can walk right over at 11 a.m. to see the ducks walk the red carpet into their fountain (all without the ridiculous price tag of the Peabody Hotel!)Great location. Great staff. Wonder if cleaning staff actually knows how to clean. Bathroom was disgusting. The walls in bathroom needed a soap and water cleaning. Filth from previous guests everywhere. Gross. Mirror in closet was disgusting. Curtain rod was broke, blinds were broke and tv kept turning its self off. Glad we got such a great rate and only stayed one night.Location is all this place has. Room is small, dark, but clean. Was guaranteed a nonsmoking king which was not available when I arrived. They did however offer a double bed, handicap accessible room (no tub). Halls are hot and carpets very dirty, and look like they should have been replaced years ago. The hallways seem to have no air conditioning - you can work up a sweat just waiting for the slow elevators. The hotel is right next to they Greyhound bus station, and I was woke up several nights by patrons arguing on the street below, as well as several hours of loud cars passing by each evening. Not sure I'd stay here again, there has to be better options for the price.We stayed there over spring break. It is close to everything. The free breakfast buffet at TGIFridays was very good. Beale Street is about 2 blocks away and the FedEx Forum is only a little bit further. The rooms are roomy and the staff is friendly. We had a great time and I wouldn't hesitate to stay ther again.The Doubletree Downtown definitely has the location, but not much more. My room had a view of the Greyhound station and bright lights from the baseball stadium were piercing through the broken curtains of my window. The room overall was comfortable, but the AC unit was loud. The joint operation with TGI Friday's is not good for the hotel. Really- who wants to eat at Friday's for breakfast (or at all?) Parking will run $15/day and they must park the car far away because it takes a while to get it. So I recommend calling ahead to get your car in the morning if you are in a hurry. Bottom line: I think the hotel is overpriced for what you get.Very pleasant place to stay. I've stayed at a couple throughout the United States and have always had an ejoyable experience. Close to everything downtown. Not to sound redundant to all the other reviews but yes gotta love the cookies.I ended up staying at this hotel after being stranded in Memphis during one of Chicago's recent spring snowstorms. The location of the hotel was excellent, walking distance from Beale Street but far enough from the noise and across the street from the Peabody Hotel.I was disappointed with the cleanliness of the hotel and quality of the rooms. First, their business center was pretty crappy. They had two incredibly slow computers. The rooms were pretty shabby. The walls were paper thin and the room looked kind of old. Overall pretty low quality for a Hilton hotel. I was pretty disappointed and will just stay at a neighboring Marriott next time.Very nice staff. Even got a free tix to a Redbird game (just for asking). Parking at valet for $22 is only option. Ask for a corner room if your a HH member. OH and amazing govt rate.Location is great, and the building is very neat (modern rooms in an old building). Staff is great, etc...I'm a financially-driven traveler, and this was worth every penny.
review_content_80: The good: Is right near Beale St., the ballpark, and a lot of happening places. The rooms are nice, beautiful fascade when you walk in, and you gotta love cookies with the room.The bad: internet connection clocked in at the slowest wireless I've ever seen (ex. I bought an episode on iTunes, and it was going to take 23 hours to download....yikes). The staff didn't know what an ethernet cable was, and said they couldn't give me a receipt for my room after checking out since I booked with Hotwire (? maybe this is legit, just seems weird).For the price & the fuss, I'd still go here again.I'm a frequent business traveler to Memphis and stay at most of the better Hilton properties in the city on a regular basis.  Of the major hotels, the two Doubletrees in Memphis are unfortunately at the bottom of the list.  The downtown Doubletree has a very modern and smart interior, with a very cool historic building facade making up one of the atrium walls.  The rooms, however, are small, dark, and often in various states of disrepair.  Stained walls, ceilings, and carpets are the norm, as well as ragged fixtures and appointments (the room I was in while I wrote this had a shower curtain torn down the middle).  The worst part of this hotel is definitely it's parking, which is valet only.  On workday mornings there is frequently a 15-30 minute wait around 8am, which made the Doubletree impractical for me until we discovered that parking on the street next to the hotel is free at night.  The best part of the hotel is obviously it's downtown location, which is somewhat of a saving grace given the disappointing choice of TGI Friday's as the hotel's anchor restaurant.  I'd suggest walking a few streets over to Monroe St and dining at Flight or McEwen's.  If you can help it, stay somewhere else instead, such as the Hilton in East Memphis (my favorite) or the new Hampton Inn on Beale Street, which I've heard is very good.boyfriend & i stayed here for 2 nights/3 days 2nd wk of this june.did not have a rental car so am unable to review their valet service.however, the service elsewhere we recieved was amazing.impeccable bed/ bath rooms..& the daily housekeeping did a great job.neutrogena sundries.wolfgang puck coffee & coffee mate creamer.(only 1 regular coffee packet though.. but im sure if i would have requested more, i would have gotten them!)the staff members that held our luggage while we waited for check in time were very polite & professional.the front desk associates were also great.for example, we arrived around 9 am & check in time is not until 3 p.m but the lady at the desk said she would call us if a room opened up, & alas, we were called before noon to let us know our room was ready!& on our last day, our return flight departed at 7 pm & check out time is at noon, & guess what?we were allowed to stay until 3 p.m!the lobby is spacious & comfy & stylishly decorated.the elevators big & clean.the pool is very small!& only 2 tables!& 3 reclining lounges!but no problem.. i can barely swim anyway!but i was able to sun bathe in the southern sun for a couple of hours with no problem!& their complimentary pool towels were always stocked..the adjacent restaurant is unfortunately, a TGI Fridays (for those of you who are not familiar with this chain of restaurants, it is like a Dennys w/ a full bar) but they are open untill 1 a.m on fri & sat nights, so thats good if you want to take some food to go up to your room.though we did not use room service, i did peek at the menu, & their food items are reasonably priced ($10 or so for a burger & fries) & the charge is $3 plus a 20% gratuity.. that is a lot less than the Hiltons we've stayed at !all in all, we were very pleased with this hotel.NO rude staff at all.in fact, we were greeted by chipper "good mornings!" by about 3 different associates just from the short walk from our room to the elevator!the rooms were a tad bit small (the ottoman was strangely placed between the bed & the chair, so if you are kind of on the bigger side, you might have to move the ottoman)the closet was very big!the tub/shower also big.unfortunately, the toilet is right next to the shower, as is the sink & mirror so i could not do my makeup & hair while my boyfriend was in the shower..if we ever return to memphis, we will for sure stay here..3 blocks from beale st (where blues city cafe & bb kings is) its very close to beale st.. i was able to walk back in 4 inch heels after lots of cocktails w/no problem;)directly across the street from autozone park (baseball games, i think?)& directly across the street from..................RENDEZVOUS BBQ !!!so you can place your name on their hour long wait list, & return to your room & have a couple of beers & walk back in less than an hour!thanks, doubletree staff for making our stay so comfy!oh, & the wi-fi is complimentary!I agree with most of the other yelpers.....its not the Ritz, but it will certainly do! We only stayed for two nights, so maybe if youre going for a longer vacation you might want to upgrade, but we had no problems with it. We also booked it on hotwire for around $70 a night as opposed to the $140 a night on other sites; I dont think it is worth $140. The room and bathroom were clean and pretty spacious, as was the lobby. The ac was a bit noisy but didnt bother us; it could have been a little cooler though. The location is the best perk; walking distance to whatever youd want to see in downtown Memphis including Beale St. which was the highlight of our trip. Ive read complaints about the valet service and they were fine for the most part, but we lost our ticket upon check out and it took a little too long for them to bring the car around. The front desk staff was really nice and helpful. All in all, if I was going for another quick trip I would definetely stay there again. Just an FYI-Rendezvous is closed on Sunday and Monday so we missed out this time =(I stayed at the Downtown Memphis Doubletree with some friends on a weekend trip. The location was excellent--we were across the street from The Peabody and seconds away from Beale St, which was great for a trip during Elvis Week.  So, if all you want out of a hotel is a centrally located building, have no qualms about booking a reservation here. Otherwise, I would look elsewhere. One of the first things I noticed was a TGIFriday's in the lobby. My first thought was, "Hey, how convenient"--but then I realized that this restaurant was replacing my free continental breakfast. It was a great way for those businesses to promote each other's interests, but what did I get out of the arrangement? Well, I got a cookie. To quote the wax-paper bag that my cookie came in: "Why a cookie? Simple. Cookies are warm, personal and inviting. Much like our hotels and the staff here that serve you."  Despite the friendliness displayed by my cookie-wrapper, we never received new towels or had our beds made. Additionally, when we called the desk about extra blankets, they responded that they would see if they had any and hung up before we could inquire further. When my roommate asked if they had any complimentary coffee for guests, (which you can find at many banks and grocery stores)  the woman at the desk reminded her of the coffee pot in our room with its one-serving bag, which, by the way, was never refilled. I might not be so annoyed if it weren't for the cookie wrapper, which, unfortunately, I had actually read and not thrown away. Along the way, the cookie wrapper gained a sarcasm unintended by its creators. But it's so well written, so I'll leave you with their carefully chosen words: " [the cookies are] a symbol of our unique kind of hospitality and commitment to comfort. In other words, we think cookies are the perfect way for us to say, 'Welcome.'"  In my opinion, that's a lot of responsibility to place on one little cookie.

review_content: We went to the Peabody to see the famous MARCHING PEABODY DUCKS....but the place was so PACKED !!!!...It was so packed, it was hard to get a glimpse of the "infamous waddle" as they emerged from the elevator and made their way to the fountain the glizy lobby of this gorgeous hotel.But, at least we can say we were in this amazing hotel from the HEY DAY era, and we can say "HEY, we once went to the Peabody in Memphis" I love to have little moments like this that are forever embedded into our memories. I have always tried to do this for my children growing up...tons of fun memories to remember their mommy by!!!The Peabody of Memphis is the South's Grand Hotel, a blast from the glitzy glamorous past.  It is conveniently located only about 2 maybe 3 blocks from Beale Street, so its extremely easy to hop over from the jazzy melodies on Beale to the quiet lobby of the Peabody.  I would love to have the extra money to spend the night in this Elegant Jewel of Memphis !!!!This is a beautiful hotel just two short blocks from Beal Street. We stayed in a suite on the 11th floor, and were disappointed by a few things. First off we were right next to the elevator which can be heard at all hours moving up and down. There was no real comforter on the bed, and the maids seemed a little lazy (not putting things away ect). However, what really got to me was how crappy the valet service is. I had called down ten minutes before arriving in the lobby to have our car pulled around, got down to find out that no one ever "got the word" the valets were lazy and slow walking around and showing no hustle. Otherwise, the hotel is gorgeous, great location, and friendly front desk and suite personnel.Okay, I am an animal lover, so I might be bias, but I just adore this hotel. I mean come on... ducks that ride an elevator!! Plus, the hotel is pet friendly! If you are traveling with a nonhuman family member, they give you a bowl, a cute poo baggy holder for your leash, and a list of animal-friendly activities in the area. Some people might find this frustrating, however, I REALLY appreciate it, but they require vaccination records for pets. What a relief that you don't have to worry if there was a weirdo in your room before you who let their poor dog contract kennel cough and then subsequently pass it on to your furry family. They do charge a pet fee for cleaning purposes but it's exponentially cheaper than boarding or a pet sitter, plus you know you're not gonna be sleeping in someone else's cat's hair. They also allow you to leave your pet unsupervised in the room (which most hotels don't), but if for some reason your neighbor's bird or  puppy goes psycho, they have security take them to the hotel's kennels so you can sleep, or sleep in, or drink in peace :) Also, I love the character and charm. It's on the National Register of Historic Places, as well as many other registries. I feel like this is what all hotels should be. It's updated but Romantic and cozy (notice I used a capital 'r', in 'Romantic', not a lower case one.. if you don't know the difference, you probably won't get it). EVERYONE that works here is awesome. I've never had a problem with anyone anytime I've stayed here. Let's face it, any big city comes with its fair share of crime, but I love how diligent they are here (without being obnoxious or making you feel sketched out). PS. Room service/ in-room dining is pretty darn good. I really like their little pizzas. Also, pretty great location, you can basically walk anywhere in Memphis from here; unless you wanna walk like Jesus, on the water, across the Mississippi, you can't do that from here. But you can walk alongside the Mighty River. You might even find a prairie dog... probably not though.*High five* to The Peabody Memphis!If you are just visiting Memphis, or if you've lived here your entire life, then you already know The Peabody is synonymous with opulence and class.Originally built in the 1920's and later purchased by the Belz family in the 1970's and restored to its magnificent current style, it is a place that you must visit if you are in town. You will regret it if you miss the experience so just do it. Everything here just oozes luxury without being pompous or untouchable. For instance, when I used to live in Memphis and worked downtown, I'd run across the street and get my haircut at Gould's in the basement of the Peabody. It seemed so special to walk in here and kind of a treat in itself just to do a mundane thing as getting a haircut over a lunch break.We recently stayed here for the first time during a quick 2-day trip to town. So glad we splurged a little for the special occasion! The rooms are small, but pretty special. The main enjoyment is the actual lobby, the ultra cool bar, the duck fountain (of course!), absolutely spectacular and gorgeous floral arrangements, and the fun shops. Go to Lansky at the Peabody. Mr. Lansky was the personal clothier to Elvis Presley himself! I had the pleasure of meeting him many years ago when stopping in the shop and once buying a tie for my boss. There's now a hip and trendy Lansky addition which features a fabulous selection of clothing for women and men as well. If you have kids (or you're a kid at heart) then make sure and visit in time for the duck march! You will not be disappointed!We did not stay at the Peabody but we did walk through and grab a drink and dessert in the lobby. Based on our lobby visit, we'll definitely return when in town and stay a night or two. The hotel is beautiful and well kept. The service was a slow to be served but they were also busy. Drinks and dessert were expensive but no more than you'd expect in any other fancy hotel. The staff was polite, friendly and helpful. A+If you want to see the definition of Southern charm and hospitality, The Peabody is for you!I had the pleasure of being a guest recently and couldn't have enjoyed my stay more. The property is classy, historic, romantic and is the home to some adorable ducks. Yes, there are really ducks in the lobby fountain.  The rooms, while not huge, are well-appointed (I am a sucker for a bed with LOTS of pillows) with everything you need including very comfortable bathrobes for your lounging enjoyment. One caveat - the walls are a little thin so you may hear a dog or two barking at odd hours since the hotel is pet friendly.Grab a seat on a comfy couch in the gorgeous lobby lounge and see the Duckmaster give an entertaining history of the hotel and their famous feathered residents during their march (each day at 11 and 5). You can also visit the ducks at their palace on the roof during their 'off hours'.All this and a great location with easy walking distance to many fun restaurants and bars?  YES!We walked in planning to stay one night, took one look and decided to stay two nights and extend our long road trip. Beautiful property, excellent service and just gorgeously decorated for Christmas. The room was spacious enough for two double beds. And like a number of these older hotels, the bathroom was tiny but beautiful and well appointed. The robes were lovely. I find that this is always the trade off between classic old hotels and the modern monstrosities. The bathroom and internet. Peabody wifi is really poor. Our family has a nightly ritual of watching TV shows on Netflix or Amazon but the wifi wouldn't support it. We got the breakfast package but the breakfast buffet itself was insipid and uninspired. I wish I had just ordered breakfast from the regular menu. But the coffee was outstanding. They serve French pressed coffee which is wonderful. We ordered room service both nights, once for a late night snack and the second night for dinner (we were watching the democratic debate in the room) and both nights, we enjoyed the food very much. If you are in the mood for indulgence, do order their freshly baked cookies with milk. Just divine. We also enjoyed hanging out in the lobby bar. A place for people watching and a place to be seen (I presume for the locals). We ran into a lovely librarian couple who were in town to take in a Tony Bennet concert and had a nice chat. Overall, we were happy that we stayed here. It was definitely lovely. One little complaint . We left a few things behind and I called the hotel to have them mailed and they wanted me to pay for shipping. It is not an unfair request but I once had a Holiday Inn Express mailing something for free. No, we don't leave behind things routinely :) But wealthy people don't become wealthy by giving money free away. The same logic applies to rich hotels as well!The hotel is beautiful. I made the mistake of going on the Friday after Thanksgiving to see the ducks go up for the night and the Christmas tree lighting. Wow, lots of people. Most likely their busiest event of the year.  It was all lovely but holy wall to wall people...The Peabody Memphis is gorgeous and historic. The chandelier in the main lobby was stunning and the ducks are quite something to see. How is it that those ducks are even more well-behaved than other children?I read somewhere that the hotel was one of the hotels (if not *the* hotel) where people went to see and be seen, especially for the uppercrust crowd. I do not think that was an exaggeration, as it really does exude elegance, charm and everything one would attribute to Southern aristocracy of old.Had I been given a choice, The Peabody is where I would have stayed when I was in town, as they are also located near other famous Memphis landmarks (Beale Street, National Civil Rights Museum, and Auto Zone Park are all within walking distance).Guess where I will be staying at next time I am in Memphis?It's the Peabody - it's classic Memphis. If you don't stay here, at least take in either the morning (11:00) or afternoon (5:00) duck walk.  Google for details. If you miss the ducks, the bar is still worth visiting. Good drinks, great coffee and pastries.  Lobby is gorgeous.  Everything about the Peabody is first rate.The first time I was here at this hotel was almost 20 years ago. Twenty years later, the ducks are still doing their march to the fountain. This place is such a nice hotel. Rooms are modest, but comfortable. The swimming pool and hot tub are clean and other amenities are up to par with the best (spa, gym, etc.) The lobby bar was pretty cool because you get to sit 5 feet from the ducks by the fountain (at least until 5pm).There is also a coffee shop, two restaurants, and another corner bar. The service is great and the souvenir shops have all things ducks. If you get the opportunity to stay here, please do! You won't regret it! Oh and it's also about 15 minutes from the airport and 1 block from Beale street. GREAT location!The duck March is awesome but in actuality it's only a few minutes long. So it's getting four stars. It's awesome and the ducks are super cute but not really worth five stars. And if you got lots of other things planned in Memphis then I guess it could be something you miss. The guy who leads the duck March is really nice and will happily answer your questions. I learned a lot about ducks and I hope that he was truthful in that they go to the nights farm and not the scary farm that we tell our children their pets go to when they die.Staying here is all about the charm of staying at the oldest hotel in Memphis.  With that... It's the oldest hotel and although very clean and well Maintained the Rooms are very small and furnishings old world. I prefer a larger room with a large bathroom and updated furnishings.  Seeing the ducks March on Sunday mornings is fun but you can do that for free without a $436 night stay.* see ducks and have a drink in the lovely lounge bar area and take a pic next to Gorgeous fresh flower arrangement in lobby!The lobby is always buzzing and the shops are nice it's definitely a place to visit for the experience of it but doesn't require a nights stay.The holiday brunch is always delicious, where there's always a huge spread of food, from breakfast brunch food  (eggs, bacon, sausage, biscuits and gravy) plus Thanksgiving dinner food, plus a large variety of desserts  (cookies, M&Ms, cake bites, and brownies). The wait staff was very attentive and always made sure you had drink refills if needed. The brunch is about the only meal you can eat for Thanksgiving based on the spread of food :). The only downside is the price,  so it's not somewhere you can go on a budget.Was a great stay until check out. Our room was beautiful, clean and comfortable.  The check in staff and concierge were friendly and helpful.  But that's where the good stops.  The valet are horrible.  We called down 15 min before checking out to get our car - then checked with the valet desk when we got downstairs.  We checked back with the valet every 10 min and were repeatedly lied to and told our car was on its way - after 30 min standing in the cold I asked how many cars were ahead of ours. It was then that they looked for the actual key and found it still hanging on the board.  When you spend $400 per night on a hotel they shouldn't be so shoddy and lie but tell you really how long it will be. If I hadn't kept checking with them I would still be standing there in the cold waiting.  Now we have to rush to the airport to hopefully make our flight.We stopped in solely for the morning duck march. The entire presentation was wonderful. Anthony, the duck master, did an excellent job of engaging the audience and answering their questions. Sit in the mezzanine level for a better view of the march. Definitely worth stopping in if you're in town. The ducks march at 11 a.m. and 5 p.m. daily.TennesseeI have bin in this state many times. I have bin their, over their, and here. I have also seen this great state during the winter. Every time I have enjoyed my visit. This time it was extra special, because of my stay at the Peabody Hotel. This hotel not only had fascinating history, it also had music history.  The atmosphere was classy, and fun. They had a duck theme. At the end of my stay I became duck crazy. I wanted everything that had a duck on it. Including the towel's. But at the end I walked away with one free bar of soap shaped like a duck, and my great memories of this great hotel. Everything that is amazing about Memphis is in walking distance. It's centrally located.Our journey to The Peabody started on Priceline a few weeks back. After reading many reviews on Yelp I decided to try my hand at bidding for a room through Priceline. Bid was accepted and I couldn't wait. There are a couple of things you only try once or twice in your life and staying at The Peabody for me is one of them.. I couldn't wait to check into my room and get out of the sweltering heat and humidity.  I could see my hair was already turning into Monica's humidity-ridden mane from that one episode where they are in Barbados!  Ugh! The heat!The moment we drove up we were greeted politely  by the bell-hop and directed to check in. It was all sunshine and smiles every step of the way :)Check in was smooth, nice polite hotel agent. Sad I didn't catch her name she did a great job and had a welcoming smile!  The walk to our room was very easy.Unlocking the door to our double queen room, which I was counting down to, was met with beautifully ice-kool refreshing air! Aaahhh!! I was in heaven!!... ok, ok.. onto the room... the view..the sites....the bed..The Duckies.... duckie soap, duckies to purchase and take home..duckie labels on the tissue roll ... I was loving the duckie motiff!Now onto the:Upside: Brilliant decor & architecture.Such amazing attention to detail throughout the building that started off in 1925 at its 2nd location. Marble all around the lobby with gorgeous columns lining the area.Comfy beds I didn't wanna wake up!Wonderful downtown location close to Beale Street.The charming hotel is famous for the matching ducksPool and hot tub on lower level were quite cozy and yet spacious at the same time. 3 areas conforming around the pool make up the workout areas. Downside: 3 phones in our room. The only working phone is the phone in the bathroom. *pic below*Shower head for a 4 hotel I would think should be better and a higher grade from the lower end it had.Low water pressure Self Serve Parking $18.00 a night which is doable however the parking structure is not a hop, skip & a jump away it's more, like a hike through Mt. Rainier. Going in and out of buildings and up and down elevators through a few different corridors until you've realized you are at the end of Beale Street. Picture to be added but before that we will need to prepare for the journey by packing a sack lunch and taking a few changes of clothes lol!Over all our weekend stay was great. No complaints as my vacay comes to an end.The Good: I was in Memphis for work and I have to say the Peabody is a very nice hotel. The room was very big and lovely. The ducks are also a nice touch. Also, it is in a fun area. I didn't have a car but found it easy to walk around. The Bad: I was not pleased with the customer service. I had a nice j crew sweater that I did not end up wearing and never left my room. At the end of my stay, I could not find the sweater after looking up and down for. It was white so I figured it could of easily been mistaken as a towel or sheet. I called the front desk and they said they would alert housekeeping and security. They were unable to find the sweater before I left the hotel but said they would follow up with me. A few days later I never heard from them. After calling the hotel and leaving a message with security, I never heard back. Pretty upsetting since it was a new sweater and didn't really feel the hotel was accommodating with following up and helping me locate it.Carved & painted wooden beams adorn the grande lobby, rivaling any palatial gathering spot.Strangers cannot help but enter and be amazed by its beauty.  Be a fly on the wall in the lobby bar and take it all in: conference attendees, international tour groups, and groups of Memphians.Majestic fountain with cascading flowers in bloom; Sonorous Trickling overflow of water.Fowls swim in lobbyOdd tradition hatched years pastNo duck on menu#NOLA_Haiku #Haiku#Memphis #PeabodyHotel#ElvisPresley #Graceland#GreaterMemphis#MidSouth #SouthernCharm
review_content_20: I love happy hour at Peabody Memphis!!  Red and white wines alike  get Happy at Happy Hour 5-7Great hotel with great atmosphere! Historic hotel with cute duck themed decor due to the trained ducks you can watch in the lobby. Really very cute. My room was a double room and the room was very cozy and comfortable. Beds were fluffy and not too springy, blankets were thick and heavy. Bathroom was on the smaller size, but still very comfortable and clean.The location is prime. Close to the Mississippi- could take a jog along the promenade. Right near Beale St., civil rights museum and main st. Easy to find.Bar and lobby are very charming. Ballroom and conference rooms spacious and lovely. Make sure to check out older photos of the ballroom! Since it is a historic hotel, it is of course older and some of the neighbors could be heard. Not that big of a problem though.On a side note, I read the Shining before staying here, probably not the best of ideas because it is also about a large historic hotel and terrifying.First off my review is based on the hotel itself, and not a stay. I stopped in to enjoy a drink and watch the famous Peabody Ducks whom swim in the lobby fountain during the day before they receive the grand exit treatment. Yes, this hotel takes these ducks seriously and they are ushered back to their private quarters for the evening as part of a grand presentation which fills the lobby and balcony of people wanting to get a look at the ducksWhile waiting for the ducks to make their exit I explored the lobby and open area of the hotel, which is very interesting. There is so much history to the hotel that it will take you a while if you stop and read about everything. Next time I am in Memphis, I am planning on booking a night here to experience the history and take in more of this amazingly historic hotel.As far as the ducks, it was an interesting concept however once it was said and done I was a little disappointed that I waited around to watch a grand presentation of some ducks walking out on a red carpet into an elevator. I understand the history behind it, however it just seemed a little silly. I appreciated the architecture and rich history of the hotel more than I did the ducks. Overall it was an experience and I can check it off my list.My wife chose to book this place, as she found a killer deal called home for the holidays or something and she said it was about half off or something like that. I'm not too sure but I think she found the deal directly through their website. Anyhow, upon checking in, we both realized what an amazing place this was right off the bat. The front desk staff was kind, and courteous. And I've never/rarely seen a hotel lobby this lively. They had a live piano going with a very nice Cocktail bar, and lounge smack dab in the center of the lobby. The place was very tastefully decorated all around. In the very center of the lobby was a big fountain with a great big amazing fresh flower arrangement, which was very beautiful. Everything was very elegant, and tasteful.So we get to our room, and it was awful... HA gotcha! Just kidding!!!So we get to our room, and it was gorgeous, and spacious. A big soft bed, nice flat screen TV, and all the decor was beautiful. My only complaints would be that both my wife and I agreed that the walls seemed a bit thin as we could hear our neighbors a bit too much. And the bathroom seemed a bit too small. Besides that everything was great...Went to a wedding reception and valet parked. After 1 hour at the reception they charged me $20.00. Robbery and low class.Stayed at this hotel a few years ago on a trip through the south.  We were excited to stay in this historic hotel with the famous duck march.  We were planning on staying 2 nights but after checking in and seeing what poor condition the room was in we decided to checkout the next day.  What a huge disappointment!! Our trip consisted fn many other historic hotels and they were all beautifully restored or maintained so there is absolutely NO reason this hotel should be so neglected.  The amount of tourists that frequent this hotel should be incentive enough to take pride in ownership and not let this place go so downhill.  Sad, sad, sad!!My stay at Peabody was one of the worst I've ever experienced. Giant bedbugs ate my foot. I posted pictures of it. I would stay away go find any other hotel this one's infested with bedbugs it was disgusting. A terrible experiencesThis place is a wonderful place to visit while you are walking around discovering so many of the wonderful places Memphis has to offer.  Almost every time I am in the area, I at least stop by to enjoy the history that is the Peabody.  They have done a great job of maintaining a lot of the history that surrounds the Peabody and some of the visitors that have spent time living in this beautiful historic hotel. You can see Francis Scott Key's piano. (He wrote the Star-Spangled Banner for those that did not know.) They maintain a beautiful reception area with a bar and a beautiful fountain. Daily you can watch the Duck Master bring the ducks to swim in the fountain and then take them back to their suite. If you are feeling romantic and want a very nice French restaurant, I highly suggest Chez Phillip, but don't expect to get Duck a l'orange as the Peabody will never serve duck. I have not yet tried any of the other cuisine you can get here, but I am sure the Peabody does a wonderful job.My first Thanksgiving in Memphis was spent alone as my husband was participating in Operation Enduring Freedom. A co-worker and I went to the late seating of the Thanksgiving dinner buffet. The food spread out along the entire second floor would have been suitable for the gods on Olympus. It was divine.The staff made you feel like family, couldn't do enough or refill your champagne glass enough for you even though they were obviously exhausted from the early seating masses. Glad I wasn't driving. The Peabody is a must for all. The ducks, John Phillips Sousa's square baby grand piano, Chez Phillipe and they are on the register as one of the historic hotels in America. The Peabody was my first check off my bucket list of historic hotels and will always hold a special place in my heart.My wife and I decided to spend one random night in Memphis as a mini-vacation. The Peabody was running some Expedia specials for 15% off, which made this historic hotel decently affordable, especially when combined with a $25 Expedia hotel credit I had earned.They have an attached parking garage with a covered walkway. It's pretty convenient, though it is $18 overnight. The official check-in time is 4:00, but we had no problem getting our room at 3:15. The Peabody's location makes it perfect for hopping around Beale Street.We had a traditional queen room, which was very nice. It wasn't overly spacious, but there was still plenty of room. Best of all, it was perfectly clean! The Tiffany-blue walls and the chandelier definitely added a touch of class that you don't find in a lot of hotels.
