Our bed was also decently comfy, so we slept well. They have complimentary tea and coffee in the morning, but we didn't partake. We did, however, make good use of the complimentary wifi in the room.Obviously the duck march is something you have to do when you stay at The Peabody. This happens twice a day at 11:00am and 5:00pm, but make sure to stake out your viewing spot at least 30 minutes in advance, if not sooner.The staff members here were all exceedingly friendly and helpful. The Peabody is more of an experience than it is just a place to sleep.What an amazing hotel.  Takes you back to the late 1800s when the hotel was built.  From the time you pull your car up, to check in, to the entry into your room, it was all amazing.  The feel of the hotel immediately takes you back to where everyone would dress for dinner.  Extremely royal feeling and very welcoming.  The hotel is excellently located within walking distance of everything.  The most interesting thing about the hotel is all of the history.  Below is just a tidbit of one of the key items (For all of you Elvis Fans) A receipt dating back to 1955 was sold at auction in 1999 for a reported $65,000 - close to 15 times the amount of the transaction it represented. It was piece of rock and roll history, a one-of-a-kind piece of memorabilia typed on The Peabody stationery and signed by Elvis Presley and his father, Vernon. It documented the receipt of a $5,000 bonus for signing with RCA, along with a smaller sum from Presley's publisher...minus Colonel Tom Parker's commission. The fact that the document was typed on a piece of The Peabody stationery makes it all the more valuable. Elvis' ties to the hotel date back to his teenage years when The Peabody was the location for his senior prom.Wow!!! This place is amazing and the duck show was very interesting as well. Hotel employees are very nice and friendly. A definite two thumbs up!Beautiful hotel and lobby, definitely worth walking through even if you're not staying there. The duck walk is adorable, however, the staff was surly and overbearing, and really tarnished the experience for us. The lobby security/duck Gestapo took their jobs a bit too seriously, and were very rude to anyone standing, talking, moving, doing human activities, etc., even the children. They're ducks, not Bengal tigers. Relax.I loved my stay at the Peabody Memphis. I've always wanted to stay here since I came to see the ducks as a child. I'm happy to report I'm not too cool to be impressed with the ducks, the duck master, and the overall spectacle of the whole thing. Beyond the ducks, I loved getting to stay at the Peabody. It was outside of our company limits, but then I found a deal on Kayak that put it in just the right range. I was so happy I could make it work, and I was not disappointed. The hotel itself is just as grand, perhaps even more so than I remember it being. The nice restaurants, the hotel bar, the full-service staff at every turn, right down to the duck designs inlaid in the marble inside the elevators. I loved my room. The bed and the linens were wonderful, and the room itself had everything I needed. I felt safe and secure, and the room was quiet in the way only older hotels seem to be. The housekeeper did a nice job, and there's not much better in life than a room service breakfast, IMO, and this was no exception.Love the hotel, but if you stay there, make sure NOT to stay to stay on the 4TH FLOORwhich is the "pet friendly floor. I've never heard so many dogs with separation anxiety from their owners in my entire life and I surely would not have expected that at The Peabody.This hotel lobby is beautiful but there is no coffee makers..microwave or fridge in the rooms. The bed was comfy. The carpets in the room are filthy. If u do self parking u have to walk forever to get to your car. I m not sure why it got 5 star rating.We had desserts at night by the fountain. All decedent! Lovely sophisticated atmosphere with a piano player playing requests. Wish the Ducks were in the fountain, but they leave at 5pm. We didn't have food ( just desserts), but would like to try some day. I would also recommend seeing the duck March at 11am and 5 pm.We booked this hotel because of its location, and of course, The Ducks. The Peabody and the ducks did not disappoint. Located in the heart of downtown, the Peabody provides easy access to any of a number of things to do in Memphis:  A short walk to Beale St., Sun records, or Gus's Famous fried chicken. The rooms were good size for a downtown city hotel. The room was clean and decorated nicely with a large flat screen TV, a desk and sitting area. The bathroom was a little small but had all the necessary amenities. The hotel was decorated for Christmas and was nothing short of spectacular and had one of the largest indoor Christmas trees I have ever seen in my life. The ducks perform each day at eleven and five o'clock, and the show is an absolute must see.  The staff was very pleasant and provided any assistance necessary. Regardless of why you go to Memphis, be it for business or pleasure, you can't go wrong at the PeabodyOkay first off...this review is for the entire building itself, hotel rooms and lobby, etc. The lobby is gorgeous, no doubt about that. The ducks are fun, everyone knows what that's like. Get there early, everyone knows that (I will say though that if you go in the evening when they go upstairs for the night, it's much less crowded than in the morning - but still packed). There's shops which are nice.The rooms though...it's an old building, I get that. Unfortunately, it's got everything bad about older buildings and nothing good. It's really loud in the rooms. Throughout the day, the chatter of the people in the lobby makes its way upstairs and echoes and amplifies, so it sounds like everyone is right outside your door. It's a little annoying at 2 pm but it's very annoying at night when you're trying to sleep. It's noisy in the hallways, you can hear doors slamming. Ugh.The water pressure in the bathrooms is terrible. It took me upwards of 20 minutes to wash my hair, and I'm still not sure I got all the shampoo out. It takes me five minutes at home. I don't expect insanely strong water pressure that'll peel my skin off, but that's just unacceptable.And the price. Unless you luck out and get in on some sale, you're looking at $200+/night. Given the sad state of the rooms, that's a huge rip-off.That said, the lobby itself is gorgeous, as I said. It's definitely worth it to go and have a drink by the fountain and check out the ducks. The food is pretty good, too. The whole lobby area is very classy and there's also some sculptures to look at if you're either waiting for the ducks to come/go or just wandering around.Great rooms! seriously I had no idea about all the ducks etc! It was a great surprise. The staff is friendly and there is of course great valet parking which is always awesome. Prices are 5 star hotel prices ! Cool deal!
review_content_40: This review is for the umpteenth duck viewing and lounge martinis. Great entertainment for free and great value and quality for supping. I love this lounge especially as Christmas. Elvis had his prom here and if it was good enough for the King then 'nuff said. Have said here long ago, rooms were small - due to age of hotel and pricey.If you're unlucky enough to have to be in Memphis, this might be the best place to be. Historic hotel that is a must just for the ducks. If you're unlucky enough to have an adjoining room to some other guest, beware you can hear everything. Everything is overpriced and touristy.The hotel is beautiful and we visited the bar area. We spent a nice evening relaxing on the couch, people watching, and sipping on wine. I love the ducks and the story behind them, and I love just sitting in the lobby doing some writing for a couple of hours while I people watch. I come here almost once a year and I have a great experience each and every time, I have never had any kind of experience less than perfect.We stayed here for one night on 9/8/15. The lobby was absolutely gorgeous, there was live piano music, people in the lobby, great atmosphere. We ordered a Mississippi mudslide, so good! We got there kinda late so hubby and I had to get a room with two queen beds. I liked the decorations, everything has ducks, from the pillow, to the soap and even the toilet paper. We stayed to watch the ducks walk down the red carpet and swim in the fountain. I loved everything in the hotel except for the grill restaurant, it was a bit lack luster and eggs benedict were awful.16 stays here now. We are always treated like royalty. Thank you so much to Graham in VIP services.Beautiful place. Stop in to see the ducks and (if you're lucky!) the duck march!The Peabody is an experience not to be missed, and agree completely after spending time here. I had heard that the hotel is a landmark in Memphis, and indeed it is. First of all the lobby is exquisitely decorated and the beautiful detail is best enjoyed while enjoying a drink or snack in the lobby. I was lucky enough to meet Doug, the GM who made sure that he added a special touch to make the visit memorable. The main attraction of the hotel is of course the ducks, who parade down each morning at 11am and up again at 5pm. During business hours you can see the 'Duck Palace' on the roof of the hotel, where the ducks hang out when not in the lobby. This roof deck also has a spectacular view of the city. Overall a landmark and experience not to be missed!We did not stay here but, we always go down to the Peabody whenever we visit Memphis. It's the happening place to be anytime. We love to go to the bar and have a drink and just people watch. it's also great fun to see the Peabody Ducks either come down in the morning or go back up in the evening as they walk the red carpet and follow the Duck-master. One of the best times to visit is also during the holidays. They have a huge tree all decorated and blazing with lights as is the entire lobby. It's also a great place to park and hang out before a game or a visit to Beale Street. The Trolly is currently not running but, when it runs again, you might also be able to catch it and go over to the Pyramid.The Peabody is a beautiful hotel. The lobby is gorgeous with an ornate ceiling and amazing woodworking. The staff are all, every single person, warm and friendly and welcoming. I loved the whole duck parade/ducks in the fountain thing they have going on. Nice to see a large hotel giving in to a sweet piece of whimsy. Location can not be beat - it is walking distance to Beale St., quite a few museums, and many delicious restaurants. I visited two of the hotel bars, and while expensive, both made a good cocktail.The room was nicely decorated. Beds were comfortable. The bathroom was one of the smallest hotel bathrooms I have ever seen. You could actually soak your feet in the bathtub while sitting on the toilet (if you were so inclined). And would it cost that much to add at least one towel bar in the bathroom? Sure would be helpful! Oh yeah, and add a coffee machine to all the rooms, too, instead of offering that as a perk if you "upgrade" your room (for $85).Finally-it was SO noisy in our room. Between the staff bustling about in the hallway, and every few minutes the SLAM! of a room door, it was not a room conducive to sleeping. Oh well. I would stay there again, but I'm definitely bringing earplugs next time!They should really serve free breakfast considering the price you pay per night. Wth?Nice place to visit, but not worth the money to stay.Great place for a company conference. There are so many meeting rooms of different sizes that can accommodate any size crowd. The price of course a little on the higher end but it is worth it.The hotel is very nice and the room was clean. Everything has the charm one would expect from a historic hotel. The Peabody will be our first choice, should we return to the wonderful city of Memphis.Didn't stay here just came for the "famous" ducks... give 3 stars because the hotel was pretty and the Ducks were cute but I almost pied my pants when i saw the "show" we were told that there was this duck show very important to see.. and that we had to get there an hour before to have a good spot to see. So we were there 30 minutes before and it was packed.. we had an ok spot and everybody was waiting for the big events. Then at 5 pm some "duck master" started telling this long ass story about the hotel history which nobody could hear because he spoke so soft and then after about 7 minutes talking he went up to the Ducks who were swimming in the fountain in the lobby and with 3 man with a stick they leaded the 5 ducks out of the fountain towards the elevator.. that was it...... what a show !!! Oh my... everybody was like.. did we miss something ????? We just laughed about it... I mean like for the kids maybe it's fun but they make it seem like it's something super extraordinary... well I got ducks in my garden that will do the same thing when I let them follow me with food and a stick but ok... they were cute though hahaOur first visit to Memphis was rich with history and it started the moment we pull up to The Peabody! This place screams elegance and tradition the moment you walk through the doors! The staff was friendly, rooms were nice and we were within walking distance to the places we wanted to visit. I would recommend this place to a couple, family or someone in town for business. We will be staying here again without a doubt!My husband is in the Navy and we booked a room here on Hotels.com just a few days before he leaves for boot camp, so we could have a romantic evening together alone, before he's gone for 2 months. We also made dinner reservations at Chez Philippe. When we arrived the girl at the counter told us to wait for a minute and the manager would come talk to us. The lobby was packed with Arkansas fans so our hearts fell immediately. When the manager finally came we were notified that we no longer had a room. She was very sweet and obviously felt terrible, it was clear that she cared. She had found us a room at another hotel and would transport us there free of charge and offered a return stay. We went to our dinner reservations and the staff and food were incredible. Never in my life has anyone treated me so much like they really cared about me as an individual and the inconveniences. In the end we didn't end up getting a hotel room anywhere because everyone was fully booked, except the heartbreak hotel, which didn't appeal to us, but they offered a few different things and most definitely redeemed themselves. review_content_60: I've been coming to Memphis on and off now for about three years and had never stayed at the Peabody. Was finally able to book a room and now see what we've been missing. We loved shopping at Lansky's (aka Clothier to the King)...and who doesn't love the ducks!Exceptional place to stay! Truly a hotel with a southern charm. Make sure to valet your car..because their self parking situation is a little bit inconvenient.I was very unhappy with Valet and customer service.  We were told that if we went into the hotel they would validate the parking and there would be no cost as long as we made a purchase.  That is not true at all.  We spent a lot on over priced drinks and they would not validate.  Even talked to the Manager and she was not professional at all.  Her name was Linda Green.  We asked for someone above her and she said she was it.  I would never stay there if they treat customers like that.  I travel all over the world and stay at amazing 5 star hotels and never have been treated like this or lied to.Ahh, the Peabody.  Besides the famous BBQ and Blues, this was the only landmark I could really ever associate Memphis with.  The "Grand Hotel of the South" was originally created in 1869, and its current location has stood since 1925.  It is one of 3 AAA 4 diamond hotels in Memphis, and I had a lot of high expectations.  In fact, I would rather want to stay in a hotel built in the beginning of the 20th century than something more modern.  I like the history and the grandeur associated with places like this. My travel plans for the weekend got derailed at the last minute, and I noticed on expedia I could find get a room for either $179/189 a night.  Rooms usually run $240 and up ($233 with AAA).  I figured this would be a good excuse to jack up my review count.Upon entering the parking deck, you go left for valet ($26), and straight for self park.  Now here is a tip- if you have trouble walking or need help with luggage, my advice to you is to spend the extra $$ for the valet.  The walk to the deck can be quite long if you get winded easily, and there is no bell boy out in the deck.  For someone with a backpack, it wasn't too much of an issue (except the humidity).Also, one thing that is kind of annoying- the famous ducks.  Well, it isn't their fault.  Hell- I love the ducks.  They rock.  Unfortunately though, they come downstairs at 11AM (the same time as check out) and go back up at 5PM (an hour past check in time).  What am I getting at?  The elevators and lobby get hellish at the 2 most important times of the day.  Check in was easy thankfully, but waiting for an elevator took about 15 minutes, as everyone lined up (as there were 4 elevators for the hotel) wanting to go see the ducks on the roof.  They should time that differently, IMO.I got room 1111, which had 2 double beds and a decent view of Auto Zone Park (could see the jumbotron from the room).  The room was on the smaller side (one of the smaller rooms I have stayed in), but it got the job done.  The bathroom had marble inlay, and tons of towels too.  The toilet flushed quietly, and there was a phone in there to multitask.  The shower had light pressure, but got the job done.  Overall, the room wasn't too bad.  One thing I did notice too, there was not a coffee maker to my knowledge in the room.  There were robes though, and there were thirsty robes.  After taking a shower, I would be dry within minutes- a nice touch.After getting situated, it was time to walk around the lobby and whatnot- to find the pool and other things.  So we (my roomie and I) went to the M floor and walked around.  There is a history room, that I shocked not more people were in- hell, we were the only people in there!  It documented the entire history of the Peabody.  2 highlights included a Babe Ruth signature and Elvis' first recording contract bonus with RCA.  Cool shit.  A nice place to check out if you have the 5 minutes.The next thing was to look for the pool that I kept hearing about.  I was told it was 24 hour fitness center for guests and club members.  The pool was nice, but small- I really wanted to jump in, but the place was filled.  The locker room was somewhat small, for a 464 room hotel.  2 showers, 1 stall.  We knew would would come back later.After getting drinks in the lobby (which we have done plenty of times before) and getting nice and fuzzy- it was time to venture out, as we didn't have to drive anywhere and we were located in the backyard of Beale St.  We came back a little after midnight, and much to our dismay, we couldn't get into the fitness area.  So much for 24 hours?  So we went back to the room to retire.  I realized that they had the breakfast thing, so I decided to get 2 breakfasts set for 920-940AM.  I had placed it on the door before the 2AM deadline...  As when I woke up the next day and saw the bill on the ground, the bfast thing was taken.For whatever damn reason, I waited, and waited.  Breakfast never came.  That was some horseshit!  I hope it doesn't show up on the updated bill, because my breakfast wasn't until 5PM today unfortunately...When it was time to check out, the elevator situation sucked again, as this time, one of the elevators was cutoff for the ducks.  When we got down to the lobby at like 1045, the lobby was full.  And then the new duckmaster was telling the story of the ducks.  We watched for a few, then got the hell out of there.  On the what seemed to be a mile long walk to the car, there was a pay station that said to PAY here before leaving.  If you are paying with a CC, ignore this- as a CC reader is at the exit.  Also, I noticed that you can tap your hotel card to exit, but I didn't even think of using it out of bad faith.  It never listed anything about free parking for guests, unless I overlooked that completely.  Well, if the room key gets you out, then hell yea.  If not, it is $18 a night.  If I were you: stay at the Westin and come to the Peabody for drinks and entertainment.The Peabody has a history in Memphis and probably the most recognized high end hotel.  A few blocks from Beale, it is a good location in Memphis.  Across the street is the minor league baseball team as well.  Walking in the lobby alone gives you the feel of this eloquent hotel.  Come here, rest in the lobby, order a drink and watch how the other half lives.I love this hotel.  True southern elegance and charm.  The ducks just addTo the character.  Staff is always super friendly and the lobby bar is one of the best in America!The Peabody's beauty is in it's history. Oh yes and the duck's are a cute touch too. The room we stayed in for a conference was fine, nothing special, but fine. They do, however have a ton of great bonuses such as:1) Rooftop Parties in the summer2) Happy Hour at The Corner Bar - $2 wine on Wednesday! 3) Shopping! Lots of shopping4) Convenience as you can litterally walk across the street to the Redbirds, Beale Street, and many great restaurants4) Lobby Bar with live music (pianist)5) Salon in the basement - Gould's offers massage, facial, hair, and nails6) When you're always working like me, FedEx becomes your bff and there is one connected to the Peabody LobbyHeck, maybe I should give them 5 stars...I'm giving this hotel a four star on the lobby alone! Really happening lobby bar with lots to look at. The service in this area is top notch. Love the ducks on the fountain. We were on the concierge floor (12). Very good service at the lounge. Food needs to be worked on though. More variety, quantity and quality food. Also, real brewed coffee! Enough of this instant coffee that kuereig spits out!!Our room was small but nice. Bed very comfy. The bathroom needs updating. Not enough lighting and tub needs to be replaced with a shower. The toilet did not look clean by the floor. Noise was a problem. You can here every door closing and people talking. Oh Helio 6am!This review is for the Peabody Ducks only! I did not stay at The Peabody, but I did stay in Memphis down the street. I had never heard of The Peabody Ducks before this short trip, but my traveling companion declared we had to see two things in Memphis (besides Pearl Jam at FedEx Forum, and Beale Street that we had visited the night before.) One was Graceland, of course, and the other was The Peabody Ducks. Two times a day this happens. The Peabody Ducks march in and out of the Peabody Hotel's fountain watched on by many people who stay in the hotel, people who don't stay in the hotel, people who are taking a bus tour and, I assume, people who are just sitting at the bar trying to drink in peace. Since there is a bar right there. They literally roll out a red carpet for these little guys and the whole process takes about 5 minutes. That is, unless you get there super early to get a good seat. The Duck Master, in like, a tux, comes out and announces the ducks and this fancy, official, royal-sounding music plays. The elevator opens up and 4 little guys waddle out and down the red carpet to hop into the fountain. It is adorable. They are brown ones that look like they came out of a park lake, but I heard these lucky ducks actually have some very expensive apartment at the top of The Peabody.There is no charge to get up on here and you can watch from the first or second floor. If you drink, why not show up a little early and enjoy yourself, I guess! The Peabody Ducks are a cute must-see at least once if you are in Memphis anyway. :)The Peabody Memphis is an historic hotel located in the heart of Memphis, just 2-3 blocks from Beale Street.I stayed here for a work conference and felt that it was one of the nicest, most unique hotels I have ever stayed in. Because the hotel is in a historic building, the decor is grand- with mahogany paneling, thick crown molding, marble floors. The marching of the Peabody ducks in to and out of the hotel lobby fountain twice daily is a major tourist attraction and makes staying at the hotel that much more unique. The service is absolutely top notch. The staff are cheerful and helpful.The rooms are beautiful! Even the basic rooms (which I stayed in) are richly appointed. The bath products are also unique, with soaps in the shape of ducks.This is an absolutely beautiful hotel.  Beautiful.  It has that old school, old money mahogany feel that you don't really get in hotels anymore.  In the very center is a beautiful fountain surrounded by a great bar...where the ducks do their walk twice a day.  If you're ever in town, I suggest you check it out - its a fun little touristy thing to do, and they do put on a great show.Plus...its fun to squeeze (or attempt to squeeze) ducks cause they're so cute!There are a number of stores and restaurants here, and the room was comfortable (albeit...quite small, must remember to upgrade next year).  We were also consumed by the overwhelming number of republicans here for the convention...odd.  The gym was small but nice, decent equipment and the people working there were very friendly.  The one thing I did note was the insane...insane...prices of the food and room service here.  I mean, I know I'm in a hotel...but I'm also in memphis.  37 dollars for a small pizza and a bottle of water?  That's ridiculous.  AND I'm from NY where I expect to over pay for things.That being said, I decided to walk across the street in the middle of the night for water and some lovely local followed me back to my hotel asking me to buy him dinner. You're not in the nicest neighborhood folks, so if you don't have your stun gun, your donk, or people with you...don't wander off by yourself.  For the most part, people in the south are very sweet, but there are criminals everywhere!PSA done for the day.My favorite Frank Sinatra quote is, "I feel sorry for people who don't drink. When they wake up in the morning, that's as good as they're going to feel all day."I like that quote because there is just something old school glamour about it. Maybe that is why I like the Peabody? It is, without a doubt, my favorite place in Memphis to get a drink. It has the best people watching plus it defines what Memphis is to me - at least all of the best parts. I've had holiday meals here with my family, debutante balls, met celebrities, drinks with my loved ones, and spent numerous special occasions here. I guess "special" is the best word I can come up with to accurately describe it, even though that seems totally lame. Someone once told me that a limo could make even the most boring night interesting...I think drinks at the bar by the fountain applies here too. If you're in town, even if you don't stay here, get a drink and watch the ducks splash around!!We booked this place based on a great recommendation, sadly we weren't sold! The bathroom is extremely small. There was no room to put things aka contacts, makeup.... The lobby is loud and super crowded most of the time. The staff at Duck Time are less than friendly, but seemed in good sports aside from that. The room was clean and the paint color really did brighten up the area. We could hear the roof party from our room, so if you like music that's good! The location is great, close the Beale St. The idea of ducks in a fountain is really exciting but not worth that lobby rush or the elevator ride after! All in all, three stars- great location, great sight seeing, loud lobby, over priced eateries!We came into Memphis late friday afternoon and checked into the hotel. On a BFF/sister road trip.  The hotel staff Charles (the valet), Laporciea (forgive the misspelling), Jeffrey (bellman), Justin (engineering) all pleasant individuals and very helpful. However things took a turn when the toilet began to clog (later clearing itself) Jeffrey alerted engineering and Justin checked it out for us. Hotel is beautiful convenient location.Later, my sister and I headed out for the evening and when we returned about 11-11:30 pm. I went to use the rest room and the handle to the toilet did not work.  So my sister, (being the room is registered in her name called down to the front desk.) Janice offered to change our rooms and have someone contact us with the change. Enter Ladonna who confirms the room change and is sending someone to assist in the move. The gentlemen arrives with no luggage cart and had to leave to retrieve one. By this time I am heated and annoyed. (Heated because something weird was going with the AC that the room never truly became cool. Something that did not become evident until the room change).Back to the situation... we are finally moved to the new room and the room has shrunk. (Tight fit in the first room to begin with.) So Ladonna is contacted and a compensation for inconvenience and reduction in room space is sought, maybe a waiver of the valet fee. My sister was told this couldn't happen because they focus on the service attached like wifi (when we checked in we were told it's free) or coffee and tea services (we don't drink coffee and it"s 80 degrees outside at almost midnight!) At this point Michelle the night "manager" steps in and things went from bad to worse. To the tune of..1. We can move you again...you said needed two beds in your room...2. We are unable to offer a discount because of third party booking.3. No complmentary valet because she doesn't have "authority" because that's a different department and it requires money to change hands.4. Offered a free buffett???5. When asked about her boss we were was told, "he is in here tomorrow, oh he's not here tomorrow." "I know there not going to be able to do it."6. Provided information. That free valet is offered to 5th and 6th floor residents.My issues with this conversation,  1. Any upgrades for the inconvenience of your hotels lack of working equipment, the offer should of been extended before the room change. I shouldn't have to pick up the luggage and etc. that I am traveling to 4 states  with back and forth through the hotel hallways. I need two beds because that is what I ordered and paid for and that as a customer is what I should get for two people.2. Your statement of third party vendors is not only insulting to your affiliates, partners, and the travel agents that supply business but to the customers that depend on your professionalism and care. So your customers who are booked "third party" do not deserve the same respect, care and attention as your direct booking customers????3. Short answer figure out how to apply the best customer service methods for the customer. I'm not interested in your departments or problems. No one on a vacation is.4. I have planned out my itinerary with my travel agent and eating at the buffett is not one of them, especially after this ordeal. 5. Bad customer service form to add to the rest of the above.6. You know if complimentary service is offerd to those floors and you moved us there erasing the valet fee we would of never known and I would of thought the world of this hotel and staff. It was comunicated with the initial move that floor choice wasn't a issue.In closing we were in Birmingham,  AL the night before at the Hilton Garden Inn in a suite that was 1 1/2 times as big and half the price. A hotel I did not give enough credit to before I arrived and thought that if the room at the Hilton was awesome Then the  Peabody should be extraordinary,  sadly  that was wishful thinking, right now at 1:29 a.m. I wish I was at the Hilton Garden Inn.I couldn't find where it was worth $250 a night to stand in line to watch 5 ducks walk to and from an elevator...but it did at the Memphis Peabody.It's a nice old hotel, with tiny motel-sized rooms ($250/night) and 5 ducks.We stayed at the hotel this past weekend to celebrate our 40th Wedding Anniversary..thought something special was in order...turned out only average accommodations with not special staff.Friday night we went to the Memphis Redbirds baseball game (across from the hotel) and returned about 9:00 to find a message on the phone from the concierge stating we had a package at the desk (11 floors below) back downstairs we went to find a vase of flowers sent by my daughter...this hotel that boasts of southern charm and quality service couldn't send someone up to our room with the vase of flowers...the concierge desk at that! Extremely disappointing and disappointed...send someone up and leave them in the darn room for our surprise...'ya think?Won't return to the Peabody!The Peabody is a grand 'ol beauty. Somehow we were upgraded to the "Peabody Club" floor which requires placing your key card over a special reader in the elevator while you look down with disgust on the "common" people on their way to the roof for the great and totally free view of the city (make sure everyone is watching when you do it so you look like a super posh jerk).Not certain how we qualified for this privilege but I do have a [ridiculous] theory. I have a dead cheap piece of junk IKEA garment bag, which oddly is super-luminous blinding white. Since I was too cheap to valet park, I carried all my clothes in this bag at once and draped my weird jacket over the bag (has sort of a nehru style collar). The combo looked like I was carrying some royal garment from a faraway land with deep pockets for my meeting with Memphis investors, thus the upgrade! (it is just a theory) In reality they thought "poor idiot, just look at his cheap crap garment bag, let's give him a thrill for once".The heavily mentioned Peabody Club 12th floor is nice. Benefits of this exclusive concierge level are: "complimentary drinks and snacks throughout the day, a welcome cocktail, and honor bar". So, basically not too many benefits.Recently renovated, the room was fresh and new. Modern comfortable furniture, cool lighting (little motion sensing LED nightlights under the furniture to avoid late night toe stubbing). This "swanky" floor includes a couple nice lounge areas and a healthy dose of superiority. For all the hype, you won't feel any "Ritz-Carlton" awkwardness here. Though the historic building is beautifully decorated and dripping in brass, hardwoods and red velvet, this is still the South. Once you leave the lobby, rooms are pretty average.  My rating of the Peabody is on a regional curve. It is the most luxurious hotel, in Memphis. Full of friendly middle class families visiting the big city from rural Arkansas during my stay, you'll just have a good time here and receive good service. It is close to all Memphis attractions. A short, safe walk to Beale, FedEx Forum, etc. Even if you choose to stay at one of the many acceptable lower priced options in the area (the Peabody is honestly not a good value) stop in to enjoy a drink in the beautiful lobby, say hi to the ducks and head up to the roof for a few photos. FYI check-in and getting around is a bit of a nightmare during the very popular daily duck march.Well, where to start?Self parking never worked right. Even at 18$ a day. They forgot to tell us to make reservations for breakfast, and wouldn't seat us. The only other on property restaurant was a counter of cereal and muffins- that's not going to happen! Fortunately we went to The Bon Ton. It's close and good, and the concierge offered it up after she decided that the place further away would be too busy because she sent everybody else there.In retrospect they're challenged as far as being able to feed their guests and that's probably because there are plenty of decent food locations nearby. Even the bar was waitstaff challenged. The ducks are fine but I think they focus too much on them and not enough on us as customers. My biggest complaint is that someone took clothes out of our room and no one ever offered us any help or offered anything in return. Maybe it was just a tough weekend, maybe the good managers were on vacation, maybe the bad weather drove the employees to act in a not very helpful manner. I don't know, but at the end of the day we had things taken out of our room, and the Hotel and its staff didn't care. I say lock up your valuables and go off campus for every meal.$9.50 for a mimosa??? $6.75 for a Bloody Mary is not too bad but the other prices are way too much. I'm not sure why everyone loves the ducks so much but they are worth seeing once I guess. For the price of this hotel: I would never stay here.
review_content_80: Beautiful hotel with excellent lobby, and rooms are thoughtfully decorated. I want to sell my house and move into this hotel.I came here when about 15 years ago during a spring break trip and came by. My how has the place changed. It is so built up now. It was overcrowded and seeing the ducks were incredibly hard to see. I'd have rather they limit the amount of people that can see the ducks to guests and those buying drinks at the bar.Get here at least 30 minutes early to get a good viewing spot.  You can also sit in the lobby/bar and order some coffee while you wait. We got there about 15 minutes before 11am, and it was crowded and the place had filled up already.  About 10 minutes before 11am, the duck master comes out and gives a talk on how the Peabody ducks got started.  Then he goes up the elevator and everyone patiently waits for the elevator to come back down with the ducks.  After the ducks come down, it takes them about 10 seconds to get down the red carpet and into the fountain.... the whole thing went by in a blur... literally (as seen on my camera)!Beautiful architecture, but absolutely minuscule bathrooms, which are surprisingly dark and impractical. Cleanliness wasn't fabulous either. Room was tidy, but not well vacuumed. Debris and detritus from previous guests is never a good way to welcome new guests. Front desk clerk was rather surly and lacking the hospitality so often associated with the South. However, the other staff members were positively delightful. The ducks are cute, but this Grand Dame is resting on her laurels. There's an element of faded glory. That said, there isn't all that much competition. I suspect that's what allows them to charge room rates that are disproportionate to the level of quality and service. With a refresh and greater attention to detail and courteousness, perhaps The Peabody can regain its former stature. Until then, this big fish should hope no more competitors crowd this pond.Absolutely beautiful hotel. The staff is tremendous, so friendly and willing to accommodate you. William is the best, he really went above and beyond to make our stay better. Very appealing ball and conference rooms as wellGood service. This place is a time capsule. It looks like it did in the late 1800s. Beautiful.Currently staying here on business from NYC so I can't speak to the prices of anything in the hotel, but the building is beautiful and full of historical value. The duck parade, while fleeting, is charming and a nice touch of fun history for all ages. The staff are friendly and polite: everyone greets you with a smile and "have a great day."The lobby is impressive and you will get the best view for photos from the mezzanine. The rooms are well-appointed and comfortable, toiletries smell nice and water pressure is good. The biggest complaint I have about my room (located on the 10th floor) is the noise. I am located right next to the service elevators so I can hear what sounds like the elevator moving up and down and the elevator cables rattling. This happens close to every 5-30 seconds. SECONDS. It's not terribly loud, but when you can hear it that often, it becomes downright aggravating. The walls are fairly thin overall. Luckily I didn't have to spend much time in the room except to sleep at night. If you're in Memphis and can afford it, I would still recommend the Peabody over nearby motels for its grandeur and charm, but you may want to bring earplugs if you're located by the elevators or sensitive to recurring noises.I LOVE this hotel! It's a beautiful hotel and the staff is very welcoming. The rooms are beautifully decorated, and the view we had was incredible! It's definitely worth that pretty penny to stay here. If you're touring Memphis and not staying at the Peabody, you at least have to stop by!Peabody brunch for Easter was nice,  orchestrated well, our server was wonderful.  Two stars for the following,  though an opulent spread odd food was presented,  the taste and quality was not up to part for the $85 price tag.  There were some lightlights, but unless it was a popular dish., it was not refreshed from what I observed walking around.  Was a nice visit,  but failed to meet my expectations based on all the press.Grand old hotel. We Pricelined and got a great deal and then upgraded to a suite on the club floor. Martini's at the bar, the Duck March at 5:00 (get a seat early!), shrimp and grits at BB Kings, walking on Beale Street, sitting on the rooftop at night at the Peabody made for a nearly perfect one night visit to Memphis. Excellent, friendly service.Hotel is a national treasure. Rooms were lovely, Italian restaurant there was very good. Concierge service was excellent. Highlight of Memphis for me was the parade of the ducks and visiting their penthouse. Great experience. I would recommend some priority be given to hotel guests for the duck parades. We had to elbow it out with the hundreds of outsiders who come in to view this.Housed in the historic Peabody Hotel main lobby, the duck march is worth the trip. Cute, funny and smart, the production put on by the hotel for visitors is worth the visit.Hint:It's gets very crowded in the lobby while the big crowd of visitors waits for the show. Go upstairs to the balcony level for a better uncrowded view.While I did not stay at the hotel, we did enjoy our visit at this classic historic hotel.I'm here at the Peabody for a summer conference.  While the interior of the hotel looks nice, and the room itself is ok, the services are certainly lacking. I have a double bed room, the bed itself is ok, the pillows are a little soft for my liking.  The room however, has a smell to it, more of a funk, not something I expect from a supposed 4-star hotel.  It all seems old and needs renovating, badly.  The walls are absolutely paper thin, you can hear everything from inside the room, the elevators, the neighbors, people going down the hall, etc. The wifi at the hotel is non-existent.  For hosting a summer conference, you need wifi, and it is ridiculous that in 2014, the wifi at a 4-star hotel is non-existent.  They offer complimentary coffee at their in-house restaurant, it is sub-par, barely palatable. Again, I expected more.  I'm just totally let down by this hotel, did not meet expectations in any way.I will not be staying here again.If this hotel was a woman it'd be a grand old dame in a splendid ball gown with big hair and a southern accent carrying a parasol and duck under her arm. Go check out the duck parade, held every day at 11am and 5pm. It's kind of a big show over very little, but it's weird and its fun and the kids love it. And the lobby, man, it's opulent. It's in the style of the grand old hotel lobbies, and the bar pumps at night. The other giant drawcard? The rooftop. Grab yoself a martini and watch the sun go down over the Mississippi. And congratulate yourself for winning at life.An historic hotel in Downtown Memphis, right by Beale Street, The Peabody may be best know for the "Duck Walk". At 5 pm daily, there are 5 ducks that will walk from the fountain in the middle of the atrium in the lobby to the elevators, on their way to the Penthouse. This has been a tradition at this hotel since the 1930's, and it is very cute! Quite a show, and very popular, especially for the kids.Check-in was fine; I was a bit surprised my room wasn't ready when I came at about 5pm (so I watched the ducks), but this particular weekend in Memphis was extremely busy with a major NCAA Basketball tournament, so I figured no worries. I did get my room within about an hour, not so bad considering the craziness!Rooms are fine, well-appointed, clean, and outlets everywhere! Comfortable beds and pillows.  Shower has great water pressure.42-inch flat screen TV in the room. TV is also equipped with the "Mobile Remote" option. If you don't know about this, GET THE APP and PAY THE .99 cents a year for the TV guide. The app is called STAYCONNECT, and it basically makes your smartphone a remote for the TV. MUCH nicer than touching a remote used by thousands of other folks, and with the TV Guide option it is a no-brainer if you travel more than 10 times a year.I chose the option to self-park, cost me $18 bucks/day. Not horrible.A real classy place. I got lucky and scored a corner room looking at the river. The rooms were very clean and the mattress/pillows were super comfy. My favorite part though was definitely the staff. This was southern hospitality at its best bWhile the hotel is really nice, I wish we had stayed somewhere else. They were so busy that we couldn't check in until 4:30pm, then it was so noisy from being so close to Beal Street that even though we were very tired from walking the whole day, we couldn't even get a good nights rest.What a wonderful experience to stay at the Peabody in Memphis. The hotel is absolutely beautiful. They do the running of the ducks into the fountain twice a day and that is quite an experience The hotel rooms are luxurious and the food is good. Definitely a treat to experience in the southern hospitality.I love the Peabody. It's not often that I go in here, but the atmosphere is just enjoyable. Come for the people watching and to see a piece of Memphis history.  This is a Memphis staple, so check it out!This is the classic hotel to stay in while in Memphis. The rooms are nice and the lobby area is outstanding! You can enjoy drinks and small food in the lobby while you wait for the march of the Peabody Ducks (either in the morning or evening).The staff are courteous and efficient too. You'll have a nice stay here.

review_content: This experience was everything I have heard it is and more.  Considering you are walking around inside someone else's personal home,  the tours of the mansion are very well organized and put together...it is really an amazing welcoming, unexplainable feeling when you first open the front door and step inside the house.  Also, being a creative person myself, I was really able to appreciate so many of the decor details.I'm so glad that because of all the "guests" that go visit every year, the Presley family have been able to keep this beautiful gem of land and keep Elvis' legacy alive for all the new generations.  All other tours are worth seeing too and very informative.   Wonderful friendly staff everywhere.I really couldn't help fallin' in love with Elvis' mansion and home. I mean, we're in Memphis here, and it really does seem like the "thing" to do. But my parents never listened to Elvis (sorry, we never tapped into that country side of America) and my only real exposure growing up was through random Napster downloads just to fill my playlist. As full as my fandom may be, it was still a great experience to visit Graceland and see the home of this legend....at least for the free garden tour from 7:00 - 9:00 on select days!Yep, that's right. We're guilty of not shelving out $40 each to the Presley estate for a tour inside the home itself. We really didn't need to. Our mission was to visit Elvis' home, pay our respects, and enjoy some of his classics while driving down to the Graceland area (which really can be sketchy at night).The garden tour allowed us to visit his gravesite, admire the beauty of his home, and avoid the rush of tourists all for free. It was a tranquil and beautiful visit, and we were satisfied with being able to at least be 'this' close to Elvis. Afterwards, we ventured across the street to the makeshift Elvis theme park and took advantage of the free photo opportunities and wall art, since it was practically deserted in the early morning.Graceland itself was a great visit for the short hour we were there, so I'd definitely recommend it for both the casual and diehard Elvis fans out there. It's something not to miss.When I'm travelling and I tell people that I'm from Memphis, it's either they sing me a song or ask me if I've been here. And I've never been until this week. I felt like I just had to go. I have to see it, to see what the fuss is all about.Honestly, I'm not a fan of Elvis. When I was born, he was already dead. Even though my dad had a collection of his albums and has gone to some of his concerts.Anyway, so this place is a good experience. It feels like you are walking in a place entirely dedicated to Elvis, because it is the home of Elvis so some of his stuff are still there. It's good to be transported back to history for at least a few minutes or an hour. It's a museum nonetheless. And the good thing is the tours are organized. The tour guides were really friendly and accommodating.I love the decorations of the house itself. I can't describe it. All I can say is, to each his own. The friend who was with me didn't really like it, but I did. After the tour, I at least appreciated Elvis more, and I might keep and treasure some of Dad's Elvis memorabilia.The food was a bit pricey for me, but my friend said that it's a normal thing for places like this where things are unique to them. So this is Elvis' home, you only see these here, so we'll charge you more. But it was worth it, worth a once-in-a-lifetime visit.For history buffs, music enthusiasts, and most especially for Elvis's fans. And also, for the kids of this generation that we can also appreciate the music of the past and the people who made music the way it is.Is this a tourist trap? Obviously. But is this still worth a visit? Of course.Coming into this place, I wasn't really a big fan of Elvis. The music really isn't my cup. But after coming here and seeing what this guy was about, I can at least appreciate the guy. Bring your wallet, because this place can get pretty pricy, really fast. Between the food options and the parking, you'll walk away with a much lighter wallet than you thought you would. Cool exhibits and some cool history to be found here.I'd always wanted to go to Graceland - my family are massive Elvis fans, and when I'm at a karaoke bar, it's Elvis all the way.I really liked the way the tours were run - each person was given an iPad with preloaded audio content (narrated, bizarrely, by John Stamos), meaning you could take it at your own pace.The property itself was so much fun to explore. It's totally garish and gaudy, but great - it's always fun to have a nosy in someone else's home, and the touches that would've been cutting edge in their day were hilarious. Three TVs next to each other, on at the same time? Sure.I also had a look at the inside of his private jet, his collection of cars, and his iconic headstone, too. A must-see if you're in the area!No cheesy Elvis jokes. No crazed fandom in this review either. I tell you what though; I was skeptical at first but Graceland was a lot of fun actually. I was also skeptical about the iPads and yet they ended up working great. Sure, you walk around looking like an octogenarian getting used to technology gadgets but they were full of insightful tid-bits. Cool. My favorite room was the trophy room because it was full of media and fun displays. The house itself was really cool to see too. Man, I would have tumbled down that mirrored  stairwell, Elvis. The automobile museum was the next best thing. Hang out here and watch the micro short film while you wait for your tour. After having visited Elvis' home in Tupelo, I surely appreciated Graceland more than I anticipated. Get here after 2pm so you don't have to wait in gas-shortage-pandamonium-long lines. If you buy your ticket elsewhere (visitor centers, etc.) you still need to stand in the ticket line to exchange it for your tour pass. So it saves you money, not time. Alrighty. I didn't bother visiting the airplanes or tasting the restaurant food.Honestly, I'm not an Elvis fan but everyone says 'you can't visit Memphis and not go to Graceland.' Trust me, yes you can.It is ridiculously expensive. I really wanted to see his airplane, but for that, you're spending about $70. So we opted for the cheapest ticket (almost $40 WITH a student / AAA discount) which just includes the Graceland Mansion / property. You can't go upstairs in the house. It's cool to see the rooms, and I suppose that if you're really into Elvis, it's more interesting to learn about him. But I'm not a fan of his music and I honestly don't find him that interesting of a person.You have been warned.If you love Elvis or are in Memphis for some vacationing, its a must see. We did the VIP tour which got us the access to the additional areas of the property. I'd say it was definitely worth it. The tour gave a pretty insightful view to his and his family's life. There was tons of memorabilia, we were able to see all his cars, and see his private jets. I was pretty impressed with how well kept the mansion was. Its definitely a life-size time capsule from the 70s.One negative thing i'll mention is that the place is definitely like a theme park as far as prices go, so be aware of that when you go. We came prepared so it wasn't too much of a sticker shock when stocking up on souvenirs.This is a difficult place to visit. At some point I felt it was wrong to be trampling through Elvis's home.  He had very little privacy, nothing sacred left when he was alive, except for Graceland.  And now thousands upon thousands (including me) come to be nosey.  I didn't enjoy the experience too much. It's chaos at the check-in/shopping center across the street. It's also ridiculous how you have to be shuttled from one spot to the next while at Graceland, even though it's walking distance from one point to the next.  They provide you with huge tablets that are video & narrated by John Stamos.  Most people are trying to deal with the tablet and looking at the tablet rather than paying attention while in the house.  They need to get rid of that and just allow people to be "present" in the home. I left feeling very sad.Elvis's spirit is everything and everywhere. There isn't anyone that can compare. I hope the Elvis Presley Estate tones it down a bit and goes for longevity and sacredness of a beautiful human being, rather than just raking in the money over a deceased loved one.I feel like part of American culture...everyone should visit Graceland in Memphis, Tennessee. After spending a couple days in Chattanooga, coming over to western Tennessee to see Elvis was a great transition.The lines were not as bad as I thought they'd be. Also, what I really enjoyed was...they give you headphones and you take a self guided tour at your own leisure! I loved this! After taking a short bus trip to the actual house, you visit almost every room including the backyard where Elvis is buried as well as his horse stable. All of Elvis' records, awards and honors are all hanging in parts of Graceland. It's truly an up close and hands on experience. The tour lasted 1 -2 hours...but take your time...being at Graceland is a surreal experience as Elvis is known as the greatest entertainer/musician of all time.I really enjoyed being at Graceland and I recommend everyone visit at some point in time. Also, the city of Memphis is great as well including Beale Street, The Peabody Hotel, Stax Museum of American Soul Music, Sun Studio, The Pyramid, Mud Island and FedEx Forum.Enjoyed visiting Graceland Manson-Elvis house. The house is like no other. The way they decorated back then was very different. Very interesting to see how he lived. Pretty neat. We got to see all the cars, Hawaii tour and all the awards and costumes. We ended up getting the VIP pass. The only negative part is that is a choice of restaurants. The places that are around the tour and shops are really gross. You have to go to downtown on Main in  Memphis for a decent place.We had pre-planned this trip thoroughly, as we had quite an extensive itenary. Started in Pigeon Forge, then onto Memphis, Tn, Nashville, Tn. I know sounds crazy, but we had specific dates set for certain attractions we were going to go see! We had a blast throughout our trip."I'm going to Graceland, Graceland, Memphis Tennessee. I'm going to Graceland....(cue the bass strings)"--Paul SimonSorry I had to do it, and you better bet your blue suede shoes that Graceland is a place that should be on everyone's bucket list to visit at least once in their lives. So, in honor of the 38th anniversary of the death of the King of Rock and Roll here's to the King, who god willing, will never die!And why should he? His house alone exemplifies exuberance and overindulgence on so many levels. Somewhat Gothic, grandiose but intimate, and unapologetically tacky with a seventies motif that is captured in time, Graceland represents what was and what still could have been. How many other personal mansions of deceased rock stars are open to the public for tours? Didn't think so. Much credit of what Graceland has become must go to his former wife Priscilla Beaulieu Presley and daughter Lisa Marie who cultivated and monetized what could have been a sad place and turned into an amazing bit of American ingenuity! So bravo to them for even considering it.Graceland is really a huge campus where the actual mansion and other supplementary buildings, with it's guided tours through audio headsets, is on one side of Elvis Presley Boulevard and the actual Visitor's Center, Restaurant, Auto Museum among others are on the other side of Elvis Presley Boulevard. In fact, it is at the Visitor's Center, otherwise known as Graceland Plaza, where you start your journey from the parking lot and get your tickets and walk through the huge gift shop and then you get in line to be handed your listening devices and board the shuttle buses that take you to the front door of the actual Graceland mansion.After a short five minute shuttle ride to Graceland, everyone can get off and take pictures in front of the house as they please. From there, everyone enters and takes a tour of the grandiose mansion. Graceland is kept in the exact same state as it was in 1977 when Presley passed away. Speaking of which, upstairs is entirely cordoned off so no one can see where Presley actually passed away. But you can see everything on the first floor, from the kitchen to the dining room to the living room to the music room (i.e. the "Jungle Room" and it really is a jungle in there!) and the basement. It was all fascinating to see the areas in which Elvis and his loved ones once roamed around. Throughout all of this area, you are guided to walk through pressing a number on a box that's attached to your headsets.  From there you walk to the indoor racquetball courts, which was ingeniously converted into my favorite part: the "Graceland Archives Experience" which featured his gold records, awards and memorabilia like his various stage outfits. Your headset tour leads you through every portion of each artifact. It was so interesting. From there you can walk around the grounds seeing the pool and the meditation garden that holds Elvis and his family members' final resting places. From there you wait back in line to get back on the shuttle back to get back across the street. Everything is so well organized, I have to give them that. On the Graceland Plaza side of the street, besides shopping and restaurants, there are more exhibits including the auto museum where you can see Presley's impressive auto collection and the two planes he once owned including the "Lisa Marie." We had a fun time in the roughly four hours we hung out on the properties enjoying all of the kitsch and nostalgia. It was very hot and humid the day we visited and they also had an ice cream shop called the "Shake, Split and Dip" where we were able to enjoy a nice treat. Thankfully we passed on getting the banana and peanut butter sandwiches that Elvis loved so much at the other onsite restaurant.Like I said, everything in Graceland seems trapped in time. Is it gaudy or tacky inside the house? Sure but that's why I think it's so vintage! Do you need to be an Elvis fan to really enjoy it? It would help for sure, but if you're a history buff like me and love museums in general, coming to Graceland was just as interesting. One year, I have decided that I am going back to experience an annual memorial service on August 16th, the day of his death. That sounds like an odd almost quixotic experience to be with all of those superfans! Trust me, there is no way Elvis is leaving this building anytime soon.If you love Elvis then you'll love Graceland but this place definitely isn't for everybody.  Nothing new in this review when compared to others so I'll bullet point it. Pros:- Well organized- Great for Elvis buffs- Good for rock music fans- AAA, military and student discounts available- Property well maintained- Staff friendly- Tickets can be bought onlineCons:- EXPENSIVE- Long lines for tickets and shuttles - Can't see upstairs of mansion- Costs extra to see cars, planes, etc. - $10 to park across the street- Crowded inside mansionThis is the quintessential Memphis tourist activity. If you are only going to do one touristy thing in Memphis this should be it. I'm not even an Elvis fan but I think it's worth seeing. Keep in mind you are going to wait in plenty of lines, spend more than its worth, be there a while, and get dumped into lots of gift shops.  My two favorite parts were the mansion and the room of cars. The whole thing is a time warp to the 1970s.  It is often an era that is overlooked because of it's cheesiness (good word, right?) but they pretty much nailed it here.  Elvis Lives (especially here.)Whoah! Be prepared to spend some serious cash. I am not a huge Elvis fan but still a fan. Husband and I bought the house tour with the audio iPad guide. It was an exceptionally  informative tour. Seeking the house and memorabilia was really neat. I thought the shag carpet was just the craziest thing ever! So 70's!Overall the trip was neat and I am glad to say I have seen where the famous peanut butter banana sandwiches were prepared!I stopped by here this past Friday morning with my wife.  We were going to be in Memphis for the weekend and so this was one of our top places to visit.  I will be the first person to admit that I don't know too much about Elvis.  Even so by the time that I was finished this ended up being a really pleasurable experience.  Of course it started out with me griping about pricing though.  You see it costs $10 a car to park before they charge you $36/person to see the mansion.  If you do the platinum package like we did then it's $40 a person although our AAA card did get 10% off.  Once we purchased our tickets we headed out through the door and boarded the shuttle to cross the street into Graceland.  We were also given IPads that were preloaded with a tour from John Stamos.  I was a little leery of the IPads at first but they ended up being pretty awesome and gave us a nice tour of the mansion and surrounding buildings.  Heading into the tour I thought it was going to be somewhat cheesy but it ended up being really well done although it did paint quite the rosy picture of Elvis.  With our platinum passes we were also able to enter a few more places like the car Musuem (guy owned a lot of expensive cars), sincerely Elvis (artifacts accompanied by pictures of him wearing them) and finally the archives which were literally every day artifacts from Elvis.The bottom line for me is I would recommend Graceland to any visitor to Memphis.  I thought that even though it was a bit pricey it was very well done and did a good job on giving Elvis' history.The Mississipi Delta shining like a National guitar...We're goin' to Graceland, Graceland, Memphis, TenneseeI'm goin' to GracelandAs Paul Simon sang, so my son and I went to Graceland. I had made the pilgrimage twice in my lifetime, and it's just something you do at least once in your life. Having been there as recently as 2011, it was easy to see some recent changes. We got there as early as we possibly could, 10am opening bell- and still things moved very slowly in getting to Graceland, and moving our tour of old people and invalids into and through the building (yes, a visit to Graceland seems to be a last dying wish for many with walkers and on life support).We were all given iPads to strap around our necks and put on headphones. In the words of my 13 year old son "the iPads were distracting, and it would have been better to have a real tour guide." Couldn't have agreed with him more. I did get a nice photo of Elvis playing bass that was only on the iPad, but between Graceland staff having to constantly train the old people on our tour how to use the iPad, and the fact that the iPad recording keeps the content you're hearing very basic and "squeaky clean",  the iPad tour ain't all that. At least beef it up with some more content to drill down into.Once you're done with Graceland you'll have to wait, wait, wait for a shuttle back to the Visitor's Center, and the rest of the tour. So many people lined up complained about this. (I'm just the messenger!). I did learn a few more things about Elvis, Memphis, but I think I'm good for awhile. Perhaps I'll be back with my walker in a few decades.So I didn't really know much about Elvis before coming here but I have to say that I am now an Elvis convert!Shell out the extra few dollars for the airplane and auto show experience, it's totally worth it. You are ushered onto a bus with a self guiding audio tour. The bus will take you straight up to the door of Graceland. The audio tour does a great job of describing each room's use and how Elvis lived in it when he was there. What really got to me was the amount of awards he won. They are all lined up in the trophy room - a huge hall of gold and platinum records. The amount of charity work he did was also news to me, and I hope that Graceland contributes some of it's income to continue his work. It was pretty amazing to see his grave and pay tribute to such a legend. The auto section was amazing! He had such a distinct and eclectic taste in cars. A real treat to see them all. The airplanes were also super cool. 24karat gold plated seat belts! Whew... this guy had taste.Had a super good time here and got to learn a lot more about Elvis. Highly recommend if you are in the area.It's Graceland!  It's Elvis!  Yea, a bit kitschy but if you are even a little bit of an Elvis fan - it's a must see. This is my 4th visit over the years and I joy it every time. It's become more and more commercial, programmed, regimented - and expensive, but it takes you back to a wonderful time in music history.
review_content_20: Really enjoyed this placed. It was fascinating to see how Elvis Presley lived. At the time, he bought this place at the age of 22 for $100k! Are you kidding me!?! This guy was living large. The tour consistented of his house, backyard, office room, gun range, record room, racquet ball room (now filled with even more records), archive room, vehicle room, his burial sight, and more. What you get to explore depends on the package you purchase. During the tour, they gave you iPads w/headphones that acted as your own private tour guide, so you can walk the premises at your own place. Tip: If you a bit of a germaphobe, I recommend bringing your own headphones. At the end of the tour, you have the luxury of visiting some of the souvenir shops and restaurant on the premises. Definitely a place you should visit in your lifetime if given the opportunity. Enjoy!!!Going in, I knew Elvis was the King of Rock N Roll, but wasn't a huge fan. It just seemed like something you had to experience if you were in Memphis. Overall, I am glad we took the time to take the tour. We only toured the house and grounds, and did not do anything else, as we had a couple of 8 yr olds with us and they were getting hungry and a little bored. You can order online and pick up your tickets at will call, which save a lot of time waiting in line when you arrive. Basically online, you choose a time, and you can show up anytime on or after that time to do the tour. Once you have your tickets, you head outside and get in line for the shuttle across the street to Graceland. In line you are provided headphones and an iPad which you use as a self guided tour through the property. It is narrated by John Stamos, and was actually pretty cool, and added to the experience. They even have the option of a 'youth' version for kids and it definitely helped keep the interest of the kids during the tour.The tour basically takes you in the front door, and through the living room, dining room, kitchen, 'jungle room', basement media and game rooms, and then outside. The inside of the house is definitely a time capsule full of all kinds of 70's kitsch, and is a good snapshot of his life at home. Once outside, you get see the 'office' where family and employees worked, the Racquet Ball court he built (which now houses some of his sweet jumpsuits and awards), and then a building containing movie memorabilia and all of his gold records. While not overly exciting, this area certainly captures just how big of a star Elvis was. It was pretty eye opening. The end of the tour takes you out past the pool and to the meditation area where Elvis, his parents and grandmother are buried. While I am not an Elvis freak, and this wasn't my nirvana place, but this was a cool stop and I am glad I experienced it. If you are coming to Memphis it is worth taking the tour.I am not a huge Elvis fan or anything. But we were in Memphis and so went to Graceland. But very glad we went there. I learned so much more about Elvis and his influence as a cultural icon and more importantly, about his philanthropy and charitable efforts. I really enjoyed the tour. Extremely well organized, it humanizes the man behind the myth and the pelvic gyrations. He was truly an interesting personality and a decent man. It was also quite sad and heartbreaking to learn of his rags to riches story and the untimely demise which could have been prevented through proper medical intervention. We also toured the auto museum because we love cars. It was really a fabulous collection.How could you come to Memphis and not go to Graceland at least ONCE??? The most iconic house in America? I mean, come on. Elvis was and still is one of the most famous and influential musicians of all time.You really get a sense for how big a deal he was as you walk through his house and see all the records and awards lining the walls. What really impressed me was how generous of a person he was, always donating money and helping people out when they needed assistance. What a guy!Tickets can be expensive so look out for discount deals that are offered every once in a while! The other aspects of the tour aren't as cool as the house, but the ones worth going to are the car museum and the airplanes.Our recent trip to Memphis included Graceland. Our family are Elvis fans so the occasional pilgrimage to Graceland is on the list. The prices have really gone up since our last visit. That is why I gave 4 stars. The good, is seeing the Presley home as a time capsule. My favorite rooms are the front living room, the parents bedroom and bathroom. I would have loved to see pictures of the rest of the house before the 70's re-do. The trophy room is an impressive display of awards by Elvis while he was alive. Almost more impressive is the awards in the racquetball court from after his death. The meditation garden allows guests to pay their respects to Elvis and his parents. For improvement, I would like the option of a live and personal tour guide instead of the iPad and headphones. All the employees at the mansion and in the gift shops were pleasant and helpful. They truly seemed to love their job. That makes for a great atmosphere. We will be back.Must-see for Elvis fans! I definitely enjoyed my visit and, as an Elvis fan myself, found every part of this tour interesting and fun! Elvis' Graceland is surprisingly smaller than I had imagined but it was spectacular nonetheless, especially when you consider than you're through the home of the King of Rock & Roll himself! The place gets crowded, as you can imagine, which can be frustrating as you go through the self-guided audio tour and the outdoor parts of the tour can be difficult in the summer time (Tennessee heat...wow!). The gift shop and other small stores on the property could really use a remodel! I recommend buying tickets in advance.Unless you are huge fan of Elvis, avoid this place. The entrance fees are in a word 'outrageous' and slowly approaching Disneyland prices. There is no guided tour by a live person; you are paying for an iPad that plays an audio tour by John Stamos that you will tune out shortly once you enter the mansion; but you can't just walk up to the mansion. You will have to pay for parking, buy an overpriced ticket, then wait for potentially over an hour to be herded into a shuttle bus across the street, then the monotony of the John Stamos audio recording, then to be herded back across the street in another shuttle bus. Save yourself the hassle and your money; buy a picture book on Amazon.Worth every penny! This was my 2nd time back to Graceland and my husband's 1st. To be in the home of the King is so special. Very cool that everything is as it was when he passed away. My favorite part was the hall of records room. So many gold records and awards and the famous outfits! You have your own iPad and earphones to listen to John Stamos telling you all about Elvis & Graceland. Great tour!This was really a surprise for me. After flying into Memphis at night, and driving to the Days Inn, just past Graceland... I was sad at how run-down the area seemed to be. I saw the Lisa Marie jet just steps from the main road... and expected the rest of the estate to be as... commonized.I was 4 when Elvis died. What I knew of him was that he was a rock 'legend' who then turned into a bloated man with issues, Liberace style, and cheesy music. The Graceland tour changed my opinion of him completely. He was an icon of his age. His estate is an icon in the US. How could we not visit when in Tennessee?The bad:It is a tad expensive, and every place on one side of the street leads to a gift shop. I really liked the iPad tour, but there was a learning curve, and I could see how some may not appreciate them or be able to use them to their full extent. They weren't completely synced up with the pace of walking through the different areas... it wasn't super obvious that you can move to different parts of the video for the area without waiting, etc. (I think we were there on a slower day... but the volume of visitors even on that day wouldn't allow for the best possible, live person tour that would also allow people to go at their own pace)It would be nice to have a live guide and a small group of 6 people with the mansion all to ourselves. That ain't happening.The good:They are very well organized. I can see how the shuttle might be annoying, especially if you have strollers or wheelchairs (not sure if there are other accommodations for those situations... can't imagine there wouldn't be). But, I imagine that this in part is how they're controlling the volume of folks at the mansion.The iPads with Lisa Marie's recorded anecdotes really brought the feeling of this being her home with her mom and dad... The rooms, their subdued opulence, and 70s funkiness were well-preserved - or seemed to be... I could care less about the gold records in all honesty (although impressive)... but hearing Lisa Marie say how generous a person he was, and listening to snippets of his various songs while looking at so many photos and other memorabilia made me rethink my experience of him. Maybe they had a psychologist involved in the tour organization... maybe it was something else... But I found myself crying towards the end of the tour, starting when I was ready to leave the racquetball court. Like, I couldn't stop. They really did a very nice job in portraying him as a real human being who did extraordinary things.My husband is a die hard Elvis fan and had been here before, he wanted to take me for our birthday. It was AMAZING! I loved every part of it and was able to capture a ton of photos. Great experience and highly recommend the VIP tour.The most famous icon of the estate is the front gate, shaped like a book of sheet music, with musical notes and a silhouette of Elvis. It has come to symbolize the estate more than the mansion itself.There is nothing I can say about Elvis or Graceland that any diehard true fan wouldn't already know. I personally had a nice time on the tour, no issues or rudeness on the staffs' part. I think they currently are deteriorating in several areas, such as, customer relations. I like looking at nice things that money buys. As I have no money to make large purchases, I live vicariously, through visiting car museums, Graceland, Pink Palace and Botanical Gardens. Graceland is a part of Americana. It needs to be savored and preserved for future generations to enjoy. I was too young, when he passed, to really appreciate who he was and what he became. I did develop a great appreciation for his music and especially for his love of Gospel.Drugs and gangs are taking over Elvis Presley Blvd memphisrap.com/2014/08/0... Elvis was definitely known for his drug use, but he stuck to using legal drugs, such as uppers, downers and diet pills to keep him up and going for his rigorous schedule. The drug scene in Memphis is on a much different scale nowadays. I have a fear of Memphis now. I want to visit it's zoo, museums and numerous diners and restaurants, but am not up to taking the risks of going back to Memphis.We visited for the first time and were pleasantly surprised at the tour, the grounds, and the overall experience. We purchased the full ticket package minus the airplanes. We loved the exhibits!The house was a great tour, but we felt a little rushed. The scheduling of the groups is a little close together, but it is truly a "go at your own pace" tour. So if you're ok to let people from other groups pass you up, then go as slow as you want! The iPad's are loaded with info and definitely im-personal. I would much prefer to have a tour guide lead the tour and interact with a person. However, the iPad had a ton of information that a guided tour probably would not be able to provide because of the amount of time it would take to lead a tour.The Archives part of the tour was fantastic! This requires an additional ticket, but was great. There are a lot of artifacts and such to browse while waiting for a 15-20 minute video presentation. The video included interviews, snipits from concerts and flics, and some peaks at old furniture from the house, etc.The Automobile Museum was a good, short tour of some of Elvis's cars and other motorized things. While everything was interesting, we were disappointed that the iconic pink Cadillac was not present because it was out as part of a traveling exhibit.
