Bummer!Those were the exhibits we visited, and it took approximately 4-5 hours for all of that. One could easily spend longer if they went to all of the exhibits, and/or ate while on-site. Overall, it was a good experience, but the tourist area could use some updating. Definitely a fun stop for tourists and Memphians alike!Elvis, I grew up on his music and had a crush on him as a small child. I found the information on point. I enjoyed the displays of his records and events in his life. This is very pacific place to visit. Only if you're an Elvis fan will this be interesting or if you are a music buff on 60's music. I say a visit is in order for you. I want to go back again at a later date and take more time to read everything.I was pleasantly surprised by the history here. The king is more my mom's generation but no doubt I appreciate early rock n roll too. The tour does a nice walk through his life and features some incredible artifacts. I enjoyed the early history of this place most - The Presley family and their children. Amazing to.see photos of the king as a boy. Poor, dirty, but uniquely elvis. Remimds me to wonder what place my children will take in this world.The sun records history and music was also fantastic. That was Elvis at his best. I started to feel a bit sad as the Hollywood elvis took over - typecast supreme artists are an immense waste. Rooms in the surprisingly modest mansion were Shagadelic, man. And the trophy room is frankly mind blowing. His music was truly loved by fans - he didn't write songs but was clearly the entertainer of the century. Seeing the last place he carried a tune was solemn. His dad wrote his epitaph. Reminded me how fragile things are.But in the end its a great celebration of rock n roll and a legend. It's expensive and they charge separately for parking!!! . But for two hours do the basic tour, immerse yourself, buy a tschotske for your mama and check it off the list. You'll be glad you did.Why the high reviews? A few big problems I had: The lines were awful, the price was steep, the tour is virtual, really, you can go on the same tour online, and you can only tour the first floor of the mansion. No peeping in on where Elvis slept!I am by no means an Elvis fanatic, but my wife really wanted to check out Graceland during our short stay in Memphis. Realistically, I think she just wanted to sing "Blue Christmas" over and over.We were planning on a 2-3 hour visit rather than a full-day Elvis extravaganza, so we opted for the Graceland Platinum Tour, which is still $40 a person. Parking is another $10, with shuttle service from the lot.First on the Platinum Tour was a multimedia iPad tour of the Graceland Mansion and grounds. This was a really cool way to tour, since they give you the iPads and headphones. The GPS in the iPad knows when you've entered the next tour area and starts that portion automatically. It's narrated by John Stamos for some reason. The upper floor of the mansion is off limits, but the open tour areas and the rest of the grounds were great to see. I especially liked seeing his personal firing range. Keep your wits about you, because some "guests" take Graceland waaaaaayyy too seriously.Next was the Graceland Archives Experience. The Archives are also really cool. They have everything from water bills and grocery receipts to cowboy boots and sunglasses. It gives you a glimpse into who Elvis was as a regular person.My second favorite part of Graceland was the self-guided tour of Elvis' automobile museum. His car collection is really awesome and very impressive. Unfortunately the pink Cadillac was on loan elsewhere when we were there. Sad.We also squeezed in a self-guided tour of the Elvis: Live from Vegas exhibit. There's a plethora of ridiculous jumpsuits, but not much else. We skipped the Elvis' Tupelo exhibit, mostly for time.Last up was a self-guided tour of the Elvis' Hawaii: Concerts, Movies and More! exhibit. This one was kind of hard to find; it's off by itself behind the Rock n' Roll Cafe. For the most part, this "exhibit" is just a gift shop with some movie and concert memorabilia thrown in. If you're short on time, don't feel bad about skipping this exhibit.All in all, it was a really enjoyable experience.We were in Memphis so we almost felt obliged to take the Graceland tour. We did but to be honest, we weren't expecting much. We thought it would be touristy and possibly cheesy. We couldn't have been more wrong. Yes, it's touristy and expensive, but not cheesy in the least.The tour is basically self-guided, but with first class accompaniment. With your ticket, you are issued an iPad with earphones. The iPad provides a tour narrated by John Stamos. Along with the narration, a picture of each room is displayed which can be swept around a full 360 degrees. Additional multimedia is provided -- camera and video icons are display at various locations which, when tapped, show historic pictures or film footage.When you get to a room, Stamos describes the room, how it's furnished and decorated, its significance and how Elvis used it. At any time, you can pause the narration and spend more time looking around or viewing the historic pictures and film. When the narration for the room ends, a chime sounds indicating you're ready to begin the narration for the next room. Swipe to the left from the tab on the right side or double tap the tab and you're ready to go.The narration nicely describes the house and grounds and how Elvis used it. I particularly liked the story of Elvis' music success in the hall with his gold records, the story of Elvis' film career in the hall with his film posters and the story of how he resumed live concerts in the room with his wardrobe. Fittingly enough, the tour ends at the site of the Presley family graves.All in all, it was a wonderful experience and I highly recommend that you take the Graceland tour if you're in Memphis.Not worth the $40 per person admission (plus $10 in parking). They don't allow tours in the top part of the mansion. You only see the basement and ground floor. They insist you ride the bus across the street to and from the mansion (a very walkable distance) and yet they offered no assistance with our baby stroller. It was a real hassle to cram it onto the over crowded bus, when we could have very easily walked across the street.The iPad guides do not allow you to move forward until it is done speaking, so you have to listen to the whole thing even if you are ready to move onto the next room.The trophy room was really impressive, and at least we can say been there done that. Without this I would have give the whole experience one star.After becoming a resident of Memphis, I felt it was my obligation to visit Graceland. I do like Elvis and his music and I truly did enjoy visiting Graceland.....once. Although I think that one visit in a lifetime is enough for anyone, I feel that if you are an Elvis fan, you must go at least that one time. We toured the grounds and it seemed to go on and on. I didn't like that fact that you really didn't have much of an opportunity to tour at your own pace due to the large crowd and the constant flow of customers through the narrow hallways and limited access routes. Overall I am glad that I went, but I won't go again.Graceland was great, the staff were helpful and it was very informative. I very much enjoyed being able to walk around and see something I thought I'd never see. The tour is done with iPads so if you are brining a little one with you Id bring earphones that fit them because they do not offer different sizes, my 7 year old had to deal with falling earphones the entire time.My open complain about this place is that people smoke everywhere. There is no designated smoke area and I find it inappropriate because of the children around. Other than walking though smoke the entire time. I have no other complains.
review_content_40: Ok i have to give varios stars.. 5 stars for the house, elvis grave, everything that has to do with elvis.. just the way it is... I loved to experience being in the place where the king has lived and seeing his stuff and beautiful house and range.. amazing !! Also really loved being able to pay my respects at his grave and from his parents.. now on to the bad part... what a money hunting operation goes behind this.. 10 dollars for parking????!!! Prices are overall wayyyyy to high... I took platinum tour payed 40 dollars a person that's not a problem but then on top 10 dollars parking???? And super cranky personal... Damn of all the personal only saw one older lady smile.. The rest rude rude rude and super uninterested!! Don't botter asking them any questions... they will just give you short rude uninterested answers and they dont serve you anything... bad bad bad... people spend alot of money and come from far away so a bit more interest in the people that come and make you have a job at graceland wouldn't hurt people.... Also after each "attraction" you directly enter a super expensive gift shop... wanted to buy a phone case... 40 dollars + tax! No way Jose.... oh yeah and at the beginning they make you a picture which you can pick up at the end.. 35 dollars + tax !!! Damn people who aren't rich aren't able to buy any souvenirs.. it's ridiculous!!! I ended buying a key chain for 10 bugs to at least have some souvenir... came a long way for this and seeing that people take advantage to such heights of elvis death is shamefull i belief. From what I have learned from elvis was that he was a giver to his fans... I'm sure he wouldn't be happy about the way his fans are treated.. i understand you have to pay entrance fee but all the other extras and the way you are treated... OH !! AND I HAD THIS COUPON FOR 4 DOLLARS OFF A PERSON ON MY PHONE FROM THEIR WEBSITE.. THEY WOULDN'T TAKE IT BECAUSE IT WASN'T PRINTED OFF SUCH CRAP!!!! REALLY DISAPOINTED. would give 5 stars if it was only for elvis but damn im so disappointed i just can't give 5 stars for it all..There's been a saying in Memphis that only out-of-towners go to Graceland but as a lifelong Memphian I've been to Graceland over 20 times. I've seen many changes over the years from an actual person in every room giving descriptions and telling stories, to everything being said on headphones and tape to now being on an iPad. Through their revitalizations/restorations and new things that popped up over the years and want is coming in the future Graceland is definitely a five star attraction. I've never been a huge fan on the restaurants that are located at the Graceland Plaza but that definitely does not impact me whatsoever when it comes to the shops, museums and Graceland. If you're in Memphis you HAVE to visit Graceland!Wow! Elvis was the man. Mad props.I'll admit I wanted to go to Graceland because it was on my quirky bucket list. I was beyond impressed. I learned a lot on this tour about the king of rock and roll. The mansion is a true time capsule of the mid 70's. Funky colors, jungle room, fabric on the walls, private jets, tomb stones, 100's of gold records and dozens of caped suits. If only the fabric walls could talk. If you're on the fence about this tour. GOOOO!I was only 12 when he died. So I really wasn't aware of his true impact of pop culture. He really did change the world on entertainment.A disclaimer up front: I'm not the world's biggest Elvis fan, so if you're obsessed with all things Elvis, feel free to ignore this review.When you first get to Graceland, you'll choose which tier of ticket you want to buy. The lowest tier, which we bought and includes only a tour of the mansion itself, is $36 per person. (The prices only go up from there of course, reaching an absurd $77 for the whole shebang.) While you wait a little while for a shuttle to pick you up, you can peruse the giftshop for various keychains, magnets, t-shirts, etc. When the shuttle comes, you'll get a an iPad with headphones and hop on the bus to head across the street to the mansion itself. There are no in-the-flesh tour guides anymore. Instead, you listen to some celebrity on your iPad. This is a neat idea and has some benefits, but I found myself tuning out our celebrity, John Stamos, because he really wasn't saying anything interesting most of the time. Lead by Uncle Jesse himself, we were herded through the narrow halls like cattle, briefly looking at each of the rooms but not actually entering them. They looked... well, pretty much like you'd expect -- like tacky, opulent '70s rooms. By the end, my wife and I were both ready to call it a day and picked up our pace through the final few rooms.Bottom line: Unless you're a rabid fan of the King, stay away from this overpriced march of tedium.Obviously you cannot go wrong with Elvis! I visited Memphis for the first time and decided to go to the home of Elvis. There is definitely tons of information and the tour is about 2-3 hours, depending on how deep you get into all the information provided. The tour is self-guided once the buses drop you off and you can go at your own pace. They give you i-Pads that give you information on each section of Elvis' home. The idea behind the i-Pad is good, in that it gives the visitor tons of information and things about Elvis. The downside is that you have to carry it around your neck for three hours and keep you headphones on so it is hard to have a conversation if you are with someone. Still..definitely worth the visit! Graceland also features Elvis' home in a time line fashion so you go through each section as though it was a different time period in his life. Truly a fun experience for all, especially especially especially Elvis fans. This is a must see if you are a visitor to Memphis.This was the most awesome thing I have ever experienced! The platinum tour was well worth the money and the wait. It was amazing and informative and in my opinion, priceless! I have wanted to go to Graceland my whole life and it was everything I hoped and dreamed it would be. There were plenty of opportunities to take pictures and soak up the Elvis goodness. Please stop and take this tour. You will not be disappointed!I did not know much about Elvis before visiting, being born in 1986 means I haven't been that exposed to his music, so I did not know what to expect of his home. However, I was very pleasantly surprised. Regardless of who lived there, it was very fascinating to see what a home from the 70's looked like, especially one with state-of-the-art entertainment equipment and appliances. I loved the old-school black and white CRT television sets and the wooden panels in the kitchen. Old-school American kitchens are awesome.Everything about Elvis himself was very interesting as well, his rise to fame, his philanthropy, his acting career and his return to music. I was, however, quite disappointed of how biased and one-sided the telling of his life story was. Nothing about his death, nothing about his substance abuse, nothing about his weight gain and troubles late in life. I don't see these things as anything that belittles or makes his life worth less, it just makes him more human and his story much more interesting. He was, after all, human, but the tour makes him out to be more of a demi-god.We bought the $45 tour, meaning that we had access to the studio archives, his cars and his private jets. Honestly, the mansion tour was more than enough in itself. While fun to see some of his cars (his famous, pink Cadillac was unfortunately on tour) and his jets from the inside, it wasn't worth the price jump.If you come to Memphis, you have to visit Elvis' house. We had a VIP tour and dinner here. The house is well maintained and the tour is good, there's a little place to eat here but didn't try it, during the VIP tour we had very good BBQ and they were showing some Elvis' movies.Definitely a nice and entertaining exhibition. The premises are well kept, and the iPad guide blends nicely with the physical tour for a very good experience. On the downside, the tour is rather short, you are not allowed into Elvis' room on the second floor, and the add-ons, which are bought separately (car museum, archives and others) are not worth the money or the time.All in all, I would leave feeling I had a positive experience had it not been for the fact that it is a super expensive tour (the second most basic tour is over 40 dollars!).The trip to Graceland was spontaneous. We had attempted to go before but were chased away by prices. We decided to take the plunge this time and it was worth every penny. It blew us away. For anyone that is a fan of pop culture or hey for anyone- this was an amazing experience. I am going to want to return one day. It is indescribable.What an absolutely wonderful self-guided tour of the mansion where Elvis lived. This was a bucket list item that I'm glad I did. The cost was a bit high, but why not? So close and would've regretted not doing it  a must doI love Elvis and had always been intrigued by the thought of walking through Graceland -- my boyfriend and I were staying in Nashville and I would have never forgiven myself if we didn't take the trip out to Memphis while we were down there :) There were a few different tour options (going to see his cars, his planes, etc.) but we were just interested in seeing the mansion. It was really neat to see the Lisa Marie standing right there in the parking lot though. We were given a tour time and number, and waited to be called to the shuttle buses to head onto the Graceland property. The gift shop is cute, lots of fabulously tacky trinkets for sale. Fast forward to waiting in line to board the shuttle, each guest was given an iPad and a set of headphones so they could listen to corresponding information as they entered each room/area of Graceland. I appreciated all the information available on the iPads (plus who doesn't love a good John Stamos narration) and it was interesting hearing from Lisa Marie and Priscilla; however at times I found it distracting. I felt it took away from really taking in each room and feeling the true spirit of Elvis.I was disappointed the tour did not take us upstairs but I completely respect the decision to rope it off. As we learned on the tour, Elvis was a private person (bit ironic considering we were all invading his house) so I think it was tasteful to keep some of the house private. We were able to see most of the house and the grounds, as well as an entire building which housed all his golden records, awards, famous costumes, and iconic outfits (so cool!). The tour concludes with a stop at the meditation garden, where Elvis, his mother, father, and grandmother are laid to rest. There is even a commemorative plaque for his twin brother who died at birth (buried in their hometown of Tupelo, Mississippi) -- I didn't even know he had a twin brother! I turned off my iPad when I walked into the garden and it was very moving. The entire experience was very special and I'm so glad I had the chance to visit this iconic house.As a Memphis resident for the last 29 years, taking visitors to Graceland is like Jury Duty; a civic responsibility you try to skirt out of. I've toured the house from the times tour guides had to memorize their lines. This is the first time visiting in the summer time.PARKING: $10 You have a variety of tour packages, from the basic house stroll to the all encompassing visit, planes and all.THE HOUSE TOUR: you get an IPad and headphones. The narrator is John Stamos. Uncle Jesse does a good job, and with the tablet, you get video snippets and photos to compliment your Graceland Experience.With smartphones, true fans go crazy taking photos in the house. Outside, an addition lets you see Elvis trajectory, from records, to Hollywood, to Vegas and touring...some of these accolades used to be crammed in the racquetball court, but now his jumpsuits take center stage there.Seeing the faces of wonder in fans, old and young alike, it's worth the price of admission.It's not the Biltmore, but it's Memphis Royalty preserved, and hopefully improved for future generations.Long live The King!I came here at 4:00 PM on a Tuesday after realizing I had a day to kill in Little Rock with nothing to do and I'm glad I made the trip. There was barely anyone there that late in the day, I got to move at my own pace which let me cruise through faster than most would, I also got some really great decorating ideas for my new house. I'm thinking about a jungle themed living room?The Elvis stuff was pretty cool, but I thought we were going to a Jeff Buckley theme park.Five stars and my 5th time visiting.  Swanky new ipads since last time with added video clips.  A lovely home for a lovely King, I've seen grown men with tears in their eyes here, it never gets boring - just a great deal and great gift shops.Graceland was better than expected.  Takes about 5 hrs (+/-) to see everything and has lots of great info to learn on the King.  The only downside is there is little to no info on the later years of Elvis, especially near and at the end.  Tours range from $36 to $77 per person, depending on how much you would like to see. RECOMMENDATION:  Bring a fat-tip Sharpie to leave your mark on the wall for the King.Now I'm not a big Elvis fan but touring Graceland reminded me of his incredible impact on the music scene. I was also not aware of his humanitarian side. He gave a great deal of money to less fortunateThe house is kind of small and very much overdone in the 60s/70s style. The tour is based around the use of iPads and like others who have reviewed GL I would have preferred a human tour guide. The tour is crowded; they need to cut down the size of groups. It is also somewhat claustrophobic in there. The most interesting thing to see was the Trophy Building. Dozens and dozens of various awards, outfits, and props. The only thing restraining me from a 5 star rating here was the price. If you are not a total Elvis fan you will leave feeling you didn't get value for your money.Soooo much fun! Although, I've never been a big Elvis buff as I am 33 years old and didn't grow up in his time period. My family talks about him & very much loves him. While I was passing through Memphis, my friend & I did the mansion tour. It was a blast! It's an iPad guided tour, go at your own pace with John Stamos as your audio guide. So much fun! Would love to go back & explore more of the property. Too bad you can't go upstairs but that's ok it's still worth the trip!!Although I'm not a huge fan of Elvis, I feel this is a must see while in Memphis, so I went. The line was ridiculously long, so as other reviewers mentioned, be sure to arrive early! The mansion itself isn't what I expected it to be in terms of size. The original 1970s decorations are absolutely fabulous though! The jungle room is really neat to see in person. It's disappointing that they don't let you go upstairs, but I do understand they are continuing to honor Elvis' wish, as he did not allow guests in his bedroom while he was alive. Another downside is that you are herded through like cattle in a single file line, and there isn't much time to stop and take it all in.Regardless of the negatives, I would definitely recommend Graceland. It's a piece of rock and roll history, and if that doesn't interest you, the psychedelic decor should be enough to motivate you to go!
review_content_60: I would have never thought I would be leaving Memphis this soon, and that I would leave with 849 reviews under my belt (I won't lie, I kind of slacked off recently).  With that being said, I think it is only appropriate to write this review the day I leave Memphis.Given the fact that Elvis is one of those people that is somewhat popular, having almost full access to the grounds he lived his adult life can be pretty busy.  Hell, they have a hotel, a $5 per car parking lot, and blocks of touristy things all things Elvis.  What am I getting at?  This place can get BUSY.Except the day I went.  I have no idea when it was exactly except it was a Friday afternoon, it was cold, and it was rainy  (hell, it was around Christmas, since the decorations were up)- for me- that is a perfect recipe to go to a touristy place.  Upon entering, please take note they have 3-4 different ticket levels- and you can utilize your AAA card to get a few bucks off.  I went all in, and got the VIP entourage.  I assume that it would REALLY come in handy on peak days.  It was still fine with me, because I got full access at my fingertips.As I boarded the VIP shuttle, they brought me across the street (where Graceland is actually housed, on the north side Elvis Presley Blvd) to the side of the house.  I felt real special.  As we (when I say we, I mean the shuttle driver and I) approached, I noticed the decorations were up for the holidays.  They told me those were original Christmas decorations- I thought that was cool.  Then it was time to go through the house.  One thing I think is cool is that you start the tour at the front door.  And you can take as many pictures as you want (sans flash).  The house is something else I tell you.  You are not allowed upstairs though (I hear that is sacred ground).  It is one of the most unique houses I have ever been in.  I could only imagine the amount of drugs and debauchery were done on this property.After the main house, you go through other buildings, and you see were the King and his family are buried (near the pool).  Gives you chills, I tell you.  I spent a lot of time there.  While on property, it is amazing the amount of awards and memorabilia are on property- it is crazy since it is just for one man who accomplished all of this.After going back to the side of the house, I saw one more exhibit, which had a bunch of Lisa Marie's child hood toys and stuff.  I was then greeted by another shuttle.  They took me behind the scenes, and then dropped me back across the street to the rest of the exhibits (that came with my primo ticket).  One of these tickets included Elvis's cars.  That was pretty cool if you like that sort of thing.  I did find it funny how after each exhibit there was a gift shop unique to each one.  Damn they try to milk the King's fame to the max!Then there were a few other smaller exhibits, a central gift shop, restaurants, and even 2 planes you could walk through.  Those were cool as well.All in all, being able to see how the King of Rock n Roll lived in his adulthood is truly fascinating.  The way they have persevered everything is even more fascinating.  Even if you are not an Elvis fan seeing this stuff is iconic to American culture.  This is a not to be missed, and try to plan it when everyone else is NOT expecting to go (sunny days, weekends, ETC)I am not an Elvis fan and have never professed to be. But on an American road trip that goes through Memphis, it is virtually a cardinal sin not to visit the house of The King!During our visit, I was pleasantly surprised & very much enjoyed the self guided tour of his property, his aircraft & his car collection. Having the audio guide may be a little boring in spots for a non Elvis fan, however is well worth it to get a perspective of areas of his house and leaves an impression of what he did for the music industry. Well worth the visit if you are passing through, fan or not...I am not a die hard Elvis fan - came to Graceland out of interest, to see the spectacle - and it really is exactly that. Expensive in comparison to other tourist attractions it is but a well maintained and presented museum. The bus service from the visitor centre to the mansion and back was a bit over the top - surely a foot bridge or underpass would suffice. Tablet tour guide was good - and enabled best use of multimedia (matching music with various eras of Elvis' career). Museum felt very sugar coated - didn't cover whole life, just recording career, and didn't cover artistic influences, divorce, drug use, health problems or cause of death. I guess some people want to present a particular idealized image of Elvis even to this day - not allow him to be understood warts and all. See it for the spectacle it is, but don't expect to get away cheaply. (Parking on site was an additional $10!)If you are going to come here, get ready to spend a lot of money, wait in lines, and just wait in general. First, the parking is $10 and the cheapest ticket you can get is for $36.00 for adults, $32.40 for seniors and that's just for the mansion tour. It says on the website that it comes with the Tupelo exhibit but the ticket I ended up purchasing also said the same thing, however, the physical ticket did not have the Tupelo exhibit listed on it. I purchased the platinum tour ticket which was for $40 and included the automobile exhibit tour, Sincerely Elvis (not listed on the website or their boards as an exhibit included with this ticket), I Shot Evlis exhibit, and Elvis Hawaii exhibit. Note: the website and their signs outside the ticketing area did say that the platinum comes with the Tupelo exhibit but I guess that was replaced with the Sincerely Elvis exhibit. We went and checked out the automobile exhibit first which turned out to be pretty cool. You then exit right into a gift shop. Everything here exits right into a gift shop except for the mansion! Next stop was the Sincerely Elvis exhibit which consisted of Elvis' jumpsuits and other clothing items. Then it was time for I Shot Elvis exhibit which housed some interesting photographs and the stories behind them, the photographers, etc. Last, we searched for the Elvis Hawaii exhibit but I have to say, don't waste your time looking for it. I have read some reviews stating that this exhibit was nothing special and I should have listened. It is located kind of far off the other main exhibits, amidst 4 gift shops and a restaurant but the "exhibit" room was  small, consisted of some screens playing Elvis movie clips, some posters, and awfully cheesy "Hawaii" decor.Finally, it was our turn to take the tour of the mansion. You stand in line when your number is called and they do photos before you continue to the line where they hand you your ipad and headphones and usher you to the shuttle that will take you across the street to the mansion grounds.  You don't have to purchase these photographs but in case you are wondering, it comes with an 8x10 (I believe) and 4 wallet-sized photos for $35+taxes which comes to about $38 and change. The mansion tour itself was nice. It was the best part of the tour. You get to see the luxurious way Elvis, his family, and friends lived their lives. Although the decor were very outdated, you can tell that they are high quality and most likely the best at that time. You get to go down the basement, tour through the media room as well as the pool room with the ceiling and the walls decorated in some funky patterned cloth. It's the best I can describe it. You then go up the stairs and to your right is the jungle room -- the decorations are once-again, very 1970s with carpets all over the ceiling and walls as well as the floors. There was also the carport, his dad's office located in a smaller building just outside the mansion, a building with his awards, and the Racquetball building. Of course, last but not least the tour takes you to the Meditation Garden where Elvis, his mom and dad, and grandmother's remains currently reside.Last thing was the Achieve. This is where you can see some items from his day-to-day life. There is also a 15-minute condensed film of his career as a musician. I thought it was very interesting and informative.Overall, it was a different experience. The staff were fairly friendly and if you are an Elvis fan, it is worth the trip.This is my second time here in 5 years, and it was same this time as it was the last. It has some great history to it, but it is also very, very sad. Whats even sadder is that his grandmother outlived everyone! The wait to get over to the house was pretty long, and it sucked standing out in the heat, but it's worth it in the end. If I were you I would go ahead and spend the extra 5 bucks and get the airplane tour as well. But, if you want to shell out $70 bucks a person, then you can get the full tour with the car museum as well. They not have iPads that are a lot more interactive than the old way that they use to do things. It's pretty cool and worth the money.T C B ! I will be back. Very impressed with  graceland. All the employees were nice and respectful. The only thing was i needed more of the tour i did not want the day to end! 998I wasn't a big Elvis fan until I visited Graceland. I didn't dislike him but I didn't particularly like him either. I was ambivalent. Well, one visit to Graceland changed all that and now I truly think that a visit to Memphis is incomplete without a trip to the King's residence. Yes, it's expensive but it's worth it. Of course, there's the outlandish decor, the racy cars and all the awards but what surprised me was how behind it all was a down to earth, humble & generous man who gave so much to his friends, family and the Memphis community. I'm proud to say I'm now a fully-fledged Elvis fan!We always try to go to Graceland when we visit Memphis. We really enjoy going back in time and seeing everything about Elvis. What many people don't understand is that this house sat out in the middle of nowhere back in the 50's and at the time it was a huge house. Most people think of it in todays standards and think it quite small. I'm glad that they have opened up some of the other areas that years ago were closed to the public. Try to imagine you are Elvis, who came form a poor upbringing, lived in a shotgun house in MS. when you view the rooms in the house. Can you imagine having 3 TV sets to watch each major network? Be sure you take your time looking at all the memorabilia in the show cases. parking is easy and so it the shuttle that takes you over there.No visit to Memphis is complete without a visit to Elvis' home.  You need to allow 3 hours to fully view the mansion, car museum, studio archives, and airplanes.  I suggest going as early in the morning as possible and purchasing the Platinum tour. Allow an additional 1 hour if you plan to browse gift shops and gallery.  I've been here twice and haven't been bored.  My favorites are both trophy buildings which hold his numerous awards and stage costumes.  There were plenty of fellow Americans here as witnessed by license plates from every state in the parking lot.   We were outnumbered by British, German, Australian and French tourists which was neat to see because Elvis worried that he might be forgotten.Maybe I got lucky, but I visited the mansion on a Wednesday around noon and flew through the tour. The line for the shuttle bus was short. I didn't listen to the iPad interactive/Uncle Jesse narrated tour. Those IPads are annoying. I just walked around the pad and read up on what interested me and breezed through the whole thing. I was done in about 45 minutes with the entire house tour. The planes and cars took another 20 minutes. The info center and places to eat are way outdated and reminded me of a bad '70s tourist trap time warp. They also take a green screen picture of you and your friends before you go on the bus. They'll try to hustle you for $35 after the tour. It's a rip. Overall nice afternoon well spent for this out-of-towner.Can I give this place 6 stars??? So I came here when I was about 13 yo with my brother and parents during a spring break trip to New Orleans and natcheze. I completely did not appreciate this place when I first came. We got the package that also included the car museum and the planes as well as the archives. The upgraded tickets are nice but not a must have. We went around 1 and there was not an open tour until 230 so we drove to ms to check that off my wife's list and then just sat in our car with the ac on charging our phones.We were greeted to iPads that had uncle Jesse from full house giving the tour guide. I am a big fan of true rock n roll - Johnny cash, Clapton, Dylan, winwood, Morrison, but will say I have not listened to much Elvis and am rather ashamed of it after the tour. Ep was such a techie. And the house shows it. I teared up at the grave site. Stamos you ass, why do you have to be so sentimental.I will say - and this is a bit odd - but Graceland has some great bathrooms. After 2 meals of ribs in the day before, I tried out 3 different ones during my visit and they were all nice and clean. This is a great place to come, but I do feel one needs to be of a certain age and certain interest in music to truly appreciate it.Took my mom on a trip to cross the top thing off her bucket list.....shes a huge Elvis fan.  She saw him in the 70' and has XM radio just to get the Elvis channel !!  I think Elvis is ok, I don't mind most of his songs, but would never buy one of his cd's and I think some of his movies can be kitchy fun.  But I didn't know if I was going to like the tour and even thought about dropping my mom off and picking her up later.  But I went and I am glad I did !!!     My mom got the most expensive package so she could see everything, I got a cheaper one and couldn't go on the planes but got to see most of the other things.  The car exhibit was decent but you can walk through pretty fast, some of the other exhibits for me were overkill....but obviously my mom loved everything.  But the thing that made me give it a 4 star is the mansion tour, yeah I loved it !!!  All but the 2 main rooms as you walk in the house have a late 60's early 70's kind of look but were much cooler then what I grew up with cause obviously he had a lot of money.  And with that money he really made some fun rooms, the jungle room was cool and the whole down stairs basement rocked !!!  The rooms they converted into awards rooms including the racketball court building are pretty fun, especially seeing all his old sequined costrumes.  Just a really cool experience !!     So if you are like me and are not the biggest Elvis fan, then just pay for the cheapest ticket so you can see the mansion and if you like 60's and 70's stuff you shouldn't be disappointed.  It was one of those things where I wasn't expecting much and really was surprised....oh yeah we spent like 6 hours there !!!This Place Is Amazing ! A Must If Your In The Area !the tour takes awhile but you won't know it cause time flies by herethere is so much to see.i was not the biggest Elvis fan before coming here and after seeing this tour i have a whole new Respect for the late king.all in all this is just something you must experiance WARNING: Some Of The Staff Here Is EXTREMELY MEAN !When I think of Memphis, the things that immediately come to mind are barbeque, blues, and Elvis. I will not claim to be a big Elvis fan, but I have been known to hum along to some of his songs. I love New Orleans and Hawaii and those places love Elvis. And you know, a woman in love needs must investigate everything that her beloved loved before she came along... So when I made it to Memphis, it simply was a matter of course for me to check out Graceland.The most glaringly obvious has to be said right off the bat: it is touristy. But Memphis and Elvis are kind of like peanut butter and jelly, so it is to be expected that tons of people -- big Elvis fans, casual Elvis fans, and/or people looking to kill some time alike -- come to Graceland to pay homage to The King. Across the street from the mansion is a museum that holds his prized automobiles. It is not very big, but it does offer an insight to Elvis' big love for cars and is perfect if you missed the shuttle that would take you to Graceland. There are also planes but we chose not to pay the extra bucks for it, because as mentioned, we are just casual Elvis fans. Once you make it to Graceland, the opulence is inescapable. The classic columns and the majestic lions bid you welcome, and inside are the elegant chandeliers and the luxuries of 1970's America. I particularly loved the Jungle Room, which would be called "kitschy" if found elsewhere. The rest of Elvis memorabilia are also quite neat: gold records, awards, Elvis suits... I imagine a true Elvis fan would have been at least three times more excited than I was.Graceland is indeed a must see when in Memphis. After all, we all know how big of an influence Elvis was to music history and pop culture. It is really neat to get a glimpse of this great man's life.I visited the home of the King in February..it all started with a concert nearby on my birthday to see Jerry Lee Lewis..i decided to have a rock and roll birthday trip and see Graceland as well.  I also happen to share a birthday with his daughter Lisa Marie.Just driving onto Elvis Presley Blvd, my sister and I (blaring Elvis tunes in my car) were so excited!!You walk from the parking lot into an airport like area for ticket purchasing..we had decided to go with the VIP option, as it offered a few extra perks, and lets face it..how many times will we go to Graceland??You then get a headset device that will talk to you thru the whole tour and play music that is timed with the rooms you go into, and get on a little bus to drive up to the mansion.  When you get there, you almost cant believe the front door youre actually standing in front of..and then you walk in.  I instantly got a chill..with the second floor of the home being strictly guarded and no access allowed, the stairs blocked off..it begs the question..is he alive in there? will i see a door open mysteriously, a shadow cross in front of me..?The house was restored to the decoration style of when Priscilla lived there, so its all kinds of fun 70s themed colored and patterns and fabrics..the tour is very informative, showing all sides of this legendary man.Theres soooo much to see here..from the clothes to the records to the cars to the picutes and personal belongings..it really is awe inspiring.You go from building to building on a little bus and see all that you want, as a VIP we couldve gone back and seen things more than once and even skipped lines, but there are serious hours of history here..ending up in the old raquetball room, which now houses countless platinum and gold records, you are told this is the last place he was alive..and you hear a clip of Priscillas reaction to the news of his death..my sister and I were in tears..the music playing on your headset really sets the emotional tone also..we got to tour his planes, which were out of this world awesome..also all the cars..really neat..the gift shops are amazing, everyone on the whole compund was really friendly, it was such a fun experience! i will add that all the merchandise there says Graceland: where Elvis lives..not LIVED past tense..im just saying..I did start to feel like, maybe i was intruding..so many times in the tour, and in the book I bought there, they said how he was such a private man in his personal life..would he really want all these people in his home? Visiting the graves of him and his family..which are very beautiful..?Even if this isnt on your bucket list..if you find youreself walking in Memphis..please go see Mr Presleys amazing home, all the history, and I dare you to not feel like hes right there with you.I am the biggest Elvis Pressley fan 70 and the first time I got to come to Graceland I was 10 years old and I was in all as we entered the music note gates famously seen on TV and on the news so many times as we drove up the drive and saw those pillars to that big white house I imagine being Elvis the king himself. It's probably not as big as someone expect but it's the history and the essence of Elvis from wall-to-wall a truly original experience and a couple of things that really shocked me where his horse that we're still out there in the pasture and the display of all of his outfits The rooms of the house which there are certain sections that are cut off from the public because someone in his family actually still lives there, then there is The collection of his cars and motorcycles, the Lisa Marie private jet and August of all is the whole family buried in their graves by the poolside. A few years ago they had the one night movie theater event of the Elvis concert tour remastered and I was the only person in the theater that was under 65 years old and I was shocked but every time I go to Nashville this is a spot that I must stop and see again!I really enjoyed my visit to Graceland.I loved the mansion itself. I thought it was interesting that John Stamos is your virtual guide on the iPad they give you for your tour. I was skeptical about it but it actually enhanced the tour. I learned some neat things about Elvis that I didn't know. He is buried there & I was surprised to see people crying while gathered around his grave. He truly had a big impact on a lot of people. I'm very glad I had the chance to go.You can pick up free shuttles from Beale Street that will take you to Graceland. They're sponsored by Sun Studios. I think it took 20 minutes to get there.The shuttle drops you off across from the house and you buy your tickets. It's worth it to do VIP. Otherwise you'll spend all your time waiting in line for everything. There are LITERALLY thousands of people. You get your own private shuttle to the house and immediately start your tour. We got to go through the house twice. The package includes all the exhibits which are located across the street from the house--planes, cars, costumes, his music and movie awards, etc. We couldn't finish everything in one day and we asked if we could come back to finish it and they let us, with absolutely no hassle. My favorite parts of the tour were the house (he has a TV in every single room, even the kitchen) and seeing a large case with hundreds of his checks to charity (major philanthropist!). I also liked seeing his jewelry and costumes.  Bradford is the Elvis fanatic, so I thought it would be cheesy, but I honestly had the best time. Elvis is such a big part of popular culture--so it's fun when I hear him brought up now, to have a visual connection to Memphis and Graceland.This was my 8th trip to Graceland in my 33 years of being on this planet- seven times as a child and once as an adult. So glad we decided to spend our last afternoon in Memphis at Graceland. I grew up listening to a lot of Southern rock-n-roll and as a kid I adored Elvis. It's pretty cool that his estate is open to the public like this.I liked the addition of iPads to the tour. I was not sure about it at first, but after walking into the mansion, I really appreciated being able to go at my own pace and take in everything that was around me with the help of John Stamos. Being inside of the mansion is so surreal. Priscilla and Lisa Marie add commentary to some rooms and it gives you the chills. Walking through the backyard, I stopped and just stared out at the horse pasture. I had lost my BFF inside the house and I ended up being way ahead of her. It was a good 5-6 minutes of silence and imagination while I stared out. It was a beautiful time and the serenity garden made me a little teary eyed. Maybe I should have put the iPad away at that moment! The land is beautifully maintained and you can tell the employees actually like being there and mingling with the guests. Thanks for that!The rest of the tour package I purchased included the car museum, the airplanes, the Hawaii exhibit, and the archives. Out of all of those the archive movie was my favorite and from what I understand it is a new(ish) addition to the tour. It was really nice to be able to take all that in and actually see, through the years, how fame got to Elvis- as macabre as that may sound.Overall, I was very happy to go back there and I will do it again next time I am in town. You cannot pass that up. There is no reason!Unbelievable. Go immediately. Fabulous tour. We stayed for 3.5 hrs and would've stayed longer. Don't expect to get any decent food in the area. Highly recommend this tour.
review_content_80: Graceland is a must when visiting Memphis. My parents and I had it on our list of things to do from the get-go.  Upon our arrival, we purchased our tickets and saw that our tour would be self guided with the aid of an iPad and headphones. I was intrigued by this and thought it would be good to go at our own pace. As we went through the tour, I found it to be impersonal and would have actually preferred to have a tour guide. The iPads were a bit of a distraction and congested up the viewing areas in the mansion with guests who were having trouble operating the technology. As far as the staff that is currently there, most if them seem to loathe their jobs. When standing in lines for the shuttle buses, the staff members give directions like they are herding cattle. After the tour of the mansion, we got on the shuttle to go to the archive building and the girl in the front seat simply shouted "iPads" and we gave up our tablets. During the ride, we were given scripted directions that were said in a very exasperated tone. After the archives tour, we boarded another shuttle and the guide on that bus gave directions again and did not get out of his seat and address the guests. He talked towards the front of the bus and no one was able to hear him. As far as security guards, we found them sitting in their respective golf cart and SUV chatting under the shade of a tree in the far end of the parking lot. While it was interesting to see a great part of history, our experience was soured by poor attitudes. It may benefit to have an option of self guided tours (with the iPad) or personal tour guides. A change in the attitudes of the staff is a MUST.No regrets having visited.  The thing that strikes you when you go in, is how "small" it is, compared to what one visualizes in one's mind (before visiting).Other than being an incredible musician/performer/actor, Elvis was a humanitarian as well - not sure if that is well-known.  Listening to the interviews made me realize that even when he was very rich, he always donated money to the less fortunate.  He never forgot his very humble beginnings.Seeing the living room (which I had seen in pictures), and other areas (i.e. the "jungle room", the pool room) made me realize that I was walking in the footsteps of someone who made a lot of people happy.We couldn't go all the way to Memphis and not go to Graceland, so we had to check it out. They have different tours available from $36-$75. You have options of just touring the mansion, the mansion with planes and museums, and they have some VIP options that allow you to cut the line (if there is one). We went on a Friday afternoon and it wasn't crowded at all. We waiting about 15 minutes in line to take the 2 minute shuttle ride to the mansion. The tour was self guided with an ipad and headphones. It was a little creepy that the ipad knew what room you were in. I personally thought the house felt a little haunted and after being in there for about 5 minutes, I was ready to get out. Some of the rooms are really interesting and wild. There is a lot to see and if you love Elvis, I highly suggest checking it out at least once in your life. I wasn't a big Elvis fan but it was still interesting to tour the mansion. $75 dollar is a little steep for VIP. I wouldn't pay more than $45. They also take AAA discount.My boyfriend and I went to Graceland on a long weekend in Memphis.  Neither of us are really Elvis fans, but I think it was worth the time to go and see a place this cool!Thanks to the pouring rain, and it being Superbowl Sunday, Graceland was a ghost town, which I think really helped us to enjoy the experience.  I think there was a total of ten people at the estate while we there.  The house was really neat, and the decorating (mainly done by the King himself), is downright bizarre, but gives you a sense of the guy behind "The King."  An entire building of awards and charitable causes he supported was one of my favorite parts of the tour.  My favorite was the planes, though.  I'm glad we added that to our tour.  The inside of the Lisa Marie is just mind boggling.  I mean, gold plated seat belt buckles.  The extravagance at that point in Elvis' life is so redneck crazy.  The next best part was the section in the car museum that talked about all of the "toys" that Elvis' entourage rode around in/on while on the grounds.  Ridiculous golf carts, super trikes, motorcycles, and more.  The one thing I will say (and what keeps this from being a 5 star review), is that the cost is EXORBITANT.  $45 per person for the tour, and unless you're a super mega fan (and I know that Elvis has more of those than anyone), the tour takes a couple of hours all told.What a waste of money!Prices range from $34 to $72, not including the $10 to park.It was interesting to see, but definitely not worth the money.  Only one third of the profits actually go to the Presley family.  And after every exhibit you have to go through a gift shop.Too bad some of the profits don't go towards helping out the Memphis locals.Honestly, kind of a let-down and a shakedown. -- It's like DisneyLand, get there, get nickel and dimed for extra features, be forced into their concessions and leave with a bunch of tacky pictures. Okay, actually DisneyLand actually has fun rides and Mickey.After you buy an over-priced ticket for about $35 dollars, you will have to wait about an hour to simply cross the street and begin the tour of Elvis' house. To some degree I understand since there's limited room inside Elvis' love-den but don't make us stand in lines for an hour of wasted time. They should just call back group Y at say 1:15 for the shuttle so you can view the other exhibits rather stand there idly. Poor planning.After you check out the crib and see the shaggy sex decor the rest of the grounds is basically gold records and outfits. I'm not that much of a celebrity freak that I gush to see something Elvis once touched or sat in. I guess if you deify his worldly possessions like his classic cars then bow and snap pics to your heart's content.Maybe this is the wrong place, but only by slow-absorption osmosis do you begin to get a sense of who Elvis really was. I wanted to learn more about how he learned his talents, his musical inspirations, his personality and what he was all about. But it's more showy to the life of extravagance Elvis had than a meditative experience of whom Elvis was and the impact he had.It is a classic Memphis attraction, but unless I adored Elvis, to this Suspicious Mind I felt that it was more of a tourist trap than culturally enlightening.Graceland was everything I expected it to be. There was a lot to see and I can say that after 3+ hours I learned more about Elvis than I ever cared to know (can you tell I was dragged there by a friend?). The planes were the highlight of the trip, so go for the package that gives you access to them. But, there is no need for the super deluxe skip-the-line package, because the lines were never long.While very interesting , the tour is not a guided tour. You hang an uncomfortable contraption around your neck with headphones , which I can't help but wonder, are they sanitized when returned. The snack stand is robbery , as is the souvenir store. If coming here by bus, pack a lunch.Worth the wait. The experience was amazing. Stopped by on my road trip to Austin. The interactive tour was very informative. Should definitely stop by if you're in the area.We were told we HAD to go. We paid the $10 parking fee, took one look at the lines and the prices, and RAN OUT OF THERE. Felt like idiots, so slowed to a trot and then when we were passed by another couple running the hell out of there also. I think I'll just watch a documentary instead.Graceland is, well, my Graceland!  For anyone that loves music, you'll know that Elvis has in one way or another had an impact on today's music industry.  And has since he first plucked a guitar string. Graceland is what every Elvis fan and those that are curious about him should go and visit. It is, WOW!  Now, if you want to know what inspired him, his personal everyday life activities, the father, husband and belongings, then forget Graceland.  For that info, go to Wikipedia.  Graceland is Elvis the showman, his home, outfits, awards, gold records, etc.  This is the wow factor. Make sure you get the tickets that give you access to the airplanes (which I hear are not going to be there for much longer) and the car museum. The car museum is pretty good. He's pink caddy, limo and other personal cars are there.  There are about three or four other separate exhibits which are worth checking out. You'll have to pay for parking, there are gift shops everywhere and the food is generic.  And everything is pricey.  People everywhere, some long lines.  And we weren't being forced to purchase any pictures they took of us.  What we bought, it was our choice to pay that sum here in Graceland over buying them in the drug store down the street. So, for a tourist attraction, it's everything you'll expect.  If you're tight with your money, forget it.  Go visit a public park.  But if you're visiting the city of Memphis or the state of Tennessee for that matter, and you're a fan of music and it's history, go to Graceland.  The only reason why I don't give four stars is because the tour of his home could have been more organized.  Once they drop you off at his front door, it's everyone for themselves.  You can't get a good grasp of what your seeing because there are no lines and they are dropping off people every so many minutes to start the tour. They give you an iPad and earphones to listen to John Stamos narrate the tour and your off!  You can't really listen to John and keep up with what you're seeing.  So, I listened to a couple of seconds and walked ahead to next part of the house. Overall, I got a good look of everything. And remember, Elvis is alive!I once asked my Spin/Yoga instructor to play Elvis songs for the Yoga class instead of the usually Himalayan Yoga music. After my husband told me that he planning to trough Memphis on our road trip to Arkansas, I told him that we must make a stop in Graceland. We arrived around noon on a Sunday and there was almost a 2-hour wait before we boarded the bus to tour the house. Just before boarding the bus, we were given an iPad and a headphone so we could listen to the tour narration. Being Elvis' home, the way it looks on the inside does not match the exterior of the house at all. I think Elvis' personality really came through in those rooms. Even though they are very flashy, I could see that it was also comforting to the family. I enjoyed the narration by John Stamos, Lisa Marie Presley and Priscilla Presley. The narration brought Elvis' larger than life persona to a down to earth level. I like the music that they used in the audio tour. I couldn't help not singing along.I am a huge fan so yes I am biased. I loved every second there. The staff was very friendly and very knowledgeable. The grounds were spotless. I will be back I loved it. This trip only made me more of a fan!I did not have the full Graceland experience, as I was with a private group that had rented out the space, but I did enjoy the parts I saw.Touring his home was so fun.  Such a great idea to use the audio tour, so one can take one's time.  Seeing the cheesy expensive decor which was probably the ultimate back in the day was so cool.  And how many people are fortunate enough to have their own jungle room, complete with waterfall?  Just Elvis, that's who!   Seeing all his gold records and awards really brought home the fact that he died way too young - he was only 42, and to have already accomplished so much in his career is amazing.   Even though I am not a 'true' Elvis fan, it still brought tears to my eyes to see his grave in the Memorial Garden.We went and explored his two planes next, quick tours, and then spent some time, and money, in the gift shop.  Then to a great exhibit that covered Elvis and his Las Vegas experiences.  Fun to see so many of his jumpsuits there - nobody loved a good jumpsuit like Elvis.Finished up our visit with a catered BBQ dinner in Elvis' Automobile Museum.  What an awesome collection of cars.  Neat, too, that they had personal videos of Elvis and Priscilla playing in that room on televisions.I think that love him or hate him, you will still find a visit to Graceland fascinating.Definitely worth a trip.  It was awesome to see how he lived and his accomplishments. You dont get to go upstairs,  but you get a good feel by walking thru the rest of the home.Couple things i was disappointed about relates to their service.  Look staff - it is expensive having spent $100 for 3 of us - is it so hard to be courteous??  Several times we asked for help and the response was cold and unfriendly.   (One time the staff person responded by pointing;  yeah really!)One other thing was we felt rushed while in the house.  There is so much detail but because it is small they try to "cattle herd" everyone thru there as fast as possible. The ipads are a great idea, but a little distracting when you are trying to take pics, see everything in the rooms, and listen to your spouse. ..Definitely a must see.Loved it!!!! We did the package deal and stayed at the Heartbreak Hotel. kinda had to, as the Graceland tix are $72 each, but the package including the room was only $175, so it's like getting the room for $30 ! Not that the room was so great or anything, but c'mon, it's at the end of Lonely Street! You might think it is pricey, but there is no other place like this in the world. Graceland is the ultimate Elvis experience, totally renewed my love for the King once again. So much to do, we took 2 days to see everything. I like how all the folks that work there are young people that are local to the area. Elvis keeping it in the hood! If you even are a casual fan of Elvis, this place will entertain you like no other! I will return again and again to visit the home of the one true King of rock and roll.First time here. Nice tour of the mansion using the iPad. Any fan of the 50's 60's genres can't miss this.While passing through Memphis we decided to stop at Graceland. We had never been here. After driving over we found the parking lot empty and thought we had "cornered the market" visiting on a Tuesday in freezing cold weather. Unfortunately, we discovered that beginning in December Graceland is closed on Tuesday to clean the mansion. You could still visit the stores, and the plane (we chose not to). Not being Elvis fans we decided to move on!Magic. So wonderful. Absolutely surreal. On a cross-country road trip from Los Angeles to New York, my fiance and I stopped in Memphis overnight, and had to visit Graceland. We both grew up listening to Elvis, and have wanted to visit for a long time. You really get a sense of Elvis, the man, touring his private home. It's an intimate look at his life, the estate left as though he still lived there. It's fascinating to see how he decorated. The "jungle room" and the basement were especially unique. The tour was incredibly well done and far exceeded our expectations. I also like that you can see just the mansion, or go beyond and see everything. We chose to see the mansion and cars, which we felt was worth paying extra. Next time, we stick around to see the "Lisa Marie" private jet!We were in Memphis, so we HAD to go check out Graceland.  Whether or not you're an Elvis fan, this is a bit of history and should be taken that way.  I mean, the house itself is not exactly swanky for today's standards.  You need to put yourself back in that time and see it through those eyes.  The tour was fantastic.  To be right there, where it all happened.  The Jungle Room where songs were contrived... the media room, the billiards room... oh the history!  Take your time and really soak in the sights.  The grammys.  The awards.  The outfits.  The uniforms.  The cars. The airplanes. So much to see.  So much to think about.I didn't have the kids, and that was probalby a good thing.  They'd have no clue what we were looking at or what the big deal was.  It takes a little understanding to get the full effect.  Otherwise it's someone's big old house in need of a renovation.I was so greatful to have made this trip.  It's well worth the admission and time.  Get there early and plan to spend several hours soaking in the history!
